Should You Visit Vienna?
Have you been thinking about whether to go to Vienna or not?
Let me save you the trouble: yes, you should!
Read on for what I loved about Vienna and why it should be on your travel list.
Vienna is a city I wanted to visit for many years. As a Tour Manager, I always hoped to do a tour that included Prague, Vienna, and Budapest, but I never got that chance.
A friend of mine visited Vienna several times and said it was lovely, but that was all I knew. When planning a short break, I realized that Vienna was close to Bratislava and had flights to Edinburgh, so I added it to my trip.
Vienna is the capital city of Austria with a population of just over 2 million people.
Is Vienna Worth Visiting?
Vienna is well connected to the UK by flights. It also has great train and bus connections to the rest of Europe. You can take an OBB (Austrian national railway company) train to:
They run over 520,000 trains a year, and they are lovely trains. Vienna is located on the Danube River, making it a popular stop for river cruises. Cruising on the Danube is the most popular river cruise, thanks to the wonderful cities along the way.
I traveled to Vienna from Bratislava. I could have gone by boat or train, but I chose Flixbus. The boat was quite expensive (46 Euros for a 1.5-hour trip), and the train required me to print out a ticket.
The Flixbus service took just over an hour from Bratislava Most SNP bus station to Vienna Edberg, where I could join the U3 Ubahn into the city center.
Check out flights to Vienna on or check out my travel tools for trains
Is Vienna Worth Visiting?
Vienna has a low season from January to May. I visited in March and found plenty of affordable accommodation. Some services, like Danube cruises, were not running.
The weather during my visit was warm with sunny days and temperatures around 18¬∞C. Many people enjoyed the parks in the pleasant sunshine.
July is one of the peak times to visit Vienna. It can be quite hot then, around 26¬∞C, and it usually has about two weeks of rain that month.
Is Vienna Worth Visiting?
Getting around Vienna is easy and affordable. I bought a 24-hour unlimited travel ticket for 8 Euros. This ticket covered all transport in the city center.
It‚Äôs easy to buy a ticket, and you can switch the instructions to English and pay with contactless. I mainly used the U-Bahn, which connects all the places I wanted to visit.
Vienna is also enjoyable to walk around. The pavements are clean and wide, with separate lanes for bikes and scooters. There are many beautiful buildings and parks, so there is always something to enjoy. You can also find many cafes for a nice stop along the way.
I used the hop-on and hop-off sightseeing bus to explore Vienna. It was a great way to learn some history while enjoying a great view of the city from the top deck. I also took a few rides on the Bolt taxi service because my feet were sore from too much walking in the wrong shoes!
Is Vienna Worth Visiting?
I felt very safe at all times in Vienna. The streets were well-lit, although I wasn‚Äôt out particularly late. I didn‚Äôt feel uncomfortable in any area I visited, including a non-tourist area where I stayed!
Is Vienna Worth Visiting?
Vienna wasn‚Äôt cheap, but it was good value. I ate at cafes instead of restaurants, and the food was high quality. For example, a Mediterranean breakfast cost 15 Euros, and I couldn‚Äôt finish it!
The hop-on hop-off bus ticket was 41 Euros for a 24-hour pass, but it only ran from 9:30 AM to 5:30 PM.
Is Vienna Worth Visiting?
I stayed near the Danube River, in a less touristy part of the city, which I liked. It was well connected by public transport and less than 10 minutes on the U-Bahn to the city center.
I prefer an apartment when traveling, so I stayed at the Best Western Celebrity City Suites. My accommodation was a large studio flat with a separate bathroom and toilet. It was clean, comfortable, and quiet. Two nights‚Äô accommodation cost 145 Euros.
Check out hotels on Booking.com, holiday rentals on Vrbo and reviews on Tripadvisor
Is Vienna Worth Visiting?
There is so much to see and do in Vienna! In the day and a half I was there, I did a couple of things.
The hop-on hop-off bus was my main activity. Since I spent 41 Euros on it, I did both the Red and Blue routes to cover as much ground as possible. I spent about 3 hours on the buses.
One stop on the Blue route was Hundertwasser Village. I loved this quirky place with apartments above and shops inside. The caf√© I visited had a little river running through the counter, along with gift shops and an art gallery.
I also visited the huge Westfield shopping centre. I didn‚Äôt plan to go there, but I needed new shoes. It was enormous! One whole block was a food mall with an IMAX cinema, while the other three blocks were filled with shops. It was a bit overwhelming for me, but if you love shopping, it‚Äôs great! It‚Äôs also an excellent spot for a rainy day since it‚Äôs all indoors and easy to reach on U-Bahn 1.
There are many museums and palaces to visit in Vienna, along with various parks, including Prater Park. Prater is a leisure park filled with rides and entertainment, including a steam engine and the oldest Ferris wheel in the world.
Check out tours and activities in Vienna on Get Your Guide
I had a couple of surprises during my visit. Firstly, there was a lot of graffiti, even on some older buildings. Much of it was around the Danube canal area, where graffiti is legal. This was a stark contrast to the Museum quarter.
My full day in Vienna was a Sunday, so all the shops were closed, which wasn‚Äôt a big deal. However, all the supermarkets were shut too, leaving only small convenience stores open.

Vienna seems to inspire superlatives.
It has been, by turns, the Greenest City in the World, The Smartest City in the World (in a techie urban-engineering sense), and perhaps most famously, The Most Liveable City in the World.
It is also The City of Music and The City of Dreams (after its connection to psychoanalysis). Plus, Vienna always makes a strong showing in the list of Europe‚Äôs Best Cities (currently Number 12). Austria itself is considered the third-safest country in the world, according to the Global Peace Index.
Who wouldn‚Äôt want to visit a place like that?
However, as you begin to look up these many superlatives, you may also run across a title that has dogged the Viennese for years: the capital has also been rated the Least Friendly City in the World toward foreigners.
Ouch.
My wife and I decided to spend her birthday in Vienna this year, not because it appeared on best-of (or worst-of) lists, but because it was a place she‚Äôd always‚Ä¶

Content:

As I‚Äôm about to complete my first year of living in Vienna, I wanted to highlight the things that I particular like about the city. Vienna was once again elected as the most liveable city in the world according to the Global Liveability Index.
What is so great about living in Vienna?
1) Affordable and Reliable public transport
Vienna is the 4th city in which I have lived, and it‚Äôs also the one that has the best public transport system out of the four. I have lived in Strasbourg (France), Norwich (England), and Copenhagen (Denmark) before moving here and I am completely satisfied with the moving options in Vienna.
First, the public transport network covers a really huge area and is not divided into specific zones like London. It means that when you buy a pass you can travel everywhere within the city boundaries. There are plenty of means of transport: Bus, Tram, Metro and even suburban trains.
In Vienna, using public transport is very affordable. Students only have to pay 75‚Ç¨ per semester for unlimited transports across the city while the non-reduced annual ticket costs 365‚Ç¨ or 1‚Ç¨ per day. This is without mentioning other discounts for children or people with disabilities.
2) Decent pricing for a capital city
While I will not go as far as saying that Vienna is ‚Äúaffordable‚Äù or ‚Äúcheap‚Äù, prices are definitely less outrageous compared to many other capital cities in the Western World. Although I can‚Äôt really speak about hotels or short-term accommodations, I have found it quite decent to live on a student budget in Vienna.
For instance, Vienna is around 10% cheaper for restaurants and 30% cheaper for Groceries than Paris. If we talk about rent, then we are talking around 40% cheaper, which is a huge difference if you decide to settle there. If you want to have a closer look at the prices variation, click on this link.
If you are looking for a cheap city, I don‚Äôt think you should choose Vienna but if you want to enjoy a high standard of living, in a good location and with plenty of things to see, Vienna would definitely be one of my top choice !
3) The coffee culture
Cultivating coffee beans might become possible in the future due to climate change but as for now, it's not possible to get "Austrian Coffee‚Äù as such. On the other hand, Viennese caf√©s are very appreciated by locals and by visitors.
You will find very old style and traditional ones while the number of more modern coffee places is also expanding. If you like spending your afternoon reading or need a spot to study for a few hours, nobody will bother you and you won‚Äôt feel the pressure to order something just so you can stay more.
The coffee vocabulary can be a bit different from the German from Germany so here are some words you can use:
Schwarzer ‚Äî Espresso
Brauner ‚Äî Espresso with Milk
Melange ‚Äî Similar to Cappuccino but usually with less milk
Verl√§ngerter ‚Äî Similar to an Americano
Of course, most baristas in Vienna will know the English or Italian version of these words so no worries if you don‚Äôt remember them !
4) Plenty of parks and places to visit
Granted, Vienna is not as bustling than Paris or London. Nonetheless, its history and its prime location at the center of Europe makes it an awesome place to visit and to live in.
There are multiple parks throughout the city, which are particularly praised by locals during the summer months. There are plenty to choose from to enjoy a local beer or a ‚ÄúSpritzer‚Äù, a local drink that combine white wine and sparkling water.
On the other hand, Vienna is also a prime city for history and architecture as it was the center of the Austrian-Hungarian empire. From the Albertina Museum to the Sch√∂nnbrunn castle, you will be able to fulfil your interests in culture and history without any problems.
5) Close to the Alps and surrounding countries
It won‚Äôt take you long to reach the Alps from Vienna and enjoy the view of beautiful lakes and nice hikes that you can do on the weekends. Around 60% of the Austrian territory is classified as being mountainous, so there is definitely plenty of things to see if you like the mountain vibe !
Moreover, Vienna is very close to the Czech, Hungarian and Slovakian border. A quick one hour train ride can take you to Bratislava or Brno, while you can also reach Budapest in under three hours.
The Austrian Railway Company is also well developed so you can easily catch train to Germany, France, Italy, and Slovenia. I have also used Flixbus to go to Belgrade for a weekend.
Overall, Vienna is in a prime location in Central Europe and coupled to the various transportations means, you can easily explore so many cities and places that you could ever count.
Thank you for reading my first piece about the Viennese capital ! If you are interested in other articles related to Vienna, feel free to let me know.

As a resident of Budapest, I visit Vienna frequently, at least twice a year.
The city‚Äôs proximity, vibrant cultural life, and bustling atmosphere draw me in like a magnet. Several of my friends live in Vienna, and I visit them regularly, but this time, I explored the city of classical music and coffeehouses with my wife.
Budapest and Vienna, two significant Central European capitals, have maintained a close relationship for centuries. During the Habsburg rule, both cities played crucial roles in the empire, though Vienna was the center.
In the 19th century, particularly after the 1867 Austro-Hungarian Compromise, Budapest rapidly developed, emerging as a rival to Vienna in cultural and economic spheres. An intense cultural exchange occurred between the two cities, influencing the artistic and intellectual life of both metropolises.
Although the relationship between the two cities transformed following the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire in 1918, their cultural and historical heritage continues to bind them together.

Four days of Vienna exhausted me completely. The long drive from and to Amsterdam did not help. German roads were dug up for long stretches, but Austria was a little better.
Traipsing through yet another historic European city made me realise these places were never designed for this amount of people, this level of tourism, this much traffic. The city was panting in the heat and groaning with the strain of it all, almost as much as I was.
Footsore, but still enjoyed great art, Klimt, Schiele, imposing buildings, decorated walls, big portions of stodgy local food, great cakes, a varied restaurant and bar scene, adequately cold beer in large glasses.
Travelling in time as well as in space, Frances and I reenacted a romantic Amsterdam restaurant memory from 40 years ago.

Content:

Posted: 3/21/24 | March 21st, 2024
I think Vienna is one of the most beautiful cities in Europe. The historic core of the city is a massive UNESCO Heritage Site brimming with incredible museums, beautiful galleries, and sprawling Baroque palaces.
The city is a history buff‚Äôs dream and there‚Äôs a lot more to see and do here. There‚Äôs an incredible caf√© culture, a nearby wine region, tons of amazing eateries, awesome live music (including world-class opera), and much more.
I‚Äôve been coming here for years and I never get tired of visiting. (I love the city so much I used to run tours here!)
Naturally, I‚Äôve stayed at countless hotels during my visits. Here‚Äôs my list of the best hotels in Vienna:
This two-star hotel is one of the few affordable lodgings in the city center. It has simple but bright rooms that feature comfortable beds, plenty of space, and large windows that let in a lot of natural light. The design is a bit dated (the carpeted rooms don‚Äôt look particularly stylish) but everything is clean and functional. Rooms include basic amenities like a flatscreen TV, desk, and free Wi-Fi. The bathrooms are pretty small, but they‚Äôre clean and the showers have good water pressure. The hotel offers a hearty continental breakfast and the owner is friendly and welcoming. If you‚Äôre on a tight budget, there are small, no-frills single rooms with a shared bathroom available as well.
Book here!
This boutique four-star hotel has small, clean rooms with d√©cor that makes you feel like you‚Äôre back in Vienna‚Äôs imperial past. The rooms have plenty of light and lots of antique touches, such as wooden desks and tables, and upholstered armchairs. Rooms also have free Wi-Fi, a flatscreen TV, and a coffee/tea maker. The bathrooms, while not particularly fashionable (the tiles are kind of ugly), are very spacious and the showers have excellent water pressure. The breakfast, which can be included in the price, has tons of variety, including lots of different fresh breads and cheeses.
Located in the city center, I think this is one of the best value places to stay if you want to be in the center of it all.
Book here!
One of the few hotels in the Rossau neighborhood (just northwest of the city center), this budget-friendly three-star hotel boasts large rooms with lots of natural light. Rooms are spacious and decorated in light colors and feature hardwood or parquet floors. There are lots of other wooden touches too, such as desks/tables, and large wooden headboards. Free Wi-Fi is included, as is a flatscreen TV and AC (a must if you‚Äôre visiting in the summer). Some rooms include coffee machines. The hotel boasts a filling breakfast spread each morning with lots of fresh fruit and pastries. There‚Äôs also a bar on-site and the staff are always happy to share their tips and advice too.
Book here!
Located in the Wieden neighborhood, this stylish four-star hotel is named after the eponymous 19th-century Austrian composer. The hotel is set in a historic Art Nouveau building that‚Äôs been entirely renovated, with rooms that have lots of natural light and a soft, welcoming color palette. Rooms include a flatscreen TV, minibar, coffee/tea maker, desk, and sofa. I really like that there‚Äôs a lot of art around the property, including in the rooms (naturally, much of the art is music centered). The tiled bathrooms are huge, with lots of light and great water pressure. I especially like that the breakfast buffet is enormous and features a lot of variety. The staff is exceptionally friendly too and happy to help you make the most of your stay.
Book here!
Located in Landstrasse near the iconic Belvedere Palace, this luxe four-star hotel feels more like a five-star property. It has a chic lobby and large, bright rooms with super comfy beds. Everything is fashionable and trendy, with lots of rich colors from a darker palette. The large bathrooms are bedecked with dark tiles and are well lit, featuring plush bathrobes and relaxing rain showers. Rooms also include a flatscreen TV, desk, and coffee/tea maker. The breakfast buffet is huge and has a lot of options, but I especially love that the on-site restaurant has a Michelin star (it does amazing modern takes on traditional Austrian dishes).
The hotel is a perfect choice for travelers who want some luxury without breaking the bank.
Book here!
This is arguably the fanciest hotel in town. A five-star property right in the heart of the city, this hotel is spread across four historic palaces (yes, actual palaces). While the hotel feels palatial, it has understated d√©cor with a chic minimalist design (think lots of white space with touches of color or artwork). The marble bathrooms are huge and the showers have perfect water pressure. The rooms are also massive and have big, comfy beds (as well as desks, AC, sofas, and electric kettles).
There‚Äôs also a gigantic breakfast buffet offered each morning and a free glass of champagne when you check in. The hotel also has a pool that plays music underwater, a fitness center, sauna, steam room, and three different spas on-site. In short, it‚Äôs the pinnacle of luxury in the city and the best choice for travelers looking to splurge on an elegant stay.
Book here!
***
Vienna is a beautiful city. I always love coming here. While it can be expensive, by staying in one of the hotels above, you‚Äôll be sure to get great value, whether you‚Äôre looking to keep to a budget or splash out on a luxury stay.

Title: How I spent a day in Vienna in the autumn of 2022.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
I closed my eyes and thought to myself ‚Äî what comes to my mind when I think of Vienna? A photographic memory from 2015 surfaced. A simple road sign where it is written ‚ÄúWien‚Äù with a right arrow on a green reflective board seen through a train window. It was a memory from my backpacking trip from Prague to Bratislava in 2015. A moment when I wished I could afford to visit Vienna and it got etched in my memories.
After 7 long years I was able to visit Vienna as part of business. I couldn‚Äôt just keep it all business but planned one day out of my schedule to enjoy my long-awaited Wien visit.
Arriving in Vienna
I arrived in Vienna on a late evening. The first thing I did was buying a 3-day pass to the well-connected public transport of the city. Vienna is rich in its cultural and architectural heritage and old buildings. I was lucky to find my accommodation in such a classic and cozy place. My host had a huge collection of books and music that filled every wall in that house. Even though I couldn‚Äôt meet him, he left all the instructions on the table with physical maps of the city (which I love to use and collect).
The City of Vienna ‚Äî Romantic and Musical!
The moment I stepped on the streets of the city, it took my breath away. There was something special in this city. A special calm amidst the busy streets. A special beauty in everything I looked at. It felt like I could hear Beethoven‚Äôs symphonies and Mozart‚Äôs compositions in the air. Those were the moments when the solo traveler in me longed for a company to share it with. To hold her hands and to walk those streets in awe of what we see around together.. To kiss her while those centuries-old buildings witness..
That walk led me to a big magnificent cathedral. Nothing but the St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral of Vienna.
The St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral
Arriving at the Stephensplatz which is the town square, I stood in admiration looking at the Cathedral standing tall at 136 meters in its complex Gothic architecture. A structure that was built and maintained over centuries starting from the 12th century. Most European cities have a cathedral in the city center and the city grew outwards. Vienna is no different.
As I appreciated what I saw, little did I know what was waiting for me in the interiors. Stepping into the cathedral there was a mass going on in Latin. The chanting deeply echoed on the walls of the cathedral and blended into everything and everyone inside. I was immersed in my thoughts and enjoyed the calmness inside even with visitors around. I let my camera capture some pictures of the altar and the multiple ornate chapels. It's impressive how such a tall structure is made centuries back without iron reinforcement.
The Bells of the Cathedral
The bells of the cathedral have stories to tell. Composer Beethoven discovered the totality of his deafness from these bells. He saw birds flying out of the bell tower when the bells were tolling but could not hear the bells. What a way to make the mind accept one‚Äôs own disability! :)
The church has a total of 22 bells. The largest bell weighs a whooping 20,130 kg! It is the second largest swinging-bell after the bell of the St. Peters Cathedral of Cologne. It rings only on special occasions.
I could spend more time there, but I had to move on. I walked further into the Hofburg Palace and further to the Spanish riding school.
The Holfburg Palace
Another beautiful and heritage building in Vienna ‚Äî the Holfburg Palace. Built in the 13th century, it is currently the official residence and workplace of the President of Austria. We can walk through it on foot or rent a horse chariot. I could see fountains and beautiful sculptures outside the palace.
It was one sight watching those beautiful horse-ridden carriages.
I was running out of time, I should head over to my next destination- the Belvedere Palaces.
The Upper and Lower Belvedere Palaces
Most attractions in the city center are all walkable and I did it on foot. But this one I had to take the metro. A walk to a nearby station from Stephensplatz and I could take the redline directly to the Belvedere. I still remember how thirsty I was on my way. I could find a kiosk to get a coke and it was the best coke I ever had! :)
It was quite relaxing to walk from the upper Belvedere Palace to the lower one and visit the exquisite gardens and fountains around them. The skies were magical that day organising me a warm welcome :) I will rest my pen and will let the pictures speak.
The Austrian Food Experience ‚Äî Schnitzel
No travel is complete without trying the traditional local cuisine. Many people think Schnitzel is a German dish, but its actually Austrian. I had a very nice Schnitzel from one of the restaurants near the city center. As always ‚Äî loved it.
Did I like Vienna?
NO ‚Äî I loved it. Every bit and piece of it. I still have a lot to explore in this beautiful city and I have to go back there. Maybe with that special someone, someday. Do some cafe hopping, make some love, and get lost in its streets together. Live life again!

Disclaimer : This is a long post and will require more attention span than scrolling through reels. :) So read at your own convenience
I have been extremely fortunate to travel to a lot of places in my lifetime. From the majestic temples in South India to the gigantic mountains in the north-east of India, I have pretty much covered it all. However, I recently traveled for work to Europe and it was by far one of the most memorable trips ever. Every journey brings forth some old lessons and new learnings. It reunites you with old friends and introduces you to strangers only to appreciate that life is nothing but the precious moments shared with friends, family, and other beautiful people.
I happened to visit Amsterdam, Rust(Germany), Basel, Paris, and Vienna, and each city had its own story that had to be unfolded. It was an 18-day trip, and I will be sharing my experiences in multiple articles. This article will solely be dedicated to my exploration of Vienna, and later ones will cover other cities.
I visited Vienna as the last leg of my journey after finishing all my work commitments. Vienna was not going to be on my list, but like any Indian Parent, my parents did not want me traveling to the West for the first time alone. So I was persuaded to stay with family, and I thought I‚Äôd rather make the best of my trip than sulk about not visiting other sought-after locations in Europe.
I arrived in Vienna on a Monday and spent the day with my cousin, just resting at home. The next day, I planned to visit Sch√∂nbrunn Palace and booked a tour around the city from GetYourGuide to see the most important centers around the city center or the Ringstra√üe.
Vienna is a city that is truly a mix of art, intelligence, war, and grandeur. Today it‚Äôs one of those nations, that is not a part of NATO, and in the past, it was not a part of the Allies but was occupied by them. Austria comprises 9 provinces(federal states), with Vienna being the capital city of Lower Austria province. It has continuously been ranked in the top position as the most livable city. It has an immensely well-connected public transport where for every place in the city, you will have access to a tram, a bus or a U-bahn station.
I leveraged this highly interconnected public infrastructure and booked a ticket on the Wien mobile app to venture out for my first day of sightseeing alone. The fun part of traveling alone is that I have the complete freedom to decide what I want to see, when I want to see it, and how I want to see it.
The Sch√∂nbrunn Palace was my first choice because it topped the list of the must places to visit in Vienna and looked extremely magnificent. I got a ticket that also included an audioguide. Apart from the public transport and infrastructure, one stark difference is tourism in Europe is well-planned and structured. Every place I visited, I had the option to opt for an audioguide which would brilliantly explain the tiniest detail of that place.
Sch√∂nbrunn Palace was the summer residence of the Habsburg dynasty who had ruled for over 600 years in the Austrian region. The current architecture was modeled and remodeled during Maria Theresa‚Äôs reign who was the only female to ever hold the position in the empire. This palace along with its Gardens is also categorised as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The Palace embodies the Baroque architecture which is known for its illustrative fresco paintings, grandeur, and opulence. To create a sense of luxury, marble and gold are used extensively. Domelike ceilings are adorned with intricate fresco paintings. Sch√∂nbrunn Palace comprised various rooms that depicted the imperial architecture, paintings of the various rulers of the Habsburg dynasty, miniature paintings, and elaborate halls where weddings were conducted.
One of the rulers of Austria was Franz Joseph I, and his infamous wife Sisi.There is an entire Netflix series based on her life called ‚ÄúEmpress‚Äù. Known to be an eccentric modern woman and a rebel in her time, she traveled all around Europe. She was always unhappy and very isolated but a beautiful woman nevertheless. She has been extensively marketed as the face of Vienna, with her kind of jewelry sold at exorbitant prices and her face on every fridge magnet or postcard.
One of the rooms of the Sch√∂nbrunn Palace contained her dressing room, where a figurine resembling her with long and lustrous hair was placed. The picture below shows this.
After I spent about an hour and a half at the palace, I had to reach a point in the city center where I was supposed to meet my guide for the walking tour. It was a treasure hunt in disguise to decode the route from the palace to the center, considering everything was written in German. After much strife, I managed to reach the center just in time to meet my guide, who was an extremely eloquent and funny woman.
Austria is predominantly Catholic with spectacular Cathedrals and Churches in almost every town and city. It was without a doubt that the walking tour would also start at a Church. We started at the Minorites Church which was a beautiful Catholic church made by Italians. Back in the day, there was a marginal population of Italians who lived in Austria and that‚Äôs how this Church came to be. It follows the Gothic architecture about which I will speak in just a while. However, the remarkable point about this Church was a grand-sized Mosaic picture of the infamous Last Supper(which of course was originally painted by Leonardo Da Vinci in Milan, Italy), but here it was Giacomo Raffaelli, who made this mosaic art piece. There is a funny backstory to this. Napolean, when he was married to, Marie Louise, one of the daughters belonging to the Habsburg Dynasty, wanted the original Last Supper in Vienna. He tried numerous ways to dismantle the mural painting from the refectory in Milan and bring it to Vienna but in vain. He then summoned Giacomo, who created a replica of the original mural painting but through mosaics. Even today, the replica is used to maintain and refurbish the original painting because a mosaic doesn‚Äôt fade away.
After the Church, we walked to Hofburg Palace in the Ringstrase. Since 1946, it has been the official residence and workplace of the President of Austria, who is just a figurine head of the state. It is also on the balcony of this palace, that Adolf Hitler had announced, on the 15th of March 1938, that Austria would also be a part of his idea of Germany. Many Austrians were also super enthusiastic Nazis. Adolf Hitler was an Austrian too.
Austria was a major global superpower before the First World War. It initiated the WWI when the erstwhile Austria-Hungary invaded Serbia in July 1914. When the war ended, Austria abolished the monarchy and became a democratic republic.
While walking through these important landmarks, we also passed the imperial library(which I visited on my last day), Albertina, and Spanish Riding School. During the walking tour, I also befriended two very sweet young ladies(in their 60s and 70s) from Scotland. They were extremely kind and inquired about all the places I would visit in the next couple of days. They even gave me a couple of suggestions on do‚Äôs and don‚Äôts.
The highlight of the tour was saved for the end. It was the St.Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral. This resplendent Cathedral was constructed in a span of 300 years and the South Tower took about 65 years to complete. The beauty of Gothic Architecture lies in the tall spires. These spires which are visually spectacular also embody the aspirations of humans to reach God. Another remarkable architectural detail is the ornate patterns and the stories that are painted on the glass of the Cathedral. This was prevalent in medieval times since not everyone knew how to read and write, and paintings were the easiest way to communicate stories of religious importance.
With this, the walking tour came to an end, and so did my sightseeing for the day. I enjoyed a traditional Vienna dessert called Kaiserschmarrn, topped with plum sauce, which was brilliant. I also went up the north tower for a beautiful view of the city and booked a classical concert on the way back.
P.S : looks like I only managed to cover Day 1 in this article. I always wanted to chronicle my travels to Europe in as much detail as possible, and hence, I don‚Äôt mind writing multiple articles as long as I do justice to them. I will cover Day 2 in the next article.
Have you traveled to Europe or Vienna before? What was your experience?
--
--
1

The city has come to a standstill. Caf√©s, bakeries, and shops are hidden behind shutters. So, I stand here in the middle of a cobblestone street, clutching my phone as if it can magically summon a croissant. Or, anything to fill my empty stomach.
Yesterday, this same street was alive with the rhythm of the city. The low hum of voices. The sound of countless footsteps bouncing off the stones. But today, it‚Äôs as if someone pressed pause, and I don‚Äôt know what to do with myself.
Then I remember it‚Äôs Sunday. By law, most shops in Austria are closed to honor the Christian tradition of it being a day of rest. People are still, but in a way that doesn‚Äôt feel like an absence. Instead, it feels like a choice, like the entire city has collectively decided to pause. To breathe.
The slow pace of Vienna on a Sunday morning is a stark contrast to back home, where Sundays are a time to catch up on errands. To check off tasks from a never-ending to-do list. And I must admit it feels unnatural at first. Almost wrong to let the day stretch out before me with no agenda. No plan. But as I wander through the streets of Vienna, I realize something. The‚Ä¶

I wrote this at the end of December but it has been stuck in drafts.
Looking back it was a lovely day and such fascinating history I saw.
Enjoy!
I was thinking about a hike today, but then I woke up to rain and wind so I quickly squashed those plans.
Instead, I decided to walk over to the Hundertwasser Museum, a place I‚Äôve wanted to visit for a while.
Friedensreich Hundertwasser created eclectic buildings and works of art. The trash incineration plant in Vienna was even designed by him after the old plant burned down.
The museum building itself stands out, and the inside continues the themes. The floor is uneven so you experience it like nature. There is so much to see inside with art work, biographical details and so much more. Just fascinating and well worth the visit. Of course the museum has a shop and a cozy caf√© to while away the time. Perfect for a rainy afternoon!
On the way to the museum, I discovered yet another piece of classical music history when I happened upon the building where Beethoven completed his 9th Symphony in 1823/24, one of my favorite pieces of music: so powerful!
Everywhere you walk here there is a plaque indicating some classical musician or other famous character lived.
All in all a relaxing and enjoyable day in Vienna. And more reasons why I love living here.
Happy Holidays!
For more on me and my writing, check out my author website!

Title: Vienna, Courtyards & Balconies
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Brutally Dandy

--
Listen
Share
This is a list of pretty courtyards of Vienna. Feel free to use it whenever you are lost in existential boredom. Here is a list on the Google Maps that I‚Äôve compiled for your comfort. The route I walked is largely based on the one that the City of Vienna suggests on their city. In this text, I‚Äôm bringing together images and human-comments (vs. mechanical nomenclature texts that the city has put up) so that you can decide if visiting these locations worths your time.
All in all, I‚Äôve found the chase for the inner yards fascinating in its own right. Vienna as a city is somewhat unwelcoming for walks. Most of the routes are extremely functional and channel you along the lines of the facades. There is nothing wrong with it in principle. In the long run, though, it gets very boring, when your city experience is reduced to walking by the endless storefronts and unappealing coffee-houses (most of the Austrians haven‚Äôt discovered graphic design yet; most of the people working here ask you ‚Äúwhat is service design‚Äù with absolute blue-eyed honesty). In this context, many of the courtyards listed by the city are offering a stunning alternative to the predominant city plan.
I actually would recommend this route primarily to Austrians and their families. To such audiences, it should go with a message: ‚ÄúSee? The world doesn‚Äôt end if you unlock your courtyard to the visitors. And, more so, you can pay the renovations with the money that retail and services on the ground floor can bring! The courtyards can be way more than just locked storage for your rubbish containers‚Äù.
The Stadt Wien website recommends Margaretenplatz as a starting point for the route and I can‚Äôt agree more. It is a very bobo area, somewhat off the tourist route. So you won‚Äôt be harassed by desperate men in Mozart suits or won‚Äôt have to watch miserable horses tugging tourist families in the carriages.
Margaretenhof in its 1884 glory reflects the flamboyant attitudes of the old money. Sadly, you can‚Äôt really get any closer to the building. Don‚Äôt worry, there is plenty more around. Read more or even more
Here you can check out the inner yard rented out by the city for commercial use. As I understand it (which might be wrong, cause Vienna has a very messy real estate public record), the property is historical and currently belongs to the city. Apparently, people really like this spot for no obvious reason. So the buildings on this spot have changed one another since the 16th century. The current one is from the late 1700s. It is not particularly special, but it is representative of Vienna‚Äôs looks pre-real-estate-boom. In the 19th century, rich people went nuts and started investing their fortunes in opulent real estate projects that now shape the splendor of Vienna. Of course, the trust-fund rich babies had no clue how the economy works and in 1873 the stock market crashed. Anyhow, here is a glimpse of what the city-block planning was like prior to this investment wave. Read more
This is one of my favorite locations on the list. There is nothing particularly splendid about it. Technically, it is just a commercial street fixed into a walk-though chain of the courtyards. I guess that the contrast with a relatively loud surrounding makes it very calming. Here you can also find a pretty good vegetarian place called ‚ÄúSecret Garden‚Äù.
It seems like the street is currently struggling to find a format and purpose that could interest tourists and locals in 2020. Some of the stores are in the Berlin-like decay state, some change the owners regularly. It is also not wheel-chair-, bike-, pram-accessible, in case you care. Read more
This yard is very cute. The business owners, running the venue on the ground floor have the taste that expands on the heritage and doesn‚Äôt go all-in on the stereotypes. I‚Äôm curious to come by in winter and see if they manage to utilize the yard as nicely.
This is one of the typical Pawlatschenhof, a courtyard with Pawlatschen-type balcony, that some guides will recommend you to visit. This was actually an entry point for me into the whole route. I wanted to see more of the housing solutions that utilized courtyard balcony raws. This is quite common in Budapest and very common in Tbilisi, whereas in Vienna you can‚Äôt find them so often. In the current trends around indoor-outdoor living spaces, this is a type of solution, that could be interesting to retro-fit to the existing housing. Actually, some of the house-owners in Vienna do it, and I may later include a few samples of such work to this list. Read more
Adlerhof‚Äôs scale is impressive. It‚Äôs a long corridor of identical well-yards and passages. Would I go there again? Not sure. Can it look good on a selfy? Absolutely.
This passage has suffered from pretty violent renovations and door-replacements. Vienna is actually quite bad in preserving original window-frames and doors. Burglary is common here and people often opt for ugly-but-safe options. Adlerhoft has had some original doors replaced with barn-like aluminum nonsense and some of the original windows were plastered. Read more
This passage is monumental. The state of it is pretty tragic, as the ground floor is occupied by rather tastelss and careless businesses, and columns are plastered with ridiculously ugly commercials. But the bones of the structure are quite impressive. Perhaps, when the wave of gentrification reaches this place, it will have a breath of fresh air. Read more
Lange Gasse 34 courtyard is not eventful. It worth a glance on your way from one place to another, just to see how one of these older patios looks like without a functional purpose to it. The funny thing about this structure is that you see it both in the Roman ruins and in the colonial houses (such as the ones you see in both of the Americas). If you have a good read on the raise and fall of this block-planning paradigm ‚Äî let me know. Read more
The ground floor of this inner yard is a wreck. It is hard to say if the owners are working on renovating it or if they use it to dump construction rubbish in. But then the way the facades have developed through time is pretty interesting. Read more
The 90s and 2000s have railed hard over this passage. The oversized floor tiles make it look like you are on a Lewis Carroll‚Äôs bad trip. The absolutely shameless signage from Berlitz should actually be forcefully removed by the city as damaging to the soul. The vitrines are full of rubbish that only old tasteless ladies would care about. Should you visit? Perhaps. Some detailing on the doors, railing, and wood-carving is still interesting. But overall it is in a very tragic state. Read more
The yards on Blutgasse 3 were one of the most unexpected finds for me. I can not stand the 1st district in Vienna as a whole. It is a consumer-tourist hell, that I try to avoid in every city I visit. But then this chain of the backyards is actually very sweet. If it wasn‚Äôt on your tourist map ‚Äî tag it for a change. Read more
To each their own, I guess. I find the look of this courtyard pretty tragic. But then if you want to check out the 15th-century wall segment ‚Äî here you go. Read more
Here is one more victim of the 90s. This place could have been very Diagon-Alley-like, but then messy cheap signage, concrete floor, and an absolute lack of coordination make it more of a walk of shame. For crying out loud, they have a vitrine with toilet seats in the very center of the historical town. I highly doubt that this sells anything. Read more
At first, I wanted to skip this location. Because, honestly, it is doesn‚Äôt offer much. But then I couldn‚Äôt skip this storefront. I think the reasons are obvious. Read more
S√ºnnhof doesn‚Äôt try too hard to be likable. To be honest, it doesn‚Äôt even care if you exist. The hotel, that runs this passage is processing large batches of Chinese guests. The busses with them unload on the Ungargasse. They spend the night here, eat sausage, and continue on their prisoner-tour. Technically it is actually a very interesting street. It breaks down impossibly long blocks of Landstra√üe into a few walkable segments. It will also look like you are having a good time if you post a selfy from here to your Instagram. Read more
--
--
Brutally Dandy
Media, Concept & Service Designer in the Wild-Wild Capitalist ‚ÄúWest‚Äù

Title: A four day family trip to Vienna
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I‚Äôve just returned from four days in Vienna with the family. It‚Äôs a great place for adults and kids. Expensive, but great. I‚Äôve put the total prices of things below. Here‚Äôs what we got up to.
I‚Äôve also written about how we packed for this trip with just two cabin sized bags.
Vienna was chosen by a usual plan of looking at the price of flights in the October half term and finding something reasonable. Once flights were looking good, we checked out Airbnb filtered by Superhosts and those with a decent number of 4.5+ reviews. We lucked out on our Airbnb, it was excellent.
It felt like we did less planning for Vienna. It‚Äôs a big place with tons of stuff to do. Looking through our go-to Lonely Planet felt kind of pointless; too much to do in not enough time. The ‚Äô72 hours in Vienna‚Äô tips are kind of helpful, but we‚Äôve learnt over time to make trips like this an 80/20 split in favour of the kids. And we know they‚Äôll be happy with a constant supply of food and playgrounds.
Side note: The map that came with the guide book was poor and missed off the area we were staying in, so I bought this map from Stanfords. It wasn‚Äôt needed though as the map provided by the host was better than this.
Early start for our flight but made easier staying at an airport hotel. Time for coffees, juice and pastries before the 2.5 hour flight from Manchester.
Had planned to get the quick CAT train from the airport, but ticket machines said trains not running. Joined the queue for the longer/cheaper S7 S-Bahn train and checked with staff to make sure that train was running, it wasn‚Äôt. Had an helpful message from our Airbnb host to let us know about train issues.
Got an Uber to Wein Mitte station where train would have got us to (‚Ç¨26). Had a leisurely 2 mile stroll to our Airbnb apartment via Stadtpark, St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral, across the Donaukanal, Wettsteinpark. Me and the boy snacked on a slice of take away pizza (‚Ç¨4.50 each) and my wife and daughter shared some take away calamari (‚Ç¨11).
We were staying a few minutes from the impressive Augarten. Met our host, relaxed for an hour, then spent a few hours wandering through the Augarten, stopping at the playgrounds and wondering what two massive concrete tower blocks were. Looked online to see they‚Äôre WWII anti-aircraft structures called Flak Towers.
They peek out from behind trees, somehow hidden from view for large parts of time walking through the park. I‚Äôm really glad they haven‚Äôt been demolished.
Ate at a local pizza restaurant recommended by the host. Really reasonable for the 3 pizzas, fries, pasta and 6 drinks (‚Ç¨65).
Distance walked: 6.5 miles
A busy day started with our usual tradition of pastries from a local bakery (‚Ç¨22). Noticeably expensive. Checked Monzo for our trip to Bordeaux last year; same amount of pastries were ‚Ç¨14.
Strolled to the closest U-Bahn (underground) at Friedensbr√ºcke. Bought 48 hour travel passes which cover underground, overground trains, trams and buses (‚Ç¨56).
Caught the U4 line to Schottenring and strolled to the Jewish Museum Vienna (‚Ç¨30). Really interesting and informative exhibitions across three floors dating back to 1300‚Äôs. Kids really enjoyed learning about Jewish Identity in the Football Stadium and teams like Bayern Munich, Tottenham Hotspur, Ajax. Starting at the top floor meant we ended with Our City! Jewish Vienna ‚Äî Then to Now which included 1945 to present day. Tickets last 7 days and cover a second venue at Museum Dorotheergasse.
40 displays of eye-distorting illusion and a highlight of the trip (‚Ç¨48). The kids really loved this place, so did we. Hands on puzzles, optical illusions, and clever displays to make excellent photos. The staff were really helpful too, pointing out how and where to take good photos. The ‚Äúfixed gangway inside a rotating light display has you clinging to the rails entirely unnecessarily‚Äù was spot on.
Stopped for a coffee and cake at Caf√© Hawelka, a dark, broody cafe that we didn‚Äôt realise was famous. 2 coffees, 2 juices, 3 cakes and a frankfurter got no change from ‚Ç¨50.
Walked through the Volksgarten and headed towards some brass band music. Got to see the last minute preparations for the Prime Minister of Romania (we think) visiting. The 30 minute boot inspections was fascinating.
Caught the U3 at Volkstheater and felt on edge by an aggressive man asking for money. Pissed me off as I was holding my lads hand at the time and his tone scared him. On the tube had a gut feel we were next to a pickpocket and instincts kicked in so we got off at the next stop.
Ate at McDonalds (‚Ç¨22) and walked back to the apartment.
Distance walked: 7.5 mies (14 miles total)
Started the day with a coffee on the apartment balcony whilst the kids watched some TV. Opted from pastries from a local Billa supermarket (‚Ç¨15).
Caught the number 5 tram towards the centre as my wife really wanted to see the famous dancing white Lipizzaner horses. Booked tickets online to see the horses trained to music (‚Ç¨67).
Wife really enjoyed it, I found it quite relaxing listening to classical music for an hour, the kids were bored within 5 minutes. Later on that day my daughter said she‚Äôd spent the time thinking about how the seats were made. She gets the random thoughts from me.
Caught the U4 west to visit Sch√∂nbrunn Palace, apparently Austria‚Äôs most frequently visited tourist attraction. It was busy, but it‚Äôs so vast that it really wasn‚Äôt crowded. Felt good to be around space and trees and greenery. Entrance to the gardens is free and we wandered aimlessly.
If you visit do make sure you walk up the zig zag path towards the Gloriette as you‚Äôll be rewarded with an outstanding view of the palace and Vienna in the background.
We visited the maze within the gardens which was excellent (‚Ç¨20). 3 mazes, a playground and coffee from vending machine at 45c. This was one of the kids highlights, particularly the climbing chiming poles with bells to ring if you get to the top. The did with some assistance.
Caught the U4 back to the centre, getting off at Schwedenplatz. Strolled through the Leopoldstadt area to visit a homeware store that my wife had seen online. Hopped on a tram that was heading in the direction of the apartment to save some tired feet.
Popped back to Billa as we were craving some home cooked food. Pasta for the kids, schnitzel and potatoes for us.
Distance walked: 7 miles (20.5 miles total)
26th October is a national holiday in Austria and our host had told us that most shops would be closed but travel, museums and the theme park would be open. Children also travel for free on this day too.
Our last day started with packing up as we were checking out. Our Airbnb hosts thankfully let us store our bags in the apartment which made for a much more pleasant stroll to Prater.
As our 48 hour travel passes had expired, we strolled the 2 miles stopping on the way at Sperling im Augarten for a mid-way drink. 2 espressos, 2 orange juices for a bargain ‚Ç¨23.
This theme park was a great place to end the trip. The kids were excited to go on a some rides and amusement games. Their highlight was the Labrynth game/ride/puzzle where they had to work their way out. Basketball was a top arcade game. Free to wander round, most rides were ‚Ç¨5 per person.
This iconic ferris wheel at Prate dates back to 1897 and was one thing that I‚Äôd wanted to do. It didn‚Äôt disappoint. It takes around 30 minutes to slowly go round and the views from the top are outstanding. I‚Äôm fine with heights, but the gentle swaying from 65 metres up was enough to make me check the kids weren‚Äôt near the doors (‚Ç¨34).
Our time in Vienna was coming to an end and we‚Äôd booked a final night in the Moxy Airport hotel. At ‚Ç¨224 for the night it wasn‚Äôt cheap, but with a 3am alarm call the following morning being a 5 minute walk from the airport felt more reassuring that waiting on a taxi or Uber.
The Moxy is a beautiful hotel, modern vibe to the place and nicely kitted out. Our family room had two double beds, each in a separate room and each with their own tv. The kids loved it.
Welcome drinks vouchers were a great touch and we had a relaxing drink, played some board games, ate a final Viennese meal and headed up for an early night. Thankfully the kids got to sleep before the guests in the room above us started their thudding, slamming, shouting routine for the next few hours. Asking reception to have a word didn‚Äôt do anything. Got to sleep after midnight a few hours.
Stunning, but pointless. Waiting to hear back on my refund request.
Distance walked: 7.5 miles (28 miles total)
Woke up early, packed up and in the airport for 3.15am, ready for a coffee. Found out that things didn‚Äôt open until 4am, bugger.
The ‚Ç¨36 pastries, 1 coffee, 2 juices from Veganista in the airport rounded off the trip nicely.
Landed back in Manchester and was home for 9am.
Cheers Vienna.
--
--
Quite family man. Travelling, walking, camping, wild swimming or just sitting with a coffee in the garden make me happy.

Title: Three Days in Vienna ‚Äî Prices, Sightseeing, and Tips!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The (Counter)Cultural One-Stop for Nonfiction on Medium‚Ä¶ incorporating categories for: ‚ÄòArt‚Äô, ‚ÄòCulture‚Äô, ‚ÄòEquality‚Äô, ‚ÄòPhotography‚Äô, ‚ÄòFilm‚Äô, ‚ÄòMental Health‚Äô, ‚ÄòMusic‚Äô and ‚ÄòLiterature‚Äô.

--
7
Listen
Share
Family holidays have a contrasting character. They are calm, and serene, without the excess of novelty, since their aim is a morning coffee in a picturesque square, a tour full of history and mystery in an ancient building, and a relaxing walk in the snowy center of the Austrian city. On the other hand, they are erratic ‚Äî think of a cannon full of gunpowder where all it takes is an irony to light the fuse. My family holiday in Vienna had a little of everything. For those not interested in personal drama, don‚Äôt go. There will be tips and places you absolutely must visit in that frosty lady called Vienna. Let‚Äôs get started‚Ä¶
At first, the trip starts with the classic fear of the plane. We arrive in Thessaloniki, sleep all the way from Larissa, pass through security, browse some liquor and chocolates, and boarding begins. We get into the ‚Äúbucket‚Äù of the plane and a delicate lady sits next to me. She crosses herself, mumbles things, and at the first announcement from the captain she bites her lip in agony. On take-off, as if I remember, she let slip a scream. The weather was overcast, the cabin was quiet and I, with my headphones glued to my ears, was enjoying this mechanical miracle of flight. I distinctly remember when we reached maximum altitude, where the autopilot was activated and snacks were served, the clouds below us spread out like the most tender blanket. The sun colored the blanket golden and I, with the imagination of a seven-year-old, hoped I could sleep just once alongside all those who once existed and left, envisioning that after death there is this something, an indefinite continuity.
As soon as we landed, the cold greeted us with the question of how to get from the airport to the center of Vienna. The feeling of everyone now speaking a different language always fills me with optimism. Optimism because I managed to travel, and a trip always promises a new memory. But to the point‚Ä¶ Here I will give you the 1st tip:
With plenty, we boarded the OBB, exchanged a few words with each other, and comfortably, I‚Äôd say, we made it to the center. As soon as we exited the station, a huge building rose up in front of us, which was the mall. We quickly said we would come back someday to browse and shop; we never did.
I fondly remember busting into the first bakery we found. For some reason, I was stuck with the idea of taking a warm espresso and wandering like a true Larissa resident through the cobbled streets of the Austrian city. The same enthusiasm didn‚Äôt continue, however, as I took a small sandwich with a piece of turkey, cheese, and a tomato, and paid close to 8‚Ç¨. Single espresso, of course. I knew from the first steps that the city bites and unfortunately it bites on food.
Our compass was a little golden statue that towered over every building in the city. The eye gazed at the oddities of Vienna. Cars stopped at crosswalks, statues popped out of buildings and all the passers-by seemed to me to be sulking. And while the eye gazed absentmindedly, the compass led us to St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral. Its appearance reminded me of the Duomo of Milan, only in miniature. The roof was mosaic-textured with Gothic architecture adorned with many statues. The statues, for the most part, represented religious, humble, and fearful people. Some held crosses, others were imprisoned behind stone bars, and as you continued to observe, the eye would somewhere fall upon monstrous creatures of the night with huge teeth and sharp angles. The visit to the cathedral was brief as the fatigue of the whole day began to emerge strongly.
And this is where the first coffee was made. The first impressions were painted vividly on the white table as the coffee came down. Father smoked happily, mother‚Äôs eyes feasted on the new images and sister enjoyed just being with us all.
After coffee, Google Maps worked, and we wandered around the market for a bit more when we finally got on the metro. By the time we got home, the bellies were purring as if we were the most coordinated choir.
We ordered Burger Kings 60‚Ç¨. 5 burgers, some fries, and a Coca-Cola if I remember correctly. So expensive‚Ä¶ But, here comes the good part. My family was in a state of confusion, because putting both my and my father‚Äôs incessant hunger and expenses into the same equation, the math were unfortunately not coming out. The confusion brought much thought when the father blurted out the idea of a supermarket. Our room was on Wiedner Gurtel Street and right next door was a HOFER store. HOFER was super in every sense of the word since the products were decent and the prices were unbelievable. 2nd tip then:
Of course one night out of the 3 we stayed in Vienna we ate grand mansions. More specifically, we dined at the Purstner restaurant which is a traditional Bavarian tavern. The staff didn‚Äôt speak English, however, when you are hungry everything is easily translated. The interior design was vibrant, with stuffed animals flying from the ceiling, traditional beer pots adorning the shelves, and murals of jesters all around us. My sister got the traditional schnitzel (like foam but delicious), I got beef and pepper (too much pepper), my mother got soup and my father got something like a pork chop. And somewhere around here, I‚Äôll give you the 3rd tip:
Following on from the above narrative about Day 1, after hitting the burgers, we slept in, recharged our batteries, and then visited Belvedere Palace. This palace was built as the summer estate of Eugene of Savoy. I imagine in the winter he got bored of it and went elsewhere. I‚Äôm not very good with humor.
Before the palace, there was a myriad of gardens of all shapes and colors. A waterfall dominated the center of the manicured vegetation and some weird statues lined the gardens, separating them from the paths. After much walking, we reached the entrance. We bought 2 bottles of water, paid 8‚Ç¨ and with a sweaty face we poured ourselves into the pure beauty of the marbles.
The welcome hall was an oasis of art. An imposing chandelier bathed the pageantry of colours representing a feast of angels and men. There were fireplaces in every corner, and from every wall hung paintings of every era, every concept, and every artist capable of making his mark. In addition to paintings, there were also sculptures in the palace. The most special of which was an exhibition where each sculpture captured in its expression a source of emotion, highlighting the fact that body language sometimes transcends poor words. Finally, I want to admit that enough said about my experience, I don‚Äôt want to prejudge your impression of the next attractions. So I‚Äôll just list the sights we visited that took our breath away. Tip 4:
Another feature that struck me was the fact that there were men dressed as charlatans everywhere trying to convince you to attend an opera, ballet, or even a gallery tour. I‚Äôve never seen art like that before. In Greece, when you see streetwalkers, they usually sell you some stolen glass. Anyway, we snapped up the offer and in the evening my sister and I met up at a palace to watch a ballet duet and listen to opera. I can say that this virgin experience impressed me. For the first time, I realized that music really does speak to your soul, if only you are absorbed in it. Violin, pirouettes, small voices, and champagne made up a beautiful evening in the cold Austrian city.
Finally, go for coffee at Central!
Hi! My name is Konstantinos, and I am studying Production Engineering and Management at the Technical University of Crete. If you liked the content of this piece, support us by subscribing for free here, and you will be the first to read our work.

Title: Vienna: Is it waiting for me?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
Vienna is so special to me‚Ä¶ It will always be the city with unforgettable many memories. I feel tons of emotions on that trip: fear, love, excitement, suspicion, admiration, understanding, enthusiasm‚Ä¶ Vienna is waiting for me, again.
Vienna is filled full of first experiences for me. First trip, first abroad, first flight‚Ä¶ I am grateful that it all started with Vienna.
I have two of my best friends while in Vienna, we explored together, we laughed, we danced (it was so funny), tasted‚Ä¶
We stayed in the most beautiful hotel and after many experiences, it still protects its place on my top list. I can recommend it with peace of mind. Our receptionist was cheerful, friendly and sincere. He talked about his travels to our home country, tried to talk in our main language, sent videos about our traditional foods on WhatsApp‚Ä¶ When I look at our hotel‚Äôs photos or think about it, I feel the beautiful smell of the hotel exactly. Magical.
We arrived in Vienna in the evening, and after settling in the hotel, we went to Mariahilfer Street. Since it was the first time, I was shocked by the early closing of the shopping places. The life stops early‚Ä¶ I am not used to it.
The second day in Vienna started with a meeting with our Erasmus student friend at Karlskirche, it was a long time since we had seen him. Also, we met with a student from Vienna Technical University who was very interested in cars and Austria.
Our city exploration started! There were a lot of architectural masterpieces‚Ä¶ Fascinating!
I had a detailed plan for the itinerary, nevertheless we started to be ahead on the plan. We went to Hundertwasser Houses and Prater on the second day instead of the third day.
I think we give the biggest appreciation to Prater‚Ä¶ Me and my friend really like the Before Sunrise movie, and the place was special for us. We recorded videos, spent many times at the photo booth cabin, watched‚Ä¶ It was fun.
My friend had kept talking about Wiener Rathaus since we arrived, her excitement spreaded to me. First, the architectural beauty captured us, then a closer look‚Ä¶ Ice rink, fancy ornaments‚Ä¶ All was magical. There was a song playing, suddenly we started to dance haha it was silly but funny! We stood right next to the ice rink and started watching around. I tried to keep that atmosphere in memory with every detail. Kids were skating, laughs were everywhere. Also, the screen on the building shows the area sometimes, we were seeing ourselves on the screen. Shaking hands‚Ä¶ Our cheeks were hurting from smiling!
Third day, again St. Stephan Cathedral. One of the favorite spots‚Ä¶
We went to gothic Votivkirche.
We had melange on a cafe has Votivkirche view. It was delicious and despite of being soft coffee served with water, interesting.
Bonus Memory!
I studied for my lesson and before coming to Vienna, I researched Sisi and watched the trio. There were many references in the streets. Understanding them was making me feel satisfied.
Overall
Vienna is a little bit over the student budget. I want to visit Vienna again with a rich budget and at that time I must spend my time in the museums, have schnitzel in a more elegant restaurant, go on the Christmas time and skate at Wiener Rathaus.
Regards, √ñzlem.

Title: My Culture Shock(s) in Vienna
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
When I first arrived in the city, I heard someone say ‚ÄòVienna has it all, why would you ever leave?‚Äô‚Äù
Intrigued by this perspective, I decided to check whether it was true.
After basking in a few glorious autumn days and surviving gloomy winter in Vienna, I thought I‚Äôd document my observations. Here are a few things I didn‚Äôt expect when moved to *Wien*:
Vienna ranked the world‚Äôs ‚Äòunfriendliest city‚Äô in 2022. There is even a Viennese term that describes grumpy locals ‚Äî Wiener Grant.
I was kinda ready to meet unfriendly Viennese when I just moved to Austria. But after a few months living in the city, I still can‚Äôt grasp where to find Wiener Grant. Yes, strangers don‚Äôt smile on the subway. But how cringy would it be if they did?
Why don‚Äôt I meet Wiener Grant that often? Either it is my language barrier that prevents me from understanding all the ugly things people complain about on a bus. Or, locals are actually nice, but they don‚Äôt want ‚Äúouties‚Äù to know that. Why would Viennese want to share their nice public transport or clean tap water with others?
I‚Äôve also heard this edgy theory ‚Äî that I don‚Äôt get cold shoulders from strangers that often because I‚Äôm the ‚Äúright‚Äù kind of immigrant: a taxpayer, a woman with a ‚ÄúWestern look.‚Äù However, I would like to believe that Viennese are friendly by nature, no matter who is in front of them.
I wish I lived in Vienna when I was a smoker. Locals freely smoke in public, and bus stops seem to be their favorite spots. Throughout the city there are billboards for Camel cigarettes and tobacco kiosks.
It‚Äôs still far from Greece where students smoke in the uni cafeteria but smokers would love it here in Vienna.
Another thing I find outfashioned is the amount of printed newspapers and leaflets. Every week, a giant pile of printed leaflets is delivered to my post box.
So much waste. Call klima-aktivists.
[Apparently, if you place a sticker on your post box that says ‚ÄúBitte keine Werbung,‚Äù you‚Äôll stop receiving unwanted leaflets].
Vienna has all kinds of clubs, communities and events that range from the quirky to the downright bizarre. Here are some of the local clubs: Men‚Äôs Health Club, Shut Up & Write Club, Vienna Philosophy Circle, Stitch and Bitch, Badminton Society, Vegan Meetups.
Take, for example, the Granny Square Gang, a group dedicated to making crocheted blankets for homeless dogs. Ok, I made that one up. Yet, it certainly has the potential to exist in Vienna.
I have lived in many cities, but only Vienna offers so many opportunities to blend in.
In Vienna, I am not alone in my foreignness. From Turkish kebab stands to Vietnamese noodle stores, the city is a melting pot of cuisines, religions and languages. The best thing? Diasporas and locally born ones learned to co-exist.
Vienna, like a true multi national city offers a unique opportunity ‚Äî to become Viennese (if you want to). All you need is to find your tribe, greet others by Gr√º√ü Gott and not to be afraid to shout ‚ÄúZweite Kassa, bitte‚Äù in the supermarket.
All jokes aside. It inspires me to see so many foreign souls fearlessly making their homes in the capital of Austria. Vienna may not become ‚Äúhome‚Äù right away, but it has the potential for a smooth beginning.
Locals care a lot about the city.
In fact, once you register, you can also report whenever you see something broken, dirty or just plain wrong around Vienna (there is a neat little app for that purpose). Even if you are a foreigner, you can make a direct impact in the city.
Vienna has its less attractive sides as well. There are a few things to get used to ‚Äî grey winter days, unfurnitured apartments, labyrinthine bureaucracy, supermarkets closing early on weekdays.
But after settling in, you will discover more reasons to love the city ‚Äî the endless array of events, museums, and hiking trails, the sense of security, rich wine culture, and cherry on top ‚Äî subway running all night on the weekend.
Maybe this city has everything to offer after all. You just need to find your favorite spots and people to care about, and you are good to go.
P.S. Many Viennese speak English proficiently, but delving into the language of the city ‚Äî German ‚Äî will make your life easier and give a deeper understanding of its unique vibes. Don‚Äôt shy away from putting your German skills to the test. As my one and only Austrian colleague once told me, ‚ÄúHere in Vienna, we got used to rusty German‚Äù.

Title: (Austria) A Magical Christmas in Vienna: The Ultimate Winter Getaway
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
If you‚Äôve ever dreamed of stepping into a real-life Christmas wonderland, Vienna in December is the place to be. From twinkling lights draped across historic buildings to the scent of mulled wine and roasted chestnuts filling the air, the city feels like something straight out of a fairy tale. I had always heard that Vienna was one of the most magical places to visit during the holiday season, but nothing prepared me for just how breathtaking it would be.
Reaching Vienna is easier than you might think. If you‚Äôre flying in, Vienna International Airport (VIE) is well-connected with flights from all over the world. From the airport, you can take the City Airport Train (CAT) which gets you to the city center in just 16 minutes. If you‚Äôre coming from a nearby European city, trains are an excellent option too, offering scenic routes through Austria‚Äôs picturesque countryside. I took a train from Munich, and as the snow-covered landscapes passed by, I knew I was in for something special.
Vienna is famous for its Christmas markets, and let me tell you, they do not disappoint. Here are a few you absolutely cannot miss:
The most iconic of them all, this market in front of Vienna‚Äôs City Hall is like something out of a holiday movie. With over 150 stalls selling handcrafted gifts, ornaments, and delicious food, it‚Äôs impossible to leave empty-handed. I grabbed a cup of Gl√ºhwein (mulled wine) and wandered through the market, soaking in the festive atmosphere.
For a more elegant setting, the Sch√∂nbrunn Palace Christmas Market is perfect. The backdrop of the grand palace makes everything feel even more magical. This market is ideal for finding high-quality artisan gifts and tasting traditional Austrian holiday treats.
Tucked away in narrow, cobblestone streets, this market feels cozy and intimate. It‚Äôs less touristy, making it a great spot to experience Vienna like a local. Here, I tried Kaiserschmarrn, a shredded pancake with powdered sugar and plum sauce ‚Äî absolutely divine!
One of Vienna‚Äôs most famous landmarks, this Gothic cathedral looks even more stunning with Christmas lights twinkling around it. Climbing to the top rewards you with breathtaking panoramic views of the city.
Not only does this palace house Gustav Klimt‚Äôs famous painting The Kiss, but it also has its own charming Christmas market. Walking through the snow-dusted palace gardens at night was like stepping into a dream.
If you love music, you cannot leave Vienna without experiencing an opera or classical concert. I managed to get last-minute tickets to The Nutcracker, and it was pure magic. The combination of Tchaikovsky‚Äôs music and the grandeur of the opera house made it an unforgettable experience.
Vienna‚Äôs winter calls for rich, hearty dishes that warm you up from the inside. Here are a few must-try foods:
This classic Austrian dish ‚Äî a breaded and fried veal cutlet ‚Äî is crispy, golden, and absolutely delicious. I had mine with potato salad at Figlm√ºller, a restaurant famous for its schnitzel.
No trip to Vienna is complete without trying the world-famous Sacher Torte, a rich chocolate cake with a layer of apricot jam. The best place to try it? Caf√© Sacher, of course!
A warm slice of Apfelstrudel (apple strudel) with a side of vanilla sauce was the perfect dessert to enjoy at a cozy caf√© while watching the snow fall outside.
One of the most magical moments of my trip was ice skating at the Rathausplatz Ice Rink, right in front of the beautifully illuminated City Hall. The atmosphere was electric, with Christmas music playing in the background and families gliding across the ice. I hadn‚Äôt been on skates in years, but somehow, in that moment, I felt like a kid again, completely lost in the joy of the season.
Vienna in December is more than just a destination ‚Äî it‚Äôs an experience that stays with you. There‚Äôs something about the combination of history, music, food, and festive spirit that makes it feel truly special. Walking through the snow-covered streets, wrapped in my warmest coat, with the sounds of classical music drifting through the air, I felt an overwhelming sense of joy and peace.
If you‚Äôre looking for a holiday getaway that feels straight out of a storybook, Vienna is the place to go. Trust me, once you experience Christmas here, you‚Äôll want to come back every year.
