Disclaimer : This is a long post and will require more attention span than scrolling through reels. :) So read at your own convenience
I have been extremely fortunate to travel to a lot of places in my lifetime. From the majestic temples in South India to the gigantic mountains in the north-east of India, I have pretty much covered it all. However, I recently traveled for work to Europe and it was by far one of the most memorable trips ever. Every journey brings forth some old lessons and new learnings. It reunites you with old friends and introduces you to strangers only to appreciate that life is nothing but the precious moments shared with friends, family, and other beautiful people.
I happened to visit Amsterdam, Rust(Germany), Basel, Paris, and Vienna, and each city had its own story that had to be unfolded. It was an 18-day trip, and I will be sharing my experiences in multiple articles. This article will solely be dedicated to my exploration of Vienna, and later ones will cover other cities.
I visited Vienna as the last leg of my journey after finishing all my work commitments. Vienna was not going to be on my list, but like any Indian Parent, my parents did not want me traveling to the West for the first time alone. So I was persuaded to stay with family, and I thought I‚Äôd rather make the best of my trip than sulk about not visiting other sought-after locations in Europe.
I arrived in Vienna on a Monday and spent the day with my cousin, just resting at home. The next day, I planned to visit Sch√∂nbrunn Palace and booked a tour around the city from GetYourGuide to see the most important centers around the city center or the Ringstra√üe.
Vienna is a city that is truly a mix of art, intelligence, war, and grandeur. Today it‚Äôs one of those nations, that is not a part of NATO, and in the past, it was not a part of the Allies but was occupied by them. Austria comprises 9 provinces(federal states), with Vienna being the capital city of Lower Austria province. It has continuously been ranked in the top position as the most livable city. It has an immensely well-connected public transport where for every place in the city, you will have access to a tram, a bus or a U-bahn station.
I leveraged this highly interconnected public infrastructure and booked a ticket on the Wien mobile app to venture out for my first day of sightseeing alone. The fun part of traveling alone is that I have the complete freedom to decide what I want to see, when I want to see it, and how I want to see it.
The Sch√∂nbrunn Palace was my first choice because it topped the list of the must places to visit in Vienna and looked extremely magnificent. I got a ticket that also included an audioguide. Apart from the public transport and infrastructure, one stark difference is tourism in Europe is well-planned and structured. Every place I visited, I had the option to opt for an audioguide which would brilliantly explain the tiniest detail of that place.
Sch√∂nbrunn Palace was the summer residence of the Habsburg dynasty who had ruled for over 600 years in the Austrian region. The current architecture was modeled and remodeled during Maria Theresa‚Äôs reign who was the only female to ever hold the position in the empire. This palace along with its Gardens is also categorised as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The Palace embodies the Baroque architecture which is known for its illustrative fresco paintings, grandeur, and opulence. To create a sense of luxury, marble and gold are used extensively. Domelike ceilings are adorned with intricate fresco paintings. Sch√∂nbrunn Palace comprised various rooms that depicted the imperial architecture, paintings of the various rulers of the Habsburg dynasty, miniature paintings, and elaborate halls where weddings were conducted.
One of the rulers of Austria was Franz Joseph I, and his infamous wife Sisi.There is an entire Netflix series based on her life called ‚ÄúEmpress‚Äù. Known to be an eccentric modern woman and a rebel in her time, she traveled all around Europe. She was always unhappy and very isolated but a beautiful woman nevertheless. She has been extensively marketed as the face of Vienna, with her kind of jewelry sold at exorbitant prices and her face on every fridge magnet or postcard.
One of the rooms of the Sch√∂nbrunn Palace contained her dressing room, where a figurine resembling her with long and lustrous hair was placed. The picture below shows this.
After I spent about an hour and a half at the palace, I had to reach a point in the city center where I was supposed to meet my guide for the walking tour. It was a treasure hunt in disguise to decode the route from the palace to the center, considering everything was written in German. After much strife, I managed to reach the center just in time to meet my guide, who was an extremely eloquent and funny woman.
Austria is predominantly Catholic with spectacular Cathedrals and Churches in almost every town and city. It was without a doubt that the walking tour would also start at a Church. We started at the Minorites Church which was a beautiful Catholic church made by Italians. Back in the day, there was a marginal population of Italians who lived in Austria and that‚Äôs how this Church came to be. It follows the Gothic architecture about which I will speak in just a while. However, the remarkable point about this Church was a grand-sized Mosaic picture of the infamous Last Supper(which of course was originally painted by Leonardo Da Vinci in Milan, Italy), but here it was Giacomo Raffaelli, who made this mosaic art piece. There is a funny backstory to this. Napolean, when he was married to, Marie Louise, one of the daughters belonging to the Habsburg Dynasty, wanted the original Last Supper in Vienna. He tried numerous ways to dismantle the mural painting from the refectory in Milan and bring it to Vienna but in vain. He then summoned Giacomo, who created a replica of the original mural painting but through mosaics. Even today, the replica is used to maintain and refurbish the original painting because a mosaic doesn‚Äôt fade away.
After the Church, we walked to Hofburg Palace in the Ringstrase. Since 1946, it has been the official residence and workplace of the President of Austria, who is just a figurine head of the state. It is also on the balcony of this palace, that Adolf Hitler had announced, on the 15th of March 1938, that Austria would also be a part of his idea of Germany. Many Austrians were also super enthusiastic Nazis. Adolf Hitler was an Austrian too.
Austria was a major global superpower before the First World War. It initiated the WWI when the erstwhile Austria-Hungary invaded Serbia in July 1914. When the war ended, Austria abolished the monarchy and became a democratic republic.
While walking through these important landmarks, we also passed the imperial library(which I visited on my last day), Albertina, and Spanish Riding School. During the walking tour, I also befriended two very sweet young ladies(in their 60s and 70s) from Scotland. They were extremely kind and inquired about all the places I would visit in the next couple of days. They even gave me a couple of suggestions on do‚Äôs and don‚Äôts.
The highlight of the tour was saved for the end. It was the St.Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral. This resplendent Cathedral was constructed in a span of 300 years and the South Tower took about 65 years to complete. The beauty of Gothic Architecture lies in the tall spires. These spires which are visually spectacular also embody the aspirations of humans to reach God. Another remarkable architectural detail is the ornate patterns and the stories that are painted on the glass of the Cathedral. This was prevalent in medieval times since not everyone knew how to read and write, and paintings were the easiest way to communicate stories of religious importance.
With this, the walking tour came to an end, and so did my sightseeing for the day. I enjoyed a traditional Vienna dessert called Kaiserschmarrn, topped with plum sauce, which was brilliant. I also went up the north tower for a beautiful view of the city and booked a classical concert on the way back.
P.S : looks like I only managed to cover Day 1 in this article. I always wanted to chronicle my travels to Europe in as much detail as possible, and hence, I don‚Äôt mind writing multiple articles as long as I do justice to them. I will cover Day 2 in the next article.
Have you traveled to Europe or Vienna before? What was your experience?

The city has come to a standstill. Caf√©s, bakeries, and shops are hidden behind shutters. So, I stand here in the middle of a cobblestone street, clutching my phone as if it can magically summon a croissant. Or, anything to fill my empty stomach.
Yesterday, this same street was alive with the rhythm of the city. The low hum of voices. The sound of countless footsteps bouncing off the stones. But today, it‚Äôs as if someone pressed pause, and I don‚Äôt know what to do with myself.
Then I remember it‚Äôs Sunday. By law, most shops in Austria are closed to honor the Christian tradition of it being a day of rest. People are still, but in a way that doesn‚Äôt feel like an absence. Instead, it feels like a choice, like the entire city has collectively decided to pause. To breathe.
The slow pace of Vienna on a Sunday morning is a stark contrast to back home, where Sundays are a time to catch up on errands. To check off tasks from a never-ending to-do list. And I must admit it feels unnatural at first. Almost wrong to let the day stretch out before me with no agenda. No plan. But as I wander through the streets of Vienna, I realize something. The‚Ä¶

Title: My Life In Imperial Vienna
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Frequently, people ask me about my life in Vienna. I give roughly the same answer: ‚ÄúVienna is an interesting city.‚Äù
An interesting city for sure. Unlike Madrid or Budapest ‚Äî cities I found very welcoming ‚Äî Vienna, for me, was not love at first sight. Neither was it love at second sight or the third, for that matter.
But Vienna was the right city at the right time. It‚Äôs an imperial city, and it has a lot to offer: museums, art, culture, cleanliness, quietness, and more.
While this may sound like a slow-burn love affair, it‚Äôs not. Not fully, at least, or perhaps not yet.
Unlike most major cities, such as Paris, London, New York, Barcelona, Berlin, Prague, or even Budapest ‚Äî which was once part of the same Empire and ‚Äî built, in parts, to emulate the wealthier neighbor, Vienna is a ‚Äúhidden city.‚Äù By hidden city, I mean that the nice architecture is not ‚Äúin your face.‚Äù
Vienna is like the introvert of cities, a little more reserved than its extroverted cousins. The grand palaces and monuments do not jump out at you, but once you peel back the layers, the architecture and history are simply fascinating.
Frequently, I meet tourists near the Belvedere area ‚Äî where I happen to live ‚Äî who can‚Äôt find the Belvedere Castle. ‚ÄúHow can you miss a castle?‚Äù one, who has never visited Vienna, might ask. You can, if the castle is downhill and the walls around it cover its beauty.
But once you find the Belvedere, it‚Äôs truly breathtaking. The baroque architecture and the beautiful gardens make it a feast for the eyes. It‚Äôs almost like a secret garden, but with a royal twist.
And the Upper Belvedere is one of my favorite museums in the city. It contains stunning artwork including many pieces by one of my favorite artists, Gustav Klimt ‚Äî himself a rebel among his contemporaries.
The Belvedere Castle is not the only famous landscape that‚Äôs hidden. Vienna is like a game of spies. The most well-known landmarks are like the city‚Äôs best-kept secrets.
Hidden again, the Sch√∂nbrunn Palace. A fairytale castle, surrounded by gorgeous gardens and fountains.
Also hidden, Volksgarten, with its beautiful statues and beds of roses is a hidden oasis in the heart of the city, and perhaps the most important of them all: the Imperial district. The district is home to some of Vienna‚Äôs most iconic landmarks like St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral, but it‚Äôs not exactly obvious where it starts and ends.
The most famous place and institution when it comes to music, Musikverein ‚Äî which contains the same hall where the famous New Year‚Äôs concert is held, also seems nothing special from most angles, except the main entrance. Hard to believe that the famous Golden Hall is placed somewhere inside that, perhaps unimpressive, building.
‚ÄúYou see that?‚Äù a friend asked the months we were in Vienna. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Musikverein. It‚Äôs so famous in China [the country she was born in] and it looks so plain from here.‚Äù
Musikverein may look ordinary, given the surrounding architecture, but inside, it‚Äôs a total stunner. The Golden Hall is the star of the show ‚Äî all gilded and ornate with famous acoustics that just make the music touch your soul deeply.
Another question I get asked a lot is ‚ÄúHow do you compare Vienna to other cities you lived before?‚Äù
I think comparing Vienna to the other cities would be unfair. In almost all the cities I previously lived with the exception of Budapest, I was a poor student, and the activities I could do were limited.
It‚Äôs not a fair comparison. To me, it feels like comparing apples and Wiener schnitzel.
Vienna is rich in history, cultural offerings, and elegant architecture. But the move to Vienna was not voluntary, my employer relocated, and I even found myself in Vienna after a separation, with all of a sudden more free time on my hands. I get to occupy that time with cultural activities.
Yet, despite its cultural richness, Vienna is known for being conservative, rigid, and at times, unwelcoming. [Vienna keeps getting ranked both as one of the most liveable cities and most unwelcoming to foreigners.] This is especially true for women, who are often expected to adhere to traditional roles such as raising children, and for third-country citizens. I belong to both of these categories.
At times, it feels like the city is still holding onto its 18th-century manners or something of the like. And while the cultural activities are great, the rigidity and the resulting bureaucracy can be a bit of a killjoy.
Now and then, as a reminder that you live in a country that has frozen time, one may even get shouted at in some cafes. Sometimes it feels almost as hard to penetrate as trying to get into a high-society ball without an invitation.
So, when I am asked about my life in Vienna, I confidently say that it‚Äôs a chapter of my life that has shaped me in unexpected ways (and continues to do so).
It may not have been love at first sight, but it is on the path of becoming an important chapter in my life‚Äôs story. Living here has highlighted even more the disparities and expectations placed upon women and outsiders, yet it has also offered opportunities for more understanding and empathy.
Vienna has made me question norms and values, pushing me to explore the intersection of tradition and modernity. The city definitely brings out the part of me that calls for social change.
Where does this desire come from? I don‚Äôt know. What I know is that I will listen to it and do what I can to be the change I‚Äôd like to see. Writing these Medium articles is a step toward that change. After all, change happens one step at a time.
Thank you for taking the time to read about my thoughts. If you enjoyed the article feel free to reach out at arieda.muco@gmail.com or on Twitter, Linkedin, or Instagram. Feel free to also share it with others.
--
--
Econ Ph.D., Researcher, Coding, ML and NLP Instructor

Content:

Vienna is so special to me‚Ä¶ It will always be the city with unforgettable many memories. I feel tons of emotions on that trip: fear, love, excitement, suspicion, admiration, understanding, enthusiasm‚Ä¶ Vienna is waiting for me, again.
Vienna is filled full of first experiences for me. First trip, first abroad, first flight‚Ä¶ I am grateful that it all started with Vienna.
I have two of my best friends while in Vienna, we explored together, we laughed, we danced (it was so funny), tasted‚Ä¶
We stayed in the most beautiful hotel and after many experiences, it still protects its place on my top list. I can recommend it with peace of mind. Our receptionist was cheerful, friendly and sincere. He talked about his travels to our home country, tried to talk in our main language, sent videos about our traditional foods on WhatsApp‚Ä¶ When I look at our hotel‚Äôs photos or think about it, I feel the beautiful smell of the hotel exactly. Magical.
We arrived in Vienna in the evening, and after settling in the hotel, we went to Mariahilfer Street. Since it was the first time, I was shocked by the early closing of the shopping places. The life stops early‚Ä¶ I am not used to it.
The second day in Vienna started with a meeting with our Erasmus student friend at Karlskirche, it was a long time since we had seen him. Also, we met with a student from Vienna Technical University who was very interested in cars and Austria.
Our city exploration started! There were a lot of architectural masterpieces‚Ä¶ Fascinating!
I had a detailed plan for the itinerary, nevertheless we started to be ahead on the plan. We went to Hundertwasser Houses and Prater on the second day instead of the third day.
I think we give the biggest appreciation to Prater‚Ä¶ Me and my friend really like the Before Sunrise movie, and the place was special for us. We recorded videos, spent many times at the photo booth cabin, watched‚Ä¶ It was fun.
My friend had kept talking about Wiener Rathaus since we arrived, her excitement spreaded to me. First, the architectural beauty captured us, then a closer look‚Ä¶ Ice rink, fancy ornaments‚Ä¶ All was magical. There was a song playing, suddenly we started to dance haha it was silly but funny! We stood right next to the ice rink and started watching around. I tried to keep that atmosphere in memory with every detail. Kids were skating, laughs were everywhere. Also, the screen on the building shows the area sometimes, we were seeing ourselves on the screen. Shaking hands‚Ä¶ Our cheeks were hurting from smiling!
Third day, again St. Stephan Cathedral. One of the favorite spots‚Ä¶
We went to gothic Votivkirche.
We had melange on a cafe has Votivkirche view. It was delicious and despite of being soft coffee served with water, interesting.
Bonus Memory!
I studied for my lesson and before coming to Vienna, I researched Sisi and watched the trio. There were many references in the streets. Understanding them was making me feel satisfied.
Overall
Vienna is a little bit over the student budget. I want to visit Vienna again with a rich budget and at that time I must spend my time in the museums, have schnitzel in a more elegant restaurant, go on the Christmas time and skate at Wiener Rathaus.
Regards, √ñzlem.

I wrote this at the end of December but it has been stuck in drafts.
Looking back it was a lovely day and such fascinating history I saw.
Enjoy!
I was thinking about a hike today, but then I woke up to rain and wind so I quickly squashed those plans.
Instead, I decided to walk over to the Hundertwasser Museum, a place I‚Äôve wanted to visit for a while.
Friedensreich Hundertwasser created eclectic buildings and works of art. The trash incineration plant in Vienna was even designed by him after the old plant burned down.
The museum building itself stands out, and the inside continues the themes. The floor is uneven so you experience it like nature. There is so much to see inside with art work, biographical details and so much more. Just fascinating and well worth the visit. Of course the museum has a shop and a cozy caf√© to while away the time. Perfect for a rainy afternoon!
On the way to the museum, I discovered yet another piece of classical music history when I happened upon the building where Beethoven completed his 9th Symphony in 1823/24, one of my favorite pieces of music: so powerful!
Everywhere you walk here there is a plaque indicating some classical musician or other famous character lived.
All in all a relaxing and enjoyable day in Vienna. And more reasons why I love living here.
Happy Holidays!

Title: Vienna‚Äôs Little Treasures ‚Äî Hidden in Plain Sight
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Sybarite is devoted to stories of pleasure and luxury, and is allergic to all forms of self help.

--
Listen
Share
I moved to Vienna from Britain in September 2004. Initially, I wasn‚Äôt sure how long I was going to stay, so I decided to make the best of whatever time I had in this magnificent city and visited all the main sights in short order.
Sch√∂nbrunn Palace, St. Stephen‚Äôs cathedral, Belvedere Palace, Karlskirche, Prater‚Ä¶this place is just brimming with wonderful things to see and do. If you‚Äôre lucky enough to be here for a longer period, you can get off the beaten path and discover some of the city‚Äôs lesser-known gems.
After almost 20 years living in Vienna, it‚Äôs these tiny, unknown points of interest that make out the charm of the city I now proudly call home. The ones standing unnoticed on street corners, in shop basements, or even next to train lines. Passed by thousands of people every single day, they are part of the urban furniture and topography; and yet only a few locals know their true significance.
Tucked away in a tiny courtyard in the 4th district, a stone‚Äôs throw away from Karlsplatz, the Heum√ºhle (pictured above) is a monument to the area‚Äôs past.
The nearby U4 subway line follows the line of the Vienna River (Wienflu√ü), a lively tributary of the Danube that runs down to the river from the surrounding hills. During the 13th century, a mill stream was built to divert water away from the river and power a series of water mills: the B√§renm√ºhle (‚ÄúBear Mill‚Äù), the Schleifm√ºhle (‚ÄúGrinding Mill‚Äù) and the Heum√ºhle (‚ÄúHay Mill‚Äù).
Milling in this area continued until the mid-1800s when the mill stream was filled in and both the B√§renm√ºhle and the Schleifm√ºhle were demolished to make way for new urban developments as the city grew.
The B√§renm√ºhle is commemorated in the name of a block of modern flats built on the site, as well as the passageway built through a part of it (B√§renm√ºhlhaus, B√§renm√ºhldurchgang). The Schleifm√ºhle lives on in the name of a street in the area ‚Äî the Schleifm√ºhlgasse.
Only the Heum√ºhle remained standing. Concealed by new city developments, it was left by its owners to crumble for many years.
That solid 14th century construction wasn‚Äôt going anywhere too fast though, and a renovation in 2007 returned the mill to its former glory (or at least structural soundness).
These days, the mill houses the showroom of an office furniture company and can be viewed by curious members of the public during the day when the gates to the courtyard are open.
Being an ancient city with multiple layers of history, there‚Äôs plenty to discover under Vienna‚Äôs streets ‚Äî from Roman remains to concealed waterways to cinematically famous sewers (think: The Third Man).
A particularly special feature of subterranean Vienna can be found in the first-level cellar of the house on the corner of Ertlgasse and Kramergasse in the 1st district (now occupied by a shop).
The vaulted ceiling of the old brick cellar contains one of only two surviving ‚ÄúJosephinian columns‚Äù. These supports were built into the cellars of the houses lining the Rotenturmstrasse in the early years of the 18th century in preparation for the transport of the famous ‚ÄúPummerin‚Äù bell from the shores of the Danube to its destination, St. Stephen‚Äôs cathedral.
The Pummerin bell, partially cast from the iron of Turkish cannons captured during the siege of 1683, was so heavy that people feared transporting it up the street would cause the street to buckle and collapse into the cellars below. Holy Roman Emperor Joseph I ordered these columns to be built into the foundations of the surrounding buildings to help this project of city pride to its completion.
The old Pummerin bell hung in the north tower of St. Stephen‚Äôs cathedral until 1945 when it suffered a devastating fire in the final months of the 2nd World War. The vast bell fell to the ground and smashed into several pieces.
The new Pummerin, in situ since 1957, is only rung on important occasions (e.g. the death of the Pope, new year). Just like its predecessor, it is a beloved symbol of peace and regeneration after the carnage of war.
Close to Schwedenplatz lies one of Vienna‚Äôs oldest churches: Maria am Gestade. ‚ÄúGestade‚Äù is an old German word meaning ‚Äúshore‚Äù or ‚Äúbank‚Äù. Looking at the church in 2023, this might seem a little confusing as it clearly isn‚Äôt located next to the river and the Danube Canal is still a few minutes‚Äô walk away. However, before the Danube was regulated in the 16th century, this church did actually sit on the banks of an arm of the mighty river. Local lore tells that this is the place where river fishermen would dock and say their prayers.
Besides being a very beautiful building and marking the start of a pilgrimage route, the church has an unusual feature which harks back to Vienna‚Äôs earliest days as a Roman settlement. If you stand at the main entrance of the church and look down towards the high altar, you will see that the building has a slight ‚Äúkink‚Äù in the middle.
This subtle asymmetry in the church‚Äôs construction is because it was built along the lines of the early city walls ‚Äî which themselves followed the boundaries of the Roman camp of Vindobona.
The Romans, being fans of both symmetry and sound military logic, built their garrison in a perfect rectangular shape with two sides backing onto the river and its direct tributary, the Ottakring stream. That left them with only two sides to defend in the event of an attack. However, being at the intersection of two waterways also left them seriously exposed to flooding.
Which is exactly what happened. Archaeologists believe that extreme flooding in the 4th century resulted in the northwest corner of the Roman settlement (located at the point where the Ottakring stream flowed into the Danube) collapsing into the river and being swept downstream (check out this illustration for a better understanding).
The pragmatic Romans adjusted to the reformed geography and rebuilt the settlement‚Äôs boundaries along the new, post-flood line of the river bank: the line we now see in the crooked construction of Maria am Gestade.
Want to find out more about the historical curiosities scattered around Vienna? Read part two of ‚ÄúVienna‚Äôs Little Treasures ‚Äî Hidden in Plain Sight‚Äù here!

Title: Vienna districts guide
Content:

Share
Vienna (Austria) is divided into 23 districts ‚Äî administrative areas of different sizes and with their own specific characteristics and charm. Vienna districts are both numbered and have a name, so it is easy to navigate. Their numbers are linked to postal codes, so if an address in Vienna has a postal code 1210, it is in 21st district (middle number from postal code 1210). Here is another example ‚Äî 1010 is a postal code from first district ‚Äî 1010.
Also, street names displayed on plates are numbered with district numbers, so if plate reads 4. Prinz Eugen-Stra√üe, this means you are in the 4th district. This makes navigation through Vienna really easy.
From 23 districts, first nine are considered inner districts as they are located around city center. The remaining 14 districts (10‚Äì23) are considered outer districts as they are further away from the city center.
Here is the list and brief info about Vienna districts with their postcodes (zip codes):
The main, central district located in the geographical center of Vienna. Home to Stephan Platz (Stephansplatz) and St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral (Stephansdom). This is the main tourist flocking district with many important landmarks and high-end shopping and dining areas. It is a part of the Old Town and has couple of pedestrian areas popular with tourists and Vienna resident alike. Innere Stadt is circled with Ringstra√üe, spacious boulevard following the route of former city walls.
The first district is a home to Kunsthistorisches (Art History) and Naturhistorisches (Natural History) museums, National Library and several other important museums. The district has many palace buildings, mostly from 19th and early 20th century: Palais Nieder√∂sterreich, Palais Dietrichstein, Stadtalais Liechtenstein, Palais Porcia, Palais Starhemberg, Palais Esterhazy, Hochhaus Herrengasse and main ne being The Hofburg.
Leopoldstadt is the district on the island between the Danube and the Donaukanal. It shares the island with 20nd district, Brigittenau. It is home of Praterstern, city‚Äôs busiest traffic node, and Prater Park with Viennese Giant Ferris Wheel. Second districts has several more landmarks and attractions such as: Augarten park with Palais Augarten and Porcelain Factory, Wiener S√§ngerknaben (Vienna Boys‚Ä≤ Choir, also in Palais Augarten), Carmelite Church (Karmeliterkirche), Karmelitermarkt, Produktenb√∂rse (Corn Exchange) and Kirche St. Leopold.
Leopoldstadt has a strong Jewish heritage and also unfortunate history as Jewish people were gathered from here to be send to the concentration camps during the Holocausts. Today, Jewish presence in culture and commerce is revived and thriving in the second district.
The second district has very central position and it is well connected to the city centre, so it is very popular residential area as well, with much lower rent than 1st district.
Landstra√üe is next to Innere Stadt (district 1), right on the right side of the Donaukanal. It includes Belvedere Palace and central train station of Vienna, Wien Mitte. Apart from Belvedere, there are few notable cultural institutions in this districts as well: Kunsthaus Wien, Hundertwasserhaus Wien, Akademietheater, Konzerthaus and Heeresgeschichtliches Museum.
There are also several palaces of historical importance: Schwarzenberg Palace, Palais Schwarzenberg, Palais Wittgenstein and Palais Rasumofsky. Third district also have several churches from different denominations and architectural styles: Gardekirche, Elisabethinenkirche, Rochuskirche Church, Kirche Maria Geburt and the Russian Orthodox Church.
From other landmarks, it is worth mentioning Schwarzenbergplatz Square with Hochquellbrunnen Fountain, and the Soviet War Memorial.
Wieden is a small district in south to the city center and includes Karlsplatz with famous Karlskirche and also the Vienna University of Technology. Notable attractions and landmark also include Wien Museum, Naschmarkt, Theklakirche, Paulanerkirche and Elisabethkirche.
This district is popular with tourist in the area of Karlsplatz and Naschmarkt.
Margareten and Wieden were one district until 1861. It is a small district, almost identical in size with Wieden. Famous for being a home to Austrian Society and Economy Museum, known globally for introduction of Vienna Method, data visualization method.
This district also has history in labor and workers movement all the way before WWII. It was greatly destroyed during WWII and rebuilding of it took some time. Today, the district has its charm and you can find very cheap rental and very near to the city center.
This is another of the smaller Vienna districts, part of the central city area. Popular with shopping and dining area along Mariahilfer Stra√üe and also includes Haus des Meeres Aqua Terra Zoo, Vienna aquarium.
Academy of Fine Arts is located in this district, and this is a reason in somewhat bohemian feel in the area, since district is filled with small art galleries and art and artisan souvenir shops.
Theater an der Wien is also in Mariahilf district. Mozart‚Äôs Magic Flute was first performed there. Joseph Haydn, another famous classical composer, lived in Mariahilf area. He lived near the Kirche St. Aegyd, which is now affectionately called Haydnkirche.
Another notable church in the area is Mariahilfer Church, Baroque style church from 18th century.
Mariahilf is a district popular with tourist also because offers many streets for walking and wandering around and looking at the small shops or have coffee break in one of many cafes.
Neubau is another small district, but it is a host to the Museumsquartier, a large museum and gallery complex. Leopold Museum, MUMOK, Kunsthalle Wien, Architekturzentrum, ZOOM Kindermuseum and MQ POINT are just selected top cultural institution of about 60 located in the area, which makes it one of the biggest in Europe.
Many cafes, bars and restaurants in the area are making visit to Neubau enjoyable and you can always expect some street performance in and around Museumsquartier, especially in summer.
Other than Museumsquartier, the 7th district also is a home to Volkstheater, ‚Äòpeople‚Äôs theatre‚Äô, built in 19th century, Hofmobiliendepot, museum of Imperial furniture and Stiftskaserne, former monastery turned into military base that had some dark history, especially during WWII.
As in the rest of central Vienna, there are several churches in the area: Altlerchenfelder Church, Lazaristenkirche Church and Ulrichskirche Church.
Josefstadt is the smallest one of the Vienna districts. It is situated adjacent to the Rathaus, and close to the Austrian Parliament and the University of Vienna. The district is mostly residential, but there are still number of landmarks to visit. There are several palaces in the area: Palais Sch√∂nborn, hosting √ñsterreichische Volkskundemuseum, a Museum of folk art and culture; Palais Auersperg, Palais Trautson, Palais Damian and Palais Strozzi.
There is a district museum with works of Klimt; Theater in der Josefstadt and Vienna International Theatre are two established performing arts institutions. There are also several small cabaret and small theater scenes around the district.
There are three notable churches in the district: Piaristenkirche Church, Dreifaltigkeitskirche and Mechitaristenkirche.
Alsergrund is the last of the inner districts and it closes the circle around city center. It is the area of the General Hospital and Vienna Medical University district, and also Sigmund Freud‚Äôs Museum.
From other attractions in this district, we can mention: Votivkirche Church, Palais Liechtenstein (owned by royal family of Liechtenstein) and Ro√üauer Kaserne, large building which hosted military base in the past.
Favoriten is one of the larger districts with largest population so far. It is located in the southern part of Vienna. On its northern border, there is main train station, Wien Hauptbahnhof, and Vienna‚Äôs thermal spa in its southern part.
From notable landmarks in this district we can mention following: Spinnerin am Kreuz, a rare Gothic shrine, depicting several scenes from the Bible; churches ‚Äî Oberlaa, Laarberg and Salvatorkirche; Starhemberg Kaserne, army base built at the beginning of the 20th century, and 19th century water tower, construction of a historical importance.
Simmering is a fairly large district, located next to Favoriten and on the right side of the Donaukanal. It is one of the oldest districts of Vienna, with the written records from the early 11th century.
It hosts some quite unique landmarks, such as: Gasometer City, former gas tanks converted into an apartment and office complex and Wiener Zentralfriedhof, Vienna Central Cemetery with around three million people burred there.
From other attractions in the district it‚Äôs worth mentioning Altsimmeringer Pfarrkirche, parish church from 18th century and two parks ‚Äî Herderpark and Hyblerpark.
Meidling is a small district on the southern bank of the Wien river. Current Chancellor of Austria Sebastian Kurz was raised there and has private residence is Meidling.
There are few attractions in this district: Schloss Hetzendorf and Schloss Altmannsdorf, both used as educational institutions; S√ºdwestfriedhof, the second largest cemetery in Vienna and Haydnpark, among others, smaller public parks.
Hietzing is on the southern bank of the Wien river, and on the west of Vienna city area. It includes Sch√∂nbrunn Palace as one of the top attractions in Vienna. But, Sch√∂nbrunn Palace is not the only attraction in this, arguably, greenest district of Vienna (after all, the entire area was hunting grounds for Habsburgs). Lainzer Tiergarten is large nature reserve where imperial family was doing exactly that ‚Äî hunting. And also, relaxing, as there is a villa there ‚Äî Hermesvilla, frequented by Emperor Franz Joseph I and his wife, Empress Elisabeth (popular ‚ÄòSisi‚Äô).
Heitzing was always area populated with aristocracy in past times, and now with their descendants or wealthy people in general. This is weirdly noticeable in local cemetery, Friedhof Hietzing, where expansive tombs are built for deceased wealthy citizens of the district, and not with much artistic taste.
Gustav Klimt is also buried there and this is a reason enough to visit this cemetery. Also, there is a Klimt Villa in Heitzing, where the artist lived and worked until his death in 1918.
Penzing was one district with Heitzing until they were divided into two districts in 1938. Located on the northern bank of the Wien river, the district is famous for Otto Wagner‚Äôs Church ‚Äî Kirche am Steinhof. The church is set in the center of the compound of former psychiatric hospital, one of the largest in Europe at the time.
Otto Wagner also designed two villas in Penzing, aptly named Otto Wagner Villa I and Otto Wagner Villa II. They were, of course built in the Art Nouveau style.
From other notable attractions, we recommend Technisches Museum (Technical Museum) and birth place of Klimt in Baumgarten.
This district is also quite green almost half the territory is with parks and gardens.
Rudolfsheim-F√ºnfhaus is on the northern bank of the Wien river and it is a small district surrounded by six other Vienna district form the area. It is a district with highest percentage of foreign-born population in Vienna. One of the main train station, Westbahnhof, is located here.
From notable attractions in this district we can mention Maria vom Siege church and Stadthalle, large concert venue.
Formerly a village of Ottakring, this western district is now a thriving neighborhood famous for its brewery and large Balkan immigration, especially from former Yugoslavia. The district lived through the population and construction boom in 1920s, during ‚ÄòRed Vienna‚Äô period.
Today, its Brunnenmarkt is a fair competition to famous Naschmarkt, and there are several areas with distinguished charm throughout the district. This is not a touristy area so attractions are few, but these are landmarks to visit: Schloss Wilhelminenberg (now a hotel, but you can go there for a coffee, or better, a m√©lange), Wallfahrtskirche zur Heiligen Theresia vom Kinde Jesu, a pilgrimage church whose name is not easy to pronounce (or remember), Heuriger 10er Marie, a classic tavern to have a nice break and Kuffner Sternwarte, the observatory, one of the three in Vienna.
Hernals is the district stretching towards northwestern outskirts of Vienna. This is also not touristy area and there are not many interesting things to find there. Locally famous churches to visit there are Kalvarienbergkirche, the S√ºhnekirche, and the Marienpfarre. There is also a palace with a park, Schloss Neuwaldegg, worth visiting.
W√§hring is on the northwestern of Vienna and includes the T√ºrkenschanzpark and University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences. There are several notable buildings/castles in this district, such as Schlo√ü P√∂tzleinsdorf.
This is also mostly residential district with very few attractions of interest to tourists.
D√∂bling is northern district and it is one of the larger ones. It is famous for being a residence of Beethoven and it hosts Japanese Garden.
Karl-Marx-Hof, large apartment complex dating back from 1920, period of ‚ÄòRed Vienna‚Äù is also in this district.
What makes this district popular is its location on the outskirts of Wienerwald, Vienna Woods, where many people go for outdoor activities.
Brigittenau was one district with Leopoldstadt, until they were made two districts in 1900. Named after Brigitta Chapel, built in 17 thcentury. Other churches in this district include Kirche zum G√∂ttlichen Erl√∂ser and the St. Johann Kapistran-Church.
Floridsdorf is large district located on the left bank of the Danube and in the north of Vienna and includes combination of industrial and residential areas. This can be considered suburban district in general terms. There are very few attractions or landmark to see here, such as Donaufeld church or Mautner Schl√∂ssl with districy museum.
Donaustadt is also on the left bank of the Danube and is the largest district of Vienna, occupying almost one quarter of city‚Äôs area. It is a host of the Vienna International Centre, large campus and building complex of the United Nations Office in Vienna and several agencies and also Vienna‚Äôs largest conference center.
Alte Donau (Old Danube) is a popular recreation area, together with small national parks and several public parks throughout the district.
Liesing is the southernmost district, which is also one the least populated Vienna districts. It includes the Wotruba Church, an unique example of Brutalism in architecture. There are also castles/palaces: Schloss Liesing, Schloss Rodaun and Schloss Alterlaa, villa Hofmannsthal-Schl√∂ssl and large park of Alt-Erlaa. Other than that, Liesing is mostly combination of residential and commercial buildings.
This is just a brief description of each of Vienna districts. We hope this will be useful starting point in exploration of the city. We will be writing in more details as we add articles about attractions and landmarks around Vienna. Safe travels and see you soon!
Originally published at https://allaboutvienna.com on June 30, 2020.

Title: (Austria) A Magical Christmas in Vienna: The Ultimate Winter Getaway
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
If you‚Äôve ever dreamed of stepping into a real-life Christmas wonderland, Vienna in December is the place to be. From twinkling lights draped across historic buildings to the scent of mulled wine and roasted chestnuts filling the air, the city feels like something straight out of a fairy tale. I had always heard that Vienna was one of the most magical places to visit during the holiday season, but nothing prepared me for just how breathtaking it would be.
Reaching Vienna is easier than you might think. If you‚Äôre flying in, Vienna International Airport (VIE) is well-connected with flights from all over the world. From the airport, you can take the City Airport Train (CAT) which gets you to the city center in just 16 minutes. If you‚Äôre coming from a nearby European city, trains are an excellent option too, offering scenic routes through Austria‚Äôs picturesque countryside. I took a train from Munich, and as the snow-covered landscapes passed by, I knew I was in for something special.
Vienna is famous for its Christmas markets, and let me tell you, they do not disappoint. Here are a few you absolutely cannot miss:
The most iconic of them all, this market in front of Vienna‚Äôs City Hall is like something out of a holiday movie. With over 150 stalls selling handcrafted gifts, ornaments, and delicious food, it‚Äôs impossible to leave empty-handed. I grabbed a cup of Gl√ºhwein (mulled wine) and wandered through the market, soaking in the festive atmosphere.
For a more elegant setting, the Sch√∂nbrunn Palace Christmas Market is perfect. The backdrop of the grand palace makes everything feel even more magical. This market is ideal for finding high-quality artisan gifts and tasting traditional Austrian holiday treats.
Tucked away in narrow, cobblestone streets, this market feels cozy and intimate. It‚Äôs less touristy, making it a great spot to experience Vienna like a local. Here, I tried Kaiserschmarrn, a shredded pancake with powdered sugar and plum sauce ‚Äî absolutely divine!
One of Vienna‚Äôs most famous landmarks, this Gothic cathedral looks even more stunning with Christmas lights twinkling around it. Climbing to the top rewards you with breathtaking panoramic views of the city.
Not only does this palace house Gustav Klimt‚Äôs famous painting The Kiss, but it also has its own charming Christmas market. Walking through the snow-dusted palace gardens at night was like stepping into a dream.
If you love music, you cannot leave Vienna without experiencing an opera or classical concert. I managed to get last-minute tickets to The Nutcracker, and it was pure magic. The combination of Tchaikovsky‚Äôs music and the grandeur of the opera house made it an unforgettable experience.
Vienna‚Äôs winter calls for rich, hearty dishes that warm you up from the inside. Here are a few must-try foods:
This classic Austrian dish ‚Äî a breaded and fried veal cutlet ‚Äî is crispy, golden, and absolutely delicious. I had mine with potato salad at Figlm√ºller, a restaurant famous for its schnitzel.
No trip to Vienna is complete without trying the world-famous Sacher Torte, a rich chocolate cake with a layer of apricot jam. The best place to try it? Caf√© Sacher, of course!
A warm slice of Apfelstrudel (apple strudel) with a side of vanilla sauce was the perfect dessert to enjoy at a cozy caf√© while watching the snow fall outside.
One of the most magical moments of my trip was ice skating at the Rathausplatz Ice Rink, right in front of the beautifully illuminated City Hall. The atmosphere was electric, with Christmas music playing in the background and families gliding across the ice. I hadn‚Äôt been on skates in years, but somehow, in that moment, I felt like a kid again, completely lost in the joy of the season.
Vienna in December is more than just a destination ‚Äî it‚Äôs an experience that stays with you. There‚Äôs something about the combination of history, music, food, and festive spirit that makes it feel truly special. Walking through the snow-covered streets, wrapped in my warmest coat, with the sounds of classical music drifting through the air, I felt an overwhelming sense of joy and peace.
If you‚Äôre looking for a holiday getaway that feels straight out of a storybook, Vienna is the place to go. Trust me, once you experience Christmas here, you‚Äôll want to come back every year.

Title: Vienna in 1900: Glorious and Doomed.
Content:

All great cities lay claim to at least one golden moment. While we might quibble over what‚Äôs required to earn that label, one thing seems clear: Fabled destiny often coexists with searing contradictions.
Vienna in 1900 was a perfect example.
At the beginning of the 20th century, Vienna was the imperial city of the ruling Hapsburgs and Europe‚Äôs cosmopolitan center of music and pleasure. It was home to Sigmund Freud and the two Gustavs of music and art (Mahler and Klimt ), a pantheon of poets, composers, literati, and theater notables; a yeasty mix of immigrants from throughout the sprawling Austro-Hungarian empire; the sixth largest Jewish population in the world; and plentiful parks, palaces, coffee houses, and heart-stopping pastries.
Yet as Stefan Zweig (1881‚Äì1942) ‚Äî Vienna‚Äôs native son, member of the city‚Äôs Jewish bourgeoisie, and famed author ‚Äî understood well, Vienna‚Äôs underbelly was in ferment. Suicide was rampant. So, too, were syphilis, cholera, tuberculosis, and typhoid. Infant mortality was high and life expectancy low at a mere 38 years. Anti-Semitism was also on the rise as was the disaffection of youth, shackled by rules and norms governing every aspect of life.
With the help of Zweig‚Äôs 1942, 450-page autobiography, aptly titled The World of Yesterday, here are some keen observations of this‚Ä¶

Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

9

Grateful for those who speak English while we study German
St Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral on a gray February day- Author photo
I‚Äôm not so sanguine about writing here on Medium-using just my iPad, not really sure where to publish. I comment a lot. For those who follow my comments, you might notice a wide range of subjects.
My wife and I rented an apartment in the 18th district of Vienna starting November of 2024. This came about from a desire to leave the US and certain business opportunities in Austria. We have been catching up to the process of moving while in the middle of several projects, including listing our home for sale on the East coast of FL. This required more time than we expected, and delayed our move until two weeks ago.
As soon as we arrived in Vienna, we left for Cyprus to attend a course and visit some friends. So we have actually been in the apartment for about six days. We ordered a nice mattress from SchlafTEQ right before we left for Cyprus, and they got it to us when we returned. So that‚Äôs our furniture until our container arrives in four more weeks.
We managed to buy a washer/dryer Monday, which arrived yesterday, just in time to start washing our clothes. Of course it is small compared to the monster LG units we had in Florida. It also takes two or three hours to process a load. But the clothes come out beautifully clean.
We were in the first district of Vienna yesterday, running errands, looking at furniture to complement what is coming by container. We stopped into the luxury grocery store, Julius Meinl, to buy a few items, and the cashier sarcastically commented to the patrons behind us: ‚Äútourists,‚Äù as we fumbled for unfamiliar coins. Not sure what she expects from the first district, which sees millions of tourists a year.
And we are newbie ex-pats, or maybe even immigrants, working our way through the challenges of culture, language and a new location. So it‚Äôs on us to adapt, to be respectful. To learn the language, and to accommodate the changes with grace. We are so grateful that we speak English, and that so many Viennese, especially the younger ones, speak it so well.
We ae both very excited to be here, and a bit overwhelmed by no furniture, new language, cold weather and an unfamiliar neighborhood. Almost everyone we meet, when we explain to that we came from Florida asks ‚ÄúBut why would you move here?‚Äù Not knowing how the US has become a place of strife, bad food, unkind culture, a insanely expensive medical system and a waste of resources.
Not that I do not have great respect for the good things in the US, and there are many; it is that life, for us, even with all the challenges here, offers all of the elements in Vienna that please us-food, culture, an enticing city, public transport, and ultimately a real community. We are also very happy that Vienna is such a great hub to explore all of the EU and beyond.

Title: An Insider‚Äôs Guide to Vienna, Austria
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Visiting Vienna is like taking a step back through time. The imposing architecture, glamorous cafe‚Äôs, expansive beer halls, and slow, relaxed pace of life make visitors feel as if they are living in a black and white film. While there is certainly a modern element that vibrates through the metro area ‚Äî particularly during commuting hours ‚Äî , Vienna generally runs on a pulse that syncs to the slow, steady chime of the church bells that ring throughout the city every hour on the hour. This ambient environment combined with delicious cuisine and a rich culture attract millions of visitors to Vienna every year.
There is so much to see and do, one could easily spend an entire day roaming around each of the uniquely beautiful districts, discovering all the hidden gems that Vienna has to offer. If, however, you are limited to spending only a few days in the city, here are a few tips from a local on how to hit the highlights while still having an authentic, Viennese experience.
Walk the Ringstrasse
Many of the most popular sites lie along the two and a half-mile epicenter of the city ‚Äî the Ringstrasse. While many visitors take the seven-euro tourist tram ride to view all the architecture in rapid succession, the best way to fully appreciate these magnificent buildings is to pass them slowly and on foot. I suggest starting at the Schottentor metro station and strolling down toward the Rathaus and around. Here is a post that highlights many of the more significant landmarks you will pass along the way. Once you make it all the way around and are back near Schottentor, pop into the Melker Stiftskeller restaurant/wine cellar for dinner or a late lunch. The cuisine is true authentic Austrian ‚Äî that is, packed with salt, heavy cream, and every other sinful ingredient that is a treat for the taste buds. A large Schnitzel and a few pilsner beers are just the things to revive you after your walk.
Buy Lunch at Naschmarkt and Picnic at Schloss Schonbrunn
On a Saturday morning, Naschmarkt ‚Äî an open-air farmer‚Äôs market ‚Äî will be packed with people buying fruits, vegetables, and exotic treats like olives, hummus, and freshly fried falafel. While you likely won‚Äôt want or need to stock up on groceries during your stay¬≠, you should absolutely sample some of the goodies on sale at Naschmarkt. I suggest purchasing a smorgasbord of picnic supplies and hopping on the metro to Schloss Schonbrunn. You can enter the surrounding park for free, find a bench or a grassy spot, and enjoy lunch among the beautifully groomed gardens. Afterward, you may consider touring the inside of the castle.
Have Coffee at a Viennese Caf√©
Caf√© culture is an integral part of Viennese history. During its golden era after World War I and before World War II, many Viennese aristocrats made their fortunes by importing sugar for the pastries that lined the caf√© display cases. As a result, many coffee houses around the city are now protected UNESCO world heritage sites. A visit to the city would not be complete without a M√©lange and an Apfelstrudel or Sachertorte in one of these famed cafes. Places like Caf√© Central, while very beautiful, are typically packed with tourists. It may be worth battling the crowds to check out the interior decor, but it won‚Äôt be quite the authentic experience you might be looking for. To fully enjoy the ‚Äúpublic living rooms of Vienna‚Äù in a more relaxed setting, head somewhere that is slightly less popular but every bit as beautiful. I suggest checking out Cafe Sperl or Caf√© Schwarzenberg.
Visit Klimt at the Belvedere
There are many art museums in Vienna, and if you are an art buff, you‚Äôll probably want to visit more than just one. But if you only have a few days, the must-visit museum is absolutely the Belvedere. The building and surrounding gardens are a work of art in themselves and the museum houses paintings by Vienna‚Äôs most beloved artist, Gustav Klimt. His most famous work, The Kiss, is to Austria what the Guernica is to Spain or The Statue of David is to Florence. After your visit to the museum, hop on the D line street train (Strassenbahn) heading west and find your way to 7 Stern Br√§u for a kr√ºgerl (pint-ish) of traditionally brewed beer.
Hike in the Viennese Vineyards
Vienna may be well known for its beer production, but it also produces enough wine to imbibe the entire city. Just outside the city, visitors can sample Viennese wine and hike around centuries-old vineyards that are still producing today. There are over 190 Vinters scattered in the foothills outside the city and dozens of restaurants where you can enjoy seasonal cuisine featuring fresh greens, mushrooms, or berries that are harvested from the nearby forest. Check out this post with a few recommended locations and spend the day drinking your way from winery to winery.
Vienna has so much more to offer, and as a newly minted local, I am constantly discovering places worthy of this list. However, if you only have a few days in the city, these recommended activities will ensure you experience some of the touristic highlights while having an authentic Viennese experience.

At least its not Bratislava
We went to Vienna mid-August of 2019. I‚Äôve been there previously two years ago but now we opted to go together. As you‚Äôll no doubt discover we‚Äôre both passive-ish tourists. Not that we won‚Äôt be out for the entire day when we‚Äôre abroad but often our days would start past 12pm and we‚Äôll find ourselves taking an Uber rather than running since 6am with five backpacks. Maybe that‚Äôs to come in a few years but for now its comfortable beds all the way.
It‚Äôs not everyone‚Äôs cup of tea but if you‚Äôre into arts, Baroque European architecture and a strudel or two then its the place to be. Unlike places like Rome or Paris, Vienna doesn‚Äôt suffer from swarms of tourism. Don‚Äôt get me wrong it‚Äôs not dead on the streets but if you‚Äôre used to lining up for 6 hours to get into The Colosseum you will be pleasantly surprised having to wait 10 or so minutes to get into most major attractions.
So what about museums? There are plenty of those. I had a leaflet that listed 50 or so but I looked it up and there are a 100 plus. You can pick what you‚Äôd like from Royal apartments, natural history or horses there is plenty for everyone apart from people who don‚Äôt like museums. If that‚Äôs you then go to the Film Museum as its closed for the summer.
Since Vienna is in Austria and Austria is German you can‚Äôt avoid the art college crowd. Thankfully they keep to themselves here and only provide Vienna with modern art and overpriced food. If you would like to spend 25 euros on a porridge and a smoothie Ilona would recommend Superfood Deli.
The entire city centre is littered with good shops from the fanciest H&M building to your average Saint Laurent. There is also a very large shopping street slightly outside the centre for more regular things like Esprit and mymuesli.
However if you want IQOS cigarettes like Ilona then you will have to take a train to Bratislava (which we did).
Vienna has one of the most reliable Metro systems we‚Äôve been to. For 17 euros you can get an unlimited travel pass for a week (7 days). This includes the metro, trams, buses, all that stuff. Everything is very well connected. Vienna also has Uber and Uber with Lime integration. That‚Äôs their electric scooters. There are also other brands that do the scooter service but we use Uber so here we are.
Vienna has the first Hard Rock cafe we tried in Europe that wasn‚Äôt greasy. And to be honest with the most polite staff too. Plachuttas Gasthaus zur Oper is another great place, we went for Schnitzel. For amazing Apple Strudel a good place to go would be Residence Cafe and Restaurant which is right next to Sch√∂nbrunn Palace. Sacher cake is also a must try! Ok it‚Äôs just chocolate cake but its a really really good chocolate cake.
What if you realise 25 euro porridge is not your cup of tea? What do you do then? You run to your nearest Billa supermarket and grab a poppy seed Strudel to fill you up with goodness.
You can also find your usual Spar and a re-branded Aldi but you won‚Äôt have to make that hard choice as all places are always well stocked with good food that‚Äôs well priced. Also they have some great sausages.
Honorable mention: I got a muesli with milk and a yogurt, both were under 80 cents.
This time we got an AirBNB. It was perfect. Was hosted by a lovely chap called Christian, who was more enthusiastic than most hotel staff I encountered. The apartment was 3min from one of the main shopping streets and metro and we slept with the windows open because it was so quiet.
We give Vienna a solid 9/10
Ok bye thank you.

Vienna got voted as the unfriendliest city but this one trick might help you.
Culture is beautiful. Every country has its own unique way of doing things. When I lived in the USA for six years, I got to know a new culture. A culture that is loving, caring, friendly, and patriotic. Extremely patriotic. But more on that another time.
Let me tell you about the one big difference between Americans and Austrians.
When I came to the US, the first thing I noticed was that people were friendlier. If you walk down the street, people might ask how you‚Äôre doing. For the Viennese, this is confusing. No one asks you how you‚Äôre doing in Vienna.
I remember that I didn‚Äôt know how to react to this friendliness. What was I supposed to say if I was doing badly? I had to try it. Interesting things happened when I said that.
I remember this one time when someone approached me and asked:
‚ÄúHow‚Äôre you doing?‚Äù Stranger
‚ÄúI‚Äôm ok. How are you?‚Äù I replied.
The stranger was gone.
Uhm, I asked, ‚ÄúHow are you doing!‚Äù Why would you keep walking? Plus, I said I‚Äôm ok. There is more I have to say. Come back, you human; we have to talk.

Title: Budapest, Bratislava, and Vienna ‚Äî A Europe Trip
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Nearly ten years ago, my husband and I lived in Budapest for a few months right after we were married. Every weekend, we‚Äôd pack our bags and visit a new European town or country. That was when the travel bug bit us. Fast forward to today, we were thrilled to have a wonderful opportunity to visit Budapest again. How could we possibly say no? This time, we wanted to take our son to the places where we made wonderful memories ten years ago. And of course, when you‚Äôre in Europe, visiting one city isn‚Äôt always enough. That‚Äôs how Bratislava and Vienna ended up on our itinerary as well.
Flights
First things first. To apply for a visa, you need confirmed round-trip tickets and hotel reservations for the travel dates. I know I‚Äôve mentioned this before in my Kazakhstan blog, but it‚Äôs always worth repeating ‚Äî look for cheaper flights from cities other than the one you reside in. We could have booked flights directly from Kozhikode to Budapest. But the layovers were long, which made the total travel time even longer, and the ticket prices were outrageous! The cheapest flight to Budapest from India was from Bangalore. The flight duration was shorter, and the layovers were minimal. So, we booked our flights from Bangalore. We flew to Bangalore from Kozhikode the day before and stayed overnight at a hotel near the airport. This turned out to be cheaper than booking a direct flight from Kozhikode (including both the flights to Bangalore and the hotel stay). And since we have a kid, it was much more convenient for him. Happy child = Happy Parents. It was a win-win. We booked the KLM flight from Bangalore to Budapest with a 1.5-hour layover in Amsterdam. We flew back to Bangalore from Budapest via Paris on Air France. Both flights were quite comfortable, and we had no complaints.
Stay
From our experience, Airbnb is the best stay option. It is cheaper than hotels and extremely spacious, and most rentals have a washer/dryer. That means you can carry fewer clothes and sleep in spacious rooms. Our son is a huge fan of Airbnb because of how spacious they are. Hotels simply cannot beat this offer. Of course, make sure you book an Airbnb rental with good ratings located near the city centre or one that is easily accessible via public transport.
Once our flights and accommodations were booked, the next step ‚Äî the most dreaded of them all ‚Äî was applying for a Schengen visa.
Schengen Visa
Let me be upfront ‚Äî of all the visas I‚Äôve applied for, the Schengen visa is the most complicated. I‚Äôm not joking when I say that one of the factors influencing the choice of our travel destinations is the complexity of the visa application process. All the countries we‚Äôve visited in the past few years (post-COVID) have either had straightforward visa applications or were visa-free. But when the opportunity to travel back to Budapest came up around our ten-year wedding anniversary, we couldn‚Äôt say no, especially since we started our married life there.
I‚Äôm not going to go into detail about the visa application process, but I will mention a few things that helped us during our process.
To apply for a Schengen visa, you must submit your documents to the VFS application centre closest to your city of residence. We live in Kozhikode, and the nearest VFS centre that processes Schengen visas is in Kochi. However, we couldn‚Äôt find any suitable appointment dates in Kochi, so we decided to go with the next closest VFS centre ‚Äî Bangalore. Coincidentally, we were planning a trip to Mysore during the Navratri holidays, so we extended our holiday to fit the visa appointment in Bangalore.
Before COVID-19, applying for a Schengen visa was simpler because we didn‚Äôt need an agent to help us block appointment dates. We could just log into our account on the VFS portal and pick the city, date, and time that suited us. This time, however, we couldn‚Äôt get any appointment dates when we tried to do it ourselves. It was disappointing because we took pride in managing our travel plans independently. In the end, we had to approach an agent to book an appointment, and to our surprise and eventual relief, the agent was able to get us dates that appeared unavailable on the portal. We finally got our dates, and they lined up perfectly with our Mysore holiday.
When you go for your visa appointment, it‚Äôs a good idea to bring extra documents beyond those listed on the VFS website. We carried copies of our marriage certificate, our son‚Äôs birth certificate, copies of our investments, all our old passports, and copies of all Schengen visas older than three years ‚Äî documents that were not specifically required, but which the VFS centre appreciated us having. The VFS centre also has a photo booth (in case your photos don‚Äôt meet their standards), photocopy machines, and printers, just in case you forget to bring a document. So, it‚Äôs helpful to keep digital copies of all your documents so you can easily access and print them if needed.
We received our passports stamped with the visas within a few days of application.
Now, it was time to travel!
Our First Destination ‚Äî Budapest
Although Amsterdam was our first port of entry into Europe, it was a short layover. After waiting through a long immigration line, we rushed to catch our connecting flight to Budapest.We reached Budapest at around 12 PM. Since we finished our immigration at our first port of entry ‚Äî Amsterdam ‚Äî we collected our luggage and passed through customs. We were to stay in Budapest for five days, visit Bratislava and Vienna, and then return to Budapest for a day before flying back to India. So, we purchased a two-week travel pass at the airport. This pass provides unlimited use of public transport (metro, bus, and tram) for 14 days in Budapest. There are also single tickets, one-day passes, three-day passes, and monthly travel passes, but sadly, no weekly passes. The two-week pass worked out to be the cheapest option for our 6-day overall stay. If you plan to stay in Budapest for more than three days, get the two-week pass. Don‚Äôt buy a three-day pass and then single-day passes for the extra days, as the price difference between the three-day and two-week passes is minimal. If you buy single tickets each time you use public transport, you‚Äôll lose both time and money. One thing you should know about most European cities is that you will rarely need to use a taxi/cab. The public transport system is so well-connected that you‚Äôll be constantly hopping on and off metros, buses, or trams throughout your stay. So, a travel pass makes more sense than individual tickets. Also, think of the time you‚Äôll save. Imagine having to purchase a ticket every time you use public transportation. It simply does not make sense.
With the travel pass, we took the 200E bus to K≈ëb√°nya-Kispest M and then transferred to the M3 Metro line to get closer to our accommodation. We stayed in an Airbnb just a three-minute walk from Kalvin Square (K√°lvin T√©r) Metro station (this falls on the M3 metro line).
There is also a 100E bus that goes directly from the airport to the city centre, but this is the only transport service that is NOT included in the travel pass. Since we had the pass, we skipped it and took the 200E bus instead. The 200E bus stops just outside the airport exit. You don‚Äôt need to validate your two-week pass on the bus, but make sure to keep it with you at all times. There are regular checks, and you‚Äôll need to show your pass if asked. Once we reached K≈ëb√°nya-Kispest M, we transferred to the M3 metro line and travelled to K√°lvin T√©r. At metro stations, there are no automated ticket validators. Instead, you‚Äôll need to show your pass to the staff member near the escalators, who will quickly scan it before letting you through.
We reached our metro station, walked to our Airbnb, and self-checked in. After that, we took the day off to relax.
Getting a Local Sim
We made sure our international roaming was activated before we left India. We needed data for the first hours around the city since we did not want to buy a SIM card at the airport (expensive). We visited a local Vodafone store in the city the very next day and bought a local SIM. It was around INR 2500, which got us 6 GB of data for 30 days around Europe.
Sightseeing in Budapest
We travelled in November, which meant it was cold and there were fewer tourists ‚Äî which worked to our advantage. However, the drawback was that we had to layer up every time we stepped out, which was frustrating the first few days, but later, we got used to it. We had three layers. Our regular clothes, a sweatshirt/sweater on top and a final jacket. We also had gloves, a scarf, and a beanie. We used regular walking shoes, which were quite enough since there was no snow or rain.
Places we visited in Budapest ‚Äì
As with most of my travel blogs, I‚Äôm not going to dive into the details of our itinerary or write in detail about the places we visited. Instead, I‚Äôm going to simply list the places we explored each day. We traveled with our 4-year-old son, so if you‚Äôre wondering how many places you can cover with a kid in a day, this should give you a good idea.
Day 1 ‚Äì
1. Hungarian Parliament Building Viewpoint
2. Mathias Church
3. Fishermen‚Äôs Bastion
4. Buda Castle and Old Town
5. Szechenyi Chain Bridge
Day 2 ‚Äì
1. Gellert Hill (Closed due to renovation)
2. Vaci Utca ‚Äî for shopping
3. Corvinus University
Day 3 ‚Äì
1. Shoes on the Danube Bank
2. Central Market
3. Vajdahunyad Castle
4. Heroes Square
Day 4 ‚Äì
1. Ferris Wheel of Budapest
2. Vaci Utca for the second time
3. Christmas Markets around the city
Day 5 ‚Äì
Budapest to Bratislava
Our Second Destination ‚Äî Bratislava
Our next stop was the city of Bratislava in Slovakia. We didn‚Äôt book any local travel in advance, so we visited the Keleti-P√°lyaudvar railway station in Budapest, a few stops away from where we stayed, and bought our train tickets to Bratislava just the day before leaving for Bratislava. This worked out cheaper for us. We also reserved seats by paying a little extra. This may not be necessary during the off-season because the trains are quite empty, and you can choose any seat, but during peak season, I suggest reserving seats. Kids under 6 travel for free! It took us 2.5 hours to reach Bratislava by train from Budapest.
We were staying in Bratislava for three days, so we bought the three-day travel pass at the railway station. The pass gives you unlimited bus and tram rides within the city. There is no metro in Bratislava, but trams and buses connect the station to the city centre. Make sure to validate your pass during your first ride. Once validated, it‚Äôs enough to do it just once, as the three days are counted from your first trip.
We stayed in an Airbnb very close to St. Michael‚Äôs Gate. The city is much smaller than Budapest, and most sightseeing within the city can be done on foot. However, visiting Devin Castle takes about 40 minutes by bus. You can use your travel pass for the bus ride there.
Places we visited ‚Äì
1. Devin Castle (must visit for breathtaking views of the Danube) ‚Äî Highly Recommended
2. Bratislava City Centre ‚Äî St Stephen‚Äôs Gate, UFO tower, Bratislava castle
Our Third Destination ‚Äî Vienna
We travelled from Bratislava to Vienna by bus. Again, we booked the bus tickets just the day before we left for Vienna. We did this online and took the Slovak Lines bus to Vienna Bus station. Remember, there are two stops in Vienna. The bus first stops at the airport and then at the central station. Make sure you book your tickets to the central station, not the airport. We were in Vienna for only a day and took the day pass at a metro station near the bus station where we were dropped off. The return buses back to Bratislava also leave from the same station.
Places we visited in Vienna ‚Äì
1. Stephensplatz and St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral
Our Vienna tradition is to have Gelato in Stephensplatz and so, that‚Äôs what we did. We went to a place ‚Äî Zanoni and Zanoni ‚Äî that had Vegan gelato and also vegan Pizza. They also had egg-free chocolate croissants. We finished a quick lunch here and spent the rest of the day looking around Vienna.
2. Hofburg Palace
3. Maria Theresa Square
4. Christmas Markets
5. Belvedere Palace
We left Bratislava on the 19th and reached Budapest. On the last day in Budapest, we simply walked around Kalvin Square, did some shopping, and called it a day. On the morning of the 20th, we boarded the flight back to Bangalore.
Travel within Europe
Within the cities, we never used a Taxi. The airports are very well connected to the city centre by public transport (Metro, Bus and Tram). If you can walk, you won‚Äôt need a cab/taxi during any part of your journey. The cities are well connected by public transport.
For kids under 6, public transport was FREE in all three cities!
About Europe in General
Please be aware of your surroundings and do not fall for tourist scams. So far, the central and eastern European countries we‚Äôve visited (Austria, Hungary, Slovenia, Slovakia, Croatia) are not particularly known for scams. However, scams are more common in places like Italy, France, and Belgium ‚Äî especially in capital cities and other popular tourist spots. There are several blogs online that discuss the various scams you may encounter, so please read up and stay informed before you travel. Scammers often try to distract you with something (such as asking you to sign a petition or attempting to give you a ‚Äúfree‚Äù gift), and while you‚Äôre distracted, another member of their group may pickpocket you or steal your bags.
Once in Paris, near Montmartre, we were approached by a girl who asked us to sign a petition for something. This is one of their most common scams. Our advice: just walk away and keep a tight grip on your bags. Also, don‚Äôt keep your phone or wallet in your pant pockets. Aravind was almost pickpocketed once but caught the girl in the act, and she quickly ran away. Luckily, he didn‚Äôt lose his wallet. The first incident happened in Paris, and the second in Rome. A third incident happened in Athens, where a lady approached me and offered me a free rose. Thankfully, I said no and left. It was only later that I realized this is another popular scam where people offer you free gifts, and once you accept them, they‚Äôll ask for something in return. We encountered no such scams in the three cities we visited this time.
As for food, many vegan eateries can be found in the popular cities if you want to try local cuisine. In Budapest, I suggest you try Napfenyes Etterem ‚Äî a vegan restaurant that serves local Hungarian cuisine. Make sure you try the Goulash soup! There are also plenty of Indian restaurants if you‚Äôre craving Indian food. We always look for Govinda‚Äôs ‚Äî ISKCON‚Äôs restaurant. They have branches in several cities and if a city we‚Äôre travelling to has one, that‚Äôs where we frequent because our son prefers Indian food to local cuisine.
Overall, Europe is always a fantastic travel destination (if you manage to overcome the initial visa hurdle) because once you enter Europe, you have free reign to go anywhere, and everything is so well connected. Also, almost every shop closes by 6 pm. So make sure to do your shopping before then!
Happy travels!
--
--

An occasional travel blogger, a full time children's author.

Content:
