Title: Keeping Control Human: Youth insights from the Vienna Conference on Autonomous Weapons
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
by Jefferson Batesimah
The Vienna Conference on Autonomous Weapons, dubbed ‚ÄúHumanity at the Crossroads,‚Äù addressed the urgent need to regulate deadly autonomous weapons systems. As a youth delegate, I gained valuable insights into this critical issue. Here‚Äôs a snapshot of what I learned:
Understanding the Big Picture
The conference shed light on the serious challenges posed by autonomous weapons. They could make conflicts worse, harm civilians, and disrupt efforts to keep peace worldwide.
Why Human Control Matters
A key lesson was the importance of humans staying in charge of decisions about using force. Letting machines make life-or-death choices raises big moral and legal questions. We need clear rules to make sure people are responsible and to stop these weapons from causing harm.
Talking Ethics
We spent time discussing what‚Äôs right and wrong when it comes to autonomous weapons. We talked about how to respect people‚Äôs dignity and protect them from these weapons‚Äô dangers. We also thought about how using these weapons might change society in the long run and change our relationship with technology.
Challenges We Face
Even though many people agree on the need for rules, there are still big challenges ahead. Some powerful governments and tech companies control a lot of the conversation. It‚Äôs tough for other voices, like from everyday people and community groups, to be heard.
Youth Power
Young people like us played a big part in the conference. Our fresh ideas and energy showed how important it is to get everyone involved in the discussion to address autonomous weapons. We left feeling inspired and ready to push for change in our communities.
What Comes Next
The conference wasn‚Äôt just talk, it was a call to action. We agreed to work even harder to establish strong global rules for autonomous weapons. But it won‚Äôt happen overnight. We need to keep up the pressure and work together to make real change.
In sum, the Vienna Conference on Autonomous Weapons was a chance to learn, share ideas, and get ready for action. We learned how crucial it is to keep humans in control of decisions about life and death in warfare. As we move forward, let‚Äôs stay focused on making the world safer and fairer for everyone.

Title: Vienna waits for you.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The first time I heard Vienna by Billy Joel, I was on a train home after college, the world outside dipped in the amber light of a tired evening. I had just bombed an interview I had poured my soul into. My head was a whirlwind of spiralling doubts‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääabout my future, about whether I had what it takes, about everything. And then Vienna arrived‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot like a pop anthem or an uplifting chorus, but like a friend who sits with you in silence and tells you exactly what you need to hear.
‚ÄúSlow down, you crazy child
You‚Äôre so ambitious for a juvenile
But then if you‚Äôre so smart, tell me
Why are you still so afraid?‚Äù
In that moment, tears welled up ‚Äî not because of the failure, but because of how deeply the song understood the ache behind it. How it met me in the in-between, where so many of us live: driven but unsure, hopeful but exhausted.
That lyric wasn‚Äôt just about me. It was about a generation raised to hustle, to quantify their worth through grades, internships, side projects, and glowing LinkedIn posts. I had come to think of life as a ladder. But Vienna whispered of a different metaphor ‚Äî a garden, perhaps. Something that grows in time, with pauses, with pruning, with seasons of bloom and rest.
It reminded me of The Midnight Library by Matt Haig ‚Äî a book about a woman who, burdened by regret, stumbles upon a mystical library containing infinite versions of her life. Each book in the library reveals a different path she could have taken. The novel forces you to ask: what if the life you‚Äôre racing toward isn‚Äôt the one that would‚Äôve made you happy? What if the pauses, the missed exits, the so-called failures, are the very fabric of the life meant for you?
‚ÄúWhen will you realize, Vienna waits for you?‚Äù
In Joel‚Äôs metaphor, Vienna isn‚Äôt a destination you rush to. It‚Äôs the life that waits ‚Äî patiently, quietly ‚Äî for you to stop sprinting long enough to hear its music. It‚Äôs the version of you that grows not by doing more, but by understanding what enough feels like. That revelation mirrored the essence of The Midnight Library: the idea that you‚Äôre not a failure just because you‚Äôre not on someone else‚Äôs timeline.
The truth is, I didn‚Äôt need a new plan that day on the train. I needed perspective. I needed someone ‚Äî or something ‚Äî to tell me that I hadn‚Äôt missed my moment, that there are many doors yet to open. And Vienna, in its tender, piano-laced wisdom, did exactly that.
‚ÄúYou can get what you want or you can just get old
You‚Äôre gonna kick off before you even get halfway through‚Äù
Those words haunted me. Because I had never thought of burnout as a kind of death. But that‚Äôs what it is: the death of wonder, of joy, of being here. I was chasing a life so hard that I was forgetting to live the one already unfolding around me.
Billy Joel‚Äôs Vienna didn‚Äôt just soften my ambition ‚Äî it redefined it. It told me that ambition rooted in fear is a form of imprisonment. But ambition rooted in patience? In stillness? That‚Äôs purpose. That‚Äôs wisdom.
So now, when I feel that panic ‚Äî that rising tide of ‚Äúnot enough,‚Äù of ‚Äútoo late,‚Äù of ‚Äúwhat am I doing with my life?‚Äù ‚Äî I don‚Äôt drown. I return to the song. To Joel‚Äôs voice, gently guiding me back.
‚ÄúSlow down, you‚Äôre doing fine.‚Äù
And just like the woman in The Midnight Library learns: the life you‚Äôre meant to live isn‚Äôt the one with the loudest applause. It‚Äôs the one where you‚Äôre fully alive. The one that waits for you ‚Äî just like Vienna.
--
--
Polymath-in-progress from Chennai. Finance major, Dostoevsky reader, indie music junkie. Writes on Medium, lives somewhere between "Suits" & soul-searching.

Things that I‚Äôm a sucker for while traveling: a unique building, a nice park, and a spooky cemetery. I will go out of my way to see these. Even if it means traveling across an entire city.
So years ago, when I was traveling in Vienna with my parents, that‚Äôs exactly what I did. I had heard about this cool building, called Hundertwasserhaus.
Although I was in my 30s, living on my own in a foreign country, and had traveled around the world, my mom didn‚Äôt want me to go alone. So she tagged along.
It‚Äôs curved, it‚Äôs straight, it‚Äôs a building, and it‚Äôs a garden.
Hundertwasserhaus is hard to describe, but it overloads your mind when you see it. There is so much to look at.
It is a colorful, eclectic apartment building. It was built in the 1980s with multiple styles and built on different planes. The windows are different sizes. The facade changes from stucco to trompe l‚Äôoeil to brick to mosaic. The street level boasts unusual, non-uniform colorful columns.
Trees pop out of the building in unexpected places. The artist called these trees on the building ‚Äútree tenants.‚Äù

Content:

‚Üí Martin Hanley: A Memoir
This memoir was written in 2004/2005
I was born on March 14th, 1931 to Margarethe and Leopold Hahn of Neueweltgasse 23 in Hietzing, Vienna. Hitzing, then as now, was a pleasant leafy, upmarket suburb, our home perhaps just ten blocks distant from Schonbrun Palace, one of the sumptuous palaces built by the Habsburg dynasty.
One of my earliest recollections goes back to the age of 5. Opposite our first floor apartment was a little triangle of grass, with a few flowers and 2 garden benches, which was tucked in between our building and the main road, the Hitzinger Hauptstrasse. The apartment had deep window ledges on which I could stand and lean against the wrought iron railings which were erected for security reasons. Later I watched Hitler‚Äôs tanks roll into Vienna from this balcony. As we lived on the 1st floor there were only a few steps to the ground floor and I was allowed to ride on the garden path alone on a tricycle parked in a ‚Äòcave‚Äô under the building. After the war I visited our old home with Susi my wife, and found the ‚Äòcave‚Äô to be a little opening in the building near the staircase outside.
Apart from the ‚ÄúSchonbrun‚Äù palace of the Emperors, Hitzing boasted a zoo and many coffee houses of note. The coffee house was an important factor in my parents‚Äô generations enjoyment of life. Its ambience, seating arrangements, free offering of daily newspapers to its clientele, not to mention the quality of its coffee and ‚Äòmehlspeisen‚Äô or cakes was serious business, similar in importance to the Anglo Saxon pub or the American local bar.
Listening to stories of the older generation I realized that although acquisition of luxuries and assets were not on the agenda, my parents and their circles lived a very agreeable life. I have pictures of family holidays taken in villages, on lovely lakes, of my parents at parties and so on. It can be explained by understanding the culture of European middle class life. In Austria, especially Vienna, the culture of theatre, music, stays in the country in summer and skiing from peasant huts in the mountains in winter was maintained to a greater or smaller degree.
Living on the outskirts of Vienna there were advantages for me, as in winter I could be taken on my sled to the ‚ÄòRotenberg‚Äô or Red Hill to slide up and down in the snow on fine afternoons. My Nanny would pull the sled up this little hill in company with other nursemaids similarly out with their charges. Nanny was a fixture, and one of whom I have fond memories. I have a picture of her with me in my leather pants aged perhaps two or three. She also cooked and made the beds. As she had off only one Sunday every fortnight some might say that she lived in slavery. Not so. She was part of the family and had a home which was warm in winter and where meals were regular. A small pittance was hers to spend as well. Far different from where she came from. This enabled people like my parents to live a very civilised life with very little money.
In the depression, working people in industry or on the land saw real hardship. I was given a spare lunch to school to distribute to children less fortunate than I.
My father was a hard worker all his life. In the 1920s and 30s he worked as a salesman in his father‚Äôs firm, Adolf Hahne & Sohne, a merchant of ‚Äúspitzen‚Äù ‚Äî feathers, boas, lace and embroideries, the traditional Austrian lace, still seen in minute quantities today, was used on almost every woman‚Äôs garment. In white or colourful on ‚Äòdirndl‚Äô, the traditional skirt, for blouses, on caps and underwear. The firm had prospered in the period when ‚ÄòDirndl‚Äô, the Austrian national costume, was the mode. Manufactured and distributed worldwide, laces were an important ingredient of fashion for what must have been at least 2 generations, as my grandfather had inherited the business. In my father‚Äôs time his 2 sons were in the business, both as salesmen. My Uncle Walter‚Äôs sales territory was part of Germany and France. He enjoyed himself very much one believes as he was single, tall and handsome. He had a good time by all accounts.
My father, on the other hand, was allotted the tougher territory, Hungary, Slovakia, Serbia and suchlike. Although also handsome, he was already married and the small traders he dealt with, mostly Jewish haberdashers in little country towns were prone to be cashless, especially after a family wedding, birth or bar mitzvah. He travelled for several weeks at a time, in a small ‚ÄòSteyer‚Äô motor car on terrible country roads.
In Vienna, in the thirties, survival in business was not always guaranteed. The Depression had driven my grandfather‚Äôs firm into bankruptcy three times. Bankruptcy in those days evolved into a sort of payment agreement, in German: ‚Äúausgleich‚Äù. Say you owed a hundred thousand with no prospect of paying it back. You settled with your creditors for whatever, agreed‚Ä¶.and then carried on. My father‚Äôs stories to me of his ‚Äúausgleich‚Äù experiences with his customers, though funny, hid the tensions of those times.
When Hitler walked into Vienna, Jewish premises were ‚ÄúArisiert‚Äù, meaning literally ‚ÄòArienised‚Äô (as in Aryan!) ie. Nazified‚Ä¶Nazi hoodlums, some in uniforms, entered, demanded all keys and normally gave the occupants a few hours to take their personal effects and get out. Confiscated just like that‚Ä¶ period, full stop‚Ä¶ premises, stock, bank accounts.
That didn‚Äôt happen to Adolf Hahn & Sohn, because the business had gone broke some years before. The company went into receivership in 1932. The Depression added another victim, but it not only the lack of business which was the cause. My grandfather, who must have been well in his sixties, married Claire, an elegant woman a good 30 years his junior. This necessitated a new house with fine furniture and the trimmings. The romance proved too big a burden on the business, as well as the two family members who worked in it.
The German Wehrmacht were welcomed by the Austrian populace after the ‚ÄúKristallnacht‚Äù Troops occupied Vienna from March 13th, 1938. On March 14th, my birthday, I stood on my window balcony and observed with childish fascination the armoured wagons, mobile cannons and personnel trucks standing on the road outside, the uniformed Wehrmacht soldiers laughing and joking with the locals while the Hietzing Synagogue around the corner was torched.
We lived in the same apartment until we escaped from Vienna, except for the very last few days when we stayed hidden in a city apartment owned by ‚ÄòTante Ida‚Äô, my grandfather‚Äôs sister and a very old lady. I was later told my father had already hidden there for a few days previously.
In the months from the Anschluss till we left the country in September 1938, I continued to attend the same school. My only vivid memory was of the same teacher, but he was wearing a red armband with a black swastika on a white circle and the Hebrew teacher‚Äôs red star of David on a yellow armband. We children did not wear any outward marking at that time.
It was time to leave Austria, where my family roots went back at least for the 3 generations I knew.

‚Üí Vienna
By 1938, America, England, Canada, Australia and most other countries had either tightened immigration intake or outright banned foreigners. Apparently a Mr. Rogers, an Australian businessman, was visiting Vienna in 1938 and somehow met our family. He offered to help and assisted my father applying for a visa to Australia, sponsoring us. The application was refused. Mr. Rogers subsequently wrote telling my father that stating to be a tradesman as a ‚Äúchauffeur‚Äù was the worst entry possible as his son, aged 17, ‚Äúcould drive a car better than you can!‚Äù That was the end of that.
The Depression had not lifted entirely in most of the Western world. In any case, the few who did receive visas to desired country destinations had to have sums of money my father did not possess. My grandfather‚Äôs business, in which my father and his brother Walter worked, barely supported the family. This was not entirely due to economic conditions ‚Äî it has been attributed largely to my grandfather‚Äôs second marriage to a beautiful woman some 30 years younger than himself. She apparently required a new house with the best trimmings.
Jews who didn‚Äôt make it to desired country destinations had the possibility of buying passports for entry to South American countries like Argentina and Uruguay. Switzerland was open only to the super rich, and then only as permanent ‚Äòtourists‚Äô. Refugees like my parents, who left matters too late with very little money, found safety in the few destinations that made no demands. There was Shanghai, Trinidad, Curacao, and small black African states. Israel, Palestine in those days, was quite sealed against Jewish immigration by British decree, although several hundred young people entered and were smuggled in right throughout the war.
You didn‚Äôt need an entry visa, you just had to get there.
My parents found a way to Shanghai, as did about 19,000 Jewish refugees from Hitler. A temporary ‚ÄúThru-visa‚Äù was available from Italy. This was issued on sight of a steamship ticket to Shanghai purchased from Italian line Lloyd Triestino, on one of the boats that steamed a regular route from Genoa to Shanghai, for an exorbitant sum. Only First Class tickets were available as a matter of course. I don‚Äôt know how but this sum was found for the Hahn family of 2 adults and a child. Train tickets were purchased to Genoa.
I remember a young girl, about my age, boarded the train with us. I never learned what was the family‚Äôs relationship to us, but my parents agreed to take her along. She was taken off the train at the border between Austria and Italy during the night, I presume because she was without papers. I have never been told what became of her and I have since often wondered whether she was returned to Vienna and her parents safely.
After a few days in Genoa we embarked on the mv. Victoria, the smallest but newest of the Lloyd Triestino fleet that sailed to the Orient regularly. We owned several ‚Äòcabin trunks‚Äô full of possessions and 114 British pounds. The voyage was a great delight for my parents, despite what must have been anxiety for the future. The mv. Victoria was the smallest ship in the line, but the latest and most modern.
First class service in all respects was still pre-war and luxurious. The voyage was very romantic, landing at exotic ports along the way. In Port Said, at the southern end of the Suez Canal, a great f√™te was held with native dancers and a feast was prepared on the dock. I believe it was an Egyptian version of an Aussie barbecue with whole beasts being cooked. Local citizens were present as well as the ship‚Äôs passengers. I was allowed down to the wharf for a little while and then taken to the cabin to sleep. I never learned why the celebration. I cannot remember the landing in Bombay or the three days passed in Singapore. Then came Hong Kong and lastly Shanghai.

Content:

Vienna is one of several European capitals that I‚Äôve personally visited many times, and it‚Äôs also one of the most visited cities in Europe and the entire world.
The picturesque Austrian capital is renowned to be one of the most liveable cities in the world, and for some very good reasons!
From a personal perspective, I already know 3 people from my little tiny country (Luxembourg) that studied in the city and subsequently decided to never leave the place and start a new life there. From all over the world people flock to Vienna, either for tourism or to move there permanently.
But what are the reasons that make Vienna such a globally recognized hotspot to live in? What makes Vienna so special in regard to other European capital cities?
Having visited the city on 4 separate occasions, I will today line out my 5 personal reasons why Vienna is considered the most liveable city in Europe, and why it is up there with the most liveable cities in the world.

Title: What to Do in Vienna If You Hate Itineraries
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I didn‚Äôt go to Vienna with a checklist. No Sch√∂nbrunn palace on the agenda. No museums lined up by hour. Just three slow-moving days, a waterproof camera backpack, and a promise to myself not to overthink it.
From the airport, I caught the 10.5‚Ç¨ bus to Westbahnhof and checked into a small guesthouse nearby. Quiet street. Solid sleep. Five-minute walk to most things that mattered.
I skipped the palaces and headed straight to a corner market for a mustard-soaked pretzel and a table with no view. I sat longer than I meant to. It was a good start.
I stumbled across the Musikverein just before noon. No grand performance, just a chamber rehearsal in the golden hall. I sat in the back. Stayed through most of it.
Across the square, the House of Music pulled me in by accident. I don‚Äôt usually do interactive museums, but this one surprised me. No pressure to move quickly. No crowds. Just quiet sound rooms layered like dreams.
Later, I caught the U-Bahn to Donauinsel, found a bench by the river, and watched the clouds shift. It started to rain lightly, but everything stayed dry ‚Äî my gear, my layers ‚Äî all tucked into that camera backpack I almost didn‚Äôt bring.
I walked aimlessly in the city centre, ducked into St. Peter‚Äôs Church, and followed the scent of coffee to K.u.K. Heiner. It felt more imperial than the cakes themselves ‚Äî but the atmosphere was enough.
Dinner was at Neubauschenke: pork stew, beef broth, locals in padded vests. I sat near the back and scribbled some notes. Later, Papaya served me one of the better duck salads I‚Äôve had in Europe. Spicy, fast, no English menu ‚Äî perfect.
I didn‚Äôt plan this trip, and it still worked.
Because Vienna is good to people who walk slowly, who sit a little longer, and who carry light.
If you‚Äôre thinking of going, don‚Äôt overpack. A lightweight waterproof camera backpack will do. The rest, the city gives you.

Vienna is so special to me‚Ä¶ It will always be the city with unforgettable many memories. I feel tons of emotions on that trip: fear, love, excitement, suspicion, admiration, understanding, enthusiasm‚Ä¶ Vienna is waiting for me, again.
Vienna is filled full of first experiences for me. First trip, first abroad, first flight‚Ä¶ I am grateful that it all started with Vienna.
I have two of my best friends while in Vienna, we explored together, we laughed, we danced (it was so funny), tasted‚Ä¶
We stayed in the most beautiful hotel and after many experiences, it still protects its place on my top list. I can recommend it with peace of mind. Our receptionist was cheerful, friendly and sincere. He talked about his travels to our home country, tried to talk in our main language, sent videos about our traditional foods on WhatsApp‚Ä¶ When I look at our hotel‚Äôs photos or think about it, I feel the beautiful smell of the hotel exactly. Magical.
We arrived in Vienna in the evening, and after settling in the hotel, we went to Mariahilfer Street. Since it was the first time, I was shocked by the early closing of the shopping places. The life stops early‚Ä¶ I am not used to it.
The second day in Vienna started with a meeting with our Erasmus student friend at Karlskirche, it was a long time since we had seen him. Also, we met with a student from Vienna Technical University who was very interested in cars and Austria.
Our city exploration started! There were a lot of architectural masterpieces‚Ä¶ Fascinating!
I had a detailed plan for the itinerary, nevertheless we started to be ahead on the plan. We went to Hundertwasser Houses and Prater on the second day instead of the third day.
I think we give the biggest appreciation to Prater‚Ä¶ Me and my friend really like the Before Sunrise movie, and the place was special for us. We recorded videos, spent many times at the photo booth cabin, watched‚Ä¶ It was fun.
My friend had kept talking about Wiener Rathaus since we arrived, her excitement spreaded to me. First, the architectural beauty captured us, then a closer look‚Ä¶ Ice rink, fancy ornaments‚Ä¶ All was magical. There was a song playing, suddenly we started to dance haha it was silly but funny! We stood right next to the ice rink and started watching around. I tried to keep that atmosphere in memory with every detail. Kids were skating, laughs were everywhere. Also, the screen on the building shows the area sometimes, we were seeing ourselves on the screen. Shaking hands‚Ä¶ Our cheeks were hurting from smiling!
Third day, again St. Stephan Cathedral. One of the favorite spots‚Ä¶
We went to gothic Votivkirche.
We had melange on a cafe has Votivkirche view. It was delicious and despite of being soft coffee served with water, interesting.
Bonus Memory!
I studied for my lesson and before coming to Vienna, I researched Sisi and watched the trio. There were many references in the streets. Understanding them was making me feel satisfied.
Overall
Vienna is a little bit over the student budget. I want to visit Vienna again with a rich budget and at that time I must spend my time in the museums, have schnitzel in a more elegant restaurant, go on the Christmas time and skate at Wiener Rathaus.
Regards, √ñzlem.

Title: (Austria) A Magical Christmas in Vienna: The Ultimate Winter Getaway
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
If you‚Äôve ever dreamed of stepping into a real-life Christmas wonderland, Vienna in December is the place to be. From twinkling lights draped across historic buildings to the scent of mulled wine and roasted chestnuts filling the air, the city feels like something straight out of a fairy tale. I had always heard that Vienna was one of the most magical places to visit during the holiday season, but nothing prepared me for just how breathtaking it would be.
Reaching Vienna is easier than you might think. If you‚Äôre flying in, Vienna International Airport (VIE) is well-connected with flights from all over the world. From the airport, you can take the City Airport Train (CAT) which gets you to the city center in just 16 minutes. If you‚Äôre coming from a nearby European city, trains are an excellent option too, offering scenic routes through Austria‚Äôs picturesque countryside. I took a train from Munich, and as the snow-covered landscapes passed by, I knew I was in for something special.
Vienna is famous for its Christmas markets, and let me tell you, they do not disappoint. Here are a few you absolutely cannot miss:
The most iconic of them all, this market in front of Vienna‚Äôs City Hall is like something out of a holiday movie. With over 150 stalls selling handcrafted gifts, ornaments, and delicious food, it‚Äôs impossible to leave empty-handed. I grabbed a cup of Gl√ºhwein (mulled wine) and wandered through the market, soaking in the festive atmosphere.
For a more elegant setting, the Sch√∂nbrunn Palace Christmas Market is perfect. The backdrop of the grand palace makes everything feel even more magical. This market is ideal for finding high-quality artisan gifts and tasting traditional Austrian holiday treats.
Tucked away in narrow, cobblestone streets, this market feels cozy and intimate. It‚Äôs less touristy, making it a great spot to experience Vienna like a local. Here, I tried Kaiserschmarrn, a shredded pancake with powdered sugar and plum sauce ‚Äî absolutely divine!
One of Vienna‚Äôs most famous landmarks, this Gothic cathedral looks even more stunning with Christmas lights twinkling around it. Climbing to the top rewards you with breathtaking panoramic views of the city.
Not only does this palace house Gustav Klimt‚Äôs famous painting The Kiss, but it also has its own charming Christmas market. Walking through the snow-dusted palace gardens at night was like stepping into a dream.
If you love music, you cannot leave Vienna without experiencing an opera or classical concert. I managed to get last-minute tickets to The Nutcracker, and it was pure magic. The combination of Tchaikovsky‚Äôs music and the grandeur of the opera house made it an unforgettable experience.
Vienna‚Äôs winter calls for rich, hearty dishes that warm you up from the inside. Here are a few must-try foods:
This classic Austrian dish ‚Äî a breaded and fried veal cutlet ‚Äî is crispy, golden, and absolutely delicious. I had mine with potato salad at Figlm√ºller, a restaurant famous for its schnitzel.
No trip to Vienna is complete without trying the world-famous Sacher Torte, a rich chocolate cake with a layer of apricot jam. The best place to try it? Caf√© Sacher, of course!
A warm slice of Apfelstrudel (apple strudel) with a side of vanilla sauce was the perfect dessert to enjoy at a cozy caf√© while watching the snow fall outside.
One of the most magical moments of my trip was ice skating at the Rathausplatz Ice Rink, right in front of the beautifully illuminated City Hall. The atmosphere was electric, with Christmas music playing in the background and families gliding across the ice. I hadn‚Äôt been on skates in years, but somehow, in that moment, I felt like a kid again, completely lost in the joy of the season.
Vienna in December is more than just a destination ‚Äî it‚Äôs an experience that stays with you. There‚Äôs something about the combination of history, music, food, and festive spirit that makes it feel truly special. Walking through the snow-covered streets, wrapped in my warmest coat, with the sounds of classical music drifting through the air, I felt an overwhelming sense of joy and peace.
If you‚Äôre looking for a holiday getaway that feels straight out of a storybook, Vienna is the place to go. Trust me, once you experience Christmas here, you‚Äôll want to come back every year.

Title: How Vienna Built an Island and What it did With it Next
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
The Viennese adore the River Danube. Over the centuries, they‚Äôve depended on it for drinking water, food, and the movement of people and goods. It flows, after all, through four more capital cities before it empties into the Black Sea. On New Year‚Äôs Eve and at weddings, Austrians dance to Strauss‚Äô joyous love song for the river, The Blue Danube waltz. Even today, the river is such a part of city life that it seems the residents believe that it runs through their back garden.
Vienna has the Danube to thank for its prosperity but, for centuries, it also lived under threat of capricious, catastrophic floods. Picture Austria and you think of mountains but the skiing capitals of Salzburg and Innsbruck are hours away by train. Vienna, home to a quarter of Austria‚Äôs 8.8 million people, sits in a geographical bowl. It‚Äôs a risky place to put a city which was, until 100 years ago, the centre of an empire. Even in the 20th century, the fear that large parts of the city could be washed away was a constraint on Vienna‚Äôs growth.
In 1988, Vienna completed its largest ever civil engineering project to address the flooding problem. Over the previous 16 years, they had dug out a new channel for the river, built two massive weirs, and piled 30 million cubic meters of soil into an island between the old and the new river. Enough soil was excavated and repurposed to cover Vienna‚Äôs largest park, the Prater, to a depth of 5 metres. It would have buried New York‚Äôs Central Park under almost 10 metres of earth. This completed Donauinsel (Danube Island) is so big that you would only have to run once around its circumference to complete a full marathon.
The construction of the Donauinsel was a project so large, requiring so much cooperation from so many different departments, that even just 31 years after its completion, it seems almost inconceivable that it could have occurred.
This is the story of how the city protected itself for the future, but also that of how the city gave its people that island as a gift.
For much of its history, Vienna perched not on the straight, steady river of today but on wetlands. Unregulated rivers flood and, in 1501, this happened cataclysmically.
The 1501 flood is as yet unmatched but as we face climate crisis, increasingly extreme summer storms and meltwater from what would previously have been freak winter snowfalls, 1501 plays on the minds of city planners. That flood destroyed bridges throughout Vienna and swept farms, orchards and livestock away. It was so destructive that, in the aftermath, Vienna‚Äôs land boundaries were completely redrawn. Landowners had lost their lives or been forced to abandon their property. For thousands of people in the city, it was time to start again.
1501 was the largest flood in Vienna‚Äôs history, but it wasn‚Äôt the last. The city lived with regular floods until the 19th century, when the Hapsburgs were at the height of their power. Famously, the emperor Franz Joseph vowed to remake the centre of Vienna. In a 30-year redevelopment project, Franz Joseph tore down the old city walls and replaced them with the Ringstrasse; a wide boulevard inspired by the streets of Paris. They erected the new Rathaus (city hall), Parliament, theatres and museums in a variety of architectural styles to give the illusion that this city-wide remodelling had happened organically, over centuries, in the context of an empire which had endured for generations and would continue for generations to come.
At the same time, Vienna‚Äôs population exploded as people came from all corners of the empire to work. In the same year the Ringstrasse was to be completed, the population was projected to break 1 million for the first time. Many of the new arrivals settled in low-lying areas of the city such as Leopoldstadt (today‚Äôs second district) and the villages of Stadtlau, Floridsdorf and Jedlsee on the other side of the Danube.
Whether the new residents knew it or not, their homes and livelihoods were in danger. The first district was on a slope, meaning that Stephansdom cathedral, the Hofburg palace, and the brand new Ringstrasse were never at risk; it was the residential districts which had to be protected if the city was to continue to prosper. We can only imagine the frustration of the Emperor who had just made over his city to his personal tastes, a man who kept lions in the garden of his summer palace and had maintained hunting ground the size of a medium sized town within the city limits, when his river wouldn‚Äôt behave.
The arrival of the telegraph in the 1840s brought some relief. With the telegraph, warning could be sent downstream from Linz when flooding was imminent. A message relayed to Vienna gave the people a days‚Äô notice. It wasn‚Äôt much but it was enough time to protect their belongings and move to high ground instead of scrambling to the roof as the water rose around them. Understandably, the citizens continued to complain that this was not enough.
The Hapsburgs took radical action to address the problem in the 1860s and 70s. Franz Joseph enlisted the engineer behind the newly completed Suez Canal and they brought the Danube under control.
The plan was this:
First, they would build the Donaukanal (Danube Canal). The new canal would separate Leopoldstadt from the first district and run from the northern to the southern edges of the city. Thanks to the weirs and locks at the borders, the water level would remain almost constant.
Then, on the eastern side of the districts of Leopoldstadt and Brigittenau, they would carve a whole new riverbed for the Danube proper.
Finally, the old curve of the river would be set aside as the Alte Donau (Old Danube) which still exists in the 21st and 22nd districts as a haven for nature and leisure.
Instead of uncontrollable wetlands, their plan gave Vienna efficient, dependable shipping channels and a wide area which could be flooded without damage to the city.
The defences were undeniably a great feat of engineering and life in the city improved. In relative safety, Vienna grew to absorb the previously precarious villages on its outskirts. The expansion of the city continued even as the Hapsburg dynasty came to an end, even as two world wars took Vienna from the central pearl of a sprawling empire to the ‚Äòfat head‚Äô of a country depleted of land, resources and population.
But Franz Joseph‚Äôs defences only held for 70 years.
In 1954, another flood ravaged the new districts. Thousands of people were evacuated from their homes. An outraged public demanded urgent plans for new flood protection.
Vienna reckoned with a number of solutions. Bigger dams were proposed but these would have been too dangerous were they to fail. The option of broadening the channel was discussed but making the river wider would also make it shallow, causing problems for large modern barges. Diverting the river to the north was a possibility but that area was already earmarked for development as the city recovered from the war.
Enter the Austrian engineer August Zottl, the first in his guild to occupy himself with the problem of alpine floodwaters. In 1957, when three years of calm weather had failed to dampen public interest in the project, he presented his plan to protect Vienna.
From the beginning, Zottl designed his system to cope with a flood of the same magnitude as that of 1501. His proposal was to build a second channel for the Danube parallel to the one dug in the 1870s. There would be a weir at the top of the new channel, which could be opened in the event of flooding to take pressure off the shipping channel. There would also be new motorways on the banks, which in times of absolute peril would act as an artificial flood plain in order to protect the city. And what to do with the vast amount of earth they would have to excavate? Place it between the two channels and construct an island from scratch.
Zottl‚Äôs plan was complicated, and he had to be persistent to win over the planners. It wasn‚Äôt until 15 years after his initial proposal that the city agreed to start work and, even then, the ground was broken before anyone had agreed on what to do with the new land they would create.
The Donauinsel is 21km long and 210 meters at its widest point. To the south, it extends all the way to the city‚Äôs border. To the north, it goes most of the way to the neighbouring town of Klosterneuburg. The idea of a modern city presented with such a vast new area for development was unheard of. Naturally, there were a lot of opinions on what to do with the land. Some wanted to use it for a major new train station, others a university campus, others for factories.
While building work continued, executives and planners sat in boardrooms, focussing largely on the idea of an industrial estate. On the Ringstrasse, however, crowds of people, the majority of them students, marched to demand that the new land be given to the people. It seemed like the most logical solution, they argued, since the people were using it already. In the summers of the 1970s and 80s, long before there was even a blade of grass on the island, sunbathers laid out their towels on the gravel and spent the day lying under the cranes.
In spite of complaints that their demand was ‚Äòcommunist,‚Äô the protesters won. Not only would the people have access to the whole island, it would be free and without fences. No private clubs. No golf courses. No industry. Just a vast space for recreation.
Today, three of Vienna‚Äôs five underground lines have stations either on the Donauinsel or the riverbank, so that the people can reach it directly from most of the city. On the island, you‚Äôll find everything from the world‚Äôs biggest floating trampoline complex to a wakeboard lift, Saturday morning kite festivals to Vienna‚Äôs Muggle Quidditch team. There‚Äôs a grammar school built on a boat moored to the island and a number of beaches reserved just for dogs. There are pontoons from which people jump into the new river channel and swim to the other side. There‚Äôs a playpark with a stream running through it where kids build muddy sandcastles in the middle of their landlocked country. In the more secluded parts of the island, there are also nudist beaches.
Every year since 1984 (four years before it was officially completed), the island has played host to Donauinselfest, a music festival that calls itself the biggest free outdoor party in Europe. Big-name acts travel from around the world to play to almost 3 million visitors. Most years, the Vienna Symphony Orchestra also puts in an appearance.
Vienna continues to invest in the Dounauinsel too. Wi-Fi is now available on a large part of the island, allowing people to work in the fresh air. The island is home to 1.8 million trees and, now they are established, projects are being undertaken to maximise the space as a habitat for diverse wildlife. Community gardens are also increasingly popular. Just last year, the city gardeners planted an orchard of 30 fruit trees. Anyone is welcome to harvest the fruit, provided they take only as much as they can hold in their hands.
Most happily, Zottl‚Äôs flood defence plan was such a success that a great deal of Vienna‚Äôs population is unaware of the critical role the Donauinsel plays. On average, the weir is opened twice a year so the new channel can take the extra water. The biggest test of the system came in July 2013 when overwhelming storms hit the Danube basin. Vienna experienced more than two months‚Äô worth of rainfall in two days. The Donauinsel was partially flooded but, while towns such as Passau were devastated by the worst floods since 1501, Vienna was undamaged.
The Danube hasn‚Äôt flowed through the centre of Vienna since the Donaukanal was first constructed. Bratislava castle is built on a rock overlooking the water. The famous Hungarian Parliament building sits on the water too, as does the whole of Old Belgrade. In Vienna, however, you have to walk for several kilometres to get from the first district to the river. You can‚Äôt see the cathedral from the water, or Karlskirche, or the Opera, or the Riesenrad Ferris wheel.
But while the Danube doesn‚Äôt run past Vienna‚Äôs most famous tourist attractions, it does go through the area where people actually live. The turbulent history of Vienna and its river was never a struggle to protect its crown jewels, its religious artefacts, its palaces. It was about saving people‚Äôs homes and their ability to put down roots without fear that they would be washed away.
Now that the flood risk is mitigated, the river is more important than ever to the Viennese as part of their life outside work, although it could be argued that an island wrought by all the might of 20th century engineering technology is a surreal place to to withdraw from the pace of urban life. Though visitors know that the island is still new, the trees have grown and the paths have weathered to the extent that the island no longer feels man made. Most importantly, if you take a bike and cycle for 20 minutes, you can only see the city in the distance. To be within the borders of a European capital and yet have it be so easy to escape is a gift.
In 1988, when the Donauinsel was opened, it was estimated that 100,000 people a day would visit. 30 years later, in a city of only 2 million people, you‚Äôll find 2‚Äì300 000 of them somewhere on the island when the sun comes out. Beer in a cooler, someone cycling up and down the footpaths selling ice cream, sun cream (hopefully) applied, the Viennese still love nothing more than a day in the fresh air by the water. And, on days like that, it must be said that the river is, quite astonishingly, blue.
--
--

Grateful for those who speak English while we study German
St Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral on a gray February day- Author photo
I‚Äôm not so sanguine about writing here on Medium-using just my iPad, not really sure where to publish. I comment a lot. For those who follow my comments, you might notice a wide range of subjects.
My wife and I rented an apartment in the 18th district of Vienna starting November of 2024. This came about from a desire to leave the US and certain business opportunities in Austria. We have been catching up to the process of moving while in the middle of several projects, including listing our home for sale on the East coast of FL. This required more time than we expected, and delayed our move until two weeks ago.
As soon as we arrived in Vienna, we left for Cyprus to attend a course and visit some friends. So we have actually been in the apartment for about six days. We ordered a nice mattress from SchlafTEQ right before we left for Cyprus, and they got it to us when we returned. So that‚Äôs our furniture until our container arrives in four more weeks.
We managed to buy a washer/dryer Monday, which arrived yesterday, just in time to start washing our clothes. Of course it is small compared to the monster LG units we had in Florida. It also takes two or three hours to process a load. But the clothes come out beautifully clean.
We were in the first district of Vienna yesterday, running errands, looking at furniture to complement what is coming by container. We stopped into the luxury grocery store, Julius Meinl, to buy a few items, and the cashier sarcastically commented to the patrons behind us: ‚Äútourists,‚Äù as we fumbled for unfamiliar coins. Not sure what she expects from the first district, which sees millions of tourists a year.
And we are newbie ex-pats, or maybe even immigrants, working our way through the challenges of culture, language and a new location. So it‚Äôs on us to adapt, to be respectful. To learn the language, and to accommodate the changes with grace. We are so grateful that we speak English, and that so many Viennese, especially the younger ones, speak it so well.
We ae both very excited to be here, and a bit overwhelmed by no furniture, new language, cold weather and an unfamiliar neighborhood. Almost everyone we meet, when we explain to that we came from Florida asks ‚ÄúBut why would you move here?‚Äù Not knowing how the US has become a place of strife, bad food, unkind culture, a insanely expensive medical system and a waste of resources.
Not that I do not have great respect for the good things in the US, and there are many; it is that life, for us, even with all the challenges here, offers all of the elements in Vienna that please us-food, culture, an enticing city, public transport, and ultimately a real community. We are also very happy that Vienna is such a great hub to explore all of the EU and beyond.
--
--
9
World traveler from a young age, foodie and cook, connoisseur of many arts, still adventurous.

All great cities lay claim to at least one golden moment. While we might quibble over what‚Äôs required to earn that label, one thing seems clear: Fabled destiny often coexists with searing contradictions.
Vienna in 1900 was a perfect example.
At the beginning of the 20th century, Vienna was the imperial city of the ruling Hapsburgs and Europe‚Äôs cosmopolitan center of music and pleasure. It was home to Sigmund Freud and the two Gustavs of music and art (Mahler and Klimt ), a pantheon of poets, composers, literati, and theater notables; a yeasty mix of immigrants from throughout the sprawling Austro-Hungarian empire; the sixth largest Jewish population in the world; and plentiful parks, palaces, coffee houses, and heart-stopping pastries.
Yet as Stefan Zweig (1881‚Äì1942) ‚Äî Vienna‚Äôs native son, member of the city‚Äôs Jewish bourgeoisie, and famed author ‚Äî understood well, Vienna‚Äôs underbelly was in ferment. Suicide was rampant. So, too, were syphilis, cholera, tuberculosis, and typhoid. Infant mortality was high and life expectancy low at a mere 38 years. Anti-Semitism was also on the rise as was the disaffection of youth, shackled by rules and norms governing every aspect of life.
With the help of Zweig‚Äôs 1942, 450-page autobiography, aptly titled The World of Yesterday, here are some keen observations of this‚Ä¶

Title: An Insider‚Äôs Guide to Vienna, Austria
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Visiting Vienna is like taking a step back through time. The imposing architecture, glamorous cafe‚Äôs, expansive beer halls, and slow, relaxed pace of life make visitors feel as if they are living in a black and white film. While there is certainly a modern element that vibrates through the metro area ‚Äî particularly during commuting hours ‚Äî , Vienna generally runs on a pulse that syncs to the slow, steady chime of the church bells that ring throughout the city every hour on the hour. This ambient environment combined with delicious cuisine and a rich culture attract millions of visitors to Vienna every year.
There is so much to see and do, one could easily spend an entire day roaming around each of the uniquely beautiful districts, discovering all the hidden gems that Vienna has to offer. If, however, you are limited to spending only a few days in the city, here are a few tips from a local on how to hit the highlights while still having an authentic, Viennese experience.
Walk the Ringstrasse
Many of the most popular sites lie along the two and a half-mile epicenter of the city ‚Äî the Ringstrasse. While many visitors take the seven-euro tourist tram ride to view all the architecture in rapid succession, the best way to fully appreciate these magnificent buildings is to pass them slowly and on foot. I suggest starting at the Schottentor metro station and strolling down toward the Rathaus and around. Here is a post that highlights many of the more significant landmarks you will pass along the way. Once you make it all the way around and are back near Schottentor, pop into the Melker Stiftskeller restaurant/wine cellar for dinner or a late lunch. The cuisine is true authentic Austrian ‚Äî that is, packed with salt, heavy cream, and every other sinful ingredient that is a treat for the taste buds. A large Schnitzel and a few pilsner beers are just the things to revive you after your walk.
Buy Lunch at Naschmarkt and Picnic at Schloss Schonbrunn
On a Saturday morning, Naschmarkt ‚Äî an open-air farmer‚Äôs market ‚Äî will be packed with people buying fruits, vegetables, and exotic treats like olives, hummus, and freshly fried falafel. While you likely won‚Äôt want or need to stock up on groceries during your stay¬≠, you should absolutely sample some of the goodies on sale at Naschmarkt. I suggest purchasing a smorgasbord of picnic supplies and hopping on the metro to Schloss Schonbrunn. You can enter the surrounding park for free, find a bench or a grassy spot, and enjoy lunch among the beautifully groomed gardens. Afterward, you may consider touring the inside of the castle.
Have Coffee at a Viennese Caf√©
Caf√© culture is an integral part of Viennese history. During its golden era after World War I and before World War II, many Viennese aristocrats made their fortunes by importing sugar for the pastries that lined the caf√© display cases. As a result, many coffee houses around the city are now protected UNESCO world heritage sites. A visit to the city would not be complete without a M√©lange and an Apfelstrudel or Sachertorte in one of these famed cafes. Places like Caf√© Central, while very beautiful, are typically packed with tourists. It may be worth battling the crowds to check out the interior decor, but it won‚Äôt be quite the authentic experience you might be looking for. To fully enjoy the ‚Äúpublic living rooms of Vienna‚Äù in a more relaxed setting, head somewhere that is slightly less popular but every bit as beautiful. I suggest checking out Cafe Sperl or Caf√© Schwarzenberg.
Visit Klimt at the Belvedere
There are many art museums in Vienna, and if you are an art buff, you‚Äôll probably want to visit more than just one. But if you only have a few days, the must-visit museum is absolutely the Belvedere. The building and surrounding gardens are a work of art in themselves and the museum houses paintings by Vienna‚Äôs most beloved artist, Gustav Klimt. His most famous work, The Kiss, is to Austria what the Guernica is to Spain or The Statue of David is to Florence. After your visit to the museum, hop on the D line street train (Strassenbahn) heading west and find your way to 7 Stern Br√§u for a kr√ºgerl (pint-ish) of traditionally brewed beer.
Hike in the Viennese Vineyards
Vienna may be well known for its beer production, but it also produces enough wine to imbibe the entire city. Just outside the city, visitors can sample Viennese wine and hike around centuries-old vineyards that are still producing today. There are over 190 Vinters scattered in the foothills outside the city and dozens of restaurants where you can enjoy seasonal cuisine featuring fresh greens, mushrooms, or berries that are harvested from the nearby forest. Check out this post with a few recommended locations and spend the day drinking your way from winery to winery.
Vienna has so much more to offer, and as a newly minted local, I am constantly discovering places worthy of this list. However, if you only have a few days in the city, these recommended activities will ensure you experience some of the touristic highlights while having an authentic Viennese experience.

Title: I went on a Workation to Vienna and that‚Äôs how it was
Content:

My first ever Workation I went on to Vienna was actually quite a lame experience. But let me start from the beginning.
I‚Äôm from Austria, so I figured why not go to its capital Vienna for a test run and see how such a trip might turn out, if I packed in everything I thought I need and if the travel bag I already owned would be enough (hint: it wasn‚Äôt, it didn‚Äôt have wheels and so I almost ruined my back and shoulder with all the stuff I brought with me). Furthermore, my sister is living in Vienna and so what could go wrong, having her around.
Now thinking back, I see that I even made some Workations before that time before even knowing what that is. I just visited my sister in her apartment, brought some cloths and my laptop with me, and spend a good time with her. I think at this time the word Workation wasn‚Äôt even invented yet and so I‚Äôm tempted to say that I was one of the pioneers of this movement.
To get a primer on Workations please check this article.
Now back to my first ‚Äúreal‚Äù Workation: There are a couple of reasons why it was such a failure. For one, I chose a pretty bad Airbnb. It was my first time on this platform and so I wasn‚Äôt that experienced yet. On the photos everything looked pretty nice, but then arriving at the apartment all the niceness was suddenly gone. The place was quite run down for a rather high price and it was on the tiny side. At least it had everything I needed: A bed to sleep, a couch to sit at, a table to work, and a kitchen to cook ‚Äî all crammed into a tiny apartment, unfortunately.
Actually, the first day was quite enjoyable. It was a holiday, so I had the whole day to walk around, explore the city, and check what I could do in the neighborhood in the next days. My first goal was to get breakfast and I found this lovely place with a good selection of food. But this wasn‚Äôt the best part: I went out on this Workation to meet people and to have some lucky encounters, which strangely happened on the first day right away, basically in the first hours of the trip. There was this elder guy sitting next to me who saw that I was reading on my iPad and approached me about his own device which he seemed to have problems with.
But that was only a small part of the conversation in the end. It turned out that he was a cook, and a pretty famous one who had travelled the world pursuing his passion and meeting quite some celebrities while doing that (Schwarzenegger, anyone?). It must have been at least one hour while I listened to him ‚Äî and the breakfast was good too.
And then reality kicked in. I vividly remember the first working day of my Workation: It was the first day after a long weekend and so I not only had more than enough to catch up with but there was also the ‚Äúadded stress‚Äù of being in a totally unfamiliar place, without the usual work gear, no breakfast bought yet, me sitting in this tiny room (which neither was beneficial to my motivation nor inspiration). And to add to that, I also needed to figure out what to do in Vienna. I mean, I was in this awesome city without a plan what to do or where to go. Oh boy, I still get the goose bumps when thinking about this moment ‚Ä¶
Another reason why I didn‚Äôt enjoy this Workation at first was that I wasn‚Äôt ready yet to see all the possibilities of such a trip, working in different places and not sitting in the apartment all day (as I‚Äôm anyway doing it at home too, so what‚Äôs the point?). Unfortunately, this didn‚Äôt change much until I went home again, but it at least gave me a glimpse of what such a trip could actually mean ‚Äî and I learned a lot from it and did much, much better on my second Workation. I‚Äôll tell you about it another article, stay tuned!
I need to admit that the weather also wasn‚Äôt in my favor and so it must have been the third day or so where I finally took the courage and went out to have breakfast and I was so bold to take my work gear with me. Unfortunately, I didn‚Äôt have much experience with that yet and the MacBook I had at this time didn‚Äôt last very long and the external battery was lame too (and surely there was no power plug nearby). So I ended up having a call with a colleague on the iPad which was also close to being out of power. At least the breakfast I had was delicious, it was a mixture of Indian food I had never tasted before with some Turkish coffee I also hadn‚Äôt experienced so far. And then there was sunshine, a lot.
I made all the mistakes you shouldn‚Äôt make when being on a Workation but despite all the challenges I tried it again the other day and sat in a caf√® near the riverside of the river Danube that flows though Vienna. It must be lovely here in the summer ‚Äî and it was also the first time when I realized how nasty direct sunlight on a laptop screen can be. But it was still an enjoyable experience, sitting outside, having a lot of people around you, being able to order some cool drinks and freeing your mind in the fresh air.
What I did pretty well on this Workation in Vienna was to explore the city in my free time ‚Äî I couldn‚Äôt wait until I finished work (which was usually quite late, as I stressed out a lot and got less work done than I wanted) to walk around, which I did a lot. I think there must have been no place in the city center that I didn‚Äôt see. And I ate a lot of good food, which Vienna is famous for, like Wiener Schnitzel or Gulasch, and drank some good local beer. Then there was also the time I spent with my sister, she even managed to show me some spots I didn‚Äôt see before and took me out to an exhibition of Keith Haring in the ‚ÄúWiener Albertina,‚Äù a famous museum.
All in all, my first Workation wasn‚Äôt the experience I was looking for and surely not the best prerequisite to go on more such trips. But it didn‚Äôt hold me back from going on another similar trip just a month later, that I had already booked and was very excited about (Trieste, Italy, to be precise). It also taught me to plan well on one side, to prevent mental overload when being in an uncommon location, but at the same time be spontaneous and appreciate all the opportunities you have in such a city.
Most of all, it allowed me to see how important it is to get out of your comfort zone and challenge yourself. I had these awesome possibilities as a former employee of Alludo and it would have been nothing short of stupid to not use them and enjoy the given freedom as much as I could.
If nothing else, the trip to Vienna helped me to see what I may have forgotten to pack and in which mistakes I should not repeat again, so it was a useful lesson how NOT to do a Workation. And that alone helped me to enjoy my future trips even more, so I tried to see the positive sides as much as I could. It also made me realize that there is nothing in life that doesn‚Äôt happen or a reason.
Would you also like to go on a Workation and avoid the same mistakes I made? I‚Äôd love to help you make this trip into an unforgettable experience. Check out my feed on Instagram and send me a message.

We are two weirdos currently living in the Netherlands and ocassioanly having a holiday.

--
Listen
Share
At least its not Bratislava
We went to Vienna mid-August of 2019. I‚Äôve been there previously two years ago but now we opted to go together. As you‚Äôll no doubt discover we‚Äôre both passive-ish tourists. Not that we won‚Äôt be out for the entire day when we‚Äôre abroad but often our days would start past 12pm and we‚Äôll find ourselves taking an Uber rather than running since 6am with five backpacks. Maybe that‚Äôs to come in a few years but for now its comfortable beds all the way.
It‚Äôs not everyone‚Äôs cup of tea but if you‚Äôre into arts, Baroque European architecture and a strudel or two then its the place to be. Unlike places like Rome or Paris, Vienna doesn‚Äôt suffer from swarms of tourism. Don‚Äôt get me wrong it‚Äôs not dead on the streets but if you‚Äôre used to lining up for 6 hours to get into The Colosseum you will be pleasantly surprised having to wait 10 or so minutes to get into most major attractions.
So what about museums? There are plenty of those. I had a leaflet that listed 50 or so but I looked it up and there are a 100 plus. You can pick what you‚Äôd like from Royal apartments, natural history or horses there is plenty for everyone apart from people who don‚Äôt like museums. If that‚Äôs you then go to the Film Museum as its closed for the summer.
Since Vienna is in Austria and Austria is German you can‚Äôt avoid the art college crowd. Thankfully they keep to themselves here and only provide Vienna with modern art and overpriced food. If you would like to spend 25 euros on a porridge and a smoothie Ilona would recommend Superfood Deli.
The entire city centre is littered with good shops from the fanciest H&M building to your average Saint Laurent. There is also a very large shopping street slightly outside the centre for more regular things like Esprit and mymuesli.
However if you want IQOS cigarettes like Ilona then you will have to take a train to Bratislava (which we did).
Vienna has one of the most reliable Metro systems we‚Äôve been to. For 17 euros you can get an unlimited travel pass for a week (7 days). This includes the metro, trams, buses, all that stuff. Everything is very well connected. Vienna also has Uber and Uber with Lime integration. That‚Äôs their electric scooters. There are also other brands that do the scooter service but we use Uber so here we are.
Vienna has the first Hard Rock cafe we tried in Europe that wasn‚Äôt greasy. And to be honest with the most polite staff too. Plachuttas Gasthaus zur Oper is another great place, we went for Schnitzel. For amazing Apple Strudel a good place to go would be Residence Cafe and Restaurant which is right next to Sch√∂nbrunn Palace. Sacher cake is also a must try! Ok it‚Äôs just chocolate cake but its a really really good chocolate cake.
What if you realise 25 euro porridge is not your cup of tea? What do you do then? You run to your nearest Billa supermarket and grab a poppy seed Strudel to fill you up with goodness.
You can also find your usual Spar and a re-branded Aldi but you won‚Äôt have to make that hard choice as all places are always well stocked with good food that‚Äôs well priced. Also they have some great sausages.
Honorable mention: I got a muesli with milk and a yogurt, both were under 80 cents.
This time we got an AirBNB. It was perfect. Was hosted by a lovely chap called Christian, who was more enthusiastic than most hotel staff I encountered. The apartment was 3min from one of the main shopping streets and metro and we slept with the windows open because it was so quiet.
We give Vienna a solid 9/10
Ok bye thank you.

Title: Budapest, Bratislava, and Vienna ‚Äî A Europe Trip
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Nearly ten years ago, my husband and I lived in Budapest for a few months right after we were married. Every weekend, we‚Äôd pack our bags and visit a new European town or country. That was when the travel bug bit us. Fast forward to today, we were thrilled to have a wonderful opportunity to visit Budapest again. How could we possibly say no? This time, we wanted to take our son to the places where we made wonderful memories ten years ago. And of course, when you‚Äôre in Europe, visiting one city isn‚Äôt always enough. That‚Äôs how Bratislava and Vienna ended up on our itinerary as well.
Flights
First things first. To apply for a visa, you need confirmed round-trip tickets and hotel reservations for the travel dates. I know I‚Äôve mentioned this before in my Kazakhstan blog, but it‚Äôs always worth repeating ‚Äî look for cheaper flights from cities other than the one you reside in. We could have booked flights directly from Kozhikode to Budapest. But the layovers were long, which made the total travel time even longer, and the ticket prices were outrageous! The cheapest flight to Budapest from India was from Bangalore. The flight duration was shorter, and the layovers were minimal. So, we booked our flights from Bangalore. We flew to Bangalore from Kozhikode the day before and stayed overnight at a hotel near the airport. This turned out to be cheaper than booking a direct flight from Kozhikode (including both the flights to Bangalore and the hotel stay). And since we have a kid, it was much more convenient for him. Happy child = Happy Parents. It was a win-win. We booked the KLM flight from Bangalore to Budapest with a 1.5-hour layover in Amsterdam. We flew back to Bangalore from Budapest via Paris on Air France. Both flights were quite comfortable, and we had no complaints.
Stay
From our experience, Airbnb is the best stay option. It is cheaper than hotels and extremely spacious, and most rentals have a washer/dryer. That means you can carry fewer clothes and sleep in spacious rooms. Our son is a huge fan of Airbnb because of how spacious they are. Hotels simply cannot beat this offer. Of course, make sure you book an Airbnb rental with good ratings located near the city centre or one that is easily accessible via public transport.
Once our flights and accommodations were booked, the next step ‚Äî the most dreaded of them all ‚Äî was applying for a Schengen visa.
Schengen Visa
Let me be upfront ‚Äî of all the visas I‚Äôve applied for, the Schengen visa is the most complicated. I‚Äôm not joking when I say that one of the factors influencing the choice of our travel destinations is the complexity of the visa application process. All the countries we‚Äôve visited in the past few years (post-COVID) have either had straightforward visa applications or were visa-free. But when the opportunity to travel back to Budapest came up around our ten-year wedding anniversary, we couldn‚Äôt say no, especially since we started our married life there.
I‚Äôm not going to go into detail about the visa application process, but I will mention a few things that helped us during our process.
To apply for a Schengen visa, you must submit your documents to the VFS application centre closest to your city of residence. We live in Kozhikode, and the nearest VFS centre that processes Schengen visas is in Kochi. However, we couldn‚Äôt find any suitable appointment dates in Kochi, so we decided to go with the next closest VFS centre ‚Äî Bangalore. Coincidentally, we were planning a trip to Mysore during the Navratri holidays, so we extended our holiday to fit the visa appointment in Bangalore.
Before COVID-19, applying for a Schengen visa was simpler because we didn‚Äôt need an agent to help us block appointment dates. We could just log into our account on the VFS portal and pick the city, date, and time that suited us. This time, however, we couldn‚Äôt get any appointment dates when we tried to do it ourselves. It was disappointing because we took pride in managing our travel plans independently. In the end, we had to approach an agent to book an appointment, and to our surprise and eventual relief, the agent was able to get us dates that appeared unavailable on the portal. We finally got our dates, and they lined up perfectly with our Mysore holiday.
When you go for your visa appointment, it‚Äôs a good idea to bring extra documents beyond those listed on the VFS website. We carried copies of our marriage certificate, our son‚Äôs birth certificate, copies of our investments, all our old passports, and copies of all Schengen visas older than three years ‚Äî documents that were not specifically required, but which the VFS centre appreciated us having. The VFS centre also has a photo booth (in case your photos don‚Äôt meet their standards), photocopy machines, and printers, just in case you forget to bring a document. So, it‚Äôs helpful to keep digital copies of all your documents so you can easily access and print them if needed.
We received our passports stamped with the visas within a few days of application.
Now, it was time to travel!
Our First Destination ‚Äî Budapest
Although Amsterdam was our first port of entry into Europe, it was a short layover. After waiting through a long immigration line, we rushed to catch our connecting flight to Budapest.We reached Budapest at around 12 PM. Since we finished our immigration at our first port of entry ‚Äî Amsterdam ‚Äî we collected our luggage and passed through customs. We were to stay in Budapest for five days, visit Bratislava and Vienna, and then return to Budapest for a day before flying back to India. So, we purchased a two-week travel pass at the airport. This pass provides unlimited use of public transport (metro, bus, and tram) for 14 days in Budapest. There are also single tickets, one-day passes, three-day passes, and monthly travel passes, but sadly, no weekly passes. The two-week pass worked out to be the cheapest option for our 6-day overall stay. If you plan to stay in Budapest for more than three days, get the two-week pass. Don‚Äôt buy a three-day pass and then single-day passes for the extra days, as the price difference between the three-day and two-week passes is minimal. If you buy single tickets each time you use public transport, you‚Äôll lose both time and money. One thing you should know about most European cities is that you will rarely need to use a taxi/cab. The public transport system is so well-connected that you‚Äôll be constantly hopping on and off metros, buses, or trams throughout your stay. So, a travel pass makes more sense than individual tickets. Also, think of the time you‚Äôll save. Imagine having to purchase a ticket every time you use public transportation. It simply does not make sense.
With the travel pass, we took the 200E bus to K≈ëb√°nya-Kispest M and then transferred to the M3 Metro line to get closer to our accommodation. We stayed in an Airbnb just a three-minute walk from Kalvin Square (K√°lvin T√©r) Metro station (this falls on the M3 metro line).
There is also a 100E bus that goes directly from the airport to the city centre, but this is the only transport service that is NOT included in the travel pass. Since we had the pass, we skipped it and took the 200E bus instead. The 200E bus stops just outside the airport exit. You don‚Äôt need to validate your two-week pass on the bus, but make sure to keep it with you at all times. There are regular checks, and you‚Äôll need to show your pass if asked. Once we reached K≈ëb√°nya-Kispest M, we transferred to the M3 metro line and travelled to K√°lvin T√©r. At metro stations, there are no automated ticket validators. Instead, you‚Äôll need to show your pass to the staff member near the escalators, who will quickly scan it before letting you through.
We reached our metro station, walked to our Airbnb, and self-checked in. After that, we took the day off to relax.
Getting a Local Sim
We made sure our international roaming was activated before we left India. We needed data for the first hours around the city since we did not want to buy a SIM card at the airport (expensive). We visited a local Vodafone store in the city the very next day and bought a local SIM. It was around INR 2500, which got us 6 GB of data for 30 days around Europe.
Sightseeing in Budapest
We travelled in November, which meant it was cold and there were fewer tourists ‚Äî which worked to our advantage. However, the drawback was that we had to layer up every time we stepped out, which was frustrating the first few days, but later, we got used to it. We had three layers. Our regular clothes, a sweatshirt/sweater on top and a final jacket. We also had gloves, a scarf, and a beanie. We used regular walking shoes, which were quite enough since there was no snow or rain.
Places we visited in Budapest ‚Äì
As with most of my travel blogs, I‚Äôm not going to dive into the details of our itinerary or write in detail about the places we visited. Instead, I‚Äôm going to simply list the places we explored each day. We traveled with our 4-year-old son, so if you‚Äôre wondering how many places you can cover with a kid in a day, this should give you a good idea.
Day 1 ‚Äì
1. Hungarian Parliament Building Viewpoint
2. Mathias Church
3. Fishermen‚Äôs Bastion
4. Buda Castle and Old Town
5. Szechenyi Chain Bridge
Day 2 ‚Äì
1. Gellert Hill (Closed due to renovation)
2. Vaci Utca ‚Äî for shopping
3. Corvinus University
Day 3 ‚Äì
1. Shoes on the Danube Bank
2. Central Market
3. Vajdahunyad Castle
4. Heroes Square
Day 4 ‚Äì
1. Ferris Wheel of Budapest
2. Vaci Utca for the second time
3. Christmas Markets around the city
Day 5 ‚Äì
Budapest to Bratislava
Our Second Destination ‚Äî Bratislava
Our next stop was the city of Bratislava in Slovakia. We didn‚Äôt book any local travel in advance, so we visited the Keleti-P√°lyaudvar railway station in Budapest, a few stops away from where we stayed, and bought our train tickets to Bratislava just the day before leaving for Bratislava. This worked out cheaper for us. We also reserved seats by paying a little extra. This may not be necessary during the off-season because the trains are quite empty, and you can choose any seat, but during peak season, I suggest reserving seats. Kids under 6 travel for free! It took us 2.5 hours to reach Bratislava by train from Budapest.
We were staying in Bratislava for three days, so we bought the three-day travel pass at the railway station. The pass gives you unlimited bus and tram rides within the city. There is no metro in Bratislava, but trams and buses connect the station to the city centre. Make sure to validate your pass during your first ride. Once validated, it‚Äôs enough to do it just once, as the three days are counted from your first trip.
We stayed in an Airbnb very close to St. Michael‚Äôs Gate. The city is much smaller than Budapest, and most sightseeing within the city can be done on foot. However, visiting Devin Castle takes about 40 minutes by bus. You can use your travel pass for the bus ride there.
Places we visited ‚Äì
1. Devin Castle (must visit for breathtaking views of the Danube) ‚Äî Highly Recommended
2. Bratislava City Centre ‚Äî St Stephen‚Äôs Gate, UFO tower, Bratislava castle
Our Third Destination ‚Äî Vienna
We travelled from Bratislava to Vienna by bus. Again, we booked the bus tickets just the day before we left for Vienna. We did this online and took the Slovak Lines bus to Vienna Bus station. Remember, there are two stops in Vienna. The bus first stops at the airport and then at the central station. Make sure you book your tickets to the central station, not the airport. We were in Vienna for only a day and took the day pass at a metro station near the bus station where we were dropped off. The return buses back to Bratislava also leave from the same station.
Places we visited in Vienna ‚Äì
1. Stephensplatz and St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral
Our Vienna tradition is to have Gelato in Stephensplatz and so, that‚Äôs what we did. We went to a place ‚Äî Zanoni and Zanoni ‚Äî that had Vegan gelato and also vegan Pizza. They also had egg-free chocolate croissants. We finished a quick lunch here and spent the rest of the day looking around Vienna.
2. Hofburg Palace
3. Maria Theresa Square
4. Christmas Markets
5. Belvedere Palace
We left Bratislava on the 19th and reached Budapest. On the last day in Budapest, we simply walked around Kalvin Square, did some shopping, and called it a day. On the morning of the 20th, we boarded the flight back to Bangalore.
Travel within Europe
Within the cities, we never used a Taxi. The airports are very well connected to the city centre by public transport (Metro, Bus and Tram). If you can walk, you won‚Äôt need a cab/taxi during any part of your journey. The cities are well connected by public transport.
For kids under 6, public transport was FREE in all three cities!
About Europe in General
Please be aware of your surroundings and do not fall for tourist scams. So far, the central and eastern European countries we‚Äôve visited (Austria, Hungary, Slovenia, Slovakia, Croatia) are not particularly known for scams. However, scams are more common in places like Italy, France, and Belgium ‚Äî especially in capital cities and other popular tourist spots. There are several blogs online that discuss the various scams you may encounter, so please read up and stay informed before you travel. Scammers often try to distract you with something (such as asking you to sign a petition or attempting to give you a ‚Äúfree‚Äù gift), and while you‚Äôre distracted, another member of their group may pickpocket you or steal your bags.
Once in Paris, near Montmartre, we were approached by a girl who asked us to sign a petition for something. This is one of their most common scams. Our advice: just walk away and keep a tight grip on your bags. Also, don‚Äôt keep your phone or wallet in your pant pockets. Aravind was almost pickpocketed once but caught the girl in the act, and she quickly ran away. Luckily, he didn‚Äôt lose his wallet. The first incident happened in Paris, and the second in Rome. A third incident happened in Athens, where a lady approached me and offered me a free rose. Thankfully, I said no and left. It was only later that I realized this is another popular scam where people offer you free gifts, and once you accept them, they‚Äôll ask for something in return. We encountered no such scams in the three cities we visited this time.
As for food, many vegan eateries can be found in the popular cities if you want to try local cuisine. In Budapest, I suggest you try Napfenyes Etterem ‚Äî a vegan restaurant that serves local Hungarian cuisine. Make sure you try the Goulash soup! There are also plenty of Indian restaurants if you‚Äôre craving Indian food. We always look for Govinda‚Äôs ‚Äî ISKCON‚Äôs restaurant. They have branches in several cities and if a city we‚Äôre travelling to has one, that‚Äôs where we frequent because our son prefers Indian food to local cuisine.
Overall, Europe is always a fantastic travel destination (if you manage to overcome the initial visa hurdle) because once you enter Europe, you have free reign to go anywhere, and everything is so well connected. Also, almost every shop closes by 6 pm. So make sure to do your shopping before then!
Happy travels!

Title: 5 reasons why Vienna is NOT perfect | some points have to change!
Content:
