Living in the world‚Äôs most liveable city comes with its own challenges! Vienna is one of the best cities in the world, however, it has lots of space for improvement ‚Äî especially when it comes to digitalization.
Austrians love their Euro bills and coins and won‚Äôt replace them completely with digital payment solutions anytime soon. More and more businesses are adapting to the digital movement, however, you can‚Äôt leave the house completely without Cash. You always need to think about carrying some Euros with you as money businesses still require you to pay in cash.After talking to some business owners we agreed that there is only one main reason for the slow adaption:
High commissions for digital payments and it‚Äôs not sustainable for businesses to allow customers to pay lower amounts with cards. Business owners pay a fixed rate of 25 cents to 45 cents per transaction PLUS a percentage of the transaction sum. It totally makes sense from a business point of view to allow card payments only for bigger transactions.
Once we started traveling a lot we started to appreciate these long opening hours in other countries. Shops in Austria are only open 6 days a week from around 7 AM to 8 PM and are closed on Sundays. When I say closed, I mean completely closed. No grocery shopping on Sundays and Holidays. There are some exceptions at main train stations and airports, but these are crowded and aren‚Äôt really meant for regular shopping.
If you‚Äôre moving to Vienna, coming from a country with strong small-talk culture, you might experience the holy private space of Viennese quite early.Privacy is one of the most important assets here in Vienna and you don‚Äôt exchange this information with strangers. Like many other topics, it has its pros and cons, and there is no right or wrong. However, that‚Äôs something that I‚Äôm missing here in Vienna. I‚Äôm originally from Iran and small talk is part of our culture. Talking to strangers without invading their personal space is totally normal, which is in most cases a very nice experience and it‚Äôs boosting your mood automatically. Of course, there are also negative experiences but I think in general it‚Äôs a good thing and is more a cultural thing, so it can‚Äôt be adapted that fast.
The older you get the more complicated it gets to meet with your friends or loved ones. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm a big fan of flexibility and spontaneity. Meeting loved ones shouldn‚Äôt become rocket science and you should be able to meet them whenever you feel the desire. Everybody is or acts super busy and opens their online calendar when you want to schedule an appointment. That‚Äôs maybe a point which most people don‚Äôt consider as a problem, but I think you only realize it once you experienced the opposite. Planning is healthy and everybody should do a little bit of planning, but don‚Äôt forget to live the moments and make space for some flexibility. If you‚Äôre a spontaneous person feel free to be a good example when living in Vienna :)
If you‚Äôre a handy person and love repairing your fridge, washing machine, pipes, and other home projects, then this point is not for you. But if you‚Äôre like me and have two left hands and need help to repair all of these things, then Vienna will welcome you with very high costs.To give you an example: The ice-maker of our fridge is broken for two years now and tried to fix it with YouTube videos, but didn‚Äôt succeed yet. So the problem is not that I‚Äôm greedy and don‚Äôt want to spend 100‚Äì150 euros to repair it. The main problem is that at the beginning you don‚Äôt really get a clear picture of the upcoming costs, because you pay only 100 ‚Ç¨ for the technician to arrive and have a look at the root cause. If you‚Äôre lucky the technician finds the root cause and replaces it for you right away. But if not, you could end up paying around 500‚Ç¨ for new parts and replacement costs. Labor is very expensive in Austria and it has the effect that many people try to repair everything by themselves, which has a nice side effect. You get handier and gain new experiences :)
We have also a YouTube Video on the same topic! Feel free to watch it and let us know in the comments below what annoys you most about your city.

I was done with buses after my previous experience, Caroline knew that, so we took a train from Bratislava to Vienna. The ride was only 60 minutes long, and both of us took the opportunity to read. I was close to finishing Atlas Shrugged and wanted to savor the final pages. Sitting next to Caroline, I was able to do that. Somehow, the silence we shared during that ride was just as romantic as the previous night. Neither of us needed to fill the air with words just for the sake of it. That‚Äôs a quality I love in not just women, but all people. Being able to shut the fuck up shows a security in one‚Äôs self.
The train station wasn‚Äôt far from the downtown area of the city, so we walked around to look for a hostel. We had no luck. When we finally got too tired to carry our bags, we stopped in a bar. We drank whatever the bartender suggested, some local beer I‚Äôm sure. That part alludes me. I usually remember what I drink in every bar. I won‚Äôt be able to tell you who was there with me, but I almost always know what I was drinking. What I do remember though, is that David Hasselhoff‚Äôs music was playing the entire time. I hated it from the jump, but had no clue who the artist was.
‚ÄúWhat is this garbage we‚Äôre listening to?‚Äù I asked Caroline.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs David Hasselhoff.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs crazy! In America there‚Äôs an actor with the same name. He‚Äôs on a show called Baywatch.‚Äù
‚ÄúAre you being serious right now?‚Äù She asked, incredulously.
‚ÄúYeah, the same exact name.‚Äù
‚ÄúIT‚ÄôS THE SAME PERSON, YOU DODO.‚Äù
‚ÄúWait, so he‚Äôs a musician too?‚Äù
‚ÄúThis is blowing my mind,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs like the most popular artist in Germany and Austria. He has more than 20 albums.‚Äù
‚ÄúOk, now you‚Äôre blowing my mind.‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd, we have Baywatch in Australia too. I don‚Äôt live on the moon.‚Äù
I was more dumbfounded than embarrassed. The fact remains though, that shit was painful to listen to. His music sounds like a knock off of Depeche Mode, but more robotic and cheesy. Luckily, while sitting at the bar, we met a few fellow backpackers. You can find the answers to most problems in a bar. You can find the causes too. They were nice enough to walk us over to the nearby hostel they were staying at. Fortunately, there were rooms available.
It was one of the nicest hostels I‚Äôd seen up until that point. There were multiple recreation areas, along with a courtyard that had one of those chessboards with foot-tall pieces. I taught Caroline chess there. The kitchen was really nice too. There were even nice wooden tables to sit at while we enjoyed the free breakfast provided each day. It was a nice change from having to eat standing up. The only thing they didn‚Äôt have was a bar, otherwise it was perfect.
I finished my book that afternoon in the courtyard while sitting next to Caroline. I felt emotional putting it down for the last time. By then the pages were completely worn down and both covers were gone. It looked like it had been through a war, and maybe it had, considering it was a late 60‚Äôs edition that I‚Äôd bought near Washington Square Park a few months prior.
I‚Äôd already finished all of Ayn Rand‚Äôs books at that point and needed more words to burn through. Instead of reading though, I decided to write some letters. I‚Äôd bought some cool, vintage airmail envelopes (the blue ones with red and white stripes around the border) in Amsterdam and really wanted to use them. I got some paper there too. For me, at the time, it was all about thin paper. Whenever I found it I had to buy it. I wanted the stuff as thin as a newspaper. I also knew I‚Äôd potentially write a book about the trip one day and wanted some documentation. I made copies of the letters by hand before sending them.
Caroline and I weren‚Äôt staying in the same room that night, so when I was done writing I said goodnight and went to bed. It was the earliest I‚Äôd gone to bed throughout the whole trip.
The next day, I woke up and took a walk by myself. I just wanted to explore and enjoy the nice spring weather, no plans at all. Again, museums were out of the question, so I just popped some Adderall and let my feet guide me. I could wander for miles on Adderall. I could do anything for hours on it really.
After a bit, I found myself in an outdoor shopping mall. While I was window shopping I faintly heard the sound of the Wu-Tang Clan song Triumph playing in a nearby store. When I looked to my right, it all made sense. It was a skate shop. I entered looking like one of the Goonies after they found One-Eyed Willy‚Äôs dabloons.
A guy who worked there was standing in the doorway. I said to him,‚ÄúYou have no clue how good it feels to hear Wu out in the wild. I‚Äôm from America and damn have I been missing hip hop. I thought all you guys played in this country was David Hasselhoff.‚Äù
‚ÄúHaha, we listen to other stuff,‚Äù he told me, in better English than I expected.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to a Raekwon show in Amsterdam next week.‚Äù
‚ÄúReally?!‚Äù
‚ÄúYeah, I was already there a couple weeks ago, but I can‚Äôt miss this show. Plus, I need to buy more weed.‚Äù
‚ÄúI can sell you some.‚Äù
I told you, drugs come to me.
I paid him 60 Euros for a quarter ounce of above par weed, and he gave it to me right in the store. I thought about buying some Nike Dunks as a good gesture, but thought otherwise after seeing the prices. I never understood people who spend all of their money on shoes. Then again, I spend all my money on weed, so‚Ä¶
We shook hands and said goodbye.
‚ÄúIf I ever come back to Vienna, this will be my first stop.‚Äù
‚ÄúCheers.‚Äù
When I returned to the Hostel, Caroline was there.
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up lady?‚Äù I asked, playfully.
‚ÄúI heard about a good bar that‚Äôs in walking distance. Some guy over there told me about it. He described it as weird and completely empty.‚Äù
‚ÄúPerfect.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is, right?‚Äù
‚ÄúI meant you. You‚Äôre just perfect.‚Äù
‚ÄúAww, you make me blush, John McEnroe.‚Äù
‚ÄúPlease‚Ä¶‚Äù
The bar was everything the guy said it was. It looked more like an empty Chili‚Äôs than a bar. There were way too many booths, and the bar only sat 6. Normally, I‚Äôd sit at the bar in that situation but Caroline didn‚Äôt want to take the chance of getting stuck with an English speaking ex-pat blabber of a bartender.
Beers turned into Sambuca shots very quickly. She was the one ordering this time, and I was certain she was trying to ply me with enough liquor so I‚Äôd finally make a move on her. Obviously, it worked. A man can only be so strong, even the best ones.
We disappeared one after the other into the men‚Äôs bathroom, as to deceive the bartender into thinking it was a normal bathroom run. Again, very Danny Ocean of me.
We started kissing as soon as she opened the door. Then I put her on top of the sink and‚Ä¶ Well, the rest I‚Äôll leave to your imagination.
After a few minutes of fun, we fixed our clothes and left the bathroom. I can‚Äôt be sure of the reason but as soon as the bartender saw us, he asked us to pay our tab and leave. As I told you before, being asked to leave is way different than being thrown out.
We kissed and fondled each other on the walk back to the hostel. I hadn‚Äôt experienced that since college. I don‚Äôt know if there‚Äôs anything better then a fondle walk. It really makes you feel like a teenager again.
When we got to the hostel, we sat and chatted before going to bed.
‚ÄúI think I want to go to Germany tomorrow. Do you want to come with?‚Äù I asked her.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so. I want to stay here longer and see museums.‚Äù
She was doing what I did to her, making me wait.
‚ÄúI understand.‚Äù
We hugged, then stared at each other, our arms still intertwined. Neither of us needed words to express what we felt. We spent five magical days together. It didn‚Äôt need to be anything more than that. We were both content.
‚ÄúGoodnight, pretty lady.‚Äù
‚ÄúGoodnight, Mr. McEnroe. See you when I see you.‚Äù

Title: The Vienna Circle and the Austrian School of Economics: Distinctions and Parallels in Vienna‚Äôs Intellectual Landscape
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
Vienna in the late 19th and early 20th centuries was a vibrant center of intellectual activity, nurturing diverse schools of thought that would leave a lasting impact on philosophy, economics, and the social sciences.
Two of the most significant intellectual movements to emerge from this environment were the Vienna Circle and the Austrian School of Economics.
While both were products of the same cultural milieu, they differed significantly in their objectives, methodologies, and areas of focus. However, they also shared certain parallels that make their comparison intriguing.
The Vienna Circle emerged in the early 20th century, primarily during the 1920s and 1930s, as a group of philosophers and scientists committed to the development of logical positivism (or logical empiricism). Their main concern was the logical analysis of scientific knowledge, with a focus on distinguishing between meaningful and meaningless statements. They sought to apply rigorous logical and mathematical methods to philosophy, with the goal of eliminating metaphysics and focusing on empirically verifiable statements.
Key figures in the Vienna Circle included Moritz Schlick, Rudolf Carnap, and Otto Neurath, who collectively aimed to create a unified scientific language grounded in empirical evidence. The Vienna Circle was particularly influenced by philosophers such as Ludwig Wittgenstein, Ernst Mach, David Hume, and logicians like Gottlob Frege and Bertrand Russell. Their work laid the foundation for much of 20th-century analytic philosophy.
In contrast, the Austrian School of Economics originated in the late 19th century with Carl Menger, whose 1871 work Principles of Economics introduced the concept of marginal utility. This school focused on economics, emphasizing individual human action, subjective value, and the limitations of central planning.
Unlike the Vienna Circle, which was preoccupied with logical analysis and the philosophy of science, the Austrian School concentrated on understanding market processes, capital theory, and the dynamics of economic systems.
Prominent figures of the Austrian School included Eugen von B√∂hm-Bawerk, Ludwig von Mises, and Friedrich Hayek. Their work contributed to key economic concepts such as praxeology (the study of human action), critiques of socialism, and the importance of price signals in a market economy.
One of the most significant distinctions between the Vienna Circle and the Austrian School of Economics lies in their respective methodologies.
The Vienna Circle championed logical empiricism and verificationism. They believed that the meaning of a statement could only be established if it could be empirically verified or if it was a tautology in logic. This focus on empirical verification and the rejection of metaphysics led them to develop complex systems of logical analysis and to apply the methods of the natural sciences to philosophical problems.
In contrast, the Austrian School relied on methodological individualism and deductive reasoning from basic axioms, particularly the principle of human action, known as praxeology. Austrian economists were skeptical of applying mathematical models and empirical methods to economics, as they believed that such methods could not fully capture the complexities of human behavior and market processes. Instead, they emphasized theoretical analysis based on logical deductions from fundamental principles of human action.
The differences between the two schools also extended to their views on science and knowledge.
The Vienna Circle sought to unify the sciences through a common logical framework. They believed that by applying the methods of logic and mathematics, it was possible to create a precise language for science, free from the ambiguities of everyday language. Their goal was to reduce all scientific knowledge to a set of logical propositions that could be verified through empirical observation.
The Austrian School, on the other hand, was more skeptical of the application of scientific methods to economics. While they valued knowledge and understanding of economic processes, they argued that economics was fundamentally different from the natural sciences because it dealt with human behavior, which could not be predicted or measured with the same precision as physical phenomena. Ludwig von Mises and Friedrich Hayek argued that economics required a different approach ‚Äî one that recognized the limits of knowledge and the role of individual decision-making in shaping economic outcomes.
Despite these differences, there were also notable parallels between the Vienna Circle and the Austrian School of Economics, particularly in their skepticism of central planning and authority.
Both schools were critical of grand metaphysical systems and authoritarian approaches to knowledge or governance.
The Vienna Circle sought to dismantle traditional philosophical systems that relied on untestable assertions, advocating instead for a form of empiricism that demanded evidence and logical consistency.
Similarly, the Austrian School critiqued centralized economic planning and interventionism, arguing that such approaches were based on flawed assumptions about the ability to predict and control complex economic systems.
Friedrich Hayek‚Äôs work, in particular, echoed some of the Vienna Circle‚Äôs concerns about the dangers of overconfidence in human knowledge. His famous critique of socialism emphasized the impossibility of central planners having sufficient information to manage an economy effectively ‚Äî a view that resonated with the Vienna Circle‚Äôs insistence on empirical verification and skepticism of grandiose claims.
Ultimately, while the Vienna Circle and the Austrian School of Economics both emerged from Vienna‚Äôs rich intellectual environment, their legacies diverged significantly.
The Vienna Circle‚Äôs influence was most strongly felt in the fields of philosophy, particularly in the development of analytic philosophy and the philosophy of science. Their ideas about logical analysis, the rejection of metaphysics, and the emphasis on empirical verification shaped much of 20th-century philosophical thought.
The Austrian School of Economics, meanwhile, became one of the leading schools of economic thought, particularly in its critiques of socialism and advocacy for free markets. Figures like Ludwig von Mises and Friedrich Hayek continued to shape economic theory and policy debates, particularly in the context of discussions about the role of government in the economy.
While the Vienna Circle and the Austrian School of Economics operated in different intellectual spheres, they shared a common context in the rich intellectual environment of Vienna. Both schools were skeptical of grand systems and central planning, yet they diverged in their methodologies, objectives, and areas of focus.
The Vienna Circle sought to apply the methods of logic and science to philosophical problems, while the Austrian School emphasized the importance of individual human action and the limitations of scientific methods in understanding economics.
Together, they represent two distinct yet parallel threads in the intellectual history of Vienna, each leaving a lasting impact on their respective fields.

‚ÄúHEAVEN, VIENNA MINE, LAUGHTER AND MUSIC AND STARS THAT SHINE, WONDERFUL CITY WHERE I BELONG, OF HER I SING MY SONG‚Äù[VIENNA, CITY OF MY DREAMS, RUDOLF SIECZYNSKI]
by Anja Mayer
Vienna, as one of the most vibrant cultural hotspots in Europe, has for centuries been home to many artists, composers, thinkers and poets from all corners of the continent. Over the years, the city‚Äôs lively intellectual and artistic scene, and unique culture has served as a catalyst for creative processes and exchanges, that left an impact all over the world. Besides being the birthplace of revolutionary breakthroughs in the fields of psychology, literature and the arts, Vienna especially had an important influence on the evolution of classical music.
From 1780 until 1824, a period which is sometimes also referred to as the Viennese Classics, composers like Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Josef Haydn and Ludwig van Beethoven revolutionized the European music scene. It was during that time that music evolved from background entertainment during social gatherings to a highly respected cultural form of art with an even higher social significance, earning Vienna the reputation as the capital of composition. Since then many more accomplished composers, musicians and artist have emerged from the city‚Äôs cultural scene onto the world stage.
To salute Vienna‚Äôs unique and extraordinary musical legacy, the Carnegie Hall in New York City will host a three-week citywide festival in the spring of 2014. The event will feature symphonic and operatic masterpieces, chamber music and a variety of new music that is emerging from the Austrian capital. The central piece of the festival is a concert series by the renowned Vienna Philharmonic orchestra. Their residency, which will include seven concert performances, will mark only the second time in history that the Viennese musicians have performed opera in concert at Carnegie Hall. The festival will extend throughout New York City and will feature other musical highlights such as Beethoven‚Äôs violin sonata cycle, Schubert‚Äôs Die sch√∂ne M√ºllerin and the premiere of new work by Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas. Apart from concert performances, the celebration will combine a variety of art disciplines including film screenings and art exhibitions at different cultural venues throughout the city. The kick-off event of the festival will be the annual traditional Viennese Opera Ball at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel on February 21, 2014.
For more information: www.carnegiehall.org/vienna/

‚ÄúMy dream writing room would be the Imperial Library in Vienna.‚Äù Fran Lebowitz
The word ‚Äúcosy‚Äù means different things to different people. For some, it‚Äôs sipping a cup of chai in the comfort of home. For others, it‚Äôs watching your favorite series without interruptions. It might be talking to friends or family about something meaningful, or spending quality time with loved ones. In other words, it‚Äôs that moment when you‚Äôre truly yourself ‚Äî when you‚Äôre not bound by any obligation, when you‚Äôre quietly loving yourself, and when you‚Äôre living, not just existing.
I try to find these cosy moments in my home, and today that moment came while painting a memory from Vienna. The art is far from perfect and still incomplete. The art is inspired from a church which was across our apartment in Vienna. I snapped a photo, thinking that one day I might paint it. Today, I finally did. When you visit a city, you carry it with you forever and Vienna is that city for me. Isn‚Äôt is beautiful you need not pay money to be an artist or a writer. Your own memories are enough. All you need is a pen and a paper and you keep doing it again and again as if that‚Äôs how you will attain salvation.
I‚Äôll take my time with this. Watercolor isn‚Äôt my favorite medium, but I will try to do my best to paint the memory.
February Weeds & Wildflowers Writing Prompt is Cosy. Sharing today‚Äôs memory for the same. Thanks to the editors of Weeds and Wildflowers publication for the space for my rambling.

Vienna ooo nah nah, half of our heart is in Vienna ooo nah nah. üéµ
Leaving Santorini was an event ‚Äî the airport was not built to support multiple departing flights and has the worst airport logistics we‚Äôve ever seen in our lives! In short, it was chaotic, people were shoving, kids were crying, there was yelling and no space or direction to where you should go‚Ä¶ so when we landed in Vienna‚Ä¶ it was the most incredible thing.
It was silent, organized, we could flush toilet paper (!!! we didn‚Äôt know Greece has poor plumbing‚Ä¶) we had McDonalds following Maeghan‚Äôs goal to eat it in every country we visit, we downloaded our fav podcasts (and Maeghan has a cameo in one!!), and facetimed family from a bus(!!!!) with real wifi and saw our family in full-resolution‚Ä¶ no more pixelated heads :D
And that was all just in the first 30 mins of being here, this city got even better after that.
We explored the beautiful buildings, the meaningful history and ate / drank the best things. Vienna is pretty awesome and we will definitely come back.
See more on our website www.alittledetour.caüåè‚úàÔ∏èüë´
Sisi of Bavaria was Empress of Austria and Queen of Hungary who had this building constructed for her and her husband to live in with plans to build an identical building across the way. She was sadly assassinated (by accident!) in 1898 and her husband stopped construction due to a broken heart.
Later in history, this Imperial Palace was used by Adolf Hitler to perform his famous speech, proclaiming Austria as part of the Third Reich.
And today, all the buildings are in such great shape‚Ä¶ looking back, I think the Parthenon in Greece may have looked similar to this one back in the day üòÉ
Meet Claire üëã she is an incredible woman we had the pleasure of meeting (by eaves-dropping and totally striking a cool Canadian conversation‚Ä¶ üòä). She is an opera singer who is studying her masters in Austria. She shared a few hours with us talking about her work, some challenges and the philosophies she lives by as she trains to as a Opera singer. It was such an inspiring conversation. Claire had such a love/passion for Opera, so much so, that she wanted to share with us and gave us two free tickets to a show!!!
We ended up going our last night in Vienna, and it was pure magic.
So there‚Äôs a thing in Vienna, where you can go see the Opera with standing tickets. They only cost 3 euros!

Title: Silent New Year‚Äôs Eve in Vienna (Austria)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Are there still fireworks in a famously quiet, central residential area in Austria‚Äôs capital?
New Year‚Äôs Eve in Vienna used to sound like being thrown into a war zone‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa staccato of explosions with sound volume close to or above the pain threshold for hours and hours and hours ‚Ä¶ But those days are gone. Over the last few years, the change of years became relatively silent in Austria‚Äôs capital. Officially, the main reason is that Vienna has forbidden all pyrotechnics above class F1 (anything children are legally allowed to use) within city borders. Further, supermarkets no longer sell fireworks, citizens are more concerned about the environmental and climate impact, and dog owners (Austrians cherish their furry family members) have become more vocal.
This is especially true for my residential area ‚Äî the Nordbahnhofviertel. This rather new part of the city, although very central, is quiet as can be. It is traffic-calmed, has many driving bans, and sometimes you get the impression that there are more cargo bikes than cars. And, predominantly inhabited by young families, it is not a party hotspot by far.
Anyway, even there, fireworks and firecrackers still exist, and people either love or hate them. Depending on the side, the reported noise quantification fluctuates between Animal Crossing and Call of Duty scenarios. Unsatisfying as this is, I have decided to put a little more data into this discussion.
I have used the mobile app Night Hark to measure the sound volume during the night and to detect the sound of fireworks/firecrackers. Therefore, I have placed an iPhone 8 next to the closed window in my apartment on the third floor and let it record the night. I put it into my home office room with closed doors, so there might be some noise contamination from my family and me, but it shouldn‚Äôt be too bad. After all, I can code there without being disturbed by my kids playing Ninja in the living room shouting the name of Jutsus.
I will report the sound volume in decibels full scale. Since mobile phones use digital microphones, one only gets the sound pressure level relative to the maximum signal capacity of the microphone (= 0 dbfs). I don‚Äôt know how much that is for an iPhone, but my best guess would be to put it somewhere close to 100 dB. The app would also return an A-filtered measure, which is tuned to the hearing spectrum of humans, but since this is at least partly about animals and I have no clue if A-filtered would be appropriate, I stick with dbfs¬†(if you know more about this, please let me know in the comments).
Before we get to the results, a last help for interpreting them: Loudness is not linear. An increase of 10 dB corresponds to a perceived doubling of loudness. So 60 dB is double as loud as 50 dB.
We can see in Fig. 1, which displays the max sound pressure level per minute, that there is a build-up till midnight when loudness jumps to its max value and stays there for around half an hour before ebbing down. During the build-up there seem to be two local maxima at around 19:00 and 21:00 ‚Äî maybe those were fireworks for very small and small children who cannot stay awake till midnight. After 2 o‚Äôclock, it is practically quiet.
Further, the scale was never maxed out with 0 dbfs, so the phone could have been able to quantify even louder sounds. The loudest minute was 0:32 with -17.8 dbfs. If my guess of a max value of 100 dB is correct, this would correspond to 82.3 dB, or for reference, a motorcycle or a crying baby. Not quiet, but only an eighth of the loudness of a disco at 110 dB or a 32nd of the pain threshold at 130 dB.
Honing in on fireworks and firecrackers, I looked at the count of either fireworks or explosion classifications with a score greater or equal to .05. (Night Hark uses YAMNet, a neural network, that can classify sound snippets of 0.975 seconds into 500+ categories. Each sound category gets a score between 0 and 1, with greater values indicating a higher likelihood that the snippet belongs to the specific category). Since the sound behind the window is somewhat muffled and the time resolution is limited, this is no 1:1 representation of the actual number of bangs, but the proportions between time-frames should be valid.
In Fig. 2, we can again see a clear peak at midnight, a local maximum at¬†20:30, and a hard stop at 02:00.
Whether this is a lot or quasi-nothing lies in the ear of the listener, but I am sure this is comparatively silent for New Year‚Äôs Eve in a metropolis. I am interested in your experiences and thoughts on that, so please let me know in the comments.
If you want to look at the data, you can find it here.
Night Hark, the app I have used for the sound measurements, is available on iOS and Android.
If you appreciate this post, here are three things you can do to support my work:
1 ‚Äî Give this story a CLAP üëè2 ‚Äî SUBSCRIBE to my upcoming stories3 ‚Äî Buy me a coffee ‚òï

Title: What Wonders are in Vienna?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Keenan‚Äôs Adventures, travels, and wordly outtings

--
Listen
Share
It is the curse of my life that I can move faster than the seasons, hop between continents overnight and change countries like fashion but I can never escape seasonal allergies. I thought coming to Vienna from Croatia would be a good change of climate and that change of seasons would get rid of my allergies. Alas, the springtime pains continue.
I spent two nights in Vienna with enough time on the first day to walk around the city and take pictures of all the baroque and neoclassical architecture. I started off at the Wein Rathaus (city hall) and then wandered through a rose garden to the Ephesos Museum and later arrived at St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral. What I noticed the most along the streets were the decorations at the top and corners of the buildings.
Many of the older buildings have statues sculpted and moulded to tell a story that I do not know. I wondered if these semiotics remained relevant today and if knowing them would make the buildings any more significant or if they‚Äôre just meaningless decoration. Somehow I doubt it.
In Invisible Cities by Itali Calvino Marco Polo says, ‚ÄúYou take delight not in a city‚Äôs seven or seventy wonders, but in the answer it gives to a question of yours.‚Äù To which Khan replies, ‚Äúor the questions it asks you, forcing you to answer, like Thebes through the mouth of the Sphinx.‚Äù
Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral is the jewel of the city and it was kinda cool but also less impressive than I expected. Mass was in session so I couldn‚Äôt walk the nave but it wasn‚Äôt as tall nor as ground as other cathedrals I‚Äôve visited.
On the south side is a tower 343 steps up to the bell tower. The entrance is sort of hidden in the corner. I thought there‚Äôd be more to it but it was literally a single spiral staircase going up and up and up. The only break was for the bell room, sans bell, and at the top it was a chamber to buy souvenirs with small windows on the four sides. I thought the cityscape would be more interesting but there wasn‚Äôt much to see. The roof had an interesting tiled pattern on it but even that was difficult to see from this vantage.
Since it was going to rain the next day I decided to check out some nearby parks to see if they were interesting. I walked along the canals and came to Augarten park which had a distinctly familiar tower. It was only after reading the plaque that I remembered seeing it in a YouTube video. These are two of six World War 2 anti-aircraft towers built to protect the city. One is a command/communication tower and the other is for the guns.
After my thesis I‚Äôve taken an interest in the architecture of memorials and dilapidated structures. The architecture of this war has been preserved as a reminder to the horrors of forced labour under the social nationalist regime ‚Äî but it got me thinking about how we preserve old and culturally important of structures. The towers are clearly decaying and concrete is spalling off. Around the base is a fence. They no longer guard the city but being surrounded by parkland are evident along the city skyline.
At first I wondered why the structure isn‚Äôt open to the public to climb and explore. Since it‚Äôs from a recent war and not a long ago castle or fortress this probably isn‚Äôt appropriate. It‚Äôs also apparently dangerous according to the youtube video because of a failed attempt to destroy it.
But to leave it to decay seems like a lost opportunity. Why isn‚Äôt there art? Murals or ribbons or lights that in the immediate term express peace juxtaposed to war. I‚Äôd first seen the towers from the top of St. Stephen‚Äôs cathedral. I‚Äôd thought them a fortress worth checking out. I suppose I was partly correct, but if they had been colourful and less stoic, maybe there would be a better relationship to the city. In the long term, seeing vegetation slowly consume the structure might be a suitable future. This would be better then the current state of decay as pigeon on roosts but I suspect realistically they will fall into disrepair to a state where the government has to demolish them.
I found this online, https://www.worldbook.com/behind-the-headlines/Mythic-Monday-The-Riddle-of-the-Sphinx:
The Sphinx is found in both ancient Egyptian and Greek mythology. In the story of Oedipus, the goddess Hera sent the Sphinx to plague the people of the ancient city of Thebes. This was punishment for an ancient crime, possibly the failure to atone for the crimes of a former king of Thebes. The Sphinx sat perched on a mountain cliff nearby the ancient city. The creature guarded Thebes with a riddle that she had learned from the Muses. Each time a traveler failed to solve her riddle, she devoured them, effectively preventing anyone from leaving or entering the city.
The riddle? ‚ÄúWhat being has four legs, then two, and then three?‚Äù Some accounts write it, ‚ÄúWhat has four legs in the morning, two at noon, and three in the evening?‚Äù
After many people guessed incorrectly and were killed, the king of Thebes announced that he would give the kingdom to anyone who could solve the riddle. The road past Mount Phicion, where the Sphinx awaited her victims, was strewn with the bones of people who had failed to find the right answer. Eventually, Oedipus, fleeing Corinth, solved the riddle. He answered, ‚ÄúMan, who crawls on all fours as a baby, then walks on two legs, and finally needs a cane in old age.‚Äù Upon hearing the correct answer, the Sphinx jumped from the cliff to her death. The plague of Thebes was lifted.
It would seem that Vienna is asking me what wonders I like while simultaneously holding me captive. But where the riddle has a simple answer, the question might be rhetoric. I‚Äôm not convinced that the answer is a wonder at all‚Ä¶
The wonders of Vienna seem to palaces and the most prominent is the Sch√∂nbrunn Palace. It was an 18th century summer home for the emperor and there are two tours of the inside. These tours have been scripted to move the highest volume of tourists through in the least time. Measured by the number of rooms (22 or 40) the latter takes just 50 minutes. Both are accompanied by audio guides to shuffle along the cattle and since photography isn‚Äôt allowed, there‚Äôs little reason to linger.
I was once again sniffled by being too old to get the student discount and ended up paying more because I visited the Sisi museum but didn‚Äôt get a combined ticket (the student rates would have been cheaper). The Sisi museum was more interesting because the second half was a story about the empress and had a narrative to follow. In both places I was surprised by the lack of luxury on the interior since there are so many other decorated buildings with statues and faces on the facades in the city. This might be because the emperor Franz Joseph was known for leading a simple life devoted to running the country. Another strange aspect of the two residence I saw, at the summer palace and in the city, were that the main rooms didn‚Äôt seem to be located central to the buildings. It was as if the emperor and empress lived to the side. There was a model of the palace and where the royal residence were was far removed from the centre.
While the buildings were somewhat of a disappointment, the Schonburnn gardens behind the summer palace was nice and free. I particularly enjoyed the Roman Ruins which were an artificial construct fashionable during the 18th century with the rise of Romanticism that symbolizes the decline of revered civilizations and the desire to preserve relics. Interestingly, romanticism intentionally creates ruins from scratch as a point of interest in the garden but does not actually preserve anything.
At the top of the hill the Gloriette Schloss Sch√∂nbrunn is an observation pavilion that looked cool but I didn‚Äôt purchase a ticket to go to the rooftop. Instead I walked around the base and then made my way back down the hill. Though it is a symmetrical garden, I was kind of surprised that the most colour was on the wings in the rose gardens. Between the palace and the hilltop was a fountain and just grass fields.
The architecture in Vienna was interesting but I found myself more interested in the typical 5 storey housing typology than the palaces or monuments. Many of these housing buildings were distinctly recognizable as Germanic and I would have liked to study the buildings and statues decorating the top more closely. Unfortunately the Airbnb I stayed was the ground floor of a grimy building of little historical significance. Other than a water fountain in the hallway, now brackish, there was little evidence of how people might have lived before a mid-century renovation. I made a poor selection in this AirBnB to save a few bucks. Neither did it help the war on allergies that the place had grimy floors or that the room smelled musty. After two nights I was very happy to leave.
I realized in my next destination that what draws me the most isn‚Äôt the seven or seventy wonders of the city but what might have been there before.
--
--

Vienna has a register for its trees. I learned this through my favourite crowd-sourcing app, iNaturalist. It allows identifying surrounding plants and animals by simply making a picture and uploading it through the app. A community of fellow users and iNaturalist algorithms suggest possible identifications.
I was scrolling on my way to give a talk but I still had some time, so I went into a park to observe some Viennese urban wildlife. One of my observations was a tree (probably poplar).
The observation is registered in iNaturalist as observation #22987310. Not long after uploading the images to iNaturalist I got the feedback that I should have listed the observation as a cultivated tree. ‚ÄúMy‚Äù tree was apparently planted and it is 45 years old and has the tree registry number 30.
It is these kinds of interactions and data linkages, that makes me love iNaturalist and its community.

Title: The Wonder of Vienna
Content:
Sign up

Discovering the History and Culture of Austria
Vienna, the imperial capital of Austria, is a city of striking contrasts. With its stunning architecture, rich history, and vibrant cultural scene, it‚Äôs no wonder that it has become a top destination for travelers from around the world. In this article, we will take you on a journey through the wonder of Vienna, exploring its history, culture, and beauty.
Vienna‚Äôs history stretches back over 2,000 years, and the city is steeped in rich culture and tradition. From the Habsburg dynasty to the Austro-Hungarian Empire, Vienna has played an important role in shaping European history. Visitors can explore this history by visiting landmarks such as Sch√∂nbrunn Palace, the former summer residence of the Habsburgs, or the Hofburg Palace, the winter residence of the Austrian emperors.
The architecture of Vienna is equally impressive, with stunning examples of Baroque, Gothic, and Art Nouveau styles. The city‚Äôs main cathedral, St. Stephen‚Äôs, is a beautiful example of Gothic architecture, while the Belvedere Palace is a masterpiece of Baroque design. The Jugendstil style, known as Art Nouveau in the rest of Europe, is also prominent in Vienna, with many buildings featuring decorative facades and intricate ironwork.
Vienna is also renowned for its music and cultural scene. The city was home to famous composers such as Mozart, Beethoven, and Strauss, and visitors can explore their legacies by visiting places such as the Vienna State Opera or attending a classical concert at the Musikverein. Vienna is also home to a vibrant contemporary arts scene, with galleries and museums showcasing both established and up-and-coming artists.
Foodies will find plenty to love in Vienna as well, with its rich culinary traditions and world-renowned coffee culture. From the famous Sachertorte chocolate cake to hearty traditional dishes such as Wiener Schnitzel, Vienna is a city that is sure to please the palate. And of course, no visit to Vienna would be complete without a visit to one of its many traditional coffeehouses, where visitors can relax and soak up the city‚Äôs atmosphere.
Beyond the city itself, Vienna is surrounded by stunning natural beauty, with the Austrian Alps just a short distance away. Visitors can take day trips to picturesque towns such as Hallstatt or explore the nearby vineyards and sample some of Austria‚Äôs world-famous wines.
When planning a trip to Vienna, there are a few must-see sights and experiences that should be at the top of any traveler‚Äôs list. First and foremost, a visit to Sch√∂nbrunn Palace is a must. This stunning palace, with its beautifully landscaped gardens, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and offers visitors a glimpse into the lives of the Habsburgs.
Another must-see attraction is St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral, the city‚Äôs main cathedral and one of the most impressive examples of Gothic architecture in Europe. Visitors can climb to the top of the cathedral for a stunning view over the city.
For those interested in the arts, a visit to the Belvedere Palace is highly recommended. This stunning Baroque palace houses one of the world‚Äôs most important collections of Austrian art, including works by Gustav Klimt and Egon Schiele.
Finally, no visit to Vienna would be complete without a visit to one of the city‚Äôs traditional coffeehouses. These atmospheric cafes, such as Caf√© Central or Demel, offer a taste of old-world Vienna and are a great place to relax and people-watch.
Vienna is considered one of Europe‚Äôs most beautiful and culturally rich cities for good reason. From its stunning architecture and world-class museums to its vibrant music scene and famous coffeehouses, there is no shortage of things to see and do in this historic city. Whether you‚Äôre a history buff, an art lover, or simply someone who enjoys the finer things in life, Vienna is sure to captivate and inspire you. So why not plan a trip to this magical city and experience its wonder for yourself?

Title: A look at Vienna through two of it‚Äôs best Caf√©s
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
A week ago I was in Vienna, Austria for 48 hours. It was a short but meaningful trip.
The city is renowned for its ‚Äúcaf√© culture.‚Äù A very particular collection of biases and instincts that shape the behaviors one can see.
The most iconic example of this particular collection is Caf√© Central, a classical, old world caf√©. Here‚Äôs an area near the front windows.
The caf√© is famous, in part, because it was Adolf Hitler‚Äôs favorite when he lived in Vienna. Joseph Stalin‚Äôs too. In fact, for a time in 1913, Stalin, Hitler, Trotsky and Freud all lived within a kilometer of this meeting place.
Needless to say, the caf√© is not a beacon of modernity.
The coffee was bitter and bland.
The service was (intentionally) bad. Half an hour before black coffee arrived.
The people were uniformly white and mostly old.
They were gossiping and gawking. Looking for and at those that didn‚Äôt fit the narrative of early 20th century Vienna.
On Monday, my 3pm flight allowed just enough time for one more Viennese caf√©.
We went in a different direction this time. To a ‚Äúthird wave‚Äù coffee shop located near the University of Vienna called Coffee Pirates.
It couldn‚Äôt have been further from what we‚Äôd seen at Caf√© Central.
The service was brisk and friendly.
The coffee was made slowly, to order, and with care.
The patrons were working, learning, building.
The presentation was thoughtful and generous.
From the moment we opened the door to the moment it closed behind us, were constantly invited to participate in the story that Coffee Pirates was telling about coffee. A story about community, about the way we connect.
Caf√© Central was telling a very different story about coffee. One much more steeped in tradition for tradition‚Äôs sake. One about the premium of exclusion and the value of difference.
Caf√© Central was a story about the ways things were.
Coffee Pirates is a story about the ways things will be.
I know where I want to spend my time.

Content:

It‚Äôs been a while since my last blog! I‚Äôve been taking some time to reflect on my summer, spend time with family and friends and have been swamped with Givesie and participating as a vendor at many local Portland events during the last few months.
But I am back this week and wanted to share with you my amazing trip to Europe this summer! I got the chance to visit Vienna, Austria and Zurich and Lucerne, Switzerland with my parents. It was by far one of the best experiences of my life! And to be able to share those memories with my mom and dad is priceless.
Vienna has this richness in history and architecture; the museums, the palaces, the statues, the cathedrals and gardens are breathtakingly beautiful and so intricate in detail! One of my favorite sights to see was the St. Stephan‚Äôs Cathedral, the mother church of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Vienna and the current Romanesque and Gothic form of the cathedral, which was completed in the year 1160. It is the most important religious building in Vienna, ‚Äúhas borne witness to many important events in Habsburg and Austrian history and has, with its multi-coloured tile roof, become one of the city‚Äôs most recognizable symbols.‚Äù Walking inside I was immediately in awe of the stunning, yet dark and dramatic beauty of the interior. Words could not describe the sense of peace, calm and excitement I felt all at once walking through.
The Schonbrunn Palace is one of the busiest tourist sites to see in Vienna. It is a neoclassical style palace and was built during the reign of empress Maria Theresa and was also the home of Franz Joseph, the longest-reigning emperor of Austria and King of Hungary, along with his wife Duchess Elisabeth of Bavaria. I loved touring through this palace, it was decorated exactly how it would have looked when it was first built. I felt like I had gone back in time, envisioning what it would have been like to be alive and living during the 18th/19th centuries.
Another one of my favorite places to visit was the Belvedere Palace. Consisting of two Baroque palaces, the Upper and Lower and set in the Baroque park landscape and the Belvedere garden, it houses the Belvedere museum. Walking through the museum I was surrounded by the most stunning pieces of historical art done by some of the most famous artists from around the world and from centuries ago! Definitely a sight to see!
As we wrapped up our tour of the museum we worked up an appetite ‚Äî so, mom, dad and I had to stop at the cutest little caf√© on the palace grounds for a late afternoon latte and pastry! So. Good.
After our amazing time in Vienna, we were off to Zurich and Lucerne, both are beautiful cities surrounded by stunning mountain ranges, lakes and charming medieval towns.
The train ride my parents and I took from Vienna to Zurich was probably one of my most favorite parts of the trip! It was an eight hour ride, but felt so much shorter! We had such a great time chatting, taking pictures, eating delicious meals, passing by and stopping through small towns, seeing the gorgeous mountainous scenery and huge lakes and rivers. We spent just a few days in Zurich, seeing Old Town, browsing through local boutique shops, shopping for souvenirs, as well as taking a day trip to Lucerne along with a boat ride on the lake. Even though it was a short time ‚Äî it was absolutely perfect! I remember sitting outside this adorable French outdoor cafe by the lake and enjoying an afternoon espresso with my parents, while people watching ‚Äî and thinking to myself ‚Äî I can‚Äôt believe I am actually here and enjoying this beautiful moment with my mom and dad that I will cherish forever.
This trip gave me such perspective and such an appreciation for travel and exploration! Being in a new environment, new people, new culture. There is such a big world out there to see and experience. We tend to get caught up in our normal routines, the everyday tasks, work, etc‚Ä¶and tend to forget that there is so much to appreciate in life! Sometimes you just have to get out of your comfort zone and your norm to be able to see things in a new light. xx
--
--
Designer, Founder & CEO of Givesie.

A city that reminds me
Of a town,
Vienna,
The one with cool winds
And cooler heads.
On a Sunday,
Everyone gets a break,
The city shuts down,
As if on a curfew.
No shoppers or eaters
Roaming on the streets,
All establishments shut
And everyone stays home.
For an outsider
Vienna seems forlorn,
Like their city did during the lockdown.
But for insiders,
It is a paradise
As they enjoy time with family
At home.
Even on a Monday,
There is no hurry,
No running behind a bus or a train
No speed walking down the pathways.
Those going to the office or school,
Stroll at their pace,
Enjoying the winds
And the sun,
And their coffee in breaks.
They work at their pace
Enjoying the task at hand,
Undisturbed by the distractions,
As if in a mystic flow.
They cycle, calm and slow,
Not in a hurry to reach their destination
For them, the journey
Seems to be their destination.
Not formal wear,
No big cars or big frills
Just them in their shorts and ts
Going about their day
Like it‚Äôs a treat.
Living their lives
In a pause,
They teach me
How to take a break,
And learn how to walk slow,
To enjoy every moment,
Whether on vacation,
Or at work.
They teach me
To lessen my agendas
To leave behind the past
And let the future rest
To be in the present,
In this here and now.
I learn to sit still,
Immerse myself in the now,
Enjoy my surroundings,
And the words I read;
Stopping for a coffee
Every now and then.

Title: In Vienna, the waiter is King
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This is not a real travel blog. There are no product reviews, no paid promotions and you will find no inside information about secret backpacking locations you can‚Äôt find for yourself online. This is a collection of our expectations and disappointments, rants and realisations.

--
Listen
Share
Like Atlas, with the weight of the world on his shoulders, wait staff in Vienna take their job very, very seriously.
Vienna: the capital of Austria, home of the Hasburg dynasty, old architecture and tardy, poker faced, sarcastic wait staff.
In one of Europe‚Äôs oldest cities, with a long and rich cultural history, and a reputation as one of the world‚Äôs centres of art and learning, the wait staff rule supreme. Long waits for service, being ignored and a general attitude of low level irritation that you want to be a customer seems to be the norm.
Ancient architecture = posh attitude
One travel brochure (The Free Map For Young and Clever People) proclaims that in Vienna, ‚ÄúThe waiter is king. Don‚Äôt be surprised if the waiters are unfriendly - not the guest is king, he is. Treat him as your superior and he will reward you.‚Äù The brochure also claims that ‚Äúwaiters NEVER smile‚Äù and that for tipping ‚Äú5-10% of the bill is the amount the king expects from his subjects.‚Äù
The advice in The Free Map for Young And Clever People is ridiculously honest and self-deprecating.
To begin with you are annoyed and maybe offended by this behaviour. But, after a few experiences you realise that it‚Äôs not actually you personally the waiter hates, it‚Äôs everybody ‚Äì perhaps it‚Äôs a persona they all adopt as part of their profession or as a survival tactic against drunk and obnoxious tourists who don‚Äôt speak German.
My personal experiences of this phenomenon were being told I had ordered children‚Äôs beer when choosing a 330ml sized glass (normal serving size in my country) instead of a ¬Ω litre. My bad. Another was overhearing the same waiter yell at a patron asking them if they wanted to see a menu. Theoretically, this sounds like he was being helpful and doing his job. However, in person, his tone, body language and glare revealed the true nature of his passive aggressive overture. What he actually said nonverbally was ‚Äúbuy something to eat or f**K off‚Äù.
When your office is this plush you might be forgiven for developing an arrogant attitude.
A further experience was when buying a Kaserkrainer (vienesse hotdog) from a street vendor in the early hours of the morning. The vendor must have been earning significantly less than the barman and really needed the customers, but felt the need to finish his entire cigarette¬†before¬†deining¬†to¬†serve¬†us. He then spent less time than it took to smoke it heating a sausage on the grill, before wrapping it and throwing it on the counter for me to collect. The patience we were expected to show while waiting was not reciprocal. While we fumbled uncoordinated and inebriated for the correct change, his bloodshot eyes glared with annoyance. How dare we bother him to prepare his advertised victuals and deign to give him a few euros¬†for¬†his¬†disgruntled¬†efforts.
This attitude is strange considering that you want to spend your money at the establishment where said wait staff are employed. You might think they would be welcoming of a tourist who wants to donate them money. You may highlight the link between your custom and their wages ‚Äì but you would be wrong. The waiter just has no f**ks to give about you and your desires to eat or drink or be treated like a human being.
‚ÄúLet them eat cake‚Äù‚Ää- Marie Antionette was a Hasburg and probably developed the attitude that cost her life while growing up in Vienna.
Sometimes this apathy worked in our favour. For example, when the bus driver was in danger of having to do something untoward, such as turn in his seat, converse with you and maybe issue you a ticket. Instead, it was easier for him to just lift his eyes, wave his hand dismissively towards the general direction of the back of the bus and grunt something. We interpreted this as there would be no charge, but it may have meant - ‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt give a s**t.‚Äù I doubt he would have come to our defence if an undercover ticket check had taken place.
Advice for ‚ÄòActing like a local'‚Ää‚Äî ‚ÄúBe Grumpy‚Äù
The Free Map for Young and Clever People makes an effort to explain why the Viennesse hate on life. Under the heading ‚ÄòAct like a Local‚Äô it was suggested that you ‚Äúbe grumpy‚Äù. Supposedly, it is ‚Äúmandatory‚Äù for ‚Äúoriginal Vienesse to complain if the bus is one minute late or the weather is too hot/cold/wet/sunny. This ‚Äúmentality‚Äù (general bad attitude) was justified as being part of the rich Vienesse culture and is based on hundreds of years of historical precedent and practice.
Back in the day (16-18th Centuries), Vienna was the home of the Hasburg Dynasty and the centre of several empires. As such it was a center of commerce, education, construction etc, and developed a large bureaucracy which served the monarchy and employed half the population of the city. Everybody knows that a high standard of living, steady employment and job security suck, so it is understandable that these unlucky civil servants developed a negative attitude.
Members of the Hasburg dynasty pretty much ruled most of Europe in the 16th‚Ää- 18th centuries
According to the Free Map for Young and Clever People this explains why wait staff, and more generally everyone (especially if they had an ancestor who worked for the government) has the historical right to be grumpy, rude or generally a dick.
Other historical facts from the Free Map include how after WWII ‚Äúall the Nazis miraculously disappear and the population suffers a collective loss of memory as far as the last 7 years are concerned.‚Äù
This appeal to history is obviously a bullsh**t excuse to act like a jerk. More likely, people being people, they could not leave their work at work and the hierarchal structure of a feudal bureaucracy permeated into their attitudes and behaviour outside of their jobs. Add a mix of simian tribalism or pack behaviour and next thing everyone is looking down their noses at anyone else their social standing allows them to ‚Äì and treating them accordingly.
What is mystifying is that in contemporary Vienna, a city where the Arts and Humanities are cultivated, this is a standard of behaviour that some aspire to. Or perhaps it‚Äôs as simple as:
‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt like a person, it‚Äôs because they remind you of something you don‚Äôt like about yourself.‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäSigmund Freud, father of modern psychology and resident of Vienna, before being forced to fleeing prior to WWII.
--
--
This is not a real travel blog. There are no product reviews, no paid promotions and you will find no inside information about secret backpacking locations you can‚Äôt find for yourself online. This is a collection of our expectations and disappointments, rants and realisations.

Title: From Pittsburgh to Vienna: How A Steelers‚Äô Fan Became Co-Owner of the Vienna Vikings
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Football has always been more than a pastime for me. I grew up just outside of Pittsburgh in the 1970s ‚Äî a golden era for football, especially for Steelers‚Äô fans. Between 1974 and 1979, the Steelers won four Super Bowls ‚Äî what a time to be part of the Steeler Nation! And for a child coming of age in Western Pennsylvania, football wasn‚Äôt just a sport ‚Äî it was part of my DNA.
As I grew into adulthood and my job took me all over the world, I never gave up on the Pittsburgh Steelers ‚Äî to this day, I remain a devoted fan with season tickets. Of course, today, I live in Vienna, Austria, and don‚Äôt often make it to Pittsburgh, but my children go to games, and I join them whenever I can. Fortunately, I found another way to get my daily football fix: the Vienna Vikings.
When I was presented with the opportunity to become co-owner (and lawyer) of the Vienna Vikings, one of Europe‚Äôs most outstanding American football teams, I didn‚Äôt think twice. While soccer is unquestionably the most popular sport in Europe, the idea of promoting American football in Vienna appealed to me on several levels.
On a personal level, I‚Äôm a huge football fan, no matter what continent it‚Äôs being played on. And to have the opportunity to move from fan, aka spectator, to actually being involved in the day-to-day decisions and management of a team ‚Äî it‚Äôs something of a dream come true. Over the years, I even built close friendships with players like the late Franco Harris, a Pittsburgh legend, and we worked on a few business projects together.
On a professional level, the investment potential is enormous, not unlike a burgeoning startup. While the Vienna Vikings are an established team with a long and proud tradition in Austria, they hadn‚Äôt yet made an impact at the international level when I joined. The Vikings had been a national amateur powerhouse and only recently joined the international European League of Football (ELF), a professional European league. I felt this was a prime moment to join the team and help it expand from the somewhat limiting national level into an international high-flier.
Of course, as with any startup, there are challenges and questions along the way. How will the Vikings compete on an international level? How will we get the best players? Will fans remain loyal to the team in the new league?All of these questions, I understood, could be addressed with strategy, forward planning, and strong leadership. And as a lawyer and a lifelong football fan, I felt I had something to contribute.
Austria has an impressive football development system, with nearly 1,000 players at the high school level working their way up from amateur leagues to the professional level. This offers a vast pool of local talent when it comes time for the draft.
ELF rules stipulate that teams can only draft four American players ‚Äî this rule keeps the playing field fair (pun intended) and prevents an unsustainable ‚Äúarms race‚Äù for foreign stars, which is what doomed previous European football leagues.
Unlike some teams in ELF who rely heavily on their American players, who often bring to the table NFL-caliber talent, the Vienna Vikings rely on a mix of local, European, and American talent.
That combination matters. Last season, for example, we were playing in Poland ‚Äî behind all game, without our starting quarterback. Even our backup got injured mid-game. That‚Äôs when our third-string QB, a 40-year-old who hadn‚Äôt played professionally in years, stepped up. Against all odds, he led the final drive and won the game in the last 30 seconds. That‚Äôs the kind of resilience and depth we‚Äôre building.
American football in Europe is still catching up to the NFL ‚Äî there‚Äôs no denying that. But that‚Äôs also what makes this journey exciting. There‚Äôs an authenticity here, a real desire to achieve the highest possible level of professionalism.
Unlike soccer, which often skews male and rowdy in its European fan base, American football here is a family affair. You‚Äôll see parents and kids enjoying the game together ‚Äî a dynamic that‚Äôs helped the sport grow across different audiences. The fact that English is the sport‚Äôs official language also broadens the audience to include diverse people from different backgrounds.
I‚Äôm optimistic about the future of American football in Europe, both as a fan and as an investor. Last year, millions of people showed up and tuned in to watch the European championship game, the Eurobowl. The Vienna Vikings reached the final, though we came up just short. But the growing international audience is undeniable.
The Vienna Vikings, in particular, have a wide and expanding fan base that extends beyond Austria. Vienna‚Äôs historical role as a cultural capital draws in fans from Hungary, Poland, Slovenia, and beyond ‚Äî making the Vikings more than just Austria‚Äôs team.
We‚Äôre in discussions with several NFL teams about building strategic partnerships. The idea of an eventual NFL Europe division featuring cities like London, Frankfurt, and hopefully Vienna is no longer a pipe dream. It makes strategic sense for the league, and we believe Vienna is in a ‚Äúsweet spot‚Äù to be a part of that future.
Personally, I believe football remains a source of joy. I love the sport, enjoy it with my children whenever possible, and am fully invested in the Vikings‚Äô growth and expansion.
Yes, there‚Äôs still work to do. The NFL has set certain standards, and Europe needs to catch up. But the trajectory is clear. The enthusiasm is real. And the foundation we are building is solid.
And I‚Äôm proud to be part of it.
--
--
Husband, father, attorney, entrepreneur, diplomat, founder of Nagel & Associates LLC. Views my own. www.joel-nagel.com, nagel.attorney
