Share
Vienna is such a historic city known everywhere around the world for its art and culture. Here is an article that will help you to enjoy your trip in the capital of Austria.
Also, remember that I‚Äôm writing on Medium and that growing a huge community over there is very important for me. The name of my channel is ‚ÄúCl√©ment Delabruy√®re‚Äù so please follow my channel : https://medium.com/@clement.delabruyere
Vienna, the capital of Austria, is a fascinating city that blends history with modernism. Covering an area of around 414 km¬≤, it is home to almost 1.9 million inhabitants. With its cobbled streets, Baroque palaces and prestigious museums, Vienna is a true cultural and architectural gem.
The city is divided into 23 districts, each offering its own unique charm and ambience. Vienna plays a major geopolitical role as the headquarters of numerous international organizations, including the International Atomic Energy Agency and the United Nations Industrial Development Organization.
Classical music has a special place in Vienna‚Äôs history, having witnessed the birth of legendary composers such as Mozart, Beethoven and Strauss. Viennese waltzes and famous operas still thrill the city. Vienna is also renowned for its culinary tradition, with historic caf√©s offering delicious pastries such as sachertorte.
The Sch√∂nbrunn Palace, a former imperial residence, and St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral, a Gothic icon, are among the iconic sites to visit. Well-tended gardens and abundant green spaces, notably Prater Park, add to Viennese quality of life.
Vienna stands out for its concern for sustainability and quality of life, regularly topping world rankings in this area. Its efficient public transport system and green initiatives are testimony to this commitment.
In short, Vienna embodies an enchanting blend of historical heritage, artistic creativity and contemporary progress, making it a city that captivates the hearts and minds of those who discover it.
Vienna‚Äôs history dates back to antiquity, when the Romans established a military camp on the banks of the Danube around the 1st century AD. This camp, called Vindobona, was the starting point for the city‚Äôs development. Over the centuries, Vindobona flourished as a point of convergence for trade routes and cultures, benefiting from its strategic position at the crossroads of Central Europe.
In the Middle Ages, Vienna became an important political and cultural center under the Babenbergs, then the Habsburgs from the 13th century onwards. In 1440, Emperor Frederick III established the imperial residence in Vienna, laying the foundations for a long period of imperial grandeur.
The 16th century saw Vienna confronted with the challenges posed by the Ottoman wars, with the sieges of Vienna in 1529 and 1683. These sieges were crucial moments in the city‚Äôs history, marking unsuccessful Ottoman attempts to conquer Central Europe.
In the 18th and 19th centuries, Vienna became the heart of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, a major power in Europe. During this period, the city became a center of classical music and art, home to such geniuses as Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert. Baroque architecture flourished, giving rise to iconic buildings such as Sch√∂nbrunn Palace.
The 20th century was marked by upheaval, including two world wars and the annexation of Austria by Nazi Germany in 1938. After the Second World War, Vienna was divided into four zones of occupation, reflecting the Cold War period.
After the end of the occupation in 1955, Vienna regained its status as Austrian capital and diplomatic center. It hosted international organizations such as the UN and OPEC, consolidating its position in world affairs.
Today, Vienna continues to shine as a cosmopolitan city, blending its historic heritage with a dynamic modernity. The city has preserved its rich past while looking to the future, making it one of Europe‚Äôs leading cultural and intellectual destinations.
This imperial palace and its magnificent gardens are a symbol of the opulence of the Austrian Empire. Don‚Äôt miss a tour of the palace‚Äôs sumptuous rooms and a stroll through the well-kept gardens.
This iconic Gothic cathedral dominates downtown Vienna. Its elaborate architecture and impressive spire make it a must-see.
This Baroque complex comprises two palaces and superb gardens. It houses a remarkable collection of Austrian art, including works by Gustav Klimt, notably ‚ÄúThe Kiss‚Äù.
World-renowned for its superb acoustics and artistic performances, the opera house is an iconic venue for classical music lovers.
A former imperial palace, the Hofburg today houses several museums and institutions, including the Austrian National Library and the Sissi Museum.
This museum houses an exceptional collection of graphic art, including drawings, engravings and prints by masters such as Michelangelo, Rembrandt and D√ºrer.
These two museums are located side by side and offer impressive collections of art and natural history.
This city park is home to the famous Wiener Riesenrad, Vienna‚Äôs iconic Ferris wheel, as well as numerous attractions, restaurants and green spaces.
These venues represent just a fraction of what Vienna has to offer in terms of culture, history and entertainment. The city is full of treasures to explore, and each corner offers a unique and enriching experience for visitors.
An Austrian composer prodigy, Mozart is one of the most influential figures in classical music. He composed over 600 works, including operas, symphonies and concertos, making a profound impact on the European musical landscape.
The father of psychoanalysis, Freud revolutionized our understanding of human psychology. His theories on the unconscious, the Oedipus complex and the role of dreams left a lasting imprint on the human sciences.
German composer and pianist, although born in Bonn, Beethoven spent much of his life in Vienna. He is famous for his transition from Classicism to Romanticism, with emblematic works such as his 9th Symphony.
Austrian Symbolist painter and leading figure of the Vienna Secession, Klimt is known for his ornate portraits and bold works, including ‚ÄúThe Kiss‚Äù. He helped shape Art Nouveau and Modernism.
An Austrian Expressionist artist, Schiele was renowned for his provocative portraits and bold artistic vision. His unique style left a lasting imprint on 20th-century art, despite his untimely death at the age of 28.
These five figures left a significant mark on the history of art, music, psychology and culture in Vienna and around the world.

Title: Vienna waits for you.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The first time I heard Vienna by Billy Joel, I was on a train home after college, the world outside dipped in the amber light of a tired evening. I had just bombed an interview I had poured my soul into. My head was a whirlwind of spiralling doubts‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääabout my future, about whether I had what it takes, about everything. And then Vienna arrived‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot like a pop anthem or an uplifting chorus, but like a friend who sits with you in silence and tells you exactly what you need to hear.
‚ÄúSlow down, you crazy child
You‚Äôre so ambitious for a juvenile
But then if you‚Äôre so smart, tell me
Why are you still so afraid?‚Äù
In that moment, tears welled up ‚Äî not because of the failure, but because of how deeply the song understood the ache behind it. How it met me in the in-between, where so many of us live: driven but unsure, hopeful but exhausted.
That lyric wasn‚Äôt just about me. It was about a generation raised to hustle, to quantify their worth through grades, internships, side projects, and glowing LinkedIn posts. I had come to think of life as a ladder. But Vienna whispered of a different metaphor ‚Äî a garden, perhaps. Something that grows in time, with pauses, with pruning, with seasons of bloom and rest.
It reminded me of The Midnight Library by Matt Haig ‚Äî a book about a woman who, burdened by regret, stumbles upon a mystical library containing infinite versions of her life. Each book in the library reveals a different path she could have taken. The novel forces you to ask: what if the life you‚Äôre racing toward isn‚Äôt the one that would‚Äôve made you happy? What if the pauses, the missed exits, the so-called failures, are the very fabric of the life meant for you?
‚ÄúWhen will you realize, Vienna waits for you?‚Äù
In Joel‚Äôs metaphor, Vienna isn‚Äôt a destination you rush to. It‚Äôs the life that waits ‚Äî patiently, quietly ‚Äî for you to stop sprinting long enough to hear its music. It‚Äôs the version of you that grows not by doing more, but by understanding what enough feels like. That revelation mirrored the essence of The Midnight Library: the idea that you‚Äôre not a failure just because you‚Äôre not on someone else‚Äôs timeline.
The truth is, I didn‚Äôt need a new plan that day on the train. I needed perspective. I needed someone ‚Äî or something ‚Äî to tell me that I hadn‚Äôt missed my moment, that there are many doors yet to open. And Vienna, in its tender, piano-laced wisdom, did exactly that.
‚ÄúYou can get what you want or you can just get old
You‚Äôre gonna kick off before you even get halfway through‚Äù
Those words haunted me. Because I had never thought of burnout as a kind of death. But that‚Äôs what it is: the death of wonder, of joy, of being here. I was chasing a life so hard that I was forgetting to live the one already unfolding around me.
Billy Joel‚Äôs Vienna didn‚Äôt just soften my ambition ‚Äî it redefined it. It told me that ambition rooted in fear is a form of imprisonment. But ambition rooted in patience? In stillness? That‚Äôs purpose. That‚Äôs wisdom.
So now, when I feel that panic ‚Äî that rising tide of ‚Äúnot enough,‚Äù of ‚Äútoo late,‚Äù of ‚Äúwhat am I doing with my life?‚Äù ‚Äî I don‚Äôt drown. I return to the song. To Joel‚Äôs voice, gently guiding me back.
‚ÄúSlow down, you‚Äôre doing fine.‚Äù
And just like the woman in The Midnight Library learns: the life you‚Äôre meant to live isn‚Äôt the one with the loudest applause. It‚Äôs the one where you‚Äôre fully alive. The one that waits for you ‚Äî just like Vienna.
--

‚Üí Martin Hanley: A Memoir
This memoir was written in 2004/2005
I was born on March 14th, 1931 to Margarethe and Leopold Hahn of Neueweltgasse 23 in Hietzing, Vienna. Hitzing, then as now, was a pleasant leafy, upmarket suburb, our home perhaps just ten blocks distant from Schonbrun Palace, one of the sumptuous palaces built by the Habsburg dynasty.
One of my earliest recollections goes back to the age of 5. Opposite our first floor apartment was a little triangle of grass, with a few flowers and 2 garden benches, which was tucked in between our building and the main road, the Hitzinger Hauptstrasse. The apartment had deep window ledges on which I could stand and lean against the wrought iron railings which were erected for security reasons. Later I watched Hitler‚Äôs tanks roll into Vienna from this balcony. As we lived on the 1st floor there were only a few steps to the ground floor and I was allowed to ride on the garden path alone on a tricycle parked in a ‚Äòcave‚Äô under the building. After the war I visited our old home with Susi my wife, and found the ‚Äòcave‚Äô to be a little opening in the building near the staircase outside.
Apart from the ‚ÄúSchonbrun‚Äù palace of the Emperors, Hitzing boasted a zoo and many coffee houses of note. The coffee house was an important factor in my parents‚Äô generations enjoyment of life. Its ambience, seating arrangements, free offering of daily newspapers to its clientele, not to mention the quality of its coffee and ‚Äòmehlspeisen‚Äô or cakes was serious business, similar in importance to the Anglo Saxon pub or the American local bar.
Listening to stories of the older generation I realized that although acquisition of luxuries and assets were not on the agenda, my parents and their circles lived a very agreeable life. I have pictures of family holidays taken in villages, on lovely lakes, of my parents at parties and so on. It can be explained by understanding the culture of European middle class life. In Austria, especially Vienna, the culture of theatre, music, stays in the country in summer and skiing from peasant huts in the mountains in winter was maintained to a greater or smaller degree.
Living on the outskirts of Vienna there were advantages for me, as in winter I could be taken on my sled to the ‚ÄòRotenberg‚Äô or Red Hill to slide up and down in the snow on fine afternoons. My Nanny would pull the sled up this little hill in company with other nursemaids similarly out with their charges. Nanny was a fixture, and one of whom I have fond memories. I have a picture of her with me in my leather pants aged perhaps two or three. She also cooked and made the beds. As she had off only one Sunday every fortnight some might say that she lived in slavery. Not so. She was part of the family and had a home which was warm in winter and where meals were regular. A small pittance was hers to spend as well. Far different from where she came from. This enabled people like my parents to live a very civilised life with very little money.
In the depression, working people in industry or on the land saw real hardship. I was given a spare lunch to school to distribute to children less fortunate than I.
My father was a hard worker all his life. In the 1920s and 30s he worked as a salesman in his father‚Äôs firm, Adolf Hahne & Sohne, a merchant of ‚Äúspitzen‚Äù ‚Äî feathers, boas, lace and embroideries, the traditional Austrian lace, still seen in minute quantities today, was used on almost every woman‚Äôs garment. In white or colourful on ‚Äòdirndl‚Äô, the traditional skirt, for blouses, on caps and underwear. The firm had prospered in the period when ‚ÄòDirndl‚Äô, the Austrian national costume, was the mode. Manufactured and distributed worldwide, laces were an important ingredient of fashion for what must have been at least 2 generations, as my grandfather had inherited the business. In my father‚Äôs time his 2 sons were in the business, both as salesmen. My Uncle Walter‚Äôs sales territory was part of Germany and France. He enjoyed himself very much one believes as he was single, tall and handsome. He had a good time by all accounts.
My father, on the other hand, was allotted the tougher territory, Hungary, Slovakia, Serbia and suchlike. Although also handsome, he was already married and the small traders he dealt with, mostly Jewish haberdashers in little country towns were prone to be cashless, especially after a family wedding, birth or bar mitzvah. He travelled for several weeks at a time, in a small ‚ÄòSteyer‚Äô motor car on terrible country roads.
In Vienna, in the thirties, survival in business was not always guaranteed. The Depression had driven my grandfather‚Äôs firm into bankruptcy three times. Bankruptcy in those days evolved into a sort of payment agreement, in German: ‚Äúausgleich‚Äù. Say you owed a hundred thousand with no prospect of paying it back. You settled with your creditors for whatever, agreed‚Ä¶.and then carried on. My father‚Äôs stories to me of his ‚Äúausgleich‚Äù experiences with his customers, though funny, hid the tensions of those times.
When Hitler walked into Vienna, Jewish premises were ‚ÄúArisiert‚Äù, meaning literally ‚ÄòArienised‚Äô (as in Aryan!) ie. Nazified‚Ä¶Nazi hoodlums, some in uniforms, entered, demanded all keys and normally gave the occupants a few hours to take their personal effects and get out. Confiscated just like that‚Ä¶ period, full stop‚Ä¶ premises, stock, bank accounts.
That didn‚Äôt happen to Adolf Hahn & Sohn, because the business had gone broke some years before. The company went into receivership in 1932. The Depression added another victim, but it not only the lack of business which was the cause. My grandfather, who must have been well in his sixties, married Claire, an elegant woman a good 30 years his junior. This necessitated a new house with fine furniture and the trimmings. The romance proved too big a burden on the business, as well as the two family members who worked in it.
The German Wehrmacht were welcomed by the Austrian populace after the ‚ÄúKristallnacht‚Äù Troops occupied Vienna from March 13th, 1938. On March 14th, my birthday, I stood on my window balcony and observed with childish fascination the armoured wagons, mobile cannons and personnel trucks standing on the road outside, the uniformed Wehrmacht soldiers laughing and joking with the locals while the Hietzing Synagogue around the corner was torched.
We lived in the same apartment until we escaped from Vienna, except for the very last few days when we stayed hidden in a city apartment owned by ‚ÄòTante Ida‚Äô, my grandfather‚Äôs sister and a very old lady. I was later told my father had already hidden there for a few days previously.
In the months from the Anschluss till we left the country in September 1938, I continued to attend the same school. My only vivid memory was of the same teacher, but he was wearing a red armband with a black swastika on a white circle and the Hebrew teacher‚Äôs red star of David on a yellow armband. We children did not wear any outward marking at that time.
It was time to leave Austria, where my family roots went back at least for the 3 generations I knew.

Title: Escape to Shanghai
Content:

Listen
Share
‚Üí Vienna
By 1938, America, England, Canada, Australia and most other countries had either tightened immigration intake or outright banned foreigners. Apparently a Mr. Rogers, an Australian businessman, was visiting Vienna in 1938 and somehow met our family. He offered to help and assisted my father applying for a visa to Australia, sponsoring us. The application was refused. Mr. Rogers subsequently wrote telling my father that stating to be a tradesman as a ‚Äúchauffeur‚Äù was the worst entry possible as his son, aged 17, ‚Äúcould drive a car better than you can!‚Äù That was the end of that.
The Depression had not lifted entirely in most of the Western world. In any case, the few who did receive visas to desired country destinations had to have sums of money my father did not possess. My grandfather‚Äôs business, in which my father and his brother Walter worked, barely supported the family. This was not entirely due to economic conditions ‚Äî it has been attributed largely to my grandfather‚Äôs second marriage to a beautiful woman some 30 years younger than himself. She apparently required a new house with the best trimmings.
Jews who didn‚Äôt make it to desired country destinations had the possibility of buying passports for entry to South American countries like Argentina and Uruguay. Switzerland was open only to the super rich, and then only as permanent ‚Äòtourists‚Äô. Refugees like my parents, who left matters too late with very little money, found safety in the few destinations that made no demands. There was Shanghai, Trinidad, Curacao, and small black African states. Israel, Palestine in those days, was quite sealed against Jewish immigration by British decree, although several hundred young people entered and were smuggled in right throughout the war.
You didn‚Äôt need an entry visa, you just had to get there.
My parents found a way to Shanghai, as did about 19,000 Jewish refugees from Hitler. A temporary ‚ÄúThru-visa‚Äù was available from Italy. This was issued on sight of a steamship ticket to Shanghai purchased from Italian line Lloyd Triestino, on one of the boats that steamed a regular route from Genoa to Shanghai, for an exorbitant sum. Only First Class tickets were available as a matter of course. I don‚Äôt know how but this sum was found for the Hahn family of 2 adults and a child. Train tickets were purchased to Genoa.
I remember a young girl, about my age, boarded the train with us. I never learned what was the family‚Äôs relationship to us, but my parents agreed to take her along. She was taken off the train at the border between Austria and Italy during the night, I presume because she was without papers. I have never been told what became of her and I have since often wondered whether she was returned to Vienna and her parents safely.
After a few days in Genoa we embarked on the mv. Victoria, the smallest but newest of the Lloyd Triestino fleet that sailed to the Orient regularly. We owned several ‚Äòcabin trunks‚Äô full of possessions and 114 British pounds. The voyage was a great delight for my parents, despite what must have been anxiety for the future. The mv. Victoria was the smallest ship in the line, but the latest and most modern.
First class service in all respects was still pre-war and luxurious. The voyage was very romantic, landing at exotic ports along the way. In Port Said, at the southern end of the Suez Canal, a great f√™te was held with native dancers and a feast was prepared on the dock. I believe it was an Egyptian version of an Aussie barbecue with whole beasts being cooked. Local citizens were present as well as the ship‚Äôs passengers. I was allowed down to the wharf for a little while and then taken to the cabin to sleep. I never learned why the celebration. I cannot remember the landing in Bombay or the three days passed in Singapore. Then came Hong Kong and lastly Shanghai.

I‚Äôve always constantly running nonstop, wonder when will it ends, i‚Äôm so exhausted, everyday is a constant battles i have to get through. One line from that song that cuts deep was ‚Äúonly fools are satisfied‚Äù cause i slowly realizes that i kept begging for validations from everyone around me even the ones i barely knew, i kept doing what they perhaps wanting me to do so that they‚Äôll like me and i can finally be in peace but that‚Äôs not what happens instead i felt more empty and sad for myself, letting myself go through all those things just to be accepted and liked. Why am i running? why am i rushing? what am i searching for? why do i keep doing this to myself? for whom? for what? i‚Äôm still questioning myself those questions and still haven‚Äôt found the answers. What i do know is i want this to stop, i want to live FOR me, vienna waits for me, i‚Äôm WAITING for ME, to finally be happy with who i am without the need of other people acceptance.

Title: What to Do in Vienna If You Hate Itineraries
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
I didn‚Äôt go to Vienna with a checklist. No Sch√∂nbrunn palace on the agenda. No museums lined up by hour. Just three slow-moving days, a waterproof camera backpack, and a promise to myself not to overthink it.
From the airport, I caught the 10.5‚Ç¨ bus to Westbahnhof and checked into a small guesthouse nearby. Quiet street. Solid sleep. Five-minute walk to most things that mattered.
I skipped the palaces and headed straight to a corner market for a mustard-soaked pretzel and a table with no view. I sat longer than I meant to. It was a good start.
I stumbled across the Musikverein just before noon. No grand performance, just a chamber rehearsal in the golden hall. I sat in the back. Stayed through most of it.
Across the square, the House of Music pulled me in by accident. I don‚Äôt usually do interactive museums, but this one surprised me. No pressure to move quickly. No crowds. Just quiet sound rooms layered like dreams.
Later, I caught the U-Bahn to Donauinsel, found a bench by the river, and watched the clouds shift. It started to rain lightly, but everything stayed dry ‚Äî my gear, my layers ‚Äî all tucked into that camera backpack I almost didn‚Äôt bring.
I walked aimlessly in the city centre, ducked into St. Peter‚Äôs Church, and followed the scent of coffee to K.u.K. Heiner. It felt more imperial than the cakes themselves ‚Äî but the atmosphere was enough.
Dinner was at Neubauschenke: pork stew, beef broth, locals in padded vests. I sat near the back and scribbled some notes. Later, Papaya served me one of the better duck salads I‚Äôve had in Europe. Spicy, fast, no English menu ‚Äî perfect.
I didn‚Äôt plan this trip, and it still worked.
Because Vienna is good to people who walk slowly, who sit a little longer, and who carry light.
If you‚Äôre thinking of going, don‚Äôt overpack. A lightweight waterproof camera backpack will do. The rest, the city gives you.

i mean, i thought my brain was programmed that way, get a good grade=get a prize, do something good=hear a compliment, it was all like that, till i started high school, the classes were harder and i found myself lost.
i remember the day i got a 50 for the first time, i was shattered, absolutely broken, and i thought my family lost their whole hope on me, i was making it bigger and BIGGER in my head, then i went home, i told my mom and‚Ä¶nothing happened.
this is my problem, making everything bigger in my head, this is a blessing and a curse, but mostly a curse, i also can‚Äôt trust people when they say something good about me, like i thought ‚Äò‚Äôif my mom said ‚Äò‚Äôit‚Äôs okay you‚Äôll do better next time don‚Äôt be sad‚Äô‚Äô that must mean ‚Äò‚Äôyou‚Äôre a failure go lock in and study until you get a good grade!‚Äô‚Äô ‚Äò‚Äô so i did that.
and that worked.
for a while.
then i had..drumrolls‚Ä¶a burn out
then i‚Äôve heard this song, vienna by billy joel, i can easily say it‚Äôs one of my all time favorite songs because it hits right in the feels.
when i‚Äôve first listened to it, i thought vienna to be a literal place,
then i got older, at 17, i thought it was a place where you‚Äôve felt happy and content, a metaphor
then i got a bit more older, at 19, now vienna means something else for me.
for me, vienna is a place where i don‚Äôt overthink..it‚Äôs a place where i can be ME, without worrying, without putting a mask on, just me, in my most naked and raw form.
all these intense, unhealthy nights spent studying and fake smiles being thrown in social gatherings, they‚Äôre not actually..me, they‚Äôs a facade i put to please other people, but when will i realize vienna waits for me?
i love studying, my education is perhaps the most important thing to me, but i don‚Äôt love ruining myself over it, no one would.
take the phone off the hook, and disappear for a while.
and that‚Äôs what i want to do, cleanse and refresh, just let the flow take me where i‚Äôm meant to be, because sometimes i think i know too much, but there are places that i haven‚Äôt been where i already belong, if i try to control everything around me too much, i‚Äôll only sabotage myself.
and acting out in a place and around people where you‚Äôre supposed to feel comfortable is so draining and i just find myself doing this ‚Äòderealization‚Äô thingy, i just feel like a stranger to myself, to everything that‚Äôs surrounding me, i feel depressed, and i think;
who am i when i‚Äôm not performing for others, what is me, where i‚Äôm actually from, a land of over-thinkers, pageant queens and big pretenders?
nah, i‚Äôll find a new place to be from.
maybe it‚Äôll take me a month, maybe three, maybe six, maybe a year, pace is different for everyone but i‚Äôll take the phone off the hook, and i will disappear for a while, just like billy joel said, i‚Äôm tired of social media making me obsesses over my identity in relation to others, i won‚Äôt let my soul rot inside me, because we only live once, so we should enjoy it, right?
if you‚Äôve read it this far, thank you, love you, and just wanna say i‚Äôm here if you need a shoulder to lean on, thanks for bearing with my stupid ranting for 3 minutes.
until next time, take care, bye!

Content:

We all know that Billy Joel is a megastar, but some of his biggest hits came from dark places. In fact, he felt like a failed musician at times. In the early 70s, he was homeless, sleeping in laundromats, haunted by Vietnam and self-pity. After a failed suicide attempt, he checked himself into a mental hospital.
When Billy Joel wrote the song Vienna, he was 28 years old. This song is very interesting and means a lot to Joel because the lyric‚Äôs from this song is all of the advice his father gave him on his career.
‚ÄúWhen will you realize Vienna waits for you?‚Äù
This hook explains to sit back and enjoy the ride. Your destination will be there when it's your time.
‚ÄúVienna‚Äù is a metaphor for old age, it‚Äôs not something to be afraid of, it‚Äôs something to embrace. ‚ÄúVienna‚Äù is in the soft rock genre, written by himself to represent his life and of the pressure he put on himself. He understood that other people might be going through what he once did.
In this song, Vienna is about enjoying the ride before the destination. For Billy Joel, it‚Äôs about his music career and how much work he puts into it. The destination for him is all the people that listen to his songs and enjoy his work.
‚ÄúSlow down, you‚Äôre doing fineYou can‚Äôt be everything you want to be before your time.‚Äù
With this line, Billy Joel is trying to spread the message that it‚Äôs ok to take a step back and take a breath, that it is ok to be wherever you‚Äôre at in life. He is telling his listeners to trust the process; the process got him where he is today. I can connect and relate to this line a lot and it helps keep me grounded. I also think most people could relate to this lyric, as humans tend to put a lot of pressure on themselves because we live in a toxic society that makes us feel like we have to be productive 24/7. This is also portrayed through the line, ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the fire? What‚Äôs the hurry about? You better cool it off before you burn it out.‚Äù Everyone, yes, even famous and successful people can experience the feeling of being burnt out.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so ahead of yourself that you forgot what you need‚Äù
Vienna is known as ‚Äúthe city of music‚Äù located in Austria. This is because it is home too many famous musicians such as Beethoven and Mozart‚Äôs. Billy Joel is reminding himself that he belongs with those extremely successful artists and he will join them in fame one day, it just will take time like all good things.
This song and the message that Joel is trying to deliver has been so successful because of his use of various musical components and elements. Having the ability to understand and properly use musical elements can help listeners grasp the message of a song.
The tone and volume of the song, along with powerful and inspiring lyrics help illustrate the underlying message. The tone is soft and inspiring. The volume or dynamics are gentle and calm, making listener feel motivated yet relaxed at the same time. The duration, also known as how long or short a sound is held, and the tempo, which is the speed, also helps deliver the message. This is because when Joel holds onto notes softly and slowly it emphasizes the importance of the lyric. Lastly, I think the overall melody of this song helps contribute to the motivational and inspiring message Joel wanted to share.
I think it is important for famous people to be vulnerable like this. It shows the more general population that everyone struggles in life, everyone needs to slow down at times and take a step back and that anyone, no matter the circumstances can have poor mental health. It is important to take care of ourselves and we as people see their idols and famous people opening up about their struggles but also then trying to fix them, it motivates others to do so as well.
It‚Äôs crazy how when you really dig into the lyrics and the past of the song writer, it can completely change your perspective on the song and the artist. After doing research on Billy Joel and his music I have gained a whole new level of respect for him. Not just for what he has been through but for his strength to share it and his ability to make good out of a bad situation.

Went to Stretch Lab for the first time ‚Äì it‚Äôs nice just laying there and getting stretched out but the time went by too fast ‚Äì and got told I have nice shoulders and biceps. That‚Äôs one I never get. Also partly why I‚Äôm overtraining right now: seeing results is addicting.

Title: Budapest, Bratislava, and Vienna ‚Äî A Europe Trip
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Nearly ten years ago, my husband and I lived in Budapest for a few months right after we were married. Every weekend, we‚Äôd pack our bags and visit a new European town or country. That was when the travel bug bit us. Fast forward to today, we were thrilled to have a wonderful opportunity to visit Budapest again. How could we possibly say no? This time, we wanted to take our son to the places where we made wonderful memories ten years ago. And of course, when you‚Äôre in Europe, visiting one city isn‚Äôt always enough. That‚Äôs how Bratislava and Vienna ended up on our itinerary as well.
Flights
First things first. To apply for a visa, you need confirmed round-trip tickets and hotel reservations for the travel dates. I know I‚Äôve mentioned this before in my Kazakhstan blog, but it‚Äôs always worth repeating ‚Äî look for cheaper flights from cities other than the one you reside in. We could have booked flights directly from Kozhikode to Budapest. But the layovers were long, which made the total travel time even longer, and the ticket prices were outrageous! The cheapest flight to Budapest from India was from Bangalore. The flight duration was shorter, and the layovers were minimal. So, we booked our flights from Bangalore. We flew to Bangalore from Kozhikode the day before and stayed overnight at a hotel near the airport. This turned out to be cheaper than booking a direct flight from Kozhikode (including both the flights to Bangalore and the hotel stay). And since we have a kid, it was much more convenient for him. Happy child = Happy Parents. It was a win-win. We booked the KLM flight from Bangalore to Budapest with a 1.5-hour layover in Amsterdam. We flew back to Bangalore from Budapest via Paris on Air France. Both flights were quite comfortable, and we had no complaints.
Stay
From our experience, Airbnb is the best stay option. It is cheaper than hotels and extremely spacious, and most rentals have a washer/dryer. That means you can carry fewer clothes and sleep in spacious rooms. Our son is a huge fan of Airbnb because of how spacious they are. Hotels simply cannot beat this offer. Of course, make sure you book an Airbnb rental with good ratings located near the city centre or one that is easily accessible via public transport.
Once our flights and accommodations were booked, the next step ‚Äî the most dreaded of them all ‚Äî was applying for a Schengen visa.
Schengen Visa
Let me be upfront ‚Äî of all the visas I‚Äôve applied for, the Schengen visa is the most complicated. I‚Äôm not joking when I say that one of the factors influencing the choice of our travel destinations is the complexity of the visa application process. All the countries we‚Äôve visited in the past few years (post-COVID) have either had straightforward visa applications or were visa-free. But when the opportunity to travel back to Budapest came up around our ten-year wedding anniversary, we couldn‚Äôt say no, especially since we started our married life there.
I‚Äôm not going to go into detail about the visa application process, but I will mention a few things that helped us during our process.
To apply for a Schengen visa, you must submit your documents to the VFS application centre closest to your city of residence. We live in Kozhikode, and the nearest VFS centre that processes Schengen visas is in Kochi. However, we couldn‚Äôt find any suitable appointment dates in Kochi, so we decided to go with the next closest VFS centre ‚Äî Bangalore. Coincidentally, we were planning a trip to Mysore during the Navratri holidays, so we extended our holiday to fit the visa appointment in Bangalore.
Before COVID-19, applying for a Schengen visa was simpler because we didn‚Äôt need an agent to help us block appointment dates. We could just log into our account on the VFS portal and pick the city, date, and time that suited us. This time, however, we couldn‚Äôt get any appointment dates when we tried to do it ourselves. It was disappointing because we took pride in managing our travel plans independently. In the end, we had to approach an agent to book an appointment, and to our surprise and eventual relief, the agent was able to get us dates that appeared unavailable on the portal. We finally got our dates, and they lined up perfectly with our Mysore holiday.
When you go for your visa appointment, it‚Äôs a good idea to bring extra documents beyond those listed on the VFS website. We carried copies of our marriage certificate, our son‚Äôs birth certificate, copies of our investments, all our old passports, and copies of all Schengen visas older than three years ‚Äî documents that were not specifically required, but which the VFS centre appreciated us having. The VFS centre also has a photo booth (in case your photos don‚Äôt meet their standards), photocopy machines, and printers, just in case you forget to bring a document. So, it‚Äôs helpful to keep digital copies of all your documents so you can easily access and print them if needed.
We received our passports stamped with the visas within a few days of application.
Now, it was time to travel!
Our First Destination ‚Äî Budapest
Although Amsterdam was our first port of entry into Europe, it was a short layover. After waiting through a long immigration line, we rushed to catch our connecting flight to Budapest.We reached Budapest at around 12 PM. Since we finished our immigration at our first port of entry ‚Äî Amsterdam ‚Äî we collected our luggage and passed through customs. We were to stay in Budapest for five days, visit Bratislava and Vienna, and then return to Budapest for a day before flying back to India. So, we purchased a two-week travel pass at the airport. This pass provides unlimited use of public transport (metro, bus, and tram) for 14 days in Budapest. There are also single tickets, one-day passes, three-day passes, and monthly travel passes, but sadly, no weekly passes. The two-week pass worked out to be the cheapest option for our 6-day overall stay. If you plan to stay in Budapest for more than three days, get the two-week pass. Don‚Äôt buy a three-day pass and then single-day passes for the extra days, as the price difference between the three-day and two-week passes is minimal. If you buy single tickets each time you use public transport, you‚Äôll lose both time and money. One thing you should know about most European cities is that you will rarely need to use a taxi/cab. The public transport system is so well-connected that you‚Äôll be constantly hopping on and off metros, buses, or trams throughout your stay. So, a travel pass makes more sense than individual tickets. Also, think of the time you‚Äôll save. Imagine having to purchase a ticket every time you use public transportation. It simply does not make sense.
With the travel pass, we took the 200E bus to K≈ëb√°nya-Kispest M and then transferred to the M3 Metro line to get closer to our accommodation. We stayed in an Airbnb just a three-minute walk from Kalvin Square (K√°lvin T√©r) Metro station (this falls on the M3 metro line).
There is also a 100E bus that goes directly from the airport to the city centre, but this is the only transport service that is NOT included in the travel pass. Since we had the pass, we skipped it and took the 200E bus instead. The 200E bus stops just outside the airport exit. You don‚Äôt need to validate your two-week pass on the bus, but make sure to keep it with you at all times. There are regular checks, and you‚Äôll need to show your pass if asked. Once we reached K≈ëb√°nya-Kispest M, we transferred to the M3 metro line and travelled to K√°lvin T√©r. At metro stations, there are no automated ticket validators. Instead, you‚Äôll need to show your pass to the staff member near the escalators, who will quickly scan it before letting you through.
We reached our metro station, walked to our Airbnb, and self-checked in. After that, we took the day off to relax.
Getting a Local Sim
We made sure our international roaming was activated before we left India. We needed data for the first hours around the city since we did not want to buy a SIM card at the airport (expensive). We visited a local Vodafone store in the city the very next day and bought a local SIM. It was around INR 2500, which got us 6 GB of data for 30 days around Europe.
Sightseeing in Budapest
We travelled in November, which meant it was cold and there were fewer tourists ‚Äî which worked to our advantage. However, the drawback was that we had to layer up every time we stepped out, which was frustrating the first few days, but later, we got used to it. We had three layers. Our regular clothes, a sweatshirt/sweater on top and a final jacket. We also had gloves, a scarf, and a beanie. We used regular walking shoes, which were quite enough since there was no snow or rain.
Places we visited in Budapest ‚Äì
As with most of my travel blogs, I‚Äôm not going to dive into the details of our itinerary or write in detail about the places we visited. Instead, I‚Äôm going to simply list the places we explored each day. We traveled with our 4-year-old son, so if you‚Äôre wondering how many places you can cover with a kid in a day, this should give you a good idea.
Day 1 ‚Äì
1. Hungarian Parliament Building Viewpoint
2. Mathias Church
3. Fishermen‚Äôs Bastion
4. Buda Castle and Old Town
5. Szechenyi Chain Bridge
Day 2 ‚Äì
1. Gellert Hill (Closed due to renovation)
2. Vaci Utca ‚Äî for shopping
3. Corvinus University
Day 3 ‚Äì
1. Shoes on the Danube Bank
2. Central Market
3. Vajdahunyad Castle
4. Heroes Square
Day 4 ‚Äì
1. Ferris Wheel of Budapest
2. Vaci Utca for the second time
3. Christmas Markets around the city
Day 5 ‚Äì
Budapest to Bratislava
Our Second Destination ‚Äî Bratislava
Our next stop was the city of Bratislava in Slovakia. We didn‚Äôt book any local travel in advance, so we visited the Keleti-P√°lyaudvar railway station in Budapest, a few stops away from where we stayed, and bought our train tickets to Bratislava just the day before leaving for Bratislava. This worked out cheaper for us. We also reserved seats by paying a little extra. This may not be necessary during the off-season because the trains are quite empty, and you can choose any seat, but during peak season, I suggest reserving seats. Kids under 6 travel for free! It took us 2.5 hours to reach Bratislava by train from Budapest.
We were staying in Bratislava for three days, so we bought the three-day travel pass at the railway station. The pass gives you unlimited bus and tram rides within the city. There is no metro in Bratislava, but trams and buses connect the station to the city centre. Make sure to validate your pass during your first ride. Once validated, it‚Äôs enough to do it just once, as the three days are counted from your first trip.
We stayed in an Airbnb very close to St. Michael‚Äôs Gate. The city is much smaller than Budapest, and most sightseeing within the city can be done on foot. However, visiting Devin Castle takes about 40 minutes by bus. You can use your travel pass for the bus ride there.
Places we visited ‚Äì
1. Devin Castle (must visit for breathtaking views of the Danube) ‚Äî Highly Recommended
2. Bratislava City Centre ‚Äî St Stephen‚Äôs Gate, UFO tower, Bratislava castle
Our Third Destination ‚Äî Vienna
We travelled from Bratislava to Vienna by bus. Again, we booked the bus tickets just the day before we left for Vienna. We did this online and took the Slovak Lines bus to Vienna Bus station. Remember, there are two stops in Vienna. The bus first stops at the airport and then at the central station. Make sure you book your tickets to the central station, not the airport. We were in Vienna for only a day and took the day pass at a metro station near the bus station where we were dropped off. The return buses back to Bratislava also leave from the same station.
Places we visited in Vienna ‚Äì
1. Stephensplatz and St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral
Our Vienna tradition is to have Gelato in Stephensplatz and so, that‚Äôs what we did. We went to a place ‚Äî Zanoni and Zanoni ‚Äî that had Vegan gelato and also vegan Pizza. They also had egg-free chocolate croissants. We finished a quick lunch here and spent the rest of the day looking around Vienna.
2. Hofburg Palace
3. Maria Theresa Square
4. Christmas Markets
5. Belvedere Palace
We left Bratislava on the 19th and reached Budapest. On the last day in Budapest, we simply walked around Kalvin Square, did some shopping, and called it a day. On the morning of the 20th, we boarded the flight back to Bangalore.
Travel within Europe
Within the cities, we never used a Taxi. The airports are very well connected to the city centre by public transport (Metro, Bus and Tram). If you can walk, you won‚Äôt need a cab/taxi during any part of your journey. The cities are well connected by public transport.
For kids under 6, public transport was FREE in all three cities!
About Europe in General
Please be aware of your surroundings and do not fall for tourist scams. So far, the central and eastern European countries we‚Äôve visited (Austria, Hungary, Slovenia, Slovakia, Croatia) are not particularly known for scams. However, scams are more common in places like Italy, France, and Belgium ‚Äî especially in capital cities and other popular tourist spots. There are several blogs online that discuss the various scams you may encounter, so please read up and stay informed before you travel. Scammers often try to distract you with something (such as asking you to sign a petition or attempting to give you a ‚Äúfree‚Äù gift), and while you‚Äôre distracted, another member of their group may pickpocket you or steal your bags.
Once in Paris, near Montmartre, we were approached by a girl who asked us to sign a petition for something. This is one of their most common scams. Our advice: just walk away and keep a tight grip on your bags. Also, don‚Äôt keep your phone or wallet in your pant pockets. Aravind was almost pickpocketed once but caught the girl in the act, and she quickly ran away. Luckily, he didn‚Äôt lose his wallet. The first incident happened in Paris, and the second in Rome. A third incident happened in Athens, where a lady approached me and offered me a free rose. Thankfully, I said no and left. It was only later that I realized this is another popular scam where people offer you free gifts, and once you accept them, they‚Äôll ask for something in return. We encountered no such scams in the three cities we visited this time.
As for food, many vegan eateries can be found in the popular cities if you want to try local cuisine. In Budapest, I suggest you try Napfenyes Etterem ‚Äî a vegan restaurant that serves local Hungarian cuisine. Make sure you try the Goulash soup! There are also plenty of Indian restaurants if you‚Äôre craving Indian food. We always look for Govinda‚Äôs ‚Äî ISKCON‚Äôs restaurant. They have branches in several cities and if a city we‚Äôre travelling to has one, that‚Äôs where we frequent because our son prefers Indian food to local cuisine.
Overall, Europe is always a fantastic travel destination (if you manage to overcome the initial visa hurdle) because once you enter Europe, you have free reign to go anywhere, and everything is so well connected. Also, almost every shop closes by 6 pm. So make sure to do your shopping before then!
Happy travels!

Vienna got voted as the unfriendliest city but this one trick might help you.
Culture is beautiful. Every country has its own unique way of doing things. When I lived in the USA for six years, I got to know a new culture. A culture that is loving, caring, friendly, and patriotic. Extremely patriotic. But more on that another time.
Let me tell you about the one big difference between Americans and Austrians.
When I came to the US, the first thing I noticed was that people were friendlier. If you walk down the street, people might ask how you‚Äôre doing. For the Viennese, this is confusing. No one asks you how you‚Äôre doing in Vienna.
I remember that I didn‚Äôt know how to react to this friendliness. What was I supposed to say if I was doing badly? I had to try it. Interesting things happened when I said that.
I remember this one time when someone approached me and asked:
‚ÄúHow‚Äôre you doing?‚Äù Stranger
‚ÄúI‚Äôm ok. How are you?‚Äù I replied.
The stranger was gone.
Uhm, I asked, ‚ÄúHow are you doing!‚Äù Why would you keep walking? Plus, I said I‚Äôm ok. There is more I have to say. Come back, you human; we have to talk.

Title: My First Time at Louis Vuitton: A Vienna Experience
Content:

I recently visited a Louis Vuitton store in Vienna, and honestly, it was an experience I won‚Äôt forget anytime soon. Here‚Äôs a casual rundown of what I saw and how each little detail was clearly designed to give you that luxury vibe, all while using clever marketing strategies that make you feel extra special.
As soon as we got there, we noticed that only a handful of people were let in at a time ‚Äî if someone left, only then would someone else get a chance to step inside. This controlled entry isn‚Äôt just about keeping the crowd at bay; it‚Äôs a smart scarcity tactic. By limiting the number of guests, LV makes you feel like you‚Äôre part of an exclusive club, boosting that ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really getting something special‚Äù feeling.
Right at the door, a friendly doorman greeted us with a big smile. Moments later, a staff member came up, asked for our name, and asked what we were after. It felt super personal ‚Äî like they were really interested in making sure we had a great time. This personal touch is all about relationship marketing; they want you to feel known and valued, not just like another face in the crowd.
While wandering around in the store, we noticed every item was displayed with gorgeous lighting and plenty of space. Each product got its own spotlight, which made them look extra tempting. This kind of visual merchandising is a classic move to trigger those impulse buys ‚Äî making everything look so exclusive and high quality that you just want to take it home.
At one point, we had our eye on a particular bag, but it was behind a counter with a staff member busy chatting with someone else. We waited a bit, and when we asked to see it, she casually said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm busy right now, but if you‚Äôre on our list, someone will be with you soon.‚Äù It was clear that they‚Äôre all about consultative selling ‚Äî taking their time so every customer feels important rather than rushed.
When we were about to leave, a man with a tablet approached and confirmed our name, saying someone would assist us shortly (not only he had our names but probably realised that we were leaving as no one was attending us). Then, he assigned another staff member who, introduced herself and led us to a cozy seating area. Firstly she asked if we would like water, tea, or champagne. Serving a drink might seem like a small gesture, but it‚Äôs a clever way to build trust through the reciprocity principle ‚Äî making you feel that the experience is all about taking care of you. She also asked some very basic but important discovery questions like what we were looking for, is there anything we found, are we looking to buy a bag for a specific occasion or in general and then casually slipping in between the conversation that not all products are displayed so we can ask for some more products in case we do not manage to zero in on something.
Out of our 3 shortlisted bags she showed us the bags one at a time and allowed us to ‚Äòtry‚Äô each bag , diving into details about each one ‚Äî talking about colour, how it would work for different occasions, and even how exclusive it was ‚Äî all without mentioning the price until we asked. Not only that she tactfully during the conversation mentioned how we can save taxes, without making us feel offended. A neat trick in luxury marketing: keeping the focus on the quality and the experience, not just the cost.
When it looked like we were not ready to decide on the bag we have shortlisted, she immediately offered to show us another option that might be a better fit for our taste. This kind of adaptive, consultative approach really makes you feel taken care of.
And then, just when we thought we were done, and about to leave without the bag (obviously because we came in for window shopping & experience), we asked if the bag could be delivered to us at our hotel. She confirmed it right away and then casually mentioned that she‚Äôd be going on vacation the day after next day and would only be available until 6:30 PM tomorrow. This little nudge of urgency was so subtle but effective ‚Äî it made me feel like we needed to act soon without ever feeling pressured.
Throughout our visit, she never once pushed us to buy something. Instead, she let us enjoy the experience ‚Äî showing one bag at a time, giving us all the details, and making us feel like we were the only customer that mattered. And when we asked for more water before leaving, she was right there with a tray, rounding off the experience with that extra touch of courtesy.
All in all, our trip to Louis Vuitton in Vienna was a perfect blend of luxury, personal attention, and smart marketing that makes you not just a buyer, but part of an exclusive experience. It‚Äôs clear why LV is a legend in luxury retail ‚Äî every detail is designed to make you feel like you‚Äôre part of something truly special.

I was done with buses after my previous experience, Caroline knew that, so we took a train from Bratislava to Vienna. The ride was only 60 minutes long, and both of us took the opportunity to read. I was close to finishing Atlas Shrugged and wanted to savor the final pages. Sitting next to Caroline, I was able to do that. Somehow, the silence we shared during that ride was just as romantic as the previous night. Neither of us needed to fill the air with words just for the sake of it. That‚Äôs a quality I love in not just women, but all people. Being able to shut the fuck up shows a security in one‚Äôs self.
The train station wasn‚Äôt far from the downtown area of the city, so we walked around to look for a hostel. We had no luck. When we finally got too tired to carry our bags, we stopped in a bar. We drank whatever the bartender suggested, some local beer I‚Äôm sure. That part alludes me. I usually remember what I drink in every bar. I won‚Äôt be able to tell you who was there with me, but I almost always know what I was drinking. What I do remember though, is that David Hasselhoff‚Äôs music was playing the entire time. I hated it from the jump, but had no clue who the artist was.
‚ÄúWhat is this garbage we‚Äôre listening to?‚Äù I asked Caroline.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs David Hasselhoff.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs crazy! In America there‚Äôs an actor with the same name. He‚Äôs on a show called Baywatch.‚Äù
‚ÄúAre you being serious right now?‚Äù She asked, incredulously.
‚ÄúYeah, the same exact name.‚Äù
‚ÄúIT‚ÄôS THE SAME PERSON, YOU DODO.‚Äù
‚ÄúWait, so he‚Äôs a musician too?‚Äù
‚ÄúThis is blowing my mind,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs like the most popular artist in Germany and Austria. He has more than 20 albums.‚Äù
‚ÄúOk, now you‚Äôre blowing my mind.‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd, we have Baywatch in Australia too. I don‚Äôt live on the moon.‚Äù
I was more dumbfounded than embarrassed. The fact remains though, that shit was painful to listen to. His music sounds like a knock off of Depeche Mode, but more robotic and cheesy. Luckily, while sitting at the bar, we met a few fellow backpackers. You can find the answers to most problems in a bar. You can find the causes too. They were nice enough to walk us over to the nearby hostel they were staying at. Fortunately, there were rooms available.
It was one of the nicest hostels I‚Äôd seen up until that point. There were multiple recreation areas, along with a courtyard that had one of those chessboards with foot-tall pieces. I taught Caroline chess there. The kitchen was really nice too. There were even nice wooden tables to sit at while we enjoyed the free breakfast provided each day. It was a nice change from having to eat standing up. The only thing they didn‚Äôt have was a bar, otherwise it was perfect.
I finished my book that afternoon in the courtyard while sitting next to Caroline. I felt emotional putting it down for the last time. By then the pages were completely worn down and both covers were gone. It looked like it had been through a war, and maybe it had, considering it was a late 60‚Äôs edition that I‚Äôd bought near Washington Square Park a few months prior.
I‚Äôd already finished all of Ayn Rand‚Äôs books at that point and needed more words to burn through. Instead of reading though, I decided to write some letters. I‚Äôd bought some cool, vintage airmail envelopes (the blue ones with red and white stripes around the border) in Amsterdam and really wanted to use them. I got some paper there too. For me, at the time, it was all about thin paper. Whenever I found it I had to buy it. I wanted the stuff as thin as a newspaper. I also knew I‚Äôd potentially write a book about the trip one day and wanted some documentation. I made copies of the letters by hand before sending them.
Caroline and I weren‚Äôt staying in the same room that night, so when I was done writing I said goodnight and went to bed. It was the earliest I‚Äôd gone to bed throughout the whole trip.
The next day, I woke up and took a walk by myself. I just wanted to explore and enjoy the nice spring weather, no plans at all. Again, museums were out of the question, so I just popped some Adderall and let my feet guide me. I could wander for miles on Adderall. I could do anything for hours on it really.
After a bit, I found myself in an outdoor shopping mall. While I was window shopping I faintly heard the sound of the Wu-Tang Clan song Triumph playing in a nearby store. When I looked to my right, it all made sense. It was a skate shop. I entered looking like one of the Goonies after they found One-Eyed Willy‚Äôs dabloons.
A guy who worked there was standing in the doorway. I said to him,‚ÄúYou have no clue how good it feels to hear Wu out in the wild. I‚Äôm from America and damn have I been missing hip hop. I thought all you guys played in this country was David Hasselhoff.‚Äù
‚ÄúHaha, we listen to other stuff,‚Äù he told me, in better English than I expected.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to a Raekwon show in Amsterdam next week.‚Äù
‚ÄúReally?!‚Äù
‚ÄúYeah, I was already there a couple weeks ago, but I can‚Äôt miss this show. Plus, I need to buy more weed.‚Äù
‚ÄúI can sell you some.‚Äù
I told you, drugs come to me.
I paid him 60 Euros for a quarter ounce of above par weed, and he gave it to me right in the store. I thought about buying some Nike Dunks as a good gesture, but thought otherwise after seeing the prices. I never understood people who spend all of their money on shoes. Then again, I spend all my money on weed, so‚Ä¶
We shook hands and said goodbye.
‚ÄúIf I ever come back to Vienna, this will be my first stop.‚Äù
‚ÄúCheers.‚Äù
When I returned to the Hostel, Caroline was there.
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up lady?‚Äù I asked, playfully.
‚ÄúI heard about a good bar that‚Äôs in walking distance. Some guy over there told me about it. He described it as weird and completely empty.‚Äù
‚ÄúPerfect.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is, right?‚Äù
‚ÄúI meant you. You‚Äôre just perfect.‚Äù
‚ÄúAww, you make me blush, John McEnroe.‚Äù
‚ÄúPlease‚Ä¶‚Äù
The bar was everything the guy said it was. It looked more like an empty Chili‚Äôs than a bar. There were way too many booths, and the bar only sat 6. Normally, I‚Äôd sit at the bar in that situation but Caroline didn‚Äôt want to take the chance of getting stuck with an English speaking ex-pat blabber of a bartender.
Beers turned into Sambuca shots very quickly. She was the one ordering this time, and I was certain she was trying to ply me with enough liquor so I‚Äôd finally make a move on her. Obviously, it worked. A man can only be so strong, even the best ones.
We disappeared one after the other into the men‚Äôs bathroom, as to deceive the bartender into thinking it was a normal bathroom run. Again, very Danny Ocean of me.
We started kissing as soon as she opened the door. Then I put her on top of the sink and‚Ä¶ Well, the rest I‚Äôll leave to your imagination.
After a few minutes of fun, we fixed our clothes and left the bathroom. I can‚Äôt be sure of the reason but as soon as the bartender saw us, he asked us to pay our tab and leave. As I told you before, being asked to leave is way different than being thrown out.
We kissed and fondled each other on the walk back to the hostel. I hadn‚Äôt experienced that since college. I don‚Äôt know if there‚Äôs anything better then a fondle walk. It really makes you feel like a teenager again.
When we got to the hostel, we sat and chatted before going to bed.
‚ÄúI think I want to go to Germany tomorrow. Do you want to come with?‚Äù I asked her.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so. I want to stay here longer and see museums.‚Äù
She was doing what I did to her, making me wait.
‚ÄúI understand.‚Äù
We hugged, then stared at each other, our arms still intertwined. Neither of us needed words to express what we felt. We spent five magical days together. It didn‚Äôt need to be anything more than that. We were both content.
‚ÄúGoodnight, pretty lady.‚Äù
‚ÄúGoodnight, Mr. McEnroe. See you when I see you.‚Äù

‚ÄúHEAVEN, VIENNA MINE, LAUGHTER AND MUSIC AND STARS THAT SHINE, WONDERFUL CITY WHERE I BELONG, OF HER I SING MY SONG‚Äù[VIENNA, CITY OF MY DREAMS, RUDOLF SIECZYNSKI]
by Anja Mayer
Vienna, as one of the most vibrant cultural hotspots in Europe, has for centuries been home to many artists, composers, thinkers and poets from all corners of the continent. Over the years, the city‚Äôs lively intellectual and artistic scene, and unique culture has served as a catalyst for creative processes and exchanges, that left an impact all over the world. Besides being the birthplace of revolutionary breakthroughs in the fields of psychology, literature and the arts, Vienna especially had an important influence on the evolution of classical music.
From 1780 until 1824, a period which is sometimes also referred to as the Viennese Classics, composers like Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Josef Haydn and Ludwig van Beethoven revolutionized the European music scene. It was during that time that music evolved from background entertainment during social gatherings to a highly respected cultural form of art with an even higher social significance, earning Vienna the reputation as the capital of composition. Since then many more accomplished composers, musicians and artist have emerged from the city‚Äôs cultural scene onto the world stage.
To salute Vienna‚Äôs unique and extraordinary musical legacy, the Carnegie Hall in New York City will host a three-week citywide festival in the spring of 2014. The event will feature symphonic and operatic masterpieces, chamber music and a variety of new music that is emerging from the Austrian capital. The central piece of the festival is a concert series by the renowned Vienna Philharmonic orchestra. Their residency, which will include seven concert performances, will mark only the second time in history that the Viennese musicians have performed opera in concert at Carnegie Hall. The festival will extend throughout New York City and will feature other musical highlights such as Beethoven‚Äôs violin sonata cycle, Schubert‚Äôs Die sch√∂ne M√ºllerin and the premiere of new work by Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas. Apart from concert performances, the celebration will combine a variety of art disciplines including film screenings and art exhibitions at different cultural venues throughout the city. The kick-off event of the festival will be the annual traditional Viennese Opera Ball at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel on February 21, 2014.
For more information: www.carnegiehall.org/vienna/

Content:

Stories of Dennett (Wildflower) & Ben (Weed) & Our Guests

Member-only story
--
3
Share
‚ÄúMy dream writing room would be the Imperial Library in Vienna.‚Äù Fran Lebowitz
The word ‚Äúcosy‚Äù means different things to different people. For some, it‚Äôs sipping a cup of chai in the comfort of home. For others, it‚Äôs watching your favorite series without interruptions. It might be talking to friends or family about something meaningful, or spending quality time with loved ones. In other words, it‚Äôs that moment when you‚Äôre truly yourself ‚Äî when you‚Äôre not bound by any obligation, when you‚Äôre quietly loving yourself, and when you‚Äôre living, not just existing.
I try to find these cosy moments in my home, and today that moment came while painting a memory from Vienna. The art is far from perfect and still incomplete. The art is inspired from a church which was across our apartment in Vienna. I snapped a photo, thinking that one day I might paint it. Today, I finally did. When you visit a city, you carry it with you forever and Vienna is that city for me. Isn‚Äôt is beautiful you need not pay money to be an artist or a writer. Your own memories are enough. All you need is a pen and a paper and you keep doing it again and again as if that‚Äôs how you will attain salvation.
I‚Äôll take my time with this. Watercolor isn‚Äôt my favorite medium, but I will try to do my best to paint the memory.
February Weeds & Wildflowers Writing Prompt is Cosy. Sharing today‚Äôs memory for the same. Thanks to the editors of Weeds and Wildflowers publication for the space for my rambling.

Title: Silent New Year‚Äôs Eve in Vienna (Austria)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Are there still fireworks in a famously quiet, central residential area in Austria‚Äôs capital?
New Year‚Äôs Eve in Vienna used to sound like being thrown into a war zone‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa staccato of explosions with sound volume close to or above the pain threshold for hours and hours and hours ‚Ä¶ But those days are gone. Over the last few years, the change of years became relatively silent in Austria‚Äôs capital. Officially, the main reason is that Vienna has forbidden all pyrotechnics above class F1 (anything children are legally allowed to use) within city borders. Further, supermarkets no longer sell fireworks, citizens are more concerned about the environmental and climate impact, and dog owners (Austrians cherish their furry family members) have become more vocal.
This is especially true for my residential area ‚Äî the Nordbahnhofviertel. This rather new part of the city, although very central, is quiet as can be. It is traffic-calmed, has many driving bans, and sometimes you get the impression that there are more cargo bikes than cars. And, predominantly inhabited by young families, it is not a party hotspot by far.
Anyway, even there, fireworks and firecrackers still exist, and people either love or hate them. Depending on the side, the reported noise quantification fluctuates between Animal Crossing and Call of Duty scenarios. Unsatisfying as this is, I have decided to put a little more data into this discussion.
I have used the mobile app Night Hark to measure the sound volume during the night and to detect the sound of fireworks/firecrackers. Therefore, I have placed an iPhone 8 next to the closed window in my apartment on the third floor and let it record the night. I put it into my home office room with closed doors, so there might be some noise contamination from my family and me, but it shouldn‚Äôt be too bad. After all, I can code there without being disturbed by my kids playing Ninja in the living room shouting the name of Jutsus.
I will report the sound volume in decibels full scale. Since mobile phones use digital microphones, one only gets the sound pressure level relative to the maximum signal capacity of the microphone (= 0 dbfs). I don‚Äôt know how much that is for an iPhone, but my best guess would be to put it somewhere close to 100 dB. The app would also return an A-filtered measure, which is tuned to the hearing spectrum of humans, but since this is at least partly about animals and I have no clue if A-filtered would be appropriate, I stick with dbfs¬†(if you know more about this, please let me know in the comments).
Before we get to the results, a last help for interpreting them: Loudness is not linear. An increase of 10 dB corresponds to a perceived doubling of loudness. So 60 dB is double as loud as 50 dB.
We can see in Fig. 1, which displays the max sound pressure level per minute, that there is a build-up till midnight when loudness jumps to its max value and stays there for around half an hour before ebbing down. During the build-up there seem to be two local maxima at around 19:00 and 21:00 ‚Äî maybe those were fireworks for very small and small children who cannot stay awake till midnight. After 2 o‚Äôclock, it is practically quiet.
Further, the scale was never maxed out with 0 dbfs, so the phone could have been able to quantify even louder sounds. The loudest minute was 0:32 with -17.8 dbfs. If my guess of a max value of 100 dB is correct, this would correspond to 82.3 dB, or for reference, a motorcycle or a crying baby. Not quiet, but only an eighth of the loudness of a disco at 110 dB or a 32nd of the pain threshold at 130 dB.
Honing in on fireworks and firecrackers, I looked at the count of either fireworks or explosion classifications with a score greater or equal to .05. (Night Hark uses YAMNet, a neural network, that can classify sound snippets of 0.975 seconds into 500+ categories. Each sound category gets a score between 0 and 1, with greater values indicating a higher likelihood that the snippet belongs to the specific category). Since the sound behind the window is somewhat muffled and the time resolution is limited, this is no 1:1 representation of the actual number of bangs, but the proportions between time-frames should be valid.
In Fig. 2, we can again see a clear peak at midnight, a local maximum at¬†20:30, and a hard stop at 02:00.
Whether this is a lot or quasi-nothing lies in the ear of the listener, but I am sure this is comparatively silent for New Year‚Äôs Eve in a metropolis. I am interested in your experiences and thoughts on that, so please let me know in the comments.
If you want to look at the data, you can find it here.
Night Hark, the app I have used for the sound measurements, is available on iOS and Android.

Title: 6 Reasons Why Vienna Is the Best Place To Spend the Christmas Period
Content:

Sign in

It‚Äôs the most wonderful time of the year ‚Äî yet advent is even more wonderful in certain locations.
Out of all the cities I‚Äôve been to, and I‚Äôve visited quite a lot in the last fifteen years, Vienna is by far the best place to be in the weeks leading up to Christmas.
Not only because of the food (even though it plays a vital role!) but also because of the traditions celebrated and the visual, glittery makeover of the city.
Here are six reasons why Vienna should be the travel destination of your choice for next December (if Corona allows).
Advent markets exist in many countries, but in Austria, they‚Äôre definitely the most beautiful! From small and rural to big and shiny ‚Äî everyone will find a market to his or her liking.
More than twenty markets grow out of the concrete in Austria‚Äôs capital alone during November.
The most famous (and touristic one) is probably in front of the Vienna City Hall with over 100 booths. Another very popular one is situated in front of the Imperial Palace Sch√∂nbrunn.
But, why are they the best in the world? Surely, not only because of the locations? No, they have far more to offer.
Delicious food, yummy hot drinks, and arts and handcraft are sold here. For me, this is one of the most important aspects of a proper Christmas market.
I‚Äôve been to markets in London, Paris, and Amsterdam but they all couldn‚Äôt keep up with the markets at home. They were far too posh and overdone, with a lot of tech stuff for sale, instead of traditional workmanship.
I prefer browsing through wooden stalls in soft lights, which display self-made candles, hand-made jewelry, knitted hoods, and gloves as well as or local delicacies.
I prefer to hear soft Christmas music instead of loud radio hits.
For one month only, I enjoy a life that doesn‚Äôt circulate around high-tech equipment and being the loudest.
Christmas wouldn‚Äôt be Christmas in Austria, without our markets, where vintage and traditional last-minute presents can be discovered.
Giant snowflakes hanging between Baroque buildings, illuminated trees guiding cars through the streets of the inner district, fairy lights shining from balconies and through windows in every other apartment.
It begins to look a lot like Christmas when the lights are switched on in the entire city.
White. Blue. Green. Red. Lila. In all shapes and forms.
There is nothing more magical than walking through the streets during December. Even getting stuck in a traffic jam feels less frustrating when shiny snowmen and glittering snowflakes guide your way.
In the shopping streets, every other shop plays Christmas music too. What a wonderful world ‚Ä¶
The scent of roasted Maroni (chestnuts), fatty Langos, and Gl√ºhwein (mulled wine) stream through the streets like the wind.
Street booths that sell these chestnuts and potatoes pop up in every corner, giving our popular ‚ÄòW√ºrstelst√§nde‚Äô a very hard time.
Yet, the culinary hot spots during advent are definitely the Christmas markets.
The choice of punch is overwhelming: Orange Punsch, Berry Punsch, Pina Colada Punsch, Jagatee, Eierlik√∂r Punsch (egg nog), Tequila Punsch, Ginger Punsch, Elderflower Punsch, white and red Gl√ºhwein, and much more.
A perfect display of the multi-cultural heritage of this country.
You can visit every Christmas market in Vienna and still won‚Äôt be through all the flavors. Trust me, I tried!
The same is true for the food. You can start with a warming bread soup, continue with gratinated toasts or potatoes, taste some Krautfleckerl or K√§sekrainer and finish with a cinnamon-drizzled Baumkuchen, chocolate-stuffed Krapfen, or chocolate-coated fruits.
The best part for me is always the tasting around. Many small, often family-owned businesses book a booth and bring their own products.
Just yesterday I tried the yummiest truffle-parmesan bread spread and a nice locally produced Gin.
No wonder my family and I always gain five kilos over December.
This is one of the most widespread Christmas customs in German-speaking Europe. You‚Äôll find at least one of these decorative pieces in every family‚Äôs living room.
The advent wreath is made out of pine branches, which are weaved into a circle. It‚Äôs then decorated with small Christmas balls, wooden figurines, ribbons, or whatever you want to put onto it.
Four big candles are placed in the wreath, to be ignited one at a time on every advent Sunday while we sing carols, read verses from a Christmas story (or from the Bible), and eat homemade cookies. And drink some more Punsch.
The custom goes back to the 19th century, where Johann Hinrich Wichern placed 20 lights on a broken wheel. Over the years, the size and number of candles were reduced to their current form.
The tradition of Nikolo and Krampus remains one of the most cherished in Austria. It‚Äôs living folklore that has survived until today, and sparks joy and fear in the hearts of children.
Every year on the 5th of December, Austrian children position cookies, milk, and a pair of shoes by the entrance door or window to give the Nikolo energy for his travel through the country.
As a thank you, he leaves sweets in their footwear.
Then, on 6th December, St. Nikolaus visits Austrian homes and kindergartens in full bishop‚Äôs robe to assess if the children have been good or bad.
But he usually doesn‚Äôt travel alone ‚Äî children must be aware of his servant, Krampus! Krampus is the complete opposite of the saint: a terrifying, horned, hoofed, and furry figure.
While Nikolo brings sweets and chocolate to the brave children, Krampus brings warnings (in earlier times also strokes) to the not-so-brave ones.
This tradition, especially the Krampus, is still very popular with adults, who like to dress up and walk the streets to frighten people.
So you better be good for one year, before you travel to Austria!
Vienna is not only known for the beautiful Christmas markets and classic music but also for its people and their grumpy-ness and Viennese ‚ÄòSchm√§h‚Äô.
We have no patience, we get easily annoyed and we‚Äôre not too shy to let everybody around us know, even nice tourists.
But, when everything around us starts to glitter and shine, and when our sharp mind is lulled in by Punsch and mulled wine, our nerves get soothed and our heart grows bigger.
We forget to be grumpy and annoyed and can even be nice. So advent is the best time to meet Austrian people and make new friendships.
If that isn‚Äôt a Christmas miracle, what is?

Title: The tree registry of Vienna

Vienna has a register for its trees. I learned this through my favourite crowd-sourcing app, iNaturalist. It allows identifying surrounding plants and animals by simply making a picture and uploading it through the app. A community of fellow users and iNaturalist algorithms suggest possible identifications.
I was scrolling on my way to give a talk but I still had some time, so I went into a park to observe some Viennese urban wildlife. One of my observations was a tree (probably poplar).
The observation is registered in iNaturalist as observation #22987310. Not long after uploading the images to iNaturalist I got the feedback that I should have listed the observation as a cultivated tree. ‚ÄúMy‚Äù tree was apparently planted and it is 45 years old and has the tree registry number 30.
It is these kinds of interactions and data linkages, that makes me love iNaturalist and its community.

Title: The Wonder of Vienna
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in
