Discovering the History and Culture of Austria
Vienna, the imperial capital of Austria, is a city of striking contrasts. With its stunning architecture, rich history, and vibrant cultural scene, it‚Äôs no wonder that it has become a top destination for travelers from around the world. In this article, we will take you on a journey through the wonder of Vienna, exploring its history, culture, and beauty.
Vienna‚Äôs history stretches back over 2,000 years, and the city is steeped in rich culture and tradition. From the Habsburg dynasty to the Austro-Hungarian Empire, Vienna has played an important role in shaping European history. Visitors can explore this history by visiting landmarks such as Sch√∂nbrunn Palace, the former summer residence of the Habsburgs, or the Hofburg Palace, the winter residence of the Austrian emperors.
The architecture of Vienna is equally impressive, with stunning examples of Baroque, Gothic, and Art Nouveau styles. The city‚Äôs main cathedral, St. Stephen‚Äôs, is a beautiful example of Gothic architecture, while the Belvedere Palace is a masterpiece of Baroque design. The Jugendstil style, known as Art Nouveau in the rest of Europe, is also prominent in Vienna, with many buildings featuring decorative facades and intricate ironwork.
Vienna is also renowned for its music and cultural scene. The city was home to famous composers such as Mozart, Beethoven, and Strauss, and visitors can explore their legacies by visiting places such as the Vienna State Opera or attending a classical concert at the Musikverein. Vienna is also home to a vibrant contemporary arts scene, with galleries and museums showcasing both established and up-and-coming artists.
Foodies will find plenty to love in Vienna as well, with its rich culinary traditions and world-renowned coffee culture. From the famous Sachertorte chocolate cake to hearty traditional dishes such as Wiener Schnitzel, Vienna is a city that is sure to please the palate. And of course, no visit to Vienna would be complete without a visit to one of its many traditional coffeehouses, where visitors can relax and soak up the city‚Äôs atmosphere.
Beyond the city itself, Vienna is surrounded by stunning natural beauty, with the Austrian Alps just a short distance away. Visitors can take day trips to picturesque towns such as Hallstatt or explore the nearby vineyards and sample some of Austria‚Äôs world-famous wines.
When planning a trip to Vienna, there are a few must-see sights and experiences that should be at the top of any traveler‚Äôs list. First and foremost, a visit to Sch√∂nbrunn Palace is a must. This stunning palace, with its beautifully landscaped gardens, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and offers visitors a glimpse into the lives of the Habsburgs.
Another must-see attraction is St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral, the city‚Äôs main cathedral and one of the most impressive examples of Gothic architecture in Europe. Visitors can climb to the top of the cathedral for a stunning view over the city.
For those interested in the arts, a visit to the Belvedere Palace is highly recommended. This stunning Baroque palace houses one of the world‚Äôs most important collections of Austrian art, including works by Gustav Klimt and Egon Schiele.
Finally, no visit to Vienna would be complete without a visit to one of the city‚Äôs traditional coffeehouses. These atmospheric cafes, such as Caf√© Central or Demel, offer a taste of old-world Vienna and are a great place to relax and people-watch.
Vienna is considered one of Europe‚Äôs most beautiful and culturally rich cities for good reason. From its stunning architecture and world-class museums to its vibrant music scene and famous coffeehouses, there is no shortage of things to see and do in this historic city. Whether you‚Äôre a history buff, an art lover, or simply someone who enjoys the finer things in life, Vienna is sure to captivate and inspire you. So why not plan a trip to this magical city and experience its wonder for yourself?

Title: A look at Vienna through two of it‚Äôs best Caf√©s
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
A week ago I was in Vienna, Austria for 48 hours. It was a short but meaningful trip.
The city is renowned for its ‚Äúcaf√© culture.‚Äù A very particular collection of biases and instincts that shape the behaviors one can see.
The most iconic example of this particular collection is Caf√© Central, a classical, old world caf√©. Here‚Äôs an area near the front windows.
The caf√© is famous, in part, because it was Adolf Hitler‚Äôs favorite when he lived in Vienna. Joseph Stalin‚Äôs too. In fact, for a time in 1913, Stalin, Hitler, Trotsky and Freud all lived within a kilometer of this meeting place.
Needless to say, the caf√© is not a beacon of modernity.
The coffee was bitter and bland.
The service was (intentionally) bad. Half an hour before black coffee arrived.
The people were uniformly white and mostly old.
They were gossiping and gawking. Looking for and at those that didn‚Äôt fit the narrative of early 20th century Vienna.
On Monday, my 3pm flight allowed just enough time for one more Viennese caf√©.
We went in a different direction this time. To a ‚Äúthird wave‚Äù coffee shop located near the University of Vienna called Coffee Pirates.
It couldn‚Äôt have been further from what we‚Äôd seen at Caf√© Central.
The service was brisk and friendly.
The coffee was made slowly, to order, and with care.
The patrons were working, learning, building.
The presentation was thoughtful and generous.
From the moment we opened the door to the moment it closed behind us, were constantly invited to participate in the story that Coffee Pirates was telling about coffee. A story about community, about the way we connect.
Caf√© Central was telling a very different story about coffee. One much more steeped in tradition for tradition‚Äôs sake. One about the premium of exclusion and the value of difference.
Caf√© Central was a story about the ways things were.
Coffee Pirates is a story about the ways things will be.
I know where I want to spend my time.

Title: Throwback To 2020: Life In Vienna During The Initial Days Of The COVID-19 Pandemic
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Read the Bangla version of this article that was published on Unish Kuri.
It was a reasonably chilly February afternoon when I first caught the attention of the sudden rise of COVID 19 cases in Europe as I made my way back home from a fine art event in one of the quintessential Viennese red and white trams. Most of these cases were overwhelmingly being reported from Italy and Spain. Like any other layperson, my initial reactions were a concoction of wishful reasoning, indifference, slight concern, and ignorance. I continued to plan and work on all the assignments and deadlines I had for the upcoming spring and summer months. My attitude was hinging towards being carefree and believing that the virus was ‚Äújust another flu‚Äù with probably slightly more severe symptoms.
However, within a matter of one week, as the number of infected people and the death toll began to rise just across the border in Italy, I finally grasped the reality of the situation and realized that it was just a matter of days before Vienna and other neighboring cities in Central Europe faced the same crisis. By the beginning of the second week of March, Austria started recording many new cases of infection daily, and I had to cancel all my plans for the upcoming months immediately without second thoughts. I started educating myself rigorously on this coronavirus to avoid unwanted panic through misinformation and fake news and arm myself to the teeth in case of the worst. Living halfway across the globe from my family in Kharagpur, it was pretty challenging to fathom and accept this unprecedented crisis and the sweeping changes it would bring in the future, both at a personal and community level.
Austria decided to go into a complete lockdown on 16th March, as the healthcare systems in Italy and Spain were put to the test for the first time since the Second World War. The number of infections rapidly rose across the European Union, prompting the WHO to declare Europe the pandemic‚Äôs epicenter. For the first time in my life, I felt completely exposed to a severe crisis, a feeling which I had only imagined partially or grasped by reading newspaper articles on wars and calamities. There was a great hustle on the days leading up to the lockdown in Vienna, with people hoarding food, medical, and other essential supplies like toilet paper and sanitizers. I, too, had to rush to multiple stores and secure basic supplies as not enough guidelines were available in English in the initial days. There was an eerie feeling that it was the silence before the storm- an impending natural disaster or war-like aggression. The government was swift to tackle this problem within a matter of days by ensuring smooth and unhindered supplies and providing detailed information in English to the expatriate community on their official website.
The quarantine days have been very stressful for me like billions of others around the globe, worrying about the human cost of this pandemic, possible shapes and forms of the job market for young graduates like myself, and their long-term psychological impact. Amidst all this negativity, the only silver lining from my quarantine has been the rediscovery of latent interests I have had, ranging from cooking various meals to experimenting with various forms of sketching. I humbly acknowledge my privilege to be able to indulge in these activities. An interesting observation arising out of being locked in the same apartment building for weeks together in this period has been the growing sense of belonging to this city and my neighborhood, which I never felt before as a foreign student. It is a life-long bond that I will carry into my old age.
The strict lockdown measures were relaxed earlier this week, and further restrictions would be lifted by the end of April. Being the first country in Europe to flatten the curve, the authorities in Austria aim to put the country back into much-needed economic normalcy by the middle of May. It seems for the moment that the initial cannonball has been dodged as deafening silence and apocalyptic scenes of deserted streets continue to loom large over the breakfast servings of apple tarts and melange coffee in Vienna. If the current levels of precautions and alertness are not maintained, the virus might regain strength again and cause another wave of casualties. The historian in me hopes that the city will overcome this dark chapter like it repeatedly did in the past in the events of the Mongol threats, the Ottoman sieges, the Spanish Flu pandemic, and the horrors leading up to and during the Second World War. And I cannot help but wonder how in these days of fighting the coronavirus, Mozart would have composed a string quartet, Klimt would have painted, and Freud would have psychoanalyzed his patients

A city that reminds me
Of a town,
Vienna,
The one with cool winds
And cooler heads.
On a Sunday,
Everyone gets a break,
The city shuts down,
As if on a curfew.
No shoppers or eaters
Roaming on the streets,
All establishments shut
And everyone stays home.
For an outsider
Vienna seems forlorn,
Like their city did during the lockdown.
But for insiders,
It is a paradise
As they enjoy time with family
At home.
Even on a Monday,
There is no hurry,
No running behind a bus or a train
No speed walking down the pathways.
Those going to the office or school,
Stroll at their pace,
Enjoying the winds
And the sun,
And their coffee in breaks.
They work at their pace
Enjoying the task at hand,
Undisturbed by the distractions,
As if in a mystic flow.
They cycle, calm and slow,
Not in a hurry to reach their destination
For them, the journey
Seems to be their destination.
Not formal wear,
No big cars or big frills
Just them in their shorts and ts
Going about their day
Like it‚Äôs a treat.
Living their lives
In a pause,
They teach me
How to take a break,
And learn how to walk slow,
To enjoy every moment,
Whether on vacation,
Or at work.
They teach me
To lessen my agendas
To leave behind the past
And let the future rest
To be in the present,
In this here and now.
I learn to sit still,
Immerse myself in the now,
Enjoy my surroundings,
And the words I read;
Stopping for a coffee
Every now and then.
--

Title: In Vienna, the waiter is King
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This is not a real travel blog. There are no product reviews, no paid promotions and you will find no inside information about secret backpacking locations you can‚Äôt find for yourself online. This is a collection of our expectations and disappointments, rants and realisations.

--
Listen
Share
Like Atlas, with the weight of the world on his shoulders, wait staff in Vienna take their job very, very seriously.
Vienna: the capital of Austria, home of the Hasburg dynasty, old architecture and tardy, poker faced, sarcastic wait staff.
In one of Europe‚Äôs oldest cities, with a long and rich cultural history, and a reputation as one of the world‚Äôs centres of art and learning, the wait staff rule supreme. Long waits for service, being ignored and a general attitude of low level irritation that you want to be a customer seems to be the norm.
Ancient architecture = posh attitude
One travel brochure (The Free Map For Young and Clever People) proclaims that in Vienna, ‚ÄúThe waiter is king. Don‚Äôt be surprised if the waiters are unfriendly - not the guest is king, he is. Treat him as your superior and he will reward you.‚Äù The brochure also claims that ‚Äúwaiters NEVER smile‚Äù and that for tipping ‚Äú5-10% of the bill is the amount the king expects from his subjects.‚Äù
The advice in The Free Map for Young And Clever People is ridiculously honest and self-deprecating.
To begin with you are annoyed and maybe offended by this behaviour. But, after a few experiences you realise that it‚Äôs not actually you personally the waiter hates, it‚Äôs everybody ‚Äì perhaps it‚Äôs a persona they all adopt as part of their profession or as a survival tactic against drunk and obnoxious tourists who don‚Äôt speak German.
My personal experiences of this phenomenon were being told I had ordered children‚Äôs beer when choosing a 330ml sized glass (normal serving size in my country) instead of a ¬Ω litre. My bad. Another was overhearing the same waiter yell at a patron asking them if they wanted to see a menu. Theoretically, this sounds like he was being helpful and doing his job. However, in person, his tone, body language and glare revealed the true nature of his passive aggressive overture. What he actually said nonverbally was ‚Äúbuy something to eat or f**K off‚Äù.
When your office is this plush you might be forgiven for developing an arrogant attitude.
A further experience was when buying a Kaserkrainer (vienesse hotdog) from a street vendor in the early hours of the morning. The vendor must have been earning significantly less than the barman and really needed the customers, but felt the need to finish his entire cigarette¬†before¬†deining¬†to¬†serve¬†us. He then spent less time than it took to smoke it heating a sausage on the grill, before wrapping it and throwing it on the counter for me to collect. The patience we were expected to show while waiting was not reciprocal. While we fumbled uncoordinated and inebriated for the correct change, his bloodshot eyes glared with annoyance. How dare we bother him to prepare his advertised victuals and deign to give him a few euros¬†for¬†his¬†disgruntled¬†efforts.
This attitude is strange considering that you want to spend your money at the establishment where said wait staff are employed. You might think they would be welcoming of a tourist who wants to donate them money. You may highlight the link between your custom and their wages ‚Äì but you would be wrong. The waiter just has no f**ks to give about you and your desires to eat or drink or be treated like a human being.
‚ÄúLet them eat cake‚Äù‚Ää- Marie Antionette was a Hasburg and probably developed the attitude that cost her life while growing up in Vienna.
Sometimes this apathy worked in our favour. For example, when the bus driver was in danger of having to do something untoward, such as turn in his seat, converse with you and maybe issue you a ticket. Instead, it was easier for him to just lift his eyes, wave his hand dismissively towards the general direction of the back of the bus and grunt something. We interpreted this as there would be no charge, but it may have meant - ‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt give a s**t.‚Äù I doubt he would have come to our defence if an undercover ticket check had taken place.
Advice for ‚ÄòActing like a local'‚Ää‚Äî ‚ÄúBe Grumpy‚Äù
The Free Map for Young and Clever People makes an effort to explain why the Viennesse hate on life. Under the heading ‚ÄòAct like a Local‚Äô it was suggested that you ‚Äúbe grumpy‚Äù. Supposedly, it is ‚Äúmandatory‚Äù for ‚Äúoriginal Vienesse to complain if the bus is one minute late or the weather is too hot/cold/wet/sunny. This ‚Äúmentality‚Äù (general bad attitude) was justified as being part of the rich Vienesse culture and is based on hundreds of years of historical precedent and practice.
Back in the day (16-18th Centuries), Vienna was the home of the Hasburg Dynasty and the centre of several empires. As such it was a center of commerce, education, construction etc, and developed a large bureaucracy which served the monarchy and employed half the population of the city. Everybody knows that a high standard of living, steady employment and job security suck, so it is understandable that these unlucky civil servants developed a negative attitude.
Members of the Hasburg dynasty pretty much ruled most of Europe in the 16th‚Ää- 18th centuries
According to the Free Map for Young and Clever People this explains why wait staff, and more generally everyone (especially if they had an ancestor who worked for the government) has the historical right to be grumpy, rude or generally a dick.
Other historical facts from the Free Map include how after WWII ‚Äúall the Nazis miraculously disappear and the population suffers a collective loss of memory as far as the last 7 years are concerned.‚Äù
This appeal to history is obviously a bullsh**t excuse to act like a jerk. More likely, people being people, they could not leave their work at work and the hierarchal structure of a feudal bureaucracy permeated into their attitudes and behaviour outside of their jobs. Add a mix of simian tribalism or pack behaviour and next thing everyone is looking down their noses at anyone else their social standing allows them to ‚Äì and treating them accordingly.
What is mystifying is that in contemporary Vienna, a city where the Arts and Humanities are cultivated, this is a standard of behaviour that some aspire to. Or perhaps it‚Äôs as simple as:
‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt like a person, it‚Äôs because they remind you of something you don‚Äôt like about yourself.‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäSigmund Freud, father of modern psychology and resident of Vienna, before being forced to fleeing prior to WWII.
--
--

Title: A Captivating Train Journey Through Stunning Landscapes From Vienna to Munich
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I decided to ditch the flight mode this time and chose to travel by train for the remainder of my Europe tour. This was the last leg of my 20-day Europe trip, and I had booked train tickets from Vienna to Munich in advance. Yes, it was a great decision.
I had traveled by train in Europe before on several other trips and the experience was stupendous. Notable among them -
Paris to Interlaken in Switzerland
Within Switzerland most of the travel I undertook by train
London to Edinburgh
Rome to Venice
Each form of transport has its advantages and disadvantages. Having different types of travel experiences is worthwhile and we must try them all. It is Fun !!
While trains have a charm of their own, one of the drawbacks is that you have to take care of your luggage and stack them in their proper place. Unlike a flight where your luggage is checked in and taken care of soon after you arrive, making you feel relaxed and free.
On the other hand, to catch a flight, you have to reach the airport at least two hours in advance and go through security, etc, while traveling by train does not involve any of these processes. Hence it is hassle-free and time-saving.
An additional reward of train travel is that you get to enjoy the bewitching countryside views.
Another benefit of train travel is that it is cheaper compared to flights.
Staying in the Ibis hotel directly opposite the railway station in Vienna was so convenient. Firstly, it was a great place to have your meals at the elaborate food court inside the station building. Similar to what we have at malls or airports, you could choose from a wide variety of cuisines.
Secondly, boarding my train to Munich was a breeze. All I had to do was cross the street and within minutes I was at the train station. Though I had the tickets downloaded on my phone, due to unfamiliar language, the platform and the seat numbers were not clear. As such a day prior to my departure, I went and clarified at the information kiosk. The result was that on the travel day everything was smooth sailing.
The railways have done a fantastic job of making train travel incredibly easy and comfortable. I really appreciate the presence of glass waiting lounges (similar to the one at Vienna) at railway stations ‚Äî a protection for passengers against harsh weather conditions.
Absorbing the last glimpse of the splendors of Vienna, as the train left the platform, the view from the window transformed into staggeringly pretty vistas. The four-and-a-half-hour journey was filled with picture postcard scenery as the high-speed train traversed through verdant countryside landscapes, charming villages, with their cute cottages and historical landmarks.
Amongst the several stoppages en route was the historic town of Salzburg. It was on my bucket list, but was unable to visit. I was quite tempted to get down there and explore, but since there wasn‚Äôt any plan or reservations done, so skipped.
In the previous train journeys food was included, and I enjoyed the luxury of being served warm, delicious food and drinks in the cozy comforts of high-speed trains. The in-between snacks were a surprise perk and a great pass time.
This time though the pantry car and availability of food was a let down. Most of the hot, fresh food and beverages were over. There were very limited options left, that too of packaged snacks, that I don‚Äôt prefer.
I was craving for a hot chocolate drink and that was over. Something that I relish immensely, not just for its creamy, lip-smacking taste but also the fact that it aided in keeping me warm from the cold weather. Had to settle for the insipid, tasteless tea instead!
It didn‚Äôt even seem as if I was traveling from one country to another in Europe, except on crossing the border from Austria to Germany, when uniformed border police personnel were there inside the train for passport checking. I didn‚Äôt know about it, luckily had my passports in my handbag and not packed in the suitcase.
From the numerous connecting flights that I took, this was a different experience. A desirable change, rather than flitting in and out of airports. Holidaying at a slow, relaxed pace, that lifted my spirits.
--

Title: From Pittsburgh to Vienna: How A Steelers‚Äô Fan Became Co-Owner of the Vienna Vikings
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Football has always been more than a pastime for me. I grew up just outside of Pittsburgh in the 1970s ‚Äî a golden era for football, especially for Steelers‚Äô fans. Between 1974 and 1979, the Steelers won four Super Bowls ‚Äî what a time to be part of the Steeler Nation! And for a child coming of age in Western Pennsylvania, football wasn‚Äôt just a sport ‚Äî it was part of my DNA.
As I grew into adulthood and my job took me all over the world, I never gave up on the Pittsburgh Steelers ‚Äî to this day, I remain a devoted fan with season tickets. Of course, today, I live in Vienna, Austria, and don‚Äôt often make it to Pittsburgh, but my children go to games, and I join them whenever I can. Fortunately, I found another way to get my daily football fix: the Vienna Vikings.
When I was presented with the opportunity to become co-owner (and lawyer) of the Vienna Vikings, one of Europe‚Äôs most outstanding American football teams, I didn‚Äôt think twice. While soccer is unquestionably the most popular sport in Europe, the idea of promoting American football in Vienna appealed to me on several levels.
On a personal level, I‚Äôm a huge football fan, no matter what continent it‚Äôs being played on. And to have the opportunity to move from fan, aka spectator, to actually being involved in the day-to-day decisions and management of a team ‚Äî it‚Äôs something of a dream come true. Over the years, I even built close friendships with players like the late Franco Harris, a Pittsburgh legend, and we worked on a few business projects together.
On a professional level, the investment potential is enormous, not unlike a burgeoning startup. While the Vienna Vikings are an established team with a long and proud tradition in Austria, they hadn‚Äôt yet made an impact at the international level when I joined. The Vikings had been a national amateur powerhouse and only recently joined the international European League of Football (ELF), a professional European league. I felt this was a prime moment to join the team and help it expand from the somewhat limiting national level into an international high-flier.
Of course, as with any startup, there are challenges and questions along the way. How will the Vikings compete on an international level? How will we get the best players? Will fans remain loyal to the team in the new league?All of these questions, I understood, could be addressed with strategy, forward planning, and strong leadership. And as a lawyer and a lifelong football fan, I felt I had something to contribute.
Austria has an impressive football development system, with nearly 1,000 players at the high school level working their way up from amateur leagues to the professional level. This offers a vast pool of local talent when it comes time for the draft.
ELF rules stipulate that teams can only draft four American players ‚Äî this rule keeps the playing field fair (pun intended) and prevents an unsustainable ‚Äúarms race‚Äù for foreign stars, which is what doomed previous European football leagues.
Unlike some teams in ELF who rely heavily on their American players, who often bring to the table NFL-caliber talent, the Vienna Vikings rely on a mix of local, European, and American talent.
That combination matters. Last season, for example, we were playing in Poland ‚Äî behind all game, without our starting quarterback. Even our backup got injured mid-game. That‚Äôs when our third-string QB, a 40-year-old who hadn‚Äôt played professionally in years, stepped up. Against all odds, he led the final drive and won the game in the last 30 seconds. That‚Äôs the kind of resilience and depth we‚Äôre building.
American football in Europe is still catching up to the NFL ‚Äî there‚Äôs no denying that. But that‚Äôs also what makes this journey exciting. There‚Äôs an authenticity here, a real desire to achieve the highest possible level of professionalism.
Unlike soccer, which often skews male and rowdy in its European fan base, American football here is a family affair. You‚Äôll see parents and kids enjoying the game together ‚Äî a dynamic that‚Äôs helped the sport grow across different audiences. The fact that English is the sport‚Äôs official language also broadens the audience to include diverse people from different backgrounds.
I‚Äôm optimistic about the future of American football in Europe, both as a fan and as an investor. Last year, millions of people showed up and tuned in to watch the European championship game, the Eurobowl. The Vienna Vikings reached the final, though we came up just short. But the growing international audience is undeniable.
The Vienna Vikings, in particular, have a wide and expanding fan base that extends beyond Austria. Vienna‚Äôs historical role as a cultural capital draws in fans from Hungary, Poland, Slovenia, and beyond ‚Äî making the Vikings more than just Austria‚Äôs team.
We‚Äôre in discussions with several NFL teams about building strategic partnerships. The idea of an eventual NFL Europe division featuring cities like London, Frankfurt, and hopefully Vienna is no longer a pipe dream. It makes strategic sense for the league, and we believe Vienna is in a ‚Äúsweet spot‚Äù to be a part of that future.
Personally, I believe football remains a source of joy. I love the sport, enjoy it with my children whenever possible, and am fully invested in the Vikings‚Äô growth and expansion.
Yes, there‚Äôs still work to do. The NFL has set certain standards, and Europe needs to catch up. But the trajectory is clear. The enthusiasm is real. And the foundation we are building is solid.
And I‚Äôm proud to be part of it.
--
--
Husband, father, attorney, entrepreneur, diplomat, founder of Nagel & Associates LLC. Views my own. www.joel-nagel.com, nagel.attorney

Title: Housing in Vienna
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
09.10.19
Vienna is well known for its high proportion of social housing. Nowadays most sources seem to estimate that around 25% of people living in the city live in some form of municipal housing. It‚Äôs evident as you walk around the city. You cannot walk along a street without coming across a housing block with the very recognisable sign outside the entrance. And with the city celebrating it‚Äôs 100th year since the first ‚ÄòGemeindebau‚Äô it‚Äôs also inescapable in every exhibition about the city‚Äôs history.
Housing is an essential component of any city. And with my background working at one of London‚Äôs largest housing design practices, I might be biased, but I didn‚Äôt think I could come to Vienna to understand how they are approaching gender equitable design without understanding how the city‚Äôs housing works.
The existing centre of Vienna is dense, typically made up of courtyard block typologies. So there are limited opportunities for new housing development. The city has a fairly rigid zoning style ‚Äòbuilding code‚Äô, which not only sets out built parameters for building lines at the front and back, as well as heights, but also sets out what land uses are allowed on a block by block basis. This has meant that an increasingly popular form of development in the centre is rooftop extensions, as in most areas only a single storey can be added.
In the centre the majority of housing is comprised of flats. It‚Äôs not until you get quite far out that you start encountering detached homes. In the older part of town the flats often have unique layouts as they do away with the traditional arrangement of rooms coming off of a hallway, and instead the rooms themselves act as circulation space. This leads to quite space efficient apartments, even if there are some quirks ‚Äî such as entering the kitchen through the bathroom! Often this comes about through separate apartments having been combined together to create a more spacious home. This also leads to difficulties with living rooms being above bedrooms and vice versa. The other thing that‚Äôs worth noting is that many apartments in Vienna in the old town do not have balconies. But as the flats have tall and lofty rooms you don‚Äôt miss this so much.
In Red Vienna the city was really reconceptualising how to design for how people wanted to live. The aim was to provide affordable homes of good quality for broad sectors of the population. The housing provided people with light, fresh air and sunshine, as well as nurseries, schools, lending libraries and other communal facilities like laundry rooms. And with more free time they had to organise their lives differently, and the architecture followed suit too ‚Äî with more space allowed for leisure too. The kitchen became a different kind of space ‚Äî often with other functions combined with this space, turning it from a purely functional space to one to dwell in. The focus on the evolving role of the kitchen in the home, at the time, ensured that the needs of all genders were taken into consideration and advanced and adapted to new social norms.
Whilst the social principles from which Red Vienna emerged are not necessarily explicitly evident as you walk around the city, many of the ideals still undoubtedly influence and inform the shape of the city and its housing that you see today. And the legacy of the city‚Äôs municipal housing undoubtedly has an influence on the shape of its future housing.
Earlier this year I was awarded the RTPI George Pepler Award by the RTPI. The George Pepler Award is a bursary granted to a person in their first 10 years post qualification experience wishing to undertake a short period of study on a particular aspect of spatial planning. I was delighted to win the opportunity to carry out my research proposal entitled ‚ÄòWhat can the UK learn from Vienna with regards to adopting a gender mainstreaming approach to shape built outcomes?‚Äô I am currently in Vienna for researching how Vienna has made itself more Gender Equal. #GenderEqualCities

Title: How a month in Vienna changed the way I think about life?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

5
Listen
Share
My first touch with Vienna was in April during my first tour of Europe. The idea was to support the launch of my book about webpack and see some new places. I never intended the trip to lead to a cascade that would change my life, but that‚Äôs what ended up happening.
Perhaps the biggest reason for that was the fact that I made new friends and began to see myself in a different light. I have an introverted past, and I fit the stereotype of a nerd well. The first trip began a still ongoing change that‚Äôs rewriting me as a person.
I encountered Vienna by chance. I was given an option to give a presentation at React Vienna to conclude the tour. As a curious person, I decided to take the chance. I felt welcomed by the community instantly, and I felt comfortable during the two-hour session.
As I happened to have some free time in Vienna, I explored the city. I‚Äôve learned that one way to get to know the local people is to go to meetups. Even though I am/was an introvert, my curious side tends to win over my natural shyness.
It‚Äôs in one of these meetups where I met someone who I consider a true friend now. We connected on an intellectual level and this grew into a deep, personal friendship. The fact that we met is mostly due to chance, but sometimes you have to get lucky to change the direction of your life.
It‚Äôs this relationship and the local community that has dragged me to Vienna over and over again. It‚Äôs a gift that keeps giving. I keep refining myself and the way I think through the constant interactions I have with the city and its residents.
I believe to get to know a city, you have to spend a long time in it. I decided to try with Vienna as I wanted to see if it‚Äôs as good city for me as it felt like the first times I saw it.
You can see that Vienna was a capital of an empire once. It combines high culture with a high-quality of living. It‚Äôs a city where you never get bored as there‚Äôs always something to do. Most importantly, nature is near.
Not everything is perfect, but it feels like an excellent compromise for me as I could have a lifestyle fitting me here while maintaining valuable personal connections.
The idea behind spending a Summer month in Vienna was simple: recharge batteries, build contacts, develop business, prepare for September presentations at ReactNext and WebExpo. I didn‚Äôt intend to change as a person much, but that happened more as a side effect.
This year has made me realize that I have lived a sheltered albeit safe life. But is that a good way to live? I‚Äôm in the best condition of my life in many ways. Excellent health and certain skills allowed me to grow myself a decent business and generate a lot of opportunities, but I always felt perhaps something is missing.
It‚Äôs easy to live your life in a bubble as you follow a certain routine without questioning. Technically that works, and it worked for me, but what if there is more to life than that? This is the question I began to ask myself more and more, and it feels like Vienna allowed me to find some answers while giving new questions.
You could say I haven‚Äôt felt much since the primary school. You shed your last pieces of emotion while you go through the army indoctrination mandatory to Finnish men. The stereotype of a man is not to show emotion in public unless it‚Äôs related to sports. Perhaps it‚Äôs not so good stereotype after all.
Strangely enough spending time in Vienna began to make me feel more alive than before. As I saw more and more people, I started to get out of my shell. I am still reserved but far less so and I actually enjoy my life instead of settling for what I have. It‚Äôs simply amazing I get to do something I like while getting paid well enough to sustain my lifestyle.
I even began to meet people of my opposite sex only to realize that‚Äôs the world I know embarrassingly little about. Doing this has given me life lessons that will stick with me for a long while. You can read all the self-help books you want, but sometimes it‚Äôs real life that teaches you the most even if it might be painful at times and might force you to feel new emotions.
I still have a long way to go on this road of discovery. I feel as if I was unchained. For me to achieve this, I had to lose my old environment and go far beyond my comfort zone. It‚Äôs a path I chose, and I have no idea where it leads, but I am happy to have chosen it.
I find it interesting that starting to do something humble like writing a book to help other people transformed my entire life. First I grew a small business only to realize there‚Äôs more to life. And now I‚Äôm living the next stage in which I‚Äôm discovering what that more is.
During this stage, I will hopefully learn to balance personal side with business as in personal business these two are interrelated. There is no one without another as I‚Äôve come to understand.
I feel as if I gained years worth of life experience by spending a month in Vienna and by being curious enough. I am more aware than ever that I have to grow and develop personally. Perhaps this was the reboot I needed for future success in both business and on a personal level.
For me the conclusion is clear. There‚Äôs life beyond computers and business.

Title: How Vienna Became the World‚Äôs Most Livable City for Two Years in a Row
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Vienna, the capital of Austria, stands as a city that seamlessly blends a rich historical legacy, vibrant culture, and a spirit of innovation. It has earned a well-deserved reputation for offering an exceptional quality of life to both its residents and visitors. Notably, Vienna has consistently secured the top spot as the world‚Äôs most livable city in esteemed international studies and rankings, such as the Global Livability Index 2022 by the Economist Intelligence Unit and the Mercer Quality of Living Survey 2022. But what distinguishes Vienna and enables it to maintain this remarkable achievement for two consecutive years? In this article, we will explore the key factors that contribute to Vienna‚Äôs unparalleled livability and unveil the myriad ways in which you can personally immerse yourself in its captivating allure.
Vienna‚Äôs public transportation system adds to its allure as an exceptional city to reside in. The city takes pride in its secure and efficient network that not only promotes sustainability and physical well-being but also effectively mitigates traffic congestion. A comprehensive range of buses, trams, trains, and metro lines seamlessly connect every corner of Vienna and its surrounding areas. Moreover, Vienna provides dedicated bike lanes, convenient car-sharing programs, and electric scooters to facilitate eco-friendly mobility options throughout the region. With the convenience of a single ticket applicable to all modes of transportation within the city limits, Vienna‚Äôs public transportation system not only offers cost-effectiveness but also remarkable practicality. According to a Eurostat report, Vienna surpasses the European average with an impressive 39% share of public transportation trips, underscoring its commitment to efficient and sustainable transportation solutions. For a seamless and stress-free commute in Vienna, rely on its dependable public transport system to take you where you need to be.
Vienna‚Äôs healthcare system stands as a cornerstone of its exceptional standard of living. Regardless of nationality or income level, all residents have access to cost-free, top-tier healthcare services. A network of highly qualified medical professionals, well-stocked pharmacies, and destigmatized mental healthcare facilities ensure the well-being of the city‚Äôs inhabitants. In the Euro Health Consumer Index report, Austria claims the ninth spot among European nations for healthcare outcomes, showcasing the effectiveness of the system. Whether seeking routine check-ups, prescription refills, or specialized treatments, Vienna‚Äôs healthcare system guarantees the provision of optimal care and unwavering support.
Vienna emerges as an extraordinary city, widely acclaimed for its remarkably low crime rates, solidifying its stature as an emblem of security and tranquility in Europe. Instances of violent crimes, including acts like homicide, assault, and robbery, manifest themselves exceptionally rarely in Vienna, thereby amplifying the city‚Äôs thoroughly deserved repute for safety. Furthermore, Vienna proudly displays an outstanding track record of minimal property crimes, encompassing theft, vandalism, and burglary. This remarkable feat can be ascribed to the city‚Äôs unflinching dedication to public safety, which encompasses a vigilant police force, an efficient justice system, and a profound sense of social cohesion among its residents. These collective elements converge to form formidable deterrents against nefarious activities. Notably, Vienna claims an impressive third position among European cities in terms of safety, as corroborated by a comprehensive report conducted by Numbeo. In your quest for a city that proffers solace and peace of mind, rest assured that Vienna transcends all expectations and bestows an idyllic milieu for a secure and harmonious lifestyle.
Vienna, a city lauded for its vibrant arts and cultural scene, bestows upon its residents an exquisitely immersive and profoundly enriching experience. With its thriving symphonic harmony, a diverse tapestry of museums and galleries, and an abundance of charming cafes, Vienna effortlessly captivates the hearts and souls of its denizens. The city exudes an unwavering pride in its artistic heritage, intricately interwoven with the illustrious names of iconic composers like Mozart, Beethoven, and Schubert. The esteemed institutions, including the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra and the Vienna State Opera, serve as majestic bastions of artistic prowess. Prepare to be submersed in the opulent and multi-faceted cultural kaleidoscope that Vienna unfurls before you. A staggering collection of over a hundred museums and galleries awaits, showcasing a splendid and eclectic assortment of ancient relics and avant-garde contemporary artistry. For the discerning aficionados of coffee, Vienna‚Äôs renowned coffee culture beckons, enticing them to indulge in an alluring array of specialized brews and savor the delightful gastronomic offerings of its quaint and inviting cafes. Allow yourself to become enraptured by the harmonious symphony of music, the captivating allure of artistic expression, and the artistry of the brewing process. Vienna, with its diverse m√©lange of experiences, promises an unparalleled journey tailored to satiate your most refined and discerning palate.
Vienna places a strong emphasis on prioritizing favorable rental conditions for its esteemed residents, ensuring a wide range of accessible and affordable housing options are readily available. With its thriving rental market, the city goes above and beyond to safeguard against exorbitant prices and promotes the widespread availability of high-quality subsidized housing. The rental agreements in Vienna operate under a comprehensive system that meticulously regulates the duration of leases, termination policies, and rent adjustments, aiming to strike a fair and equitable balance. Moreover, the city boasts a significant number of social housing units that are either owned or supported by benevolent non-profit organizations and dedicated local governments. These invaluable resources serve as an indomitable force for the well-being of diverse groups, including hardworking students, cherished seniors, and intrepid immigrants, by providing them with secure, comfortable, and cost-effective housing solutions. It is worth highlighting that Vienna stands tall, with an impressive 62% of its remarkable housing stock being designated as social housing, surging past the European average of a mere 11%, as diligently reported by the reputable organization, Housing Europe. Indisputably, Vienna takes immense pride in offering an alluring tapestry of housing options, adeptly tailored to suit the unique preferences and discerning tastes of its cherished residents. Whether one is in pursuit of a cozy haven nestled in an enchanting apartment, a grandiose residence adorned with spaciousness and elegance, or a harmonious fusion of both, Vienna proudly presents an expansive array of choices. Spanning from the labyrinthine streets of the inner city, pulsating with vibrant energy and cultural splendor, to the idyllic, serene realms of the sprawling suburbs, where tranquility dances in harmony with nature‚Äôs embrace, Vienna weaves a captivating narrative of architectural brilliance and captivating neighborhoods that beckon to be explored.
Vienna emanates an enchanting allure, captivating all those who venture into its embrace. This mesmerizing metropolis proudly showcases an immaculate atmosphere and minimal pollution, owing to its vast expanses of verdant landscapes and steadfast dedication to environmental preservation. Nestled within the confines of Vienna are an abundance of luxuriant settings, ranging from sprawling parks and flourishing gardens to majestic forests and picturesque vineyards. Title: Vienna is an elegant city
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Tuesday and Wednesday, May 6 and 7
This may be a long post because it covers two days. We are greeted by the Empress Maria Theresa, one of the rare female monarchs we have encountered. The Viennese speak warmly of her and I believe she had a long and peaceful reign. She also had 16 (!) children, one being Marie Antoinette. They were all intermarried, it seems.
There is another monarch, Empress Elizabeth, whose life was much more complicated, but more about her later.
To be honest, I have taken so many pictures of so many buildings that I can‚Äôt remember three days later which is which. I just want to give you a sense of each place. All of the cities started with the Celts, then Vikings, then the Roman Empire. Only rare bits of Roman roads and buildings can be seen.
The streets are narrow and curved in the medieval style. The buildings are from later periods. Many have been rebuilt because of WW II.
In Germany the Renaissance style buildings were over the top, like Baroque and Rococo. But Vienna is a little more subdued. It is spacious and grand and elegant without overwhelm.
So here are a few pictures of various buildings and statues. The only thing I can discern is when I‚Äôm taking pictures of a church.
This is not a church. This is the old city gate and its alcove, home to the Sisi Museum and the Lippizaner Museum ( the famous dancing white horses).
Speaking of horses, they have horse drawn carriages you can ride? But we didn‚Äôt do this.
What was cool was that the horses all had these decorative head pieces that covered their ears. I guess it gets cold in Vienna in the winter.
This is the Imperial Palace in Vienna, which has a ridiculous number of rooms.
This is some statue monarch made to associate himself with God. I‚Äôm not sure if was to honor God or himself, but there was that ‚Äúdivine right of kings‚Äù thing going centuries ago. And then you remember all the Prince Bishops‚Ä¶ so much intertwining of religious and political power.
I was surprised that a truck drove through a pedestrian area! I didn‚Äôt expect that.
Street food.
Now this really surprised me. Here is this beautiful building covered with an advertisement. I looked closed and this is actually a fabric painting reproducing the building; it hides the scaffolding and the ad helps disguise the fabric covering. You don‚Äôt even notice it‚Äôs fake. A disguise of a disguise.
This is a church. I think it‚Äôs St. Stephen‚Äôs.
Note the beautiful tiled roof.
It‚Äôs always hard to get a picture of the whole church but I got this replica.
Pictures of inside the church follow.
And there is always a gift shop.
After the official tour we decided to go wander around Vienna. Chocolate, anyone? ( I‚Äôm talking to you, Abby.) They gave samples, like at an ice cream store.
This made us hungry so we stopped in a coffee shop and of course you need a pastry to go along with your coffee. Even Chappell drank coffee in honor of the tradition.
Interesting sights along the way. Bicycles often have a large front container to carry groceries or to ferry children. If they ferry children they have little car seats with seat belts.
Poor dog!
(Rachel I know. I don‚Äôt have many dogs here but not as many people have dogs and they don‚Äôt let you pet them.)
Chappell asked me what I wanted to do next. I wanted to go to the Sisi Museum. I‚Äôm sure Jeremy knows all about this because he knows about everything. I had never heard of her but she had a tragic life. I am told it is now a Netflix series called ‚ÄúPrincess Elizabeth.‚Äù
When you go into the museum the first thing you see a is a plaster death mask. She was quite poetic and expressed her melancholy in her journals. They were posted on the walls throughout.
‚ÄúBut mournfully I spread my wide, white wings, return home to the fairy kingdom and nothing shall bring me back again.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am Sunday‚Äôs child, a child of the sun. Her golden rays she wove into my throne; with her glow she wove her crown. It is her light that I live, but should she ever wane from me, I must die.‚Äù
Sisi grew up in Bavaria out in the countryside. It was an idyllic childhood. She is the little girl in each of these pictures.
This is a bust of her at age 10. She grew into a beautiful young woman who was known for her beautiful hair.
These were some of her Crown Jewels.
And some of her ball gowns.
Her fan
These were her staterooms.
And her personal exercise room.
And her bedroom
Sisi lived a very sad life. She hated the constraints of the court and its duties, but her real torture was her mother-in-law. Her mother-in-law was terribly overbearing and ruled with an iron fist.
Even so, the couple was reasonably happy. Sisi was away on a state visit with her husband when their child died at age 6. That caused a rift in their marriage that was never repaired. Sisi began traveling throughout Europe without her husband; she seemed to have given up on her son and left him behind to the ‚Äúcare‚Äù of his mother-in-law. (Sisi‚Äôs son Rudolph was a disaster, probably as a result of his horrible upbringing.) Sisi, herself, wore black during these sad, later years.
‚ÄúElizabeth‚Äôs incessant traveling is increasingly characterized by unease and restlessness. The ‚Äúlady in black‚Äù constantly sought to escape the burden of her own personality and was prey to profound melancholy.‚Äù
At age 61 she was assassinated by an anarchist who just wanted to create some chaos. She was never meant to be the target, but she was at the wrong place at the wrong time. What a tragic life.
The next day we woke up with a boat gas station and attendant right outside our balcony. I had never thought about the need to fuel up or how they would do that. I‚Äôd love to know more about all the behind the scenes workings of the ship.
Chappell had gone to the Schonnbrun Palace (the summer residence), so I had the morning to myself. I had been thinking about going to the Klint Museum but couldn‚Äôt get an appointment that didn‚Äôt conflict with a planned afternoon tour of the Vienna Boys Choir. So I just spent a sunny morning in the lounge. (This is also where I caught up on my posts.)
This was the view of modern Vienna on the opposite bank from the old city. It‚Äôs all very new and modern.
That afternoon I took a trip to the home of the Vienna Boys choir, but it‚Äôs more than one choir of boys.
It functions as a boarding school set in a beautiful old neighborhood in Vienna.
These are the formal gardens.
Everything is ‚Äúold Vienna.‚Äù
The choir has been in existence since before 1500 and was always supported by the royalty. During these centuries the boys were dressed as little soldiers in the king‚Äôs army. After the fall of the monarchy the uniforms were changed to sailor suits. This was not because they had a navy but because sailor suits were normal attire for children at that time.
We were escorted into an oval room with perfect acoustics and serenaded by 18 boys in the choir.
Of course the music was angelic. Their voices were were so pure and clear. I think I will never forget the sound of their voices.
I had hoped for that but I learned things I never expected.
They started the performance with ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no business like show business‚Äù which was quite a surprise. They sang a wide range of music as a group, with occasional solos and duets.
The children are from all over the world and tour all over the world. It was touching to see a Russian boy and a Ukrainian boys singing side by side. It was perhaps appropriate because their last song was ‚ÄúWe are the world, we are the children.‚Äù They consider themselves as ambassadors.
They are more than a boys choir. There is a non-residential elementary school for children ages 6‚Äì10, with quite an emphasis on music. If the children show an interest and aptitude, there are simple auditions for admission to the residential middle school and choir for ages 10‚Äì14.
There are actually four choirs of about 24 boys each. Each choir is named after a great composer, such as the Brahms choir, the Mozart choir, etc. One choir is always on tour while the other choirs have school. There is also a girls‚Äô choir for ages 10‚Äì14 with their own conductor. The girls attend the school but go home at night; a dormitory for them is being planned. Their is now a high school, so the children can continue their education and be part of the youth choir. Some stay, but others opt for a normal high school life (if such a thing exists).
It‚Äôs good to know, though, that they have a normal life. I got this photo of some of the boys were playing soccer. They still get to be kids.

Title: Dear Summer
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
For the first time in a long time,
I feel like myself again.
Not the version I had to shrink to be loved,
not the one who stayed quiet to keep the peace,
not the girl who called the bare minimum ‚Äúenough.‚Äù
She walked through hell,
but I left her there ‚Äî
with the people who fed off her silence
and mistook her kindness for weakness.
Now, I‚Äôm done explaining,
done waiting to be chosen,
done carrying weight that was never mine.
I‚Äôve never felt so *light.*
There‚Äôs sunlight in my bones again,
a laugh I don‚Äôt have to fake,
and dreams I‚Äôm finally letting breathe.
Next week: Florida.
Me and my friends, chasing the sun,
singing too loud, dancing barefoot,
and soaking in every golden hour like it‚Äôs a promise.
Then‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäEurope.
A one-way ticket and no return date.
No plan but joy.
No map but instinct.
I want to get lost on purpose.
To fall in love with places, moments, and maybe even myself again.
To write my story across coastlines and caf√©s,
with no one‚Äôs voice in my head but mine.
This summer isn‚Äôt an escape ‚Äî
it‚Äôs a return.
To who I was before the noise.
To who I‚Äôve *always* been, underneath the wreckage.
And this time,
I‚Äôm not just moving on ‚Äî
I‚Äôm moving *up.*
Unapologetically.
Unstoppably.
Unforgettably.
With love (and finally, freedom),
**Me**

Title: Professor Martina Huemann Of The WU Vienna University of Economics and Business On How We Can Increase Women‚Äôs Engagement in Leadership
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

In-depth Interviews with Authorities in Business, Pop Culture, Wellness, Social Impact, and Tech. We use interviews to draw out stories that are both empowering and actionable.

--
Listen
Share
‚Ä¶Inclusive leadership training and culture change are necessary to break away from traditional, male-dominated leadership models. Women should be encouraged to lead without having to adopt a ‚Äúmale‚Äù style, and leadership training should highlight the strengths women bring to the table. I‚Äôve seen organisations that revamped their training programs to focus on emotional intelligence and collaborative leadership. This approach helped one female manager I know feel more confident and authentic in her promotion to a top management role‚Ä¶
We had the pleasure of interviewing Martina Huemann. Martina is Professor at the WU Vienna University of Economics and Business where she heads the Project Management Group in the Department Strategy and Innovation and is the Academic Director of the Professional MBA Program: Project Management. She has published widely in the fields of Project Management and Human Resource Management. For her Research on Human Resource management in Project-oriented Organisations, she received the IPMA Research Award 2015.
Thank you so much for doing this with us! Before we dig in, our readers would like to get to know you a bit more. Can you tell us a bit about your ‚Äúbackstory‚Äù? What led you to this particular career path?
Born in Vienna, Austria I am currently living between Vienna and London. While in Vienna I am Academic Director of the Vienna Executive MBA: Strategic Project Management and lead the Project Management Group in the Institute of Strategic Management at WU Vienna. For 1,5 years I am a Full Professor of Project Leadership and Society at University College London, Bartlett School of Sustainable Construction.
I am Editor-in Chief of International Journal of Project Management, the leading journal in Project Research and Founding Editor-in-Chief of Project Leadership and Society and hold several board positions in national and international Associations.
I have two children, two boys, one born 1997 and one born 2005.
Can you share the most interesting story that happened to you since you began your career?
My career was probably not expected from me. As I was the first one in my family who made it to university. My parents came from a simple background, my mother was educated as a tailor but run a small shop and my father was a warehouse worker for a newspaper. While both not having much formal education, they always gave me the feeling that I can achieve everything what I want.
I also did my studies at WU Vienna and when I entered the building I felt not belonging there, more an alien. I had no role models in my family. However, I decided that I wanted to get more knowledge and a formal education. I studied Business Administration. During the weekends Friday to Sunday night, I worked 20 hours plus in an ice cream shop to contribute to financing my life.
I always having a drive for learning, getting to know something new, but also for visiting other countries and traveling. I am a quite curious person interested in understanding different subjects and contexts, meeting new people and making a difference.
During my studies I spent one semester in Prague and later one semester in Lund Sweden. I was travelling and had the opportunity to engage in different projects, one of those was an EU funded project bringing Didactics to Middle and Eastern Europe countries like Poland, Tech Republic and Slovakia. I was engaged there as a student evaluator. Looking back this got me interested in universities, teachings and in projects and how change can be organised trough projects. Which set the ground also for my interest to research and educate how to manage projects.
When I finally finished my graduate studies, I got a position at a newly established small department at WU focused on Project Management. I supported the establishment of that university unit, its research and education programme. Finally, I received a position funded by the university and started my doctorate in Project Management. I early got involved internationally in the International Project Management Association as I was taken there through my professor. That helped me immensely to build my network.
My first son was born shortly after I received my first university financed position. This caused quite some turbulence. I was questioned by my work environment if family was now my priority and if leaving academia would be better for me. I took a quite short maternity leave and went back to keep my position and finished my doctorate.
My career was only possible with my partner and especially the of my mother and the father of my partner. who helped a lot with the childcare. To make a university career in my context I had to pursue a Habitation, and which set a further milestone in my career that opened the door for my professorship.
Can you share a pivotal moment in your career that significantly influenced your path to leadership?
As an early career researcher, I received a quite tempting invitation to apply for positions at another university abroad. But I decided not to go for it as I would have needed to take the whole family to a different country. It would have been very difficult for my partner to find a job and I felt it was not appropriate to ask my partner and my family to start somewhere new just because of my career aspirations.
This is also the reason why I did my career at WU Vienna. While it was international and I have been engaged in International Associations like International Project Management Association or Project Management Institute, I remained a stable main position at WU Vienna. However as my children are now grown up, I did apply for a professorship at University College London and reduced my position at WU.
Ok, thank you for that. Let‚Äôs now jump to the primary focus of our interview. According to this report, only about 31.7% of top executive positions across industries are held by women. This reflects great historical progress, but it also shows that more work still has to be done to empower women. In your opinion and experience what is currently holding back women from leadership and management?
Many different issues. Most of them are structural
Woman are socialized with a set of desired behaviours expected from them.
Can you share a few reasons why more women should become leaders and managers?
Women and men are different, and this is good. People are different in their personalities and talents and hey bring different perspective and contributions.
Studies show that women in board rooms make a positive effect on company performance. The offer is to see women (and other minorities) rather as an asset and help to build structures to support them to provide contributions.
Can you please share ‚Äú5 Things We Need To Increase Women‚Äôs Engagement in Leadership and Management?‚Äù If you can, please share an example or story for each.
First, targeted mentoring and coaching are essential. Women often face barriers to accessing high-quality mentorship, so structured programs help women identify their strengths, set clear goals, and navigate leadership challenges. I remember when my employer once said, ‚ÄúTry it for six months. If it doesn‚Äôt work, you can go back.‚Äù That kind of mentoring gave me a safe space to test my leadership skills without the fear of permanent failure, which really helped me move forward in my career.
Proactive networking is another important factor. Women need to actively create or join networks that connect them with senior leaders and like-minded peers. These networks provide access to important contacts and sponsorship opportunities.
Flexible working arrangements are also crucial. The challenge of balancing professional and family responsibilities often deters women from pursuing leadership roles. By adopting flexible hours, job-sharing, or part-time management positions, leadership roles can be made more accessible. In my own experience, I‚Äôve seen the positive effects of companies offering more flexibility. In one example, a company revamped its policies to allow flexible scheduling, which allowed a talented leader to balance her childcare responsibilities with her role on the board. The result was improved team performance.
Inclusive leadership training and culture change are necessary to break away from traditional, male-dominated leadership models. Women should be encouraged to lead without having to adopt a ‚Äúmale‚Äù style, and leadership training should highlight the strengths women bring to the table. I‚Äôve seen organisations that revamped their training programs to focus on emotional intelligence and collaborative leadership. This approach helped one female manager I know feel more confident and authentic in her promotion to a top management role.
Finally, objective recruitment and promotion processes are critical. Using methods like structured personality assessments and behaviour-based interviews helps combat unconscious bias and ensures candidates are chosen based on merit.
In your opinion, what systemic changes are needed to facilitate more equitable access for women to leadership roles?
Companies must embrace legislation that promotes gender diversity, like the EU‚Äôs push for more women on boards. However, quotas alone aren‚Äôt enough ‚Äî accountability is key to preventing tokenism.
Corporate cultures need to evolve to value leadership traits that women excel in, such as empathy and collaboration. Changing outdated success metrics to reflect these qualities is essential, and recruitment and promotion processes must also be free from bias, prioritising merit over personal connections.
Work-life integration policies should be standard, not exceptions. Companies must normalise flexible work options for everyone, not just working mothers. Investing in female leadership development early on through mentorship, training, and networks like the WU Executive Academy‚Äôs Female Leaders Network ensures women have the resources to succeed in senior roles.
These systemic changes won‚Äôt happen overnight, but when companies and policymakers commit to action rather than discussion, real progress follows.
What strategies have you found most effective in mentoring and supporting other women to pursue leadership positions?
My main strategy is to empower young women to find their own ways and learn to trust in themselves. I am mentoring several women to help them in their academic careers. Very operationally I help them to understand their strengths and especially help them to understand they are not required to deliver 110% all the time. A trap that I have tapped in during my career and which I could not continue especially after I had my children.
A funny story to share was at one of my first panels I was invited to. I prepared so much and worked on my performance in every detail. I just wanted to be able to provide the perfect answers to all possible questions. Which is of cause not possible. However, I did not stop preparing and did not sleep the night before the event. So, when I was sitting at the panel, I was very tired, very serious and concentrated to get it all right. Without any smile, quite fact oriented. I was knowledgeable, said the right things, but my message was not convincing. It was just one boring smart voice among many others. Additionally, when others were speaking, I was so tiered that I simply fell asleep in front of 300 people. My sleep only took some seconds, and I still hope nobody saw it. However, that situation taught me an important lesson which I use to encourage women not to over prepare, take life a little easier, consider the package, how to deliver the message and not only what.
And yes we women cannot have everything at the same time. Children and major career steps at the same time is (almost) not possible to pursue at the same time. But there is also the right time for everything. Not everything needs to happen till the age of 35.
A good personal example is my recent career step, the appointment as Professor at University College London. When I was invited to apply, my youngest child was to finish School thus it was a window of opportunity that had opened, but it is then also a decision if you want to get you out of your comfort zone.
How would you advise a woman leader about how to navigate the challenges of being a woman in a leadership role within a male-dominated industry?
When I did my first formal education in Project Management, it was in 1996 and it was the Certificate Programme ‚ÄúInternational Project Management‚Äù, back then offered by the WU Vienna and the Technical University Vienna. There were 20 participants in class, 19 men and me. All of them having technical background mainly Engineering, Construction and Information Technology, the typical industries in which Project Management was applied back then. My background was Business Administration (specialized in Marketing) and I was the only woman. I was again an obvious alien, especially as I was the only woman in the room, and I was young. In this situation I asked myself whether I fit in? But reframed my question in what I can bring to the table, what are my competencies my talents that I can contribute and makes me add value. In this situation it was my social competencies, my strength to observe, listen and ask questions, thus my talent to lead processes in groups that added value and allowed me to add value. This is also my advice to women, know what you are good at understand what added value you can bring to the table. Be authentic and play to your strengths.
How do you balance the demand for authoritative leadership with the stereotypical expectations of female behaviour in professional settings?
Well use stereotypes like the hard man and the soft woman because that makes live easier to us. But the world is not black and white. If we look in more detail I do not believe in authoritarian leadership. Hero leadership is not working, especially not with younger generations. Hierarchies have become flatter, people want to work flexible, self organised, autonomy has become important, that is reflected in a modern leadership that is flatter, shared, distributed and often puts purpose in the foreground.
A leader needs be reflective person who takes decisions timely and is accountable for them. Core competences are to navigate uncertainty, embrace change, give orientation to others, think strategically and engaging others to co-create the future of an organisation. Today leaders should be able to stand in the spotlight but also is able to share the spotlight with others.
How can our readers further follow your work online?
Easiest is to follow me on LinkedIn
Professor Martina Huemann https://www.linkedin.com/in/martinahuemann/?originalSubdomain=at
The Project Hub
https://www.linkedin.com/company/projecthubucl/?viewAsMember=true
I especially interested how we can co-create the future with projects.
Current I look into value creation by projects, careers of project professionals and investigates what motivates (young) project professionals to work on projects
Thank you for these fantastic insights. We greatly appreciate the time you spent on this.
--

I woke up this morning at dawn‚Ä¶I wasn‚Äôt quite sure where I was until I opened the window. The sun was rising in the horizon and it clicked: ‚ÄúVienna!‚Äù
I had always dreamed of Vienna as this elegant and majestuous city, home of Sisi the Empress and fairy tales my mum used to read me in bed. I remember the history books in high school with pictures of the Austro-Hungarian Empire portraying royal families and castles. The heart of Europe.
I left my hotel not knowing exactly where I was headed to; all I wanted was to travel back in time, wander through history, let the city surprise me and instinct be my guide.
As I approached the centre, the magic started to unfold: majestic buildings like the Parliament, the Museum‚Ä¶I walked through a manicured garden that led me straight into the statue of Mozart. It reminded me that Vienna is The City Of Music, home to Beethoven and Schubert and I can understand where they got the inspiration to‚Ä¶

Title: mistake
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I wish I never met you.
I don't think there was any good reason behind it I think it was an accident.
Like, Fate got distracted looking at its phone, and when it looked back up, we‚Äôd crashed into each other, and it was too late.
The damage was done, and we had met.
I don't think it was a good lesson or that it had made me tougher or a better person I think it just became part of the reason I'm not the same anymore.
The reason I'm so closed off, the reason I don't trust people at all anymore.
I don't think we were supposed to meet.
I think it was a complete misfortune.
And sometimes I think about the day it happened and how one minor decision could have stopped the whole thing.
One moment could have saved me.
Because if we had never met, I would still be all the good parts of me, and there would be a few less parts that need to be fixed.
And I would still go for drives, but you wouldn't enter my thoughts like you were robbing a bank.
And I would still have these friends, but we would not reflect on how warped I was during the time you were a part of my life.
And I would still have fallen in love again, and it wouldn't have taken as much reassurance.
I wouldn't have been shocked that love is so different than I had originally thought.
What doesn't kill you makes you stronger, sure, but I'd be strong anyway, and the time I spent around you is dead to me, wasted time.
I wish I never met you.
I wish fate had been paying attention.
It was an accident that wasn't waiting to happen, a calamity, a catastrophe, a mistake.

I am just back from a two-day workshop in Vienna. I am intellectually energized, as these small-scale workshops are the most productive academic sessions. I have visited Vienna several times, so I wasn‚Äôt into sightseeing. The weather was fantastic, and walking around the city was beautiful. Still, I could ‚Äúunsave‚Äù in my Google Maps to places in my Atlas Obscura list! Josephinum (Old-school medical museum with more than 1,000 wax anatomical models created in the 18th century) and Pathological-anatomical collection in the Narrenturm (wikipedia entry) (Striking former mental hospital from the 1700s, now home to exhibitions on anatomy, illness & death.).
