Title: Contemporary Art on the Lower Danube (Budapest, Salzburg, & Vienna)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Recently, I was on a river cruise through the Lower Danube on AmaWaterways with Christian (TellMeWhyTravel). The stops along the way included Budapest, Hungary, Bratislava, Slovakia, Durnstein, Salzburg, and Vienna, Austria. All of the cities are known for its historical importance from war, due to their strategic location on the river, to arts and culture, where some of the greatest minds which ever existed created. However, by the time you‚Äôve gotten to this page, you already know about Mozart, the Hungarian Parliament, Buda Castle, and the other tourist attractions your tour guide will show you. As our tour guide YOLO (Yes! That‚Äôs his name!) said, ‚ÄúDo you see ABC? ABC, another bloody church, additional broken castle.‚Äù While I can respect the art and architecture, and the blood, sweat, and tears that went into the churches, castles, and monuments of the era, once I‚Äôve seen one (or two) I‚Äôve kind of seen them all. (There are definitely some cool churches and castles but that‚Äôs for a different story!)
I‚Äôm going to take you off the beaten path and show you some of the art and culture of today in these cities. Today‚Äôs obscure artists will be the Mozart‚Äôs, Picasso‚Äôs, and Spielberg‚Äôs of tomorrow. The Internet has brought most of the things to our homes but art is something we must experience in person!
If you‚Äôre staying at the Aria next to the Church of St. Stephen, you‚Äôre in a good place to start.
Most of the museums are within walking distance between 1‚Äì3 miles and you‚Äôll get to see the other landmarks of Budapest along the way!
So let‚Äôs get started!
Want to check out some contemporary art museums further up?
Both of these museums looked pretty cool, unfortunately the Q was temporarily closed for installation.
If you‚Äôre already tired or didn‚Äôt see anything interesting you can check out the Sz√©chenyi Thermal Bath, which features 18 pools and saunas but also has an exciting retro architecture, which reminded me of high school.
But maybe you‚Äôre not done yet. Walk down past the ruin bars to the Palace District.
Have a drink or two here, usually you‚Äôll find some live music, poetry reading, or lively conversation!
From here there are a few advanced options:
About 25 minutes away is the Ludwig Museum, related to the Mumok in Vienna. It‚Äôs worth seeing some of the collection which includes Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol, and Joseph Beuys.
Cross the bridge and at the base of Gell√©rt-hegy Jubileumi park is Faur Zs√≥fi Gallery. We hiked to the top of it, but the park is still undergoing renovations but a stunning view nonetheless.
Also closeby is the music venue A38, where we were lucky enough to see the band Henge.
Not tired yet? Cross the chain bridge and get to the Buda side of the city.
In the oldest part of the city, Obuda, stands a shrine to one of the city‚Äôs most famous contemporary artists, Victor Vasarely, the father of the optical art movement.
Then cross back over to Pest and hit Kalman Maklary Fine Arts an interesting contemporary gallery (no exhibitions this year yet) which is close to parliament and a short stroll from the Aria.
If you happen to come in mid October, check out Art Market Budapest which is also near the first round of galleries near the opera house and the Aria.
Now if you didn‚Äôt finish all of that in your two day pre-cruise, don‚Äôt worry, you‚Äôll have a chance to come back at the end of the cruise!
Sailing
The Slovak National Gallery is close to where the ship docks.
Three options for the outskirts of the city; I don‚Äôt think you can walk here, you might need to take a taxi, bike, or public transportation.
Rudavskys Magic Garden: The garden is closed for the winter, but looks incredible when it‚Äôs warmer!
The J√∫lius Koller Society
Tranzit
Danubiana Meulensteen Art Museum: This looks like a very cool museum atop a peninsula jutting into the Danube. I didn‚Äôt see it from the ship, but along with its sculpture park, it seems like an awesome place to check out the latest contemporary art!
Sailing
The next stop is in the Wachau Valley, specifically Durnstein. While Durnstein is a quiet town with not much contemporary art, 8km from Durnstein is a small cosmopolitan town, Krems an der Donau, with some interesting art options.
The map is zoomed out to show the proximity to Durnstein where the ship is docked.
Sailing
The following day we docked and took about a 90 minute bus ride to the quaint city of Salzburg, known for being the birthplace of Mozart. It‚Äôs also known for being the backdrop to the 1960‚Äôs classic The Sound of Music.
The city is surrounded by a steep rock face which made it an impenetrable during times of war. However, the top of mountain is a contemporary art museum. You get natural and manmade art from the top of the elevator ride!
But before we get there, global gallery Thaddaeus Ropac has two locations in Salzburg! Check to see if there are exhibitions at the farther one near the train station before you trek up there.
Finally, Galerie HAAS & GSCHWANDTNER is moving from its downtown location to somewhere else within Salzburg. Check their website to see where they end up!
Sailing
We made it! Vienna, Austria the largest, most cosmopolitan city on the Danube. The art scene here is huge with tons of galleries, museums, and history.
We will try to avoid the two most famous artists from Austria, Egon Schiele and Gustav Klimt, because the Neue Gallery on 86th and 5th in New York houses Ronald Lauder‚Äôs huge collection of Austrian art including Klimt‚Äôs Lady in Gold.
The bus to old city will drop you about 5 minutes northeast of St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral.
There are a lot of galleries in the first district, here‚Äôs the east side of the city first.
The west side is next, the order is assuming that you are coming from the bus drop off location
On the east side of the outer museum loop
There are a few major art fairs that take place in Vienna:
March: Spark Art Fair
May: Affordable Art Fair
September: Vienna Contemporary and Curated By
November: Vienna Art Week
Austrian artists that I didn‚Äôt get a chance to see:
Stefan Eins: He stopped by my Times Square exhibition multiple times and had some crazy stories about when he started Fashion Moda in the South Bronx in the 80s.
Andre Heller: Multi-hyphenate who commissioned Luna Luna
Helmut Lang: the famed photographer
Franz West: Sculptor and artist
On the outskirts of the city is the Essl Museum, which houses what is considered the most important collection of Austrian art after 1945.
From here the ship sails back to the beginning port, Budapest.
Did we miss something? Drop a comment and we‚Äôll be sure to check it out next time and let you know how it was.
Interested in recreating this experience? (You‚Äôll now have the maps to save time instead of us stumbling around)
Here‚Äôs the link to the AmaWaterways cruise and the Aria hotel, which is voted the best in Central Europe consistently!
NB: There was an issue with Google Maps acting weird so instead of wasting time figuring it out, I made different maps for each art ‚Äúdistrict‚Äù in Budapest and Vienna.

An Austrian Wildlife Icon
These cute animals are European Ground Squirrels, which I saw whilst on holiday in Vienna.
I hadn‚Äôt even heard of them until quite recently. Over the last few years, the British media have been publishing more and more photos of ground squirrels and other wildlife in Vienna. Eventually, I couldn‚Äôt resist heading over to Austria to see what was going on for myself.
There are plenty of public parks in Vienna, but, as far as I know, only a couple of them have ground squirrels. All of my photos were taken at the Blumeng√§rten Hirschstetten, which you can get to quite easily by tram.
Visit in spring or summer, and you should have a great chance of seeing the squirrels. I spotted several within minutes of arriving, and one of them ran right up to my feet as if it was welcoming me to the park.
I assume the squirrels are used to people feeding them, although there are signs asking you not to.

Title: Two Cities, Two Lifestyles: Munich and Vienna in Perspective
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Since I am currently in Munich but usually live in Vienna, I would like to highlight the differences between Viennese and Munich residents. At first glance, one might not believe that Munich residents differ so much from Viennese, but a comparison reveals significant differences. Let‚Äôs first compare the cities to illustrate the differences.
The most noticeable difference is that Vienna is the capital of Austria, while Munich is ‚Äúonly‚Äù a large city in Germany. Munich is slightly smaller than Vienna and has fewer inhabitants. Although Munich has only three-quarters of Vienna‚Äôs population, it is three times as wealthy, which is evident in the people.
Usually, the population is divided into three classes: lower, middle, and upper class. In Munich, however, there seems to be no clear middle class, and the upper class appears very snobbish. This does not mean that there is no middle class, but rather that it is less noticeable. You see either people who look wealthy or those who appear poorer. The middle class behaves more subtly and hides in public: they either dress elegantly to appear upper class or wear normal clothes, making them seem poorer. I correct my previous statement and say that the middle class behaves discreetly. Now let‚Äôs look at the people in Vienna.
Vienna is divided into districts, but there are only a few districts that clearly represent a social class. Even in the wealthy districts, there are hardly any snobs or visibly rich people. In Vienna, the middle class predominates. Everyone looks as if they earn roughly the same. There are exceptions here as well, just like in Munich.
Although I have strongly criticized Munich here, it is a beautiful city. Of course, there are also unfriendly people in Munich, but I have not encountered any so far. In conclusion, both Munich and Vienna are worth visiting.

Member-only story
--
Share
It‚Äôs hard to believe that I‚Äôve now been in Vienna for over a year. I‚Äôve seen so much, but there is so much more of the city to explore.
Often I spend Saturdays walking around trying to see something new. Yesterday was exactly that.
I discovered there is an English-language bookstore here so I headed there first. I do speak and read German fluently, but I prefer English books (also to keep my English going, since I mainly live and work in German here).
The shop is appropriately called Shakespeare & Company, located in the center of Vienna at Sterngasse 2 not too far from the Danube canal. It is stuffed full of all kinds of books both fiction and non-fiction. It was a fun place to browse!
Then I wandered around that area, which I hadn‚Äôt really seen in detail so far, heading toward a meeting with a friend. The caf√© we wanted to go to was sadly closed, so we headed across the canal to the 2nd district and a lovely caf√©/bistro called Goldener Papagei (Golden Parrot) at Praterstrasse 17. We sat outside, though it was a very windy day. There are many tables under some lovely trees: a perfect spot for a chat and a drink.
The perfect day came to a close meeting an American friend from Germany for dinner at one of my favorite Israeli restaurants, Makom, at Schottenfeldgasse 18 in the 7th district.
For more on me and my writing, check out my website!

Title: Vienna Waits For You
Content:

You know that feeling when a song hits you right in the gut? Like, it wasn‚Äôt just made for you, but like it somehow knew what you needed to hear before you even did? That‚Äôs what ‚ÄúVienna‚Äù by Billy Joel did to me.
I came across that song again during my drive home, on a random night just a few weeks ago, when I was overanalyzing my life, my future, and whether I‚Äôm already too late to do something meaningful. The classic mid-to-late 20s spiral, you know? One minute I‚Äôm driving slowly through the city, the next I‚Äôm questioning my entire existence.
Then, boom; ‚ÄúVienna waits for you‚Äù.
I don‚Äôt know what it is about that line, but it unlocked something in me. I‚Äôve never thought about, let alone visited Vienna. Maybe it‚Äôs the gentle piano intro. Maybe it‚Äôs the way Billy sings it like a wise old friend sitting next to me at 3AM, telling me to breathe.
‚ÄúSlow down, you crazy child. You‚Äôre so ambitious for a juvenile.‚Äù
I felt exposed. How dare he come for my entire personality like that? But also, he‚Äôs right. I am ambitious. I‚Äôve always wanted to get things done fast, prove myself, complete all the milestones before I hit my imaginary deadline. And lately, that mindset has been eating at me. I kept thinking, ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt I have everything figured out yet?‚Äù
But Vienna reminds me that I don‚Äôt have to. I‚Äôm still young. A 26 year-old is basically a 6 year-old in the ‚Äúadult‚Äù life. And ‚Äúyouth‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean I have to hustle 24/7. It means I have time to figure things out. It means I can still dream big without burning out trying to make it happen as fast as possible.
There‚Äôs something deeply comforting about being told that it‚Äôs okay to not be in a rush. We don‚Äôt get that a lot. Being told that success doesn‚Äôt expire at 30. That if I haven‚Äôt landed my dream job, or released that album, or written that book yet, it doesn‚Äôt mean I have failed. It just means I‚Äôm still on my way.
And that‚Äôs more than okay.
‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the fire, what‚Äôs the hurry about? You better cool it off before you burn it out.‚Äù
That line gets me every time. Because that fire, yes. I have felt it. I still feel it. The desire to do something great, to not waste time. But sometimes, that fire turns into anxiety. Into comparison. Into restlessness. And this song basically told me, ‚ÄúHey, chill. You have time. You‚Äôre doing fine.‚Äù
Lately, every time I get overwhelmed about the future or about the feeling like I‚Äôm not doing enough, I put this song on. And for those three and a half minutes, I always feel like the noise quiets down. I remember that life isn‚Äôt a race. That I don‚Äôt have to catch up to anyone. That I‚Äôm allowed to take detours, to pause, to just‚Ä¶ be.
And beyond all that, the song just feels beautiful. The melody is gentle, a little wistful, but hopeful. It‚Äôs not sad. It‚Äôs patient. Like Vienna itself, whatever it symbolizes, it can wait. It‚Äôs not going anywhere. And neither is my worth.
I think the main thing that Vienna taught me is: I‚Äôm not late. I‚Äôm not behind. I‚Äôm exactly where I need to be. And sometimes, slowing things down is the most powerful thing I can do.
Because Vienna waits for me.
And that‚Äôs more than enough.

Title: Keeping Control Human: Youth insights from the Vienna Conference on Autonomous Weapons
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
by Jefferson Batesimah
The Vienna Conference on Autonomous Weapons, dubbed ‚ÄúHumanity at the Crossroads,‚Äù addressed the urgent need to regulate deadly autonomous weapons systems. As a youth delegate, I gained valuable insights into this critical issue. Here‚Äôs a snapshot of what I learned:
Understanding the Big Picture
The conference shed light on the serious challenges posed by autonomous weapons. They could make conflicts worse, harm civilians, and disrupt efforts to keep peace worldwide.
Why Human Control Matters
A key lesson was the importance of humans staying in charge of decisions about using force. Letting machines make life-or-death choices raises big moral and legal questions. We need clear rules to make sure people are responsible and to stop these weapons from causing harm.
Talking Ethics
We spent time discussing what‚Äôs right and wrong when it comes to autonomous weapons. We talked about how to respect people‚Äôs dignity and protect them from these weapons‚Äô dangers. We also thought about how using these weapons might change society in the long run and change our relationship with technology.
Challenges We Face
Even though many people agree on the need for rules, there are still big challenges ahead. Some powerful governments and tech companies control a lot of the conversation. It‚Äôs tough for other voices, like from everyday people and community groups, to be heard.
Youth Power
Young people like us played a big part in the conference. Our fresh ideas and energy showed how important it is to get everyone involved in the discussion to address autonomous weapons. We left feeling inspired and ready to push for change in our communities.
What Comes Next
The conference wasn‚Äôt just talk, it was a call to action. We agreed to work even harder to establish strong global rules for autonomous weapons. But it won‚Äôt happen overnight. We need to keep up the pressure and work together to make real change.
In sum, the Vienna Conference on Autonomous Weapons was a chance to learn, share ideas, and get ready for action. We learned how crucial it is to keep humans in control of decisions about life and death in warfare. As we move forward, let‚Äôs stay focused on making the world safer and fairer for everyone.
--
--
With growing digital dehumanisation, the Stop Killer Robots campaign works to ensure human control in the use of force. www.stopkillerrobots.org

‚ÄúBe a fool. For love. For yourself.‚Äù -Bourdain
I was done with buses after my previous experience, Caroline knew that. So, even though it was a short trip, we opted for the train. We sat in the bar car, drinking Guinness and smoking cigs for the entirety of the 60-minute ride. Caroline smoked Marlboro Lights; I smoked Parliament Regulars. They didn‚Äôt sell lights anywhere in Europe, which drove me mad. You‚Äôd think the two would taste and smoke similarly, but they don‚Äôt, not even close. It‚Äôs like if Coke tasted like Coke, and Diet Coke tasted like lemonade. Very confusing.
Things naturally became a bit more personal now that we were alone.
Caroline: How are you doing since your dad died? Wanna let anything out?
Me: Well‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm doing terrible, actually. He left me with all this pain and anger I don‚Äôt deserve or know what to do with. I thought he‚Äôd take it with him when he died, but somehow, he transferred it to me, and now I feel worse than I did when he was alive. If I‚Äôd known I‚Äôd feel this way in the end, I wouldn‚Äôt have cared about him so much; I wouldn‚Äôt have spent my whole life concerned about his health. What was the fucking point? Why did I put myself through all that when I didn‚Äôt have to?
Caroline: Sam, you learned how to be empathetic, and compassionate. You care about people deeply, that‚Äôs very rare. Those are all wonderful qualities you should be proud of. You took on responsibilities that no child should have to take on, but they only made you stronger, whether you see it now or not. Death is a part of life, and it sounds like you looked it right in the eye. It‚Äôs an experience you‚Äôll cherish one day. I believe that. With time, the pain will ease, and you‚Äôll begin to see the experience in a different light. Trust me.
Me: How do you know this?
Caroline: I‚Äôm an owl.
Me: So, what do I do in the meantime, until the pain eases?
Caroline: I don‚Äôt know, just keep hopping around. You‚Äôll figure it out.
*
We arrived in Vienna with no plans, and nowhere to stay, so we walked around the city center looking for a hostel. When we got tired of carrying our bags, we stopped in a bar to rest and ask for directions. Before Google and Yelp, it was bartenders who could tell you about every business within a 5-mile radius. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt go to that one. Go to this one. Ask for Ron. Tell him I sent you.‚Äù There‚Äôs very little of that anymore.
The music disturbed me as soon as we walked in.
Me: What is this hot garbage they‚Äôre playing?
Caroline: It sounds like David Hasselhoff.
Me: You‚Äôre not going to believe this, but, in America there‚Äôs an actor with the same name. He‚Äôs on a show called Baywatch. Isn‚Äôt that crazy?
Caroline: Are you being serious right now?
Me: Yeah, the same exact name.
Caroline: IT‚ÄôS THE SAME PERSON.
Me: Wait‚Ä¶ So, he‚Äôs a musician too?
Caroline: He‚Äôs the most popular artist in Germany and Austria. He‚Äôs put out more than 20 albums.
Me: Are you sure there aren‚Äôt two of them?
Caroline: We also have Baywatch in Australia. I don‚Äôt live on the moon.
While having a drink, we met a few fellow backpackers who were staying at a nearby hostel, the Vienna Hostel Ruthensteiner. They kindly walked us there, and to our delight, there were rooms still available.
It was the nicest hostel I‚Äôd seen up until that point, like almost hotel-level nice. There was a large kitchen with a dining room, a recreation atrium, and a courtyard with one of those life-sized chess boards where you lug the pieces from square to square. The only thing it didn‚Äôt have was a bar, which was just fine with me because I needed to lay low for a few days. My circuits had begun to fry, and I was ahead of my planned Adderall pace because I was too kind to Simon. What I needed more than anything was rest. Caroline felt the same. She‚Äôd been on the road for four weeks and was running out of juice too.
That night we shared a few bottles of wine (that was considered not drinking for me) and wrote letters to our friends back home. I‚Äôd bought some vintage airmail envelopes in Amsterdam, the blue ones with red and white stripes around the border, along with some ultra-thin paper, and I wanted to put them to use. I LOVE thin paper; there‚Äôs something about the way it feels in my hand. As a kid, tracing paper was my jam. I‚Äôd try to do my assignments on it, but teachers wouldn‚Äôt let me. As an act of rebellion, I‚Äôd take regular notebook paper and crumple it to make it softer.
I wrote Pat a letter, recounting my trip so far.
Aye,
You won‚Äôt believe me, but I jizzed while looking into a pimp‚Äôs eyes. It was as bad as you think it would be, maybe worse. I also have a travel girlfriend; her name is Caroline. We‚Äôre in Vienna together. I never thought I‚Äôd have a first date in a new country, but here we are. She isn‚Äôt Meghan, but then again, who is?
We may have sex tonight; I can feel it. The anticipation is even better than the act, though, is it not? I have no clue where I‚Äôm going next, or if Caroline will be traveling with me, but I‚Äôm thinking Germany because it‚Äôs not too far away. Then Spain. That long ride is going to be a motherfucker though.
I talked to Caroline about my dad‚Äôs death yesterday. She, you, and 2 random ladies I met in Paris are the only ones who know how I‚Äôve been feeling. I‚Äôm trying my hardest to share, but I don‚Äôt want to be a constant downer, ya know? Caroline told me it‚Äôll get easier, like you did, but I just hope I‚Äôm not too far gone before the tide turns. Her brother died tragically, but she has more perspective than me because she‚Äôs an owl. I‚Äôm a frog, by the way. I‚Äôll explain later.
I told Caroline about you, and she said to send her regards. So‚Ä¶ Regards. I miss you, man. See you on the flip side.
Sam
The place was nearly full when we checked in, so unfortunately Caroline and I couldn‚Äôt stay in the same room. We each had to take a single bed in one that was already occupied. So, after kissing goodnight, we parted ways.
Lying in bed, I felt like a high schooler, excited to see my girlfriend by the lockers the next morning. God, what an amazing feeling that was‚Ä¶ Walking the halls before school, passing by your crush‚Äôs locker over and over, trying to make your meeting seem unplanned. ‚ÄúOh me, I was just going to chemistry. Funny seeing you here,‚Äù you say, as if you‚Äôre not mentally orgasming. If they made a drug to capture that feeling, we‚Äôd all be addicted.
April 8, 2006
The next morning, we had breakfast together in the courtyard. While eating, I taught Caroline the rules of chess. Kevin was the one who taught me how to play. He‚Äôd beat me every single time then say something nice like ‚Äúyou‚Äôre really improving.‚Äù It only pissed me off more, but he meant it. We played one practice game with takebacks so she could get used to playing on her own. I stood behind her and helped her move the large pieces, rubbing up on her in the process the way a pervy golf instructor would. I wasn‚Äôt slick, but I didn‚Äôt have to be. I could tell how much she enjoyed feeling me press up against her. At one point she reached behind me to pull me closer, and I got an erection.
Me: I never thought I‚Äôd get a boner while playing chess.
Caroline: What is wrong with you?
Me: It‚Äôs a natural reaction to friction.
Caroline: Jeez, that‚Äôs not what I meant. Why do you say these things out loud?
Me: Isn‚Äôt that just part of my charm?
Caroline: I guess so, Mr. McEnroe. I guess so.
*
We went to a museum that afternoon, but for the life of me I can‚Äôt remember which one, or what was inside. It could have been dinosaur bones or art; I have no clue. Museums aren‚Äôt my thing. They do absolutely nothing for me. I mean, I want to party, not stare at a party.
A Mitch Hedberg joke comes to mind‚Ä¶
‚ÄúI was at a craft fair and there was a jar of Jellybeans. The guy said, ‚ÄòGuess how many Jellybeans are in the jar, and win a prize‚Äô. Aw, come on man, let me just have some.‚Äù
I popped out for a joint at one point, and afterwards I bought a sausage accompanied with mustard so spicy it shot out my nose when I coughed. A few teens laughed and pointed while I poured water on my face to cool down. One kid called me a ‚ÄúMus-tard.‚Äù I‚Äôll never forget that little bastard.
When I went back inside, I wreaked of weed so Caroline said it was time to go. I didn‚Äôt argue. In fact, if I‚Äôd known how self-conscious she was about the smell of weed, I would have gotten high much earlier. I‚Äôve always enjoyed spreading weed smoke to the masses. If you don‚Äôt like the smell, too bad. I don‚Äôt like your smell either.
That night Caroline and I met in the common area for our date. She made minestrone soup for us to fill up on so we could save our money for drinks. My high school crush, Laura, loved minestrone soup too. Maybe I‚Äôm just attracted to the Minestrone gene. When we were done, we searched for a place to drink using the hostel‚Äôs free internet. We decided on a place called The Chapel Bar. It was a little more up-scale than the pubs we‚Äôd been going to, but shit, we were going on a date. Why not class it up?
When we got there around 8pm we were the only ones in the place. The entire bar was empty, the tables and booths too. The bartender welcomed us like he‚Äôd been waiting for company and waved us over to the bar. He looked visibly disappointed when we beelined for a booth. Neither of us were in the mood for small talk, so each time we needed drinks, I walked up to the bar to order. It became increasingly awkward with each trip, so I started ordering in bunches, which seemed to only bother him more. We were chasing beers with shots of Caroline‚Äôs favorite drink, Sambuca. You know how I feel about Sambuca. ‚ÄúYou have to drink it,‚Äù she told me, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs named after you.‚Äù
We got drunk fast, and after a few rounds we were making out at the table. The bartender gave us nasty ‚Äúget a room‚Äù looks, but we ignored him. Then, I devised a plan, one that has been devised many a time before, but never by me.
Me: Meet me in the bathroom.
I said it with confidence. It didn‚Äôt require a response. It was a command.
When she burst in, I pulled her pants down and put her in the sink, something I hadn‚Äôt premeditated. I was in a flow state. I took her shirt off and she did the same with mine.
Caroline: Do you have a condom?
Me: Shit, I don‚Äôt.
Caroline: You didn‚Äôt get one?
Me: I forgot.
Then, we heard a knock at the door.
Bartender: We don‚Äôt allow fucking in here. Come out now or I‚Äôm coming in.
We scrambled to put our clothes back on, then I opened the door. The bartender was still standing there, bill in hand.
Bartender: I added a cleaning fee. Pay now and go.
I handed him whatever money I had on me, then Caroline and I ran out laughing hysterically.
On the walk back to the hostel, we smoked a joint and Caroline threw up. I expected to be the one puking, on account of the Sambuca, but it was Caroline heaving on the side of the road. I held her hair back. Most women cry when they‚Äôre wasted and vomiting, but Caroline laughed. She had no shame. Mid-vomit she posed a very serious question.
Caroline: Don‚Äôt you think we should end on a high note?
Me: You mean, tonight? This doesn‚Äôt seem like a very high note.
Caroline: No, I mean ‚Äúus.‚Äù Like, tonight we go to bed, and we never see each other again. We just go on our separate ways when we wake up. I want to remember you like this.
Me: Holding your hair back while you vomit?
Caroline: No. I mean, before we complicate things. I want you to live in my mind as a perfect memory.
Me: It‚Äôs not because you don‚Äôt want to have sex with me, right?
Caroline: I very much want to have sex with you. It isn‚Äôt about that. It‚Äôs about preserving a special memory and locking it away in a little box that you can peek in whenever you want. I want you just like this.
Me: I could use a box with something nice in it‚Ä¶ Right now, I only have ones I want to keep shut.
Caroline: You see what I‚Äôm saying?
Me: So, this would be it, forever?
Caroline: Yeah.
Me: What if we end up seeing each other again in another country?
Caroline: Then it was meant to be.
Me: Fair enough, pretty lady.
Caroline: Goodbye, my sweet Johnny Mac.
Me: Goodbye, Caroline.
I walked her to her room, gave her a kiss on the cheek, and that was it. She flew away the next morning, leaving me to hop around on my own, with my little box.
--
--
Writing a memoir, sharing portions here.

In praise of 15 minute cities: Why a ‚Äòcity of short distances‚Äô feels better.
‚ÄúPeople realised the state of their neighbourhoods could change. They could enjoy life in front of their front doors without owning a garden, without having a balcony,‚Äù said Vienna‚Äôs former Deputy Mayor, Maria Vassilakou.
Rated no.1 in the Economist Intelligence Unit‚Äôs (EIU) Global Liveability Index, Vienna frequently places as one of the world‚Äôs top cities to live in. And while it‚Äôs never explicitly called a 15- or 20-minute city, it nevertheless responds to the social, technological and ecological challenges that we all face.
Described as ‚Äúthe city of short distances‚Äù, urban planning policy in the city has long put pedestrians first (since the 80s, in fact). And, a few decades down the line, the results are evident everywhere: pavement expansions, improvements to public transport connectivity, sports provision and ‚Äî notably ‚Äî the longest continuous pedestrianised space in Europe, in the form of shopping street Mariahilferstra√üe.
Vienna feels equitable and inclusive, too. It‚Äôs affordable, for starters. And a focus on gender mainstreaming, a strategy adopted to achieve gender equality in society, has translated to things like fully illuminated footpaths, more entrances and exits to parks, grants for neighbourhood open space, and additional premiums for research conducted by women ‚Äî a real-world commitment to urban planning that‚Äôs led by the needs and safety of citizens.
LIVEABILITY SCORE: 8/10. A compact and connected city geared towards pedestrians, safety and people-first infrastructure.
--
--
Brands. Strategy. Culture. Places. Susie is the MD of Modern Designers & co-founder of Common Ground.

Congratulations! You managed to make the girl who didn‚Äôt believe in love fall for you.
You made her believe the two of you shared something special, something meant to be.
You made her feel like you‚Äôd never truly hurt her.
She had her doubts, but they were born out of fear ‚Äî fear because she loved you so much that she couldn‚Äôt imagine life without you.
She thought she was just being protective of her heart, until one day, all her fears became reality.
She watched the man she loved with her whole heart hurt her and let her down.
Seeing you talk to your ex, sounding so happy, broke something deep inside her.
Every ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù and ‚ÄúI promise‚Äù now feels like empty words.
She wonders how someone who says they love you could hurt you so deeply, break your trust, and make you feel like a fool for believing in them.
And yet, she stays.
She tries to work through it because she doesn‚Äôt want to give up on you.
But your words are starting to cut deeper than you realize.
She‚Äôs ‚Äútoo emotional,‚Äù a ‚Äúpick me,‚Äù or just the ‚Äúsad girl.‚Äù
The person she once felt so close and safe with now feels like a stranger.
She‚Äôs scared to be herself, scared to open up. Her heart no longer feels safe with the man she loves.
The worst part?
There‚Äôs still nothing she wouldn‚Äôt do for you. She‚Äôd destroy herself emotionally a million times over if it meant making you happy.

Title: Focus on a city : Vienna ‚Äî Austria
Content:

Vienna is such a historic city known everywhere around the world for its art and culture. Here is an article that will help you to enjoy your trip in the capital of Austria.
Also, remember that I‚Äôm writing on Medium and that growing a huge community over there is very important for me. The name of my channel is ‚ÄúCl√©ment Delabruy√®re‚Äù so please follow my channel : https://medium.com/@clement.delabruyere
Vienna, the capital of Austria, is a fascinating city that blends history with modernism. Covering an area of around 414 km¬≤, it is home to almost 1.9 million inhabitants. With its cobbled streets, Baroque palaces and prestigious museums, Vienna is a true cultural and architectural gem.
The city is divided into 23 districts, each offering its own unique charm and ambience. Vienna plays a major geopolitical role as the headquarters of numerous international organizations, including the International Atomic Energy Agency and the United Nations Industrial Development Organization.
Classical music has a special place in Vienna‚Äôs history, having witnessed the birth of legendary composers such as Mozart, Beethoven and Strauss. Viennese waltzes and famous operas still thrill the city. Vienna is also renowned for its culinary tradition, with historic caf√©s offering delicious pastries such as sachertorte.
The Sch√∂nbrunn Palace, a former imperial residence, and St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral, a Gothic icon, are among the iconic sites to visit. Well-tended gardens and abundant green spaces, notably Prater Park, add to Viennese quality of life.
Vienna stands out for its concern for sustainability and quality of life, regularly topping world rankings in this area. Its efficient public transport system and green initiatives are testimony to this commitment.
In short, Vienna embodies an enchanting blend of historical heritage, artistic creativity and contemporary progress, making it a city that captivates the hearts and minds of those who discover it.
Vienna‚Äôs history dates back to antiquity, when the Romans established a military camp on the banks of the Danube around the 1st century AD. This camp, called Vindobona, was the starting point for the city‚Äôs development. Over the centuries, Vindobona flourished as a point of convergence for trade routes and cultures, benefiting from its strategic position at the crossroads of Central Europe.
In the Middle Ages, Vienna became an important political and cultural center under the Babenbergs, then the Habsburgs from the 13th century onwards. In 1440, Emperor Frederick III established the imperial residence in Vienna, laying the foundations for a long period of imperial grandeur.
The 16th century saw Vienna confronted with the challenges posed by the Ottoman wars, with the sieges of Vienna in 1529 and 1683. These sieges were crucial moments in the city‚Äôs history, marking unsuccessful Ottoman attempts to conquer Central Europe.
In the 18th and 19th centuries, Vienna became the heart of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, a major power in Europe. During this period, the city became a center of classical music and art, home to such geniuses as Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert. Baroque architecture flourished, giving rise to iconic buildings such as Sch√∂nbrunn Palace.
The 20th century was marked by upheaval, including two world wars and the annexation of Austria by Nazi Germany in 1938. After the Second World War, Vienna was divided into four zones of occupation, reflecting the Cold War period.
After the end of the occupation in 1955, Vienna regained its status as Austrian capital and diplomatic center. It hosted international organizations such as the UN and OPEC, consolidating its position in world affairs.
Today, Vienna continues to shine as a cosmopolitan city, blending its historic heritage with a dynamic modernity. The city has preserved its rich past while looking to the future, making it one of Europe‚Äôs leading cultural and intellectual destinations.
This imperial palace and its magnificent gardens are a symbol of the opulence of the Austrian Empire. Don‚Äôt miss a tour of the palace‚Äôs sumptuous rooms and a stroll through the well-kept gardens.
This iconic Gothic cathedral dominates downtown Vienna. Its elaborate architecture and impressive spire make it a must-see.
This Baroque complex comprises two palaces and superb gardens. It houses a remarkable collection of Austrian art, including works by Gustav Klimt, notably ‚ÄúThe Kiss‚Äù.
World-renowned for its superb acoustics and artistic performances, the opera house is an iconic venue for classical music lovers.
A former imperial palace, the Hofburg today houses several museums and institutions, including the Austrian National Library and the Sissi Museum.
This museum houses an exceptional collection of graphic art, including drawings, engravings and prints by masters such as Michelangelo, Rembrandt and D√ºrer.
These two museums are located side by side and offer impressive collections of art and natural history.
This city park is home to the famous Wiener Riesenrad, Vienna‚Äôs iconic Ferris wheel, as well as numerous attractions, restaurants and green spaces.
These venues represent just a fraction of what Vienna has to offer in terms of culture, history and entertainment. The city is full of treasures to explore, and each corner offers a unique and enriching experience for visitors.
An Austrian composer prodigy, Mozart is one of the most influential figures in classical music. He composed over 600 works, including operas, symphonies and concertos, making a profound impact on the European musical landscape.
The father of psychoanalysis, Freud revolutionized our understanding of human psychology. His theories on the unconscious, the Oedipus complex and the role of dreams left a lasting imprint on the human sciences.
German composer and pianist, although born in Bonn, Beethoven spent much of his life in Vienna. He is famous for his transition from Classicism to Romanticism, with emblematic works such as his 9th Symphony.
Austrian Symbolist painter and leading figure of the Vienna Secession, Klimt is known for his ornate portraits and bold works, including ‚ÄúThe Kiss‚Äù. He helped shape Art Nouveau and Modernism.
An Austrian Expressionist artist, Schiele was renowned for his provocative portraits and bold artistic vision. His unique style left a lasting imprint on 20th-century art, despite his untimely death at the age of 28.
These five figures left a significant mark on the history of art, music, psychology and culture in Vienna and around the world.

Content:

The first time I heard Vienna by Billy Joel, I was on a train home after college, the world outside dipped in the amber light of a tired evening. I had just bombed an interview I had poured my soul into. My head was a whirlwind of spiralling doubts‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääabout my future, about whether I had what it takes, about everything. And then Vienna arrived‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot like a pop anthem or an uplifting chorus, but like a friend who sits with you in silence and tells you exactly what you need to hear.
‚ÄúSlow down, you crazy child
You‚Äôre so ambitious for a juvenile
But then if you‚Äôre so smart, tell me
Why are you still so afraid?‚Äù
In that moment, tears welled up ‚Äî not because of the failure, but because of how deeply the song understood the ache behind it. How it met me in the in-between, where so many of us live: driven but unsure, hopeful but exhausted.
That lyric wasn‚Äôt just about me. It was about a generation raised to hustle, to quantify their worth through grades, internships, side projects, and glowing LinkedIn posts. I had come to think of life as a ladder. But Vienna whispered of a different metaphor ‚Äî a garden, perhaps. Something that grows in time, with pauses, with pruning, with seasons of bloom and rest.
It reminded me of The Midnight Library by Matt Haig ‚Äî a book about a woman who, burdened by regret, stumbles upon a mystical library containing infinite versions of her life. Each book in the library reveals a different path she could have taken. The novel forces you to ask: what if the life you‚Äôre racing toward isn‚Äôt the one that would‚Äôve made you happy? What if the pauses, the missed exits, the so-called failures, are the very fabric of the life meant for you?
‚ÄúWhen will you realize, Vienna waits for you?‚Äù
In Joel‚Äôs metaphor, Vienna isn‚Äôt a destination you rush to. It‚Äôs the life that waits ‚Äî patiently, quietly ‚Äî for you to stop sprinting long enough to hear its music. It‚Äôs the version of you that grows not by doing more, but by understanding what enough feels like. That revelation mirrored the essence of The Midnight Library: the idea that you‚Äôre not a failure just because you‚Äôre not on someone else‚Äôs timeline.
The truth is, I didn‚Äôt need a new plan that day on the train. I needed perspective. I needed someone ‚Äî or something ‚Äî to tell me that I hadn‚Äôt missed my moment, that there are many doors yet to open. And Vienna, in its tender, piano-laced wisdom, did exactly that.
‚ÄúYou can get what you want or you can just get old
You‚Äôre gonna kick off before you even get halfway through‚Äù
Those words haunted me. Because I had never thought of burnout as a kind of death. But that‚Äôs what it is: the death of wonder, of joy, of being here. I was chasing a life so hard that I was forgetting to live the one already unfolding around me.
Billy Joel‚Äôs Vienna didn‚Äôt just soften my ambition ‚Äî it redefined it. It told me that ambition rooted in fear is a form of imprisonment. But ambition rooted in patience? In stillness? That‚Äôs purpose. That‚Äôs wisdom.
So now, when I feel that panic ‚Äî that rising tide of ‚Äúnot enough,‚Äù of ‚Äútoo late,‚Äù of ‚Äúwhat am I doing with my life?‚Äù ‚Äî I don‚Äôt drown. I return to the song. To Joel‚Äôs voice, gently guiding me back.
‚ÄúSlow down, you‚Äôre doing fine.‚Äù
And just like the woman in The Midnight Library learns: the life you‚Äôre meant to live isn‚Äôt the one with the loudest applause. It‚Äôs the one where you‚Äôre fully alive. The one that waits for you ‚Äî just like Vienna.

Hundertwasserhaus is hard to describe, but it overloads your mind when you see it. There is so much to look at.

‚Üí Martin Hanley: A Memoir
This memoir was written in 2004/2005
I was born on March 14th, 1931 to Margarethe and Leopold Hahn of Neueweltgasse 23 in Hietzing, Vienna. Hitzing, then as now, was a pleasant leafy, upmarket suburb, our home perhaps just ten blocks distant from Schonbrun Palace, one of the sumptuous palaces built by the Habsburg dynasty.
One of my earliest recollections goes back to the age of 5. Opposite our first floor apartment was a little triangle of grass, with a few flowers and 2 garden benches, which was tucked in between our building and the main road, the Hitzinger Hauptstrasse. The apartment had deep window ledges on which I could stand and lean against the wrought iron railings which were erected for security reasons. Later I watched Hitler‚Äôs tanks roll into Vienna from this balcony. As we lived on the 1st floor there were only a few steps to the ground floor and I was allowed to ride on the garden path alone on a tricycle parked in a ‚Äòcave‚Äô under the building. After the war I visited our old home with Susi my wife, and found the ‚Äòcave‚Äô to be a little opening in the building near the staircase outside.
Apart from the ‚ÄúSchonbrun‚Äù palace of the Emperors, Hitzing boasted a zoo and many coffee houses of note. The coffee house was an important factor in my parents‚Äô generations enjoyment of life. Its ambience, seating arrangements, free offering of daily newspapers to its clientele, not to mention the quality of its coffee and ‚Äòmehlspeisen‚Äô or cakes was serious business, similar in importance to the Anglo Saxon pub or the American local bar.
Listening to stories of the older generation I realized that although acquisition of luxuries and assets were not on the agenda, my parents and their circles lived a very agreeable life. I have pictures of family holidays taken in villages, on lovely lakes, of my parents at parties and so on. It can be explained by understanding the culture of European middle class life. In Austria, especially Vienna, the culture of theatre, music, stays in the country in summer and skiing from peasant huts in the mountains in winter was maintained to a greater or smaller degree.
Living on the outskirts of Vienna there were advantages for me, as in winter I could be taken on my sled to the ‚ÄòRotenberg‚Äô or Red Hill to slide up and down in the snow on fine afternoons. My Nanny would pull the sled up this little hill in company with other nursemaids similarly out with their charges. Nanny was a fixture, and one of whom I have fond memories. I have a picture of her with me in my leather pants aged perhaps two or three. She also cooked and made the beds. As she had off only one Sunday every fortnight some might say that she lived in slavery. Not so. She was part of the family and had a home which was warm in winter and where meals were regular. A small pittance was hers to spend as well. Far different from where she came from. This enabled people like my parents to live a very civilised life with very little money.
In the depression, working people in industry or on the land saw real hardship. I was given a spare lunch to school to distribute to children less fortunate than I.
My father was a hard worker all his life. In the 1920s and 30s he worked as a salesman in his father‚Äôs firm, Adolf Hahne & Sohne, a merchant of ‚Äúspitzen‚Äù ‚Äî feathers, boas, lace and embroideries, the traditional Austrian lace, still seen in minute quantities today, was used on almost every woman‚Äôs garment. In white or colourful on ‚Äòdirndl‚Äô, the traditional skirt, for blouses, on caps and underwear. The firm had prospered in the period when ‚ÄòDirndl‚Äô, the Austrian national costume, was the mode. Manufactured and distributed worldwide, laces were an important ingredient of fashion for what must have been at least 2 generations, as my grandfather had inherited the business. In my father‚Äôs time his 2 sons were in the business, both as salesmen. My Uncle Walter‚Äôs sales territory was part of Germany and France. He enjoyed himself very much one believes as he was single, tall and handsome. He had a good time by all accounts.
My father, on the other hand, was allotted the tougher territory, Hungary, Slovakia, Serbia and suchlike. Although also handsome, he was already married and the small traders he dealt with, mostly Jewish haberdashers in little country towns were prone to be cashless, especially after a family wedding, birth or bar mitzvah. He travelled for several weeks at a time, in a small ‚ÄòSteyer‚Äô motor car on terrible country roads.
In Vienna, in the thirties, survival in business was not always guaranteed. The Depression had driven my grandfather‚Äôs firm into bankruptcy three times. Bankruptcy in those days evolved into a sort of payment agreement, in German: ‚Äúausgleich‚Äù. Say you owed a hundred thousand with no prospect of paying it back. You settled with your creditors for whatever, agreed‚Ä¶.and then carried on. My father‚Äôs stories to me of his ‚Äúausgleich‚Äù experiences with his customers, though funny, hid the tensions of those times.
When Hitler walked into Vienna, Jewish premises were ‚ÄúArisiert‚Äù, meaning literally ‚ÄòArienised‚Äô (as in Aryan!) ie. Nazified‚Ä¶Nazi hoodlums, some in uniforms, entered, demanded all keys and normally gave the occupants a few hours to take their personal effects and get out. Confiscated just like that‚Ä¶ period, full stop‚Ä¶ premises, stock, bank accounts.
That didn‚Äôt happen to Adolf Hahn & Sohn, because the business had gone broke some years before. The company went into receivership in 1932. The Depression added another victim, but it not only the lack of business which was the cause. My grandfather, who must have been well in his sixties, married Claire, an elegant woman a good 30 years his junior. This necessitated a new house with fine furniture and the trimmings. The romance proved too big a burden on the business, as well as the two family members who worked in it.
The German Wehrmacht were welcomed by the Austrian populace after the ‚ÄúKristallnacht‚Äù Troops occupied Vienna from March 13th, 1938. On March 14th, my birthday, I stood on my window balcony and observed with childish fascination the armoured wagons, mobile cannons and personnel trucks standing on the road outside, the uniformed Wehrmacht soldiers laughing and joking with the locals while the Hietzing Synagogue around the corner was torched.
We lived in the same apartment until we escaped from Vienna, except for the very last few days when we stayed hidden in a city apartment owned by ‚ÄòTante Ida‚Äô, my grandfather‚Äôs sister and a very old lady. I was later told my father had already hidden there for a few days previously.
In the months from the Anschluss till we left the country in September 1938, I continued to attend the same school. My only vivid memory was of the same teacher, but he was wearing a red armband with a black swastika on a white circle and the Hebrew teacher‚Äôs red star of David on a yellow armband. We children did not wear any outward marking at that time.
It was time to leave Austria, where my family roots went back at least for the 3 generations I knew.

Title: Escape to Shanghai

‚Üí Vienna
By 1938, America, England, Canada, Australia and most other countries had either tightened immigration intake or outright banned foreigners. Apparently a Mr. Rogers, an Australian businessman, was visiting Vienna in 1938 and somehow met our family. He offered to help and assisted my father applying for a visa to Australia, sponsoring us. The application was refused. Mr. Rogers subsequently wrote telling my father that stating to be a tradesman as a ‚Äúchauffeur‚Äù was the worst entry possible as his son, aged 17, ‚Äúcould drive a car better than you can!‚Äù That was the end of that.
The Depression had not lifted entirely in most of the Western world. In any case, the few who did receive visas to desired country destinations had to have sums of money my father did not possess. My grandfather‚Äôs business, in which my father and his brother Walter worked, barely supported the family. This was not entirely due to economic conditions ‚Äî it has been attributed largely to my grandfather‚Äôs second marriage to a beautiful woman some 30 years younger than himself. She apparently required a new house with the best trimmings.
Jews who didn‚Äôt make it to desired country destinations had the possibility of buying passports for entry to South American countries like Argentina and Uruguay. Switzerland was open only to the super rich, and then only as permanent ‚Äòtourists‚Äô. Refugees like my parents, who left matters too late with very little money, found safety in the few destinations that made no demands. There was Shanghai, Trinidad, Curacao, and small black African states. Israel, Palestine in those days, was quite sealed against Jewish immigration by British decree, although several hundred young people entered and were smuggled in right throughout the war.
You didn‚Äôt need an entry visa, you just had to get there.
My parents found a way to Shanghai, as did about 19,000 Jewish refugees from Hitler. A temporary ‚ÄúThru-visa‚Äù was available from Italy. This was issued on sight of a steamship ticket to Shanghai purchased from Italian line Lloyd Triestino, on one of the boats that steamed a regular route from Genoa to Shanghai, for an exorbitant sum. Only First Class tickets were available as a matter of course. I don‚Äôt know how but this sum was found for the Hahn family of 2 adults and a child. Train tickets were purchased to Genoa.
I remember a young girl, about my age, boarded the train with us. I never learned what was the family‚Äôs relationship to us, but my parents agreed to take her along. She was taken off the train at the border between Austria and Italy during the night, I presume because she was without papers. I have never been told what became of her and I have since often wondered whether she was returned to Vienna and her parents safely.
After a few days in Genoa we embarked on the mv. Victoria, the smallest but newest of the Lloyd Triestino fleet that sailed to the Orient regularly. We owned several ‚Äòcabin trunks‚Äô full of possessions and 114 British pounds. The voyage was a great delight for my parents, despite what must have been anxiety for the future. The mv. Victoria was the smallest ship in the line, but the latest and most modern.
First class service in all respects was still pre-war and luxurious. The voyage was very romantic, landing at exotic ports along the way. In Port Said, at the southern end of the Suez Canal, a great f√™te was held with native dancers and a feast was prepared on the dock. I believe it was an Egyptian version of an Aussie barbecue with whole beasts being cooked. Local citizens were present as well as the ship‚Äôs passengers. I was allowed down to the wharf for a little while and then taken to the cabin to sleep. I never learned why the celebration. I cannot remember the landing in Bombay or the three days passed in Singapore. Then came Hong Kong and lastly Shanghai.

Title: What to Do in Vienna If You Hate Itineraries
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen

I didn‚Äôt go to Vienna with a checklist. No Sch√∂nbrunn palace on the agenda. No museums lined up by hour. Just three slow-moving days, a waterproof camera backpack, and a promise to myself not to overthink it.
From the airport, I caught the 10.5‚Ç¨ bus to Westbahnhof and checked into a small guesthouse nearby. Quiet street. Solid sleep. Five-minute walk to most things that mattered.
I skipped the palaces and headed straight to a corner market for a mustard-soaked pretzel and a table with no view. I sat longer than I meant to. It was a good start.
I stumbled across the Musikverein just before noon. No grand performance, just a chamber rehearsal in the golden hall. I sat in the back. Stayed through most of it.
Across the square, the House of Music pulled me in by accident. I don‚Äôt usually do interactive museums, but this one surprised me. No pressure to move quickly. No crowds. Just quiet sound rooms layered like dreams.
Later, I caught the U-Bahn to Donauinsel, found a bench by the river, and watched the clouds shift. It started to rain lightly, but everything stayed dry ‚Äî my gear, my layers ‚Äî all tucked into that camera backpack I almost didn‚Äôt bring.
I walked aimlessly in the city centre, ducked into St. Peter‚Äôs Church, and followed the scent of coffee to K.u.K. Heiner. It felt more imperial than the cakes themselves ‚Äî but the atmosphere was enough.
Dinner was at Neubauschenke: pork stew, beef broth, locals in padded vests. I sat near the back and scribbled some notes. Later, Papaya served me one of the better duck salads I‚Äôve had in Europe. Spicy, fast, no English menu ‚Äî perfect.
I didn‚Äôt plan this trip, and it still worked.
Because Vienna is good to people who walk slowly, who sit a little longer, and who carry light.
If you‚Äôre thinking of going, don‚Äôt overpack. A lightweight waterproof camera backpack will do. The rest, the city gives you.

One of Billy Joel‚Äôs song that can portray so much towards this writing is ‚ÄúVienna‚Äù, and I‚Äôve been listening to it on repeat. I tried to connect myself to the song entirely, turns out its that song that we all needed as a person who‚Äôs just entering early of adulthood. That it‚Äôs alright to disappear for awhile or as long as you want when things are seems so tough for you to carry on. That why don‚Äôt us try to slow down and just enjoy every little good things in our lives with passion and pride? What are we afraid for? As long as we can choose to slow down and take times to not rush each goals of our lives.
Choosing for ‚Äòslow down‚Äô or even ‚Äòdisappearing yourself‚Äô from life stuffs won‚Äôt make you seems like you‚Äôre abandoning your life. Everyone‚Äôs timeline are different and you can‚Äôt afford things to be exactly same as what you‚Äôve expected. Its okay when we knew other people‚Äôs timeline are way much better than us, but don‚Äôt take it as something that supposed to be rushed or being too ambitious over that until you forgot where your own life path were exactly at.
Take your time, smell the roses. You‚Äôre not in a competition.
Life will leads you to the finish line at its own right time. The timeline also won‚Äôt be exactly same like what you‚Äôve imagined it to be. Because you never know what winds will drives you and where it‚Äôll be. Growing old isn‚Äôt supposed to be that thing that rush you like you‚Äôre in a competition. Give yourself a chance to ask urself ‚Äòwhat‚Äôs you‚Äôre hurry about?‚Äô. In the end, someday the life that you wished all this times will leads you slowly to its own place.
‚ÄúSlow down you‚Äôre doing fineYou can‚Äôt be everything you want to be before your time‚Äù
Everything and everyone has its own timeline and you can‚Äôt decide your own timeline to be same like others. When others are better in their own timeline, then let them be. Someday your own body will take you wherever the place that you‚Äôre deserves to be. You can dream on over single things that you wanted, but also its good to least our expectation that not everything will come true. There some things that you‚Äôve had planned yet it turns out didn‚Äôt happened like you wanted.
Just grab off your coffee, take a slow steps to daydream and rewind everything, remember what you have and where you are right now, and take a time to be grateful over it.
Growing old supposed to be when you enjoy every small things that you experienced and take of many appreciates for it. Take every joy of life that you have without have to rush yourself. Growing old are supposed to be when you understands that patience and timing are inseparable. Learn that growth will brings you to your own final destination when you‚Äôre just enjoy for being slow down without any fear of being left behind because you already know that your patience will deserves its own timing someday.
That every life journey will always represents passion, patience, and growth.

I‚Äôve first heard this song when i was 14, right before high school, and to be frank with you, i‚Äôve always been an overachiever.
I thought that was the only way for me to be complimented and appreciated because i thought it was what they expected from me, like how they say ‚Äò‚Äôtheir success was appreciated but mine was expected‚Äô‚Äô, so i‚Äôve tried more and more and more until i burned out.
i mean, i thought my brain was programmed that way, get a good grade=get a prize, do something good=hear a compliment, it was all like that, till i started high school, the classes were harder and i found myself lost.
i remember the day i got a 50 for the first time, i was shattered, absolutely broken, and i thought my family lost their whole hope on me, i was making it bigger and BIGGER in my head, then i went home, i told my mom and‚Ä¶nothing happened.
this is my problem, making everything bigger in my head, this is a blessing and a curse, but mostly a curse, i also can‚Äôt trust people when they say something good about me, like i thought ‚Äò‚Äôif my mom said ‚Äò‚Äôit‚Äôs okay you‚Äôll do better next time don‚Äôt be sad‚Äô‚Äô that must mean ‚Äò‚Äôyou‚Äôre a failure go lock in and study until you get a good grade!‚Äô‚Äô ‚Äò‚Äô so i did that.
and that worked.
for a while.
then i had..drumrolls‚Ä¶a burn out
then i‚Äôve heard this song, vienna by billy joel, i can easily say it‚Äôs one of my all time favorite songs because it hits right in the feels.
when i‚Äôve first listened to it, i thought vienna to be a literal place,
then i got older, at 17, i thought it was a place where you‚Äôve felt happy and content, a metaphor
then i got a bit more older, at 19, now vienna means something else for me.
for me, vienna is a place where i don‚Äôt overthink..it‚Äôs a place where i can be ME, without worrying, without putting a mask on, just me, in my most naked and raw form.
all these intense, unhealthy nights spent studying and fake smiles being thrown in social gatherings, they‚Äôre not actually..me, they‚Äôs a facade i put to please other people, but when will i realize vienna waits for me?
i love studying, my education is perhaps the most important thing to me, but i don‚Äôt love ruining myself over it, no one would.
take the phone off the hook, and disappear for a while.
and that‚Äôs what i want to do, cleanse and refresh, just let the flow take me where i‚Äôm meant to be, because sometimes i think i know too much, but there are places that i haven‚Äôt been where i already belong, if i try to control everything around me too much, i‚Äôll only sabotage myself.
and acting out in a place and around people where you‚Äôre supposed to feel comfortable is so draining and i just find myself doing this ‚Äòderealization‚Äô thingy, i just feel like a stranger to myself, to everything that‚Äôs surrounding me, i feel depressed, and i think;
who am i when i‚Äôm not performing for others, what is me, where i‚Äôm actually from, a land of over-thinkers, pageant queens and big pretenders?
nah, i‚Äôll find a new place to be from.
maybe it‚Äôll take me a month, maybe three, maybe six, maybe a year, pace is different for everyone but i‚Äôll take the phone off the hook, and i will disappear for a while, just like billy joel said, i‚Äôm tired of social media making me obsesses over my identity in relation to others, i won‚Äôt let my soul rot inside me, because we only live once, so we should enjoy it, right?
if you‚Äôve read it this far, thank you, love you, and just wanna say i‚Äôm here if you need a shoulder to lean on, thanks for bearing with my stupid ranting for 3 minutes.
until next time, take care, bye!
-bet

Title: ‚ÄúSlow down you crazy child‚Äù
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Film. Music. Sports. Art. Literature. @ChristSchool.

--
Listen
Share
We all know that Billy Joel is a megastar, but some of his biggest hits came from dark places. In fact, he felt like a failed musician at times. In the early 70s, he was homeless, sleeping in laundromats, haunted by Vietnam and self-pity. After a failed suicide attempt, he checked himself into a mental hospital.
When Billy Joel wrote the song Vienna, he was 28 years old. This song is very interesting and means a lot to Joel because the lyric‚Äôs from this song is all of the advice his father gave him on his career.
‚ÄúWhen will you realize Vienna waits for you?‚Äù
This hook explains to sit back and enjoy the ride. Your destination will be there when it's your time.
‚ÄúVienna‚Äù is a metaphor for old age, it‚Äôs not something to be afraid of, it‚Äôs something to embrace. ‚ÄúVienna‚Äù is in the soft rock genre, written by himself to represent his life and of the pressure he put on himself. He understood that other people might be going through what he once did.
In this song, Vienna is about enjoying the ride before the destination. For Billy Joel, it‚Äôs about his music career and how much work he puts into it. The destination for him is all the people that listen to his songs and enjoy his work.
‚ÄúSlow down, you‚Äôre doing fineYou can‚Äôt be everything you want to be before your time.‚Äù
With this line, Billy Joel is trying to spread the message that it‚Äôs ok to take a step back and take a breath, that it is ok to be wherever you‚Äôre at in life. He is telling his listeners to trust the process; the process got him where he is today. I can connect and relate to this line a lot and it helps keep me grounded. I also think most people could relate to this lyric, as humans tend to put a lot of pressure on themselves because we live in a toxic society that makes us feel like we have to be productive 24/7. This is also portrayed through the line, ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the fire? What‚Äôs the hurry about? You better cool it off before you burn it out.‚Äù Everyone, yes, even famous and successful people can experience the feeling of being burnt out.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so ahead of yourself that you forgot what you need‚Äù
Vienna is known as ‚Äúthe city of music‚Äù located in Austria. This is because it is home too many famous musicians such as Beethoven and Mozart‚Äôs. Billy Joel is reminding himself that he belongs with those extremely successful artists and he will join them in fame one day, it just will take time like all good things.
This song and the message that Joel is trying to deliver has been so successful because of his use of various musical components and elements. Having the ability to understand and properly use musical elements can help listeners grasp the message of a song.
The tone and volume of the song, along with powerful and inspiring lyrics help illustrate the underlying message. The tone is soft and inspiring. The volume or dynamics are gentle and calm, making listener feel motivated yet relaxed at the same time. The duration, also known as how long or short a sound is held, and the tempo, which is the speed, also helps deliver the message. This is because when Joel holds onto notes softly and slowly it emphasizes the importance of the lyric. Lastly, I think the overall melody of this song helps contribute to the motivational and inspiring message Joel wanted to share.
I think it is important for famous people to be vulnerable like this. It shows the more general population that everyone struggles in life, everyone needs to slow down at times and take a step back and that anyone, no matter the circumstances can have poor mental health. It is important to take care of ourselves and we as people see their idols and famous people opening up about their struggles but also then trying to fix them, it motivates others to do so as well.
It‚Äôs crazy how when you really dig into the lyrics and the past of the song writer, it can completely change your perspective on the song and the artist. After doing research on Billy Joel and his music I have gained a whole new level of respect for him. Not just for what he has been through but for his strength to share it and his ability to make good out of a bad situation.

A few insider tips for those heading to the Austrian capital
Vienna offers some of the greatest museums in the world. The positively stately Naturhistorisches Museum and Kunsthistorisches Museum face each other across a grand courtyard, and are neighboured by the MQ (Museumsquartier) which houses the Leopold Museum and MUMOK (Museum of Modern Art). These are all worth a visit. They are truly spectacular, and utterly world-class.
But a surprise treasure among these titans is the much smaller setup of the Mozarthaus. Here, on Domgasse, the great composer‚Äôs 18th-century apartment ‚Äî and the rest of the building ‚Äî have been restored and turned into a museum exploring the music, politics and personal life of Mozart. The museum is relatively small, but excellently put-together and (despite quite minimalist exhibition spaces) really very insightful. Particularly interesting is the information on Amadeus‚Äô involvement in the Freemasons, which was new to me and showed a new side to his political and social interests.
In 1949, Vienna starred in what would come to be heralded as one of the greatest noir thrillers of all time ‚Äî The Third Man. Based on the Graham Greene novel, the film is set in post-war Vienna and follows American Holly Martins, who arrives in the city to meet his friend Harry Lime (Orson Welles), only to find that he has been killed in a car ‚Äòaccident‚Äô. Martins grows increasingly suspicious that Harry‚Äôs death was not an accident at all, leading him on a road of discovery with a shocking twist.
Vienna‚Äôs Burg Kino cinema on Opernring is among the oldest cinemas in Europe (founded in 1912) and one of the only places in the world where you can still see The Third Man on the silver screen. Catch a Friday night viewing at 11pm in the cinema‚Äôs tiny ‚ÄòStudio‚Äô screen and you can expect to be joined by no more than 10‚Äì15 others. Then, the next day, make sure you visit the Dritte Mann Museum (Third Man Museum, open Saturdays only) not far away, which tells the story of the film‚Äôs production ‚Äî and the surrounding political context ‚Äî in amazing detail. There are original posters from 20 countries, photographs, annotated scripts, cameras used in the film, and even the opportunity to see a short segment of the reel on a genuine 1930s cinema projector, complete with all the cracks, scratches and whirring. This ‚Äî and the screening ‚Äî were the highlight of my entire trip. Magical.
The Leopold Museum is one of the city‚Äôs most famous and popular museums, showcasing the height of Austrian art including works by Klimt and Egon Schiele. But in the museum‚Äôs lower floor, at time of writing, is a special exhibition on the visual art of famous novelist and poet Victor Hugo. Best known for Les Miserables, Hugo was not noted as a visual artist, and even dismissed his work as a trivial pastime in letters to his friends.
But the work is extraordinary.
Depicting horrific landscapes of death and destruction, human and supernatural evil, the violent ink and charcoal attacks on sepia paper are genuinely chilling. Some, such as the first image seen as you enter, of gallows standing in a bleak open pasture, are rooted in Hugo‚Äôs own defiance of the death penalty that was widely used by his nation during his lifetime. While Vienna is known for its classicism, these are little-advertised works of relatively contemporary art, and deeply emotive. Not to be missed.
Kaffee mit Sachertorte: Sachertorte is a must when you visit Vienna, and the temptation is to head straight to Cafe Sacher opposite the opera house where you will find a queue stretching out the door and service that feels fed up with tourism. Instead, try Cafe Mozart, an equally elegant traditional coffee house popular with musicians from the nearby Staatsoper and also where Graham Greene wrote The Third Man (see above). Great coffee, great cake.
Italian: Germany and Austria are reputed to have the best Italian restaurants outside of Italy, and there are many fine examples in Vienna. One such is the very unassuming Frascati pizzeria and gelateria at Barnabitengasse 3. Just off the ever-busy shopping street Mariahilfer Strasse, this cosy family-run place provides basic but delicious Italian meals at absolute bedrock prices. I enjoyed an enormous fresh Pizza Napoli and a large glass of wine for under ‚Ç¨10.
Wienerschnitzel: Overrated in my view, but if you do want to try the city‚Äôs famous delicacy of deep-fried veal, you won‚Äôt do much better than Plachuttas Gasthaus zur Oper. Located close to the Opera House, the Gasthaus does a traditional Wienerschnitzel with potato salad for around ‚Ç¨20 which is fairly standard across the city. If you‚Äôre going to do it, do it properly at an authentic Viennese Gasthaus. Don‚Äôt be tempted by non-veal alternatives (chicken, pork) at the city‚Äôs Greek, Italian and Turkish establishments.
It‚Äôs not exactly undiscovered, but perhaps underappreciated. Vienna is packed with amazing bars and clubs, but none quite have the atmosphere of the MQ. In all seasons, the central courtyard between the Leopold Museum and the MUMOK is a hub of activity. I visited in the winter months, and spent many evenings here enjoying a mug of Gl√ºhwein with hundreds of others ‚Äî locals and tourists alike. Sometimes there are even live DJs or bands playing. I caught Austrian band Naked Cameo performing, joined by a youth dance group, see video below. This open-air space has an amazing atmosphere of unity and social openness about it, and should be your first stop on any bar crawl of the city, especially around Christmas time.
Vienna‚Äôs nightlife is, to say the least, elusive. I spent my week there trying to sniff out the club scene, researching online, to little avail. Eventually I reached my final night, and decided to give Volksgarten a punt and hope for the best. Located in the park of the same name (literally Peoples‚Äô Garden), the club doesn‚Äôt look much from the outside. Surrounded by a metal fence, it has a Mediterranean look, open courtyards dotted with palm trees and high tables. The building itself is uninspiring. But head inside, and you won‚Äôt be disappointed. I dropped in around midnight on a November Saturday, their ‚ÄòOverground‚Äô night, and the place was already starting to fill.
‚Ç¨13 entry seemed steep, but included a free drink at the very impressive cocktail bar. I actually got two stuck together. Bonus. The highly professional bartenders make a range of top-notch cocktails, and there‚Äôs also every spirit, beer and champagne to boot. Tables surround a central island of palm trees. Behind there, it wasn‚Äôt long before the dancefloor got bouncing. By 1am it was wild. The atmosphere electric. A man appeared with a bunch of balloons which he handed out to people. Periodically, the roof over the dancefloor would slide open like Thunderbirds, letting the soft rain fall on the ravers below. House thumped here, while it was hip-hop in another room through the back. If you want a party, head to Volksgarten. Highly recommended.

Semaj checked on me today as far as taking a rest day‚Ä¶ I didn‚Äôt think I had been doing that much, and even said that a few days ago when I was wondering why I was so tired, but I guess I am. I want to ramp up to doing this much all the time, though. Especially now when I have all the time in the world.
I find myself getting off on the fact that somebody is worried about me. Kinda like back in college when I wasn‚Äôt eating enough ‚Äî I wanted someone to notice and save me. Though that would always push me to continue whatever I was doing.
A lot of foods have been a struggle lately; not sure if it‚Äôs a problem with my appetite or a fear around foods. Eggs, for example, are so high in protein but have been making me nauseas to think about. Peanut butter toast & a glass of milk has been one of the foods that I can stomach, and while the macros aren‚Äôt great, it‚Äôs something‚Ä¶ and I‚Äôve had it for dinner multiple times this week.
Having scrambled eggs and cottage cheese as I write this, but I think it‚Äôs taking me being distracted with writing to be able to finish it.
Mozzarella cheese & smoothies are two other foods I can stomach right now, which I guess aren‚Äôt horrible, but I need more variety.
It‚Äôs a gloomy day but I have to go check on Moose and take him for a walk. Still counting it as a rest day though ‚Äî my first one in 12 days.
Went to Stretch Lab for the first time ‚Äì it‚Äôs nice just laying there and getting stretched out but the time went by too fast ‚Äì and got told I have nice shoulders and biceps. That‚Äôs one I never get. Also partly why I‚Äôm overtraining right now: seeing results is addicting.
And in my defense, a lot of the time going to the gym gives me something to do.
I am so close to buying March flights to Europe‚Ä¶. Wouldn‚Äôt be my Dolomites trip, but do I trust this strong urge I have? Or am I being impulsive when I should be patient? Summer flights are sooo expensive right now though‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm talking $1,500 expensive. And the thought of snowshoeing and/or being in the snow is oddly so appealing right now‚Ä¶
I really do think I‚Äôm going to find myself in Austria next month‚Ä¶
Do I just book a flight and figure it out like I did last time?

Title: (Austria) Discovering the Magic of Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
