It‚Äôs been a while since my last blog! I‚Äôve been taking some time to reflect on my summer, spend time with family and friends and have been swamped with Givesie and participating as a vendor at many local Portland events during the last few months.
But I am back this week and wanted to share with you my amazing trip to Europe this summer! I got the chance to visit Vienna, Austria and Zurich and Lucerne, Switzerland with my parents. It was by far one of the best experiences of my life! And to be able to share those memories with my mom and dad is priceless.
Vienna has this richness in history and architecture; the museums, the palaces, the statues, the cathedrals and gardens are breathtakingly beautiful and so intricate in detail! One of my favorite sights to see was the St. Stephan‚Äôs Cathedral, the mother church of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Vienna and the current Romanesque and Gothic form of the cathedral, which was completed in the year 1160. It is the most important religious building in Vienna, ‚Äúhas borne witness to many important events in Habsburg and Austrian history and has, with its multi-coloured tile roof, become one of the city‚Äôs most recognizable symbols.‚Äù Walking inside I was immediately in awe of the stunning, yet dark and dramatic beauty of the interior. Words could not describe the sense of peace, calm and excitement I felt all at once walking through.
The Schonbrunn Palace is one of the busiest tourist sites to see in Vienna. It is a neoclassical style palace and was built during the reign of empress Maria Theresa and was also the home of Franz Joseph, the longest-reigning emperor of Austria and King of Hungary, along with his wife Duchess Elisabeth of Bavaria. I loved touring through this palace, it was decorated exactly how it would have looked when it was first built. I felt like I had gone back in time, envisioning what it would have been like to be alive and living during the 18th/19th centuries.
Another one of my favorite places to visit was the Belvedere Palace. Consisting of two Baroque palaces, the Upper and Lower and set in the Baroque park landscape and the Belvedere garden, it houses the Belvedere museum. Walking through the museum I was surrounded by the most stunning pieces of historical art done by some of the most famous artists from around the world and from centuries ago! Definitely a sight to see!
As we wrapped up our tour of the museum we worked up an appetite ‚Äî so, mom, dad and I had to stop at the cutest little caf√© on the palace grounds for a late afternoon latte and pastry! So. Good.
After our amazing time in Vienna, we were off to Zurich and Lucerne, both are beautiful cities surrounded by stunning mountain ranges, lakes and charming medieval towns.
The train ride my parents and I took from Vienna to Zurich was probably one of my most favorite parts of the trip! It was an eight hour ride, but felt so much shorter! We had such a great time chatting, taking pictures, eating delicious meals, passing by and stopping through small towns, seeing the gorgeous mountainous scenery and huge lakes and rivers. We spent just a few days in Zurich, seeing Old Town, browsing through local boutique shops, shopping for souvenirs, as well as taking a day trip to Lucerne along with a boat ride on the lake. Even though it was a short time ‚Äî it was absolutely perfect! I remember sitting outside this adorable French outdoor cafe by the lake and enjoying an afternoon espresso with my parents, while people watching ‚Äî and thinking to myself ‚Äî I can‚Äôt believe I am actually here and enjoying this beautiful moment with my mom and dad that I will cherish forever.
This trip gave me such perspective and such an appreciation for travel and exploration! Being in a new environment, new people, new culture. There is such a big world out there to see and experience. We tend to get caught up in our normal routines, the everyday tasks, work, etc‚Ä¶and tend to forget that there is so much to appreciate in life! Sometimes you just have to get out of your comfort zone and your norm to be able to see things in a new light. xx
--
--
Designer, Founder & CEO of Givesie.

Of a town,

Everyone gets a break,

As if on a curfew.
No shoppers or eaters
Roaming on the streets,
All establishments shut
And everyone stays home.
For an outsider
Vienna seems forlorn,
Like their city did during the lockdown.
But for insiders,
It is a paradise
As they enjoy time with family
At home.
Even on a Monday,
There is no hurry,
No running behind a bus or a train
No speed walking down the pathways.
Those going to the office or school,
Stroll at their pace,
Enjoying the winds
And the sun,
And their coffee in breaks.
They work at their pace
Enjoying the task at hand,
Undisturbed by the distractions,
As if in a mystic flow.
They cycle, calm and slow,
Not in a hurry to reach their destination
For them, the journey
Seems to be their destination.
Not formal wear,
No big cars or big frills
Just them in their shorts and ts
Going about their day
Like it‚Äôs a treat.
Living their lives
In a pause,
They teach me
How to take a break,
And learn how to walk slow,
To enjoy every moment,
Whether on vacation,
Or at work.
They teach me
To lessen my agendas
To leave behind the past
And let the future rest
To be in the present,
In this here and now.

Enjoy my surroundings,

Title: In Vienna, the waiter is King
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This is not a real travel blog. There are no product reviews, no paid promotions and you will find no inside information about secret backpacking locations you can‚Äôt find for yourself online. This is a collection of our expectations and disappointments, rants and realisations.

--
Listen
Share
Like Atlas, with the weight of the world on his shoulders, wait staff in Vienna take their job very, very seriously.
Vienna: the capital of Austria, home of the Hasburg dynasty, old architecture and tardy, poker faced, sarcastic wait staff.
In one of Europe‚Äôs oldest cities, with a long and rich cultural history, and a reputation as one of the world‚Äôs centres of art and learning, the wait staff rule supreme. Long waits for service, being ignored and a general attitude of low level irritation that you want to be a customer seems to be the norm.
Ancient architecture = posh attitude
One travel brochure (The Free Map For Young and Clever People) proclaims that in Vienna, ‚ÄúThe waiter is king. Don‚Äôt be surprised if the waiters are unfriendly - not the guest is king, he is. Treat him as your superior and he will reward you.‚Äù The brochure also claims that ‚Äúwaiters NEVER smile‚Äù and that for tipping ‚Äú5-10% of the bill is the amount the king expects from his subjects.‚Äù
The advice in The Free Map for Young And Clever People is ridiculously honest and self-deprecating.
To begin with you are annoyed and maybe offended by this behaviour. But, after a few experiences you realise that it‚Äôs not actually you personally the waiter hates, it‚Äôs everybody ‚Äì perhaps it‚Äôs a persona they all adopt as part of their profession or as a survival tactic against drunk and obnoxious tourists who don‚Äôt speak German.
My personal experiences of this phenomenon were being told I had ordered children‚Äôs beer when choosing a 330ml sized glass (normal serving size in my country) instead of a ¬Ω litre. My bad. Another was overhearing the same waiter yell at a patron asking them if they wanted to see a menu. Theoretically, this sounds like he was being helpful and doing his job. However, in person, his tone, body language and glare revealed the true nature of his passive aggressive overture. What he actually said nonverbally was ‚Äúbuy something to eat or f**K off‚Äù.
When your office is this plush you might be forgiven for developing an arrogant attitude.
A further experience was when buying a Kaserkrainer (vienesse hotdog) from a street vendor in the early hours of the morning. The vendor must have been earning significantly less than the barman and really needed the customers, but felt the need to finish his entire cigarette¬†before¬†deining¬†to¬†serve¬†us. He then spent less time than it took to smoke it heating a sausage on the grill, before wrapping it and throwing it on the counter for me to collect. The patience we were expected to show while waiting was not reciprocal. While we fumbled uncoordinated and inebriated for the correct change, his bloodshot eyes glared with annoyance. How dare we bother him to prepare his advertised victuals and deign to give him a few euros¬†for¬†his¬†disgruntled¬†efforts.
This attitude is strange considering that you want to spend your money at the establishment where said wait staff are employed. You might think they would be welcoming of a tourist who wants to donate them money. You may highlight the link between your custom and their wages ‚Äì but you would be wrong. The waiter just has no f**ks to give about you and your desires to eat or drink or be treated like a human being.
‚ÄúLet them eat cake‚Äù‚Ää- Marie Antionette was a Hasburg and probably developed the attitude that cost her life while growing up in Vienna.
Sometimes this apathy worked in our favour. For example, when the bus driver was in danger of having to do something untoward, such as turn in his seat, converse with you and maybe issue you a ticket. Instead, it was easier for him to just lift his eyes, wave his hand dismissively towards the general direction of the back of the bus and grunt something. We interpreted this as there would be no charge, but it may have meant - ‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt give a s**t.‚Äù I doubt he would have come to our defence if an undercover ticket check had taken place.
Advice for ‚ÄòActing like a local'‚Ää‚Äî ‚ÄúBe Grumpy‚Äù
The Free Map for Young and Clever People makes an effort to explain why the Viennesse hate on life. Under the heading ‚ÄòAct like a Local‚Äô it was suggested that you ‚Äúbe grumpy‚Äù. Supposedly, it is ‚Äúmandatory‚Äù for ‚Äúoriginal Vienesse to complain if the bus is one minute late or the weather is too hot/cold/wet/sunny. This ‚Äúmentality‚Äù (general bad attitude) was justified as being part of the rich Vienesse culture and is based on hundreds of years of historical precedent and practice.
Back in the day (16-18th Centuries), Vienna was the home of the Hasburg Dynasty and the centre of several empires. As such it was a center of commerce, education, construction etc, and developed a large bureaucracy which served the monarchy and employed half the population of the city. Everybody knows that a high standard of living, steady employment and job security suck, so it is understandable that these unlucky civil servants developed a negative attitude.
Members of the Hasburg dynasty pretty much ruled most of Europe in the 16th‚Ää- 18th centuries
According to the Free Map for Young and Clever People this explains why wait staff, and more generally everyone (especially if they had an ancestor who worked for the government) has the historical right to be grumpy, rude or generally a dick.
Other historical facts from the Free Map include how after WWII ‚Äúall the Nazis miraculously disappear and the population suffers a collective loss of memory as far as the last 7 years are concerned.‚Äù
This appeal to history is obviously a bullsh**t excuse to act like a jerk. More likely, people being people, they could not leave their work at work and the hierarchal structure of a feudal bureaucracy permeated into their attitudes and behaviour outside of their jobs. Add a mix of simian tribalism or pack behaviour and next thing everyone is looking down their noses at anyone else their social standing allows them to ‚Äì and treating them accordingly.
What is mystifying is that in contemporary Vienna, a city where the Arts and Humanities are cultivated, this is a standard of behaviour that some aspire to. Or perhaps it‚Äôs as simple as:
‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt like a person, it‚Äôs because they remind you of something you don‚Äôt like about yourself.‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäSigmund Freud, father of modern psychology and resident of Vienna, before being forced to fleeing prior to WWII.
--
--
This is not a real travel blog. There are no product reviews, no paid promotions and you will find no inside information about secret backpacking locations you can‚Äôt find for yourself online. This is a collection of our expectations and disappointments, rants and realisations.

Title: A Captivating Train Journey Through Stunning Landscapes From Vienna to Munich
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I decided to ditch the flight mode this time and chose to travel by train for the remainder of my Europe tour. This was the last leg of my 20-day Europe trip, and I had booked train tickets from Vienna to Munich in advance. Yes, it was a great decision.
I had traveled by train in Europe before on several other trips and the experience was stupendous. Notable among them -
Paris to Interlaken in Switzerland
Within Switzerland most of the travel I undertook by train
London to Edinburgh
Rome to Venice
Each form of transport has its advantages and disadvantages. Having different types of travel experiences is worthwhile and we must try them all. It is Fun !!
While trains have a charm of their own, one of the drawbacks is that you have to take care of your luggage and stack them in their proper place. Unlike a flight where your luggage is checked in and taken care of soon after you arrive, making you feel relaxed and free.
On the other hand, to catch a flight, you have to reach the airport at least two hours in advance and go through security, etc, while traveling by train does not involve any of these processes. Hence it is hassle-free and time-saving.
An additional reward of train travel is that you get to enjoy the bewitching countryside views.
Another benefit of train travel is that it is cheaper compared to flights.
Staying in the Ibis hotel directly opposite the railway station in Vienna was so convenient. Firstly, it was a great place to have your meals at the elaborate food court inside the station building. Similar to what we have at malls or airports, you could choose from a wide variety of cuisines.
Secondly, boarding my train to Munich was a breeze. All I had to do was cross the street and within minutes I was at the train station. Though I had the tickets downloaded on my phone, due to unfamiliar language, the platform and the seat numbers were not clear. As such a day prior to my departure, I went and clarified at the information kiosk. The result was that on the travel day everything was smooth sailing.
The railways have done a fantastic job of making train travel incredibly easy and comfortable. I really appreciate the presence of glass waiting lounges (similar to the one at Vienna) at railway stations ‚Äî a protection for passengers against harsh weather conditions.
Absorbing the last glimpse of the splendors of Vienna, as the train left the platform, the view from the window transformed into staggeringly pretty vistas. The four-and-a-half-hour journey was filled with picture postcard scenery as the high-speed train traversed through verdant countryside landscapes, charming villages, with their cute cottages and historical landmarks.
Amongst the several stoppages en route was the historic town of Salzburg. It was on my bucket list, but was unable to visit. I was quite tempted to get down there and explore, but since there wasn‚Äôt any plan or reservations done, so skipped.
In the previous train journeys food was included, and I enjoyed the luxury of being served warm, delicious food and drinks in the cozy comforts of high-speed trains. The in-between snacks were a surprise perk and a great pass time.
This time though the pantry car and availability of food was a let down. Most of the hot, fresh food and beverages were over. There were very limited options left, that too of packaged snacks, that I don‚Äôt prefer.
I was craving for a hot chocolate drink and that was over. Something that I relish immensely, not just for its creamy, lip-smacking taste but also the fact that it aided in keeping me warm from the cold weather. Had to settle for the insipid, tasteless tea instead!
It didn‚Äôt even seem as if I was traveling from one country to another in Europe, except on crossing the border from Austria to Germany, when uniformed border police personnel were there inside the train for passport checking. I didn‚Äôt know about it, luckily had my passports in my handbag and not packed in the suitcase.
From the numerous connecting flights that I took, this was a different experience. A desirable change, rather than flitting in and out of airports. Holidaying at a slow, relaxed pace, that lifted my spirits.
--
--

Title: Returning to the Vienna of the Past
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Airbnb Magazine celebrates humanity wherever it exists: across borders, time zones, languages, and skin tones.

--
Listen
Share
Words by Boris Fishman and Alex HalberstadtPhotographs by Francesca Catastini
THE SLATE-COLORED JANUARY MORNING drummed cold rain against the windows of Caf√© Pr√ºckel. My friend Boris and I had arrived on the red-eye from JFK two hours before. He wanted to sleep; I wanted to go to Pr√ºckel, and he‚Äôd reluctantly agreed.
Vienna is renowned for its caf√©s. There‚Äôs the toothache-inducing gilt of Caf√© Central, the faux-bohemian shabbiness of Caf√© Hawelka, the raspberry-bordello color scheme of Caf√© Sacher. But my first destination in Vienna is always Caf√© Pr√ºckel. Like the more central caf√©s, it, too, is overseen by taciturn middle-aged men in poly-blend tuxedos. (Viennese servers do not subsist on tips, a fact reflected in their unhurried gait and refreshing disinclination to smile.) But it‚Äôs more spacious and sparsely populated, always making me feel pleasurably left alone. Multilingual newspapers hang along the walls, and soft-boiled eggs arrive in eggcups alongside good espresso, and the light streaming in through tall windows invites you to dig your shoulders into the upholstery and linger.
Across the table, Boris didn‚Äôt seem to share my enthusiasm. But it wasn‚Äôt because I‚Äôd kept him from a soft mattress. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like a Soviet cafeteria,‚Äù he said, poking unhappily at the cold cuts that had arrived along with the eggs. He surveyed the vast dining area, which, admittedly, did have a wood-paneled wall or two. ‚ÄúThe bourgeois version.‚Äù I suspected that this was partly why I loved it.
I first came to Vienna when I was 9, a refugee fleeing the Soviet Union. My mother, her parents, and I shared a rundown hotel suite somewhere on the city‚Äôs edge. It was the first stop on the journey that would eventually take us to New York, and Vienna was our first encounter with what everyone in the Soviet Union referred to, usually in a whisper, as the West.
Beginning in the late ‚Äô60s, hundreds of thousands of Russian-speaking refugees passed through Vienna on their way west, mainly to Israel and the United States. Concerned about the appearance of losing so many citizens, Soviet officials preferred to release their refugees to an intermediary nation ‚Äî and its neutrality made Austria a logical choice. I suppose what I remember most about those weeks in 1979 is a peculiar mixture of emotions: sheer confusion; exhilarated discovery; the distinct embarrassment of being a stranger in what felt like a more civilized civilization; and the recent loss of everything and everyone familiar save a handful of loved ones, a presentiment cushioned for me by the fact of my childhood.
But my most indelible memories of Vienna were of caf√© interiors, especially the vitrines filled with pristine geometric pastries that looked to us like they were made by Faberg√© ‚Äî they were all the more compelling because, subsisting on an allowance from a refugee-resettlement agency, we couldn‚Äôt afford to taste them. Now, decades later, I could ‚Äî and did, an architectural piece of strudel surrounded by a moat of vanilla sauce. I was finishing a book about three generations of my family and wanted to find some vestige of our passage, and of my former self. On this, my fifth visit to Vienna in ten years, I wanted to know one more thing: Why did the city pull me to itself so relentlessly?
JANUARY IN VIENNA: I should have known better. But if Alex had proposed the Sahel in August, I probably would have said yes, too. In Alex, I‚Äôd finally met, after 29 relatively barren American years, what felt like a doppelg√§nger. He had experienced the same immigration I had, ten years earlier; it had left him with similar complexes; and he had the same degree of separation from his Russianness and Jewishness that I did.
And I was curious about Vienna. It was where my family and I encountered the West in 1988, when I was 9. No one had told me where we were going or why, but the signs weren‚Äôt good. In the months before leaving, as we pawned everything in our apartment and whittled a century in Minsk into one suitcase per person, my sweet, sheltered Soviet life gave way to unspecified terror. (Ordinary people didn‚Äôt travel outside the Soviet Union, and those who did certainly never got to return.) On the rail platform of the train to Vienna ‚Äî it was easier to imagine visiting Mars ‚Äî my mother wept as if someone had died. Soviet customs had just upended our suitcases and treated itself to my mother‚Äôs wedding ring and a set of gold cutlery. My neck burned with a gold necklace concealed under the top button.
Thirty-six hours later, we rolled into a kind of fairy tale. Even poor people seemed to drive Mercedeses. The supermarkets had automatic sliding doors, which my father learned after nearly toppling an emerging Austrian grandma. I gorged on bratwurst oozing with bergk√§se cheese and ice cream cylinders wrapped at the ends with striped twine. In this country, the sausages melted like ice cream, and the ice cream came wrapped at the ends like cured sausage! Once, I came across a kitchenware store so beautiful that, my mouth agape, I walked right into the window, my forehead leaving a spot on the glass. We might as well have been rural North Koreans trying to defect to Ibiza. (At our medical checkups, the doctor handed us a diagram that explained that my mother had to consume the pills for her earache orally, not by putting them in her ear, as previous immigrants had been doing in deference to the Soviet habit of treating earaches with ear compresses.) But Vienna ‚Äî Vienna would do.
Since immigrating, as I Americanized, then de-Americanized to reconnect with my heritage, then pureed both parts of myself into a thoroughly imperfect but more or less livable hash, I thought of Vienna now and then, the way you wonder about what might have been with someone had the timing been better. In places like Austria, I imagined, they didn‚Äôt worship ‚Äúfreedom‚Äù to the point of anarchy; were less ready to sacrifice morality for profit; did not regard intellectuals with suspicion; and took care of artists ‚Äî took care of people in general. Alex felt a deeper attachment to our adopted homeland. It was the one part of him that mystified me.
Thirty years earlier, a small number of refugees like us had found a way to remain in Vienna. ‚ÄúWhat are you all stampeding over there for?‚Äù one, named Sasha, kept asking us. He meant America, a word that to us meant more than Shangri-la. Sasha had visited Brooklyn, where we were heading. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs it like?‚Äù my mother asked. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like anything,‚Äù he said. When we finally encountered it two months later ‚Äî low-slung, dirty, and gray ‚Äî we remembered his words. What if I‚Äôd spent the last three decades in Vienna, instead? But there‚Äôs the fantasy and the cold, gray, wood-paneled truth.
MY FIRST MEMORY OF VIENNA begins aboard an Aeroflot jet, its fuselage painted with a winged hammer and sickle. My mother and I left Moscow in our winter coats, carrying two suitcases containing six changes of clothes, a photo album, and a book of poems by Anna Akhmatova. My mother‚Äôs wedding ring and watch were taken in customs. Aboard the plane we were served an unexpectedly luxurious meal of baked chicken, mashed potatoes, and a wedge of soft processed cheese in a foil wrapper that read ‚ÄúProgress!‚Äù I remember my mother slipping the metal forks and knives into her coat pockets. An hour into the flight the pilot announced, in German and then in Russian, that the plane had left Soviet airspace. ‚ÄúMeine Damen und Herren‚Ä¶,‚Äù the announcement began, and when it was finished one or two passengers, the boldest ones, clapped. At the airport in Vienna, I sat on my suitcase and gaped at a security guard with a German shepherd and a submachine gun. Then I watched a pilot walk out of the gate, his hat embroidered with the six-pointed star of Israel. ‚ÄúIs Austria a capitalist country?‚Äù I asked my mother. She said I looked ‚Äúas scared as a rabbit.‚Äù
To revisit a place remembered from childhood is to realize two rather disappointing facts: (1) Most of us recall childhood through a filter of adult sentimentality, and (2) our memories are, at best, undependable ‚Äî researchers have found that every time we mentally access a memory, our recall of it changes. We confabulate others unwittingly, with a clear conscience. And the more I thought about my weeks in Vienna in the fall of 1979, the more I had to admit that two things had occupied nearly all of my 9-year-old brain: non-Soviet makes of automobiles and eating. Luckily, my interest in cars has waned, but eating remains a preoccupation. The Viennese are preoccupied with it, too, though without the Parisian self-regard or Roman chauvinism.
As in other cities with thriving caf√© cultures, Vienna‚Äôs caf√©s and bars are cognizant of themselves primarily as social spaces. Most are laid out with watching ‚Äî and being watched ‚Äî in mind. Some are as flamboyant as stage sets, but all seem attuned to the public pleasures of tribal togetherness or the kind of low-effort nonconformism that sometimes involves an omelet.
Zum Schwarzen Kameel, where Beethoven had emptied a great many cases of red wine, was celebrating its 400th anniversary, and after a long nap to kill jet lag, Boris and I pulled up two hard barstools in its front room. Popular with maximally groomed, rather cruel-looking regulars ‚Äî it‚Äôs a hangout for conservative politicians ‚Äî it encourages competitive levels of smoking, which remains permitted in restaurants, another vestige of my Soviet past. Kameel is home to one of the country‚Äôs most thorough wine cellars and possibly the most rewarding people-watching in town. Boris and I spent a night there drinking cold Gr√ºner Veltliner, happily lost in talk, while men in quilted jackets and creased trousers crowded around the bar, jockeying for another glass of wine. The only solitary figure was an enervated young woman wearing a fox-fur waistcoat and a Chanel bag sitting across from us. She looked like someone had stood her up. She kept her vividly mascaraed eyes fixed in the middle distance and, with jeweled fingers wrapped around her glass, exhaled drafts of smoke in our faces.
I HAD GIVEN ALEX PR√úCKEL, so he agreed to give me ‚ÄúSwimming Pool.‚Äù In Mitteleuropa, when it comes to fitness, yoga and spin classes are still the interlopers, and bath complexes the standard. But we didn‚Äôt go to the century-old J√∂rgerbad pool, in the sleepy 17th district, to take the healing waters. I wanted to see whether the comparative generosity of the Austrian state meant better art. For there was going to be art at the pool, commissioned by the nonprofit arts group Brut, a mainstay of the avant-garde scene in Vienna. A performance artist and several confederates were going to use the pool to ‚Äúexpos[e] the audience to the conflicting feelings of safety and uncanniness.‚Äù Whatever that meant.
After some horsing around in the pool, the actors went off to perform various oddities. One poured what looked like red food dye into the pool gutter, making me think of chemical attacks and the extreme generosity of Austrian arts funding. (Alex deemed it ‚Äúquixotic and bad.‚Äù) At home, thanks to our new president, funding for the National Endowment for the Arts ‚Äî the equivalent of two and a half F-15s ‚Äî was under the knife.
I had become a full-time freelance writer at 24, and it‚Äôs possible that I didn‚Äôt sleep or eat for the next year or two ‚Äî I was too terrified for my future. After a year of 16-hour days and seven-day weeks, I had $22,000, a twitching left eyelid, and not one article I could point to as the product of passion instead of expedience. As bizarre as it was, ‚ÄúSwimming Pool‚Äù ‚Äî or the reality that had made it possible ‚Äî felt quite okay as an alternative. Everyone in attendance was young, attractive, and responsible ‚Äî the invitation had said to bring one‚Äôs own flip-flops, and everyone had. And serious: They gazed upon the circus before us with the utmost solemnity.
After the performance, we ended up at Rebhuhn, a traditional tavern just outside the city center. It served a Platonic version of grandmother food ‚Äî pike-perch in a white-wine-but-mostly-butter sauce, chestnut ‚Äúpasta‚Äù over cream and lingonberry preserves ‚Äî but the best thing about Rebhuhn wasn‚Äôt the food. At one table, a woman was reading a newspaper. At another, three lavishly dressed women were having what you just knew was their every-Sunday-night klatch. There were 20-somethings and 80-somethings. No one was ‚Äúdoing a concept‚Äù to ‚Äúmaximize covers,‚Äù no one was trying to pretend to touch my soul so they could scour my wallet.
When I ate out at such a place in New York, I felt guilty for lingering because I was infringing on the server‚Äôs opportunity to turn the table, something I felt responsible for because American restaurants didn‚Äôt pay their servers a living wage. Nowhere did this economic model feel as insane as at Rebhuhn in Vienna on a Sunday evening. ‚ÄúVienna,‚Äù Alex said in another theft-worthy line as he mopped sauce with a cube of fish, ‚Äúis cultural Xanax.‚Äù In America, I realized, we were undergoing a kind of national seizure, the kind where you‚Äôd stopped noticing that your shoulders were up all the time because you‚Äôd internalized terrible economic insecurity as the norm. Safety ‚Äî an uncanny feeling, indeed. Perhaps the Europe I‚Äôd been imagining ‚Äî the Vienna Alex had been telling me about almost since we‚Äôd met ‚Äî wasn‚Äôt only a fantasy.
ANOTHER THING ABOUT THE CITY that saturated my childhood imagination: the streets themselves. After growing up in one of the Brezhnev-era apartment towers that surrounded Moscow like a cinder-block forest, Vienna struck me as a marvel from a distant antiquity. In fact, the city was transformed in the 19th century by Emperor Franz Joseph I, and it is his Vienna ‚Äî neo-Baroque, orderly, martial ‚Äî that visitors see today. Franz Joseph‚Äôs vision lent the city the quality that has stayed with me most as an adult, a quality that no amount of skyscrapers can efface ‚Äî an officious, comforting solemnity.
It was just off one of these imperial streets that Boris and I spent our most educational outing in Vienna ‚Äî at Gasthaus Gr√ºnauer, a partly hidden local institution with an interior so low-ceilinged and rustic that it could‚Äôve been located in Middle-earth. We were meeting my friends. Jutta Ambrositsch is the city‚Äôs most talented winemaker; her husband, Marco, operates the business side of the winery. The restaurant‚Äôs third-generation proprietor, Christian Gr√ºnauer, owner of one of the most sardonic faces I‚Äôd seen, reminisced in unaccented English about 1980s New York, where he waited tables at an Upper East Side Italian restaurant called Elio‚Äôs. One of the regulars there was Donald Trump. ‚ÄúHe was so afraid of germs that he wouldn‚Äôt shake anyone‚Äôs hand,‚Äù Christian recalled, ‚Äúbut look at him now, slapping backs and kissing babies!‚Äù
Christian‚Äôs wife, Katja, prepared Mitteleuropean soul food ‚Äî grilled veal kidneys, delicately breaded loin of pork, pan-fried whole trout ‚Äî so flavorful it nearly made us forget about the virtual absence of vegetables. The scene got an infusion of chaos and originality with an appearance of a 60-something gent named Xandi: pear-shaped, red-nosed, leering, perversely avuncular. According to Marco, he was famous around town for his copious eating and drinking, and was rumored to be the father or guardian of 13 children. He waded around our table kissing everyone ceremoniously and wetly and doffing an imaginary hat, then sat down among us, uninvited. He proceeded to deliver a theatrical speech to Jutta that I failed to understand fully due to my meager German, but judging by the suddenly tense faces around the table, its content must have been cutting if not downright mean.
Xandi was demonstrating Wiener Schm√§h, a local strain of humor distinguished by dark absurdity, glee at your friends‚Äô misfortune, and masking insult with flattery. When I asked Marco about it later, he shrugged and said, ‚ÄúIn Vienna, no joke is too insulting.‚Äù I knew what he meant. Back in Brooklyn, Xandi‚Äôs behavior would have caused my American-born friends to lapse into embarrassed silence. But at my Russian-Jewish family‚Äôs dinner table, an imaginative verbal jab is met with laughter and a grudging appreciation of the offender‚Äôs wit ‚Äî and so it was at Gr√ºnauer. No wonder I felt at home.
FROM OUR SIX-HOUR MARATHON of eating, drinking, and smoking, the next morning I remembered only one thing, breathed into my ear by an older gentleman of uncertain employment but many opinions. (This was Xandi, Alex told me later.) ‚ÄúYou know why Vienna is perfect?‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs 10 to 20 years more slow than everywhere else.‚Äù He slapped his doughy hands together, dropping a good bit of cigarette ash onto my jeans. ‚ÄúNo complications.‚Äù
(I may have remembered only this because, irresponsibly, I didn‚Äôt take out my reporter‚Äôs notebook all night. Alex and I were very different kinds of travel writers, it turned out ‚Äî I wrote down everything, and he often waited to see what stuck in his mind. I had decided to try it his way.)
How had we gotten to a world where this was true? Where the best places in Europe were economic B-listers (Portugal, Spain) and those behind the curve (Austria)? This had its downsides. Austria had some of the most progressive social-welfare policies in the world, but you could still smoke in bars and restaurants, and it would be wrong to say Viennese dining had completely left the Wiener schnitzel behind. (Changes were coming to the safety net, too ‚Äî several weeks before we arrived, a center-right/radical-right coalition had taken power promising to slash social benefits.)
Also, the state extended cultural funding more readily to established artistic institutions than independent artists, which meant that the dynamism and dislocation created by upstart projects often found an easier home elsewhere. Vienna felt less international than almost any Western European capital I‚Äôd visited, and almost no one in it seemed to resemble ‚Äî in dress, habit, conversational references ‚Äî the globalized elite. This cultural concentrate created a heady unpredictability ‚Äî the cost, perhaps, of visiting a place like itself and no other. Pr√ºckel, ‚ÄúSwimming Pool,‚Äù Rebhuhn, Xandi: Even when mediocre, these experiences felt gloriously unrepeatable elsewhere.
GOING OVER THAT NIGHT THE FOLLOWING MORNING, a last scene came into focus: We were at Caf√© Anzengruber, a spot popular with writers and insomniacs, operated by members of a large Croatian clan. Xandi and a pair of young chefs soon appeared. The owner, Tomi, seemed occupied mostly with taunting his defeated-looking brother-in-law, who kept to himself behind the bar. Tomi brought bottles of Croatian Gra≈°evina and schnapps and God knows what else and sat down at the table, toasting extravagantly, and soon we were staggeringly drunk. All of us, that is, except Jutta ‚Äî she sat grinning shyly and a little remorsefully among seven unlaced, hammered men. Something about her expression brought me back to a scene in my childhood kitchen, where my father and four of his friends shared loud, vodka-lubricated enthusiasms about Levi‚Äôs jeans and Edgar Winter records, with my mother functioning as the scene‚Äôs unmoving, silent axis.
Later, when I related this memory to Julya Rabinowich, one of the country‚Äôs best-known authors, she let out an exasperated guffaw. ‚ÄúWhen it comes to gender equality, Austria is 50 years behind Germany or France,‚Äù she said. Despite being a liberal stronghold, Vienna didn‚Äôt provide enough day care to meet public demand, Rabinowich explained, forcing many young mothers to stay at home. As in the country of my birth, all too many men here still expected women to handle the majority of the cooking and child care. I was realizing that, culturally, Vienna shared nearly as much with Warsaw-Pact Eastern Europe as it did with the Western democracies. I found much of that kinship problematic, but I couldn‚Äôt deny that for me it made Vienna feel as familiar and comfortable as an old blazer. At last, I was deciphering what drew me to this city: It offered much of the essence and manners of my homeland, amid the relative safety and freedom of my home.
In Rabinowich I found something like a double, whose life diverged from mine in ways that interested me. We were born several months apart; her family immigrated from the Soviet Union two years before mine did, but chose to settle in Vienna. I told Rabinowich that, after arriving as a child in New York, I‚Äôd felt almost instantly American. ‚ÄúWhen I was going to school here, no one allowed me to forget I was a foreigner,‚Äù she replied. ‚ÄúOn the other hand, the government paid for my education, awarded me a stipend that allowed me to write full time, and honored my books with prizes.‚Äù We were drinking coffee in a quiet, pretty caf√© in the city‚Äôs third district, where everyone seemed to know her by name. Rabinowich, who writes a newspaper column about politics, lamented that the recent election represented ‚Äúa sharp turn to the right.‚Äù She sighed. ‚ÄúBut of course I consider myself an Austrian,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIf I leave, I‚Äôll be in exile.‚Äù
FOR ALL THE SINCERITY OF MY SEARCHING, there was very little of 1988 Vienna left to discover. Forced to remain neutral as a condition of Soviet withdrawal after the war, Austria didn‚Äôt fully accede to the European Union until the mid-1990s. ‚ÄúWhen I went to Germany in the ‚Äô80s, I carried such lists of things to buy that my German friends would jokingly ask me if I wasn‚Äôt coming from East Germany rather than Austria,‚Äù as one person told me. But once Austria joined the EU, it didn‚Äôt look back. The modest pension where my family had stayed seemed to no longer exist, and the street where it was supposedly located listed no store of kitchen supplies.
So it felt like a miracle when it turned out that the two refugee-aid agencies that had shepherded us to America, the Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) and the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS), had representatives in Vienna that had been around for the great Soviet-refugee influx 30 years earlier. (Both agencies continue to serve refugee populations.) Alex and I met them for coffee at Caf√© Frauenhuber, a tourist-district caf√© that miraculously few tourists seem to know about. (Mozart had given his last public performance upstairs, in 1791. Vienna is like that.) And all of a sudden, I was sitting in front of two men whom I very well may have had already met, half a lifetime before.
‚ÄúI had no time to go to the washroom,‚Äù Walter Juraschek, who was with HIAS, said. The child of World War II Polish refugees, he had been made for the work, and began his days at 3 a.m., coaching atheist Soviet people like my parents and grandparents on how to say the right things about Jewish identity to the American consular officers. (Religious persecution was a precondition for refugee status.) HIAS shared an office with the JDC, and Juraschek remembers the waiting rooms and corridors so packed that muscling his way back and forth to his desk proved a daily challenge. He ran interference with the authorities, such as the police officer who had his arm broken by an iron-swinging woman who thought he was coming to arrest her. When the Danish Embassy turned away a Soviet refugee who hoped to emigrate there, Juraschek bombarded the queen of Denmark with letters until she personally intervened.
Inspired by the meeting, I strayed toward the spot on the map that showed the location of the Stadttempel, the main synagogue in Vienna, located in a warren of streets known as the Bermuda Triangle. During my family‚Äôs stay in 1988, we‚Äôd been taken by the JDC to get a glimpse of the exterior, as holiday services were in progress inside. My grandfather had not come all that way to look at a facade, so he grabbed my hand, split off from the group, and, me at his waist (I still remember the naphthalene smell of his slacks), prised open the heavy wood door. Inside, we saw something we‚Äôd never seen in our atheist homeland: Orthodox Jewish men praying. ‚ÄúFanatics!‚Äù he said, not without affection, and winked at me.
True to the promise of the Bermuda Triangle, there was nothing but the backside of an ornate building where the map said the synagogue would be. It didn‚Äôt seem like I was meant to find even this ‚Äî something that definitely still existed. But then, wandering up a side street, I saw it. Or rather the police van that, sadly, so often signals a Jewish place of worship in Europe these days. Who knew if those were the same wood doors my grandfather and I had touched, but their location was the same. As I stood alone in that alley, not wanting to approach them for fear of my intentions being mistaken ‚Äî I look Middle Eastern ‚Äî what I was seeing would have to be good enough. And what I was feeling ‚Äî my grandfather had passed away a month before I‚Äôd arrived in Vienna.
ON THE MORNING AFTER the euphoric, drunken night at Gr√ºnauer, Jutta drove Boris and me to see her vineyards on the city‚Äôs northernmost edge. As we were getting into her Audi, a Japanese tour group emerged from the U-Bahn station nearby, and a woman in a pantsuit leading the tour suddenly shrieked, ‚ÄúJutta Ambrositsch!‚Äù She introduced us excitedly to the group in rapid-fire Japanese. The tourists reacted to this by surrounding us and bursting into applause.
It was an unseasonably cold, foggy day, and Boris and I ended up tramping through muddy vineyards behind Jutta and her elderly fox terrier, Edgar. The view made up for the mud. Standing among the vines on a hill called Nussberg, we looked out over downtown Vienna, anchored by the jutting, silly Millennium Tower, and finally got a sense of the Danube‚Äôs massive span. Yet the city was inaudible ‚Äî we heard only birds. ‚ÄúI live in the city center and I‚Äôm a 20-minute drive from the vineyards,‚Äù Jutta marveled, pulling a patched hunting jacket tighter around her. ‚ÄúWhere else can you do that?‚Äù
As a respite from the cold fog and my hurricane-grade hangover, I went to the Kunsthistorisches Museum to see the Bruegels. I spent a long while in the picture gallery on the second floor, looking at ten large panels. Pieter Bruegel the Elder‚Äôs village landscapes refuse to be read as religious allegory and exist as documents of rural communities. Their portrayal of the Flemish villagers is neither humorous nor moralizing nor idealistic; instead, they‚Äôre suffused with an acceptance of the cycles of daily life ‚Äî with their 16th-century miseries intact ‚Äî and a compassion that borders on the post-human.
I stood in front of Hunters in the Snow and remembered the feeling of first seeing it as a 9-year-old. I could picture myself standing beside my mother in that gallery nearly 40 years earlier; the memory was as detailed as though it had happened last week. Later I sat down at a caf√© amid the museum‚Äôs imperial-chocolate-cake decor and ordered coffee and a piece of strudel. Then I called my mother in New York. I told her excitedly where I was, and described what I remembered. She listened patiently. ‚ÄúThe admission to that museum was expensive,‚Äù she said finally. ‚ÄúSo we didn‚Äôt go. What you remember never happened.‚Äù
ON THE BROKEN-HEADED MORNING after our bacchanal, what Vienna calls coffee ‚Äî an espresso shot lost in a trough of milk and foam ‚Äî was not going to suffice. I needed rocket fuel, and, feeling morning-after shame of a different kind, headed for the only solution I could imagine: a Starbucks. There, I did something I‚Äôve never done even in America: I ordered a venti. It was only five minutes back to my rental, but it was five minutes longer than necessary to register the horrified stares of rush-hour Vienna at the RPG in my hands.
In the weeks to come, after Alex and I returned to New York, it would be this moment I‚Äôd remember more than any other from the trip, crystals of nostalgia forming almost in real time. But no matter how sweet and less mixed my recollections of Vienna became, the feeling never alchemized into a readiness to consider moving there ‚Äî or anywhere. Having spent so many years looking toward Europe with longing, I‚Äôd failed to register just how American I was becoming ‚Äî if not always ideologically, then due simply to years of being able to order mediocre coffee in three sizes. It isn‚Äôt that you can‚Äôt go home again. It‚Äôs that once you‚Äôve lost it, every place is just what another place isn‚Äôt.
That morning, our last, Alex‚Äôs friend Jutta was driving us to the 19th district, a posh enclave on the edge of the city that dead-ends in acres of vineyards, including her own. Afterward, at lunch, I told her about my Vienna history. When I mentioned the kitchenware store I‚Äôd walked into, she lit up. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs called Ostovics!‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs one right near Neubaugasse,‚Äù the street where I‚Äôd told her our pension may have been located. Memory is as vague as it is rigid. It hadn‚Äôt occurred to me that the kitchenware store might be on a nearby street.
I had an interview after lunch, but I raced to Ostovics afterward. I remembered floor-to-ceiling windows rather than its glass recessed in a brick enclosure. But the pots and serving dishes behind the glass were painted as beautifully as artworks and actually lived up to the gleam in my memory. I looked around ‚Äî no one. I‚Äôd been feeling regret that I‚Äôd not gone up to touch the synagogue doors. (How observantly Jewish, ironically, my investment of that touch with such talismanic power.) So I went up to the Ostovics window and, feeling like a lunatic, brought my forehead to it, like all those years ago. It was cold and dry outside, and the touch left no trace.
About the authors:
Alex Halberstadt is the author of a forthcoming family memoir, Young Heroes of the Soviet Union.
Boris Fishman is the author of the novels Don‚Äôt Let My Baby Do Rodeo and A Replacement Life, and will publish Savage Feast, a family memoir told through recipes, in February.

09.10.19
Vienna is well known for its high proportion of social housing. Nowadays most sources seem to estimate that around 25% of people living in the city live in some form of municipal housing. It‚Äôs evident as you walk around the city. You cannot walk along a street without coming across a housing block with the very recognisable sign outside the entrance. And with the city celebrating it‚Äôs 100th year since the first ‚ÄòGemeindebau‚Äô it‚Äôs also inescapable in every exhibition about the city‚Äôs history.
Housing is an essential component of any city. And with my background working at one of London‚Äôs largest housing design practices, I might be biased, but I didn‚Äôt think I could come to Vienna to understand how they are approaching gender equitable design without understanding how the city‚Äôs housing works.
The existing centre of Vienna is dense, typically made up of courtyard block typologies. So there are limited opportunities for new housing development. The city has a fairly rigid zoning style ‚Äòbuilding code‚Äô, which not only sets out built parameters for building lines at the front and back, as well as heights, but also sets out what land uses are allowed on a block by block basis. This has meant that an increasingly popular form of development in the centre is rooftop extensions, as in most areas only a single storey can be added.
In the centre the majority of housing is comprised of flats. It‚Äôs not until you get quite far out that you start encountering detached homes. In the older part of town the flats often have unique layouts as they do away with the traditional arrangement of rooms coming off of a hallway, and instead the rooms themselves act as circulation space. This leads to quite space efficient apartments, even if there are some quirks ‚Äî such as entering the kitchen through the bathroom! Often this comes about through separate apartments having been combined together to create a more spacious home. This also leads to difficulties with living rooms being above bedrooms and vice versa. The other thing that‚Äôs worth noting is that many apartments in Vienna in the old town do not have balconies. But as the flats have tall and lofty rooms you don‚Äôt miss this so much.
In Red Vienna the city was really reconceptualising how to design for how people wanted to live. The aim was to provide affordable homes of good quality for broad sectors of the population. The housing provided people with light, fresh air and sunshine, as well as nurseries, schools, lending libraries and other communal facilities like laundry rooms. And with more free time they had to organise their lives differently, and the architecture followed suit too ‚Äî with more space allowed for leisure too. The kitchen became a different kind of space ‚Äî often with other functions combined with this space, turning it from a purely functional space to one to dwell in. The focus on the evolving role of the kitchen in the home, at the time, ensured that the needs of all genders were taken into consideration and advanced and adapted to new social norms.
Whilst the social principles from which Red Vienna emerged are not necessarily explicitly evident as you walk around the city, many of the ideals still undoubtedly influence and inform the shape of the city and its housing that you see today. And the legacy of the city‚Äôs municipal housing undoubtedly has an influence on the shape of its future housing.
Earlier this year I was awarded the RTPI George Pepler Award by the RTPI. The George Pepler Award is a bursary granted to a person in their first 10 years post qualification experience wishing to undertake a short period of study on a particular aspect of spatial planning. I was delighted to win the opportunity to carry out my research proposal entitled ‚ÄòWhat can the UK learn from Vienna with regards to adopting a gender mainstreaming approach to shape built outcomes?‚Äô I am currently in Vienna for researching how Vienna has made itself more Gender Equal. #GenderEqualCities

The background to my being in Austria in the first place: family. My parents were immigrants to the United States where I was born and grew up. They returned to their home country at some point, which I wasn‚Äôt happy about. Long story short: My relationship with this city is ambivalent. I hated it when we first arrived from sunny southern California. It was a completely different world. Over the years, things have changed and a certain cool factor exists plus I love classical music so it‚Äôs not the worst place to be spending time.
Here are some cool and weird facts about Vienna along with some of my experiences. Some apply to Austria. Other odd factoids are typically Viennese you won‚Äôt find anywhere else.

Title: How Vienna Became the World‚Äôs Most Livable City for Two Years in a Row
Content:

Vienna, the capital of Austria, stands as a city that seamlessly blends a rich historical legacy, vibrant culture, and a spirit of innovation. It has earned a well-deserved reputation for offering an exceptional quality of life to both its residents and visitors. Notably, Vienna has consistently secured the top spot as the world‚Äôs most livable city in esteemed international studies and rankings, such as the Global Livability Index 2022 by the Economist Intelligence Unit and the Mercer Quality of Living Survey 2022. But what distinguishes Vienna and enables it to maintain this remarkable achievement for two consecutive years? In this article, we will explore the key factors that contribute to Vienna‚Äôs unparalleled livability and unveil the myriad ways in which you can personally immerse yourself in its captivating allure.
Vienna‚Äôs public transportation system adds to its allure as an exceptional city to reside in. The city takes pride in its secure and efficient network that not only promotes sustainability and physical well-being but also effectively mitigates traffic congestion. A comprehensive range of buses, trams, trains, and metro lines seamlessly connect every corner of Vienna and its surrounding areas. Moreover, Vienna provides dedicated bike lanes, convenient car-sharing programs, and electric scooters to facilitate eco-friendly mobility options throughout the region. With the convenience of a single ticket applicable to all modes of transportation within the city limits, Vienna‚Äôs public transportation system not only offers cost-effectiveness but also remarkable practicality. According to a Eurostat report, Vienna surpasses the European average with an impressive 39% share of public transportation trips, underscoring its commitment to efficient and sustainable transportation solutions. For a seamless and stress-free commute in Vienna, rely on its dependable public transport system to take you where you need to be.
Vienna‚Äôs healthcare system stands as a cornerstone of its exceptional standard of living. Regardless of nationality or income level, all residents have access to cost-free, top-tier healthcare services. A network of highly qualified medical professionals, well-stocked pharmacies, and destigmatized mental healthcare facilities ensure the well-being of the city‚Äôs inhabitants. In the Euro Health Consumer Index report, Austria claims the ninth spot among European nations for healthcare outcomes, showcasing the effectiveness of the system. Whether seeking routine check-ups, prescription refills, or specialized treatments, Vienna‚Äôs healthcare system guarantees the provision of optimal care and unwavering support.
Vienna emerges as an extraordinary city, widely acclaimed for its remarkably low crime rates, solidifying its stature as an emblem of security and tranquility in Europe. Instances of violent crimes, including acts like homicide, assault, and robbery, manifest themselves exceptionally rarely in Vienna, thereby amplifying the city‚Äôs thoroughly deserved repute for safety. Furthermore, Vienna proudly displays an outstanding track record of minimal property crimes, encompassing theft, vandalism, and burglary. This remarkable feat can be ascribed to the city‚Äôs unflinching dedication to public safety, which encompasses a vigilant police force, an efficient justice system, and a profound sense of social cohesion among its residents. These collective elements converge to form formidable deterrents against nefarious activities. Notably, Vienna claims an impressive third position among European cities in terms of safety, as corroborated by a comprehensive report conducted by Numbeo. In your quest for a city that proffers solace and peace of mind, rest assured that Vienna transcends all expectations and bestows an idyllic milieu for a secure and harmonious lifestyle.
Vienna, a city lauded for its vibrant arts and cultural scene, bestows upon its residents an exquisitely immersive and profoundly enriching experience. With its thriving symphonic harmony, a diverse tapestry of museums and galleries, and an abundance of charming cafes, Vienna effortlessly captivates the hearts and souls of its denizens. The city exudes an unwavering pride in its artistic heritage, intricately interwoven with the illustrious names of iconic composers like Mozart, Beethoven, and Schubert. The esteemed institutions, including the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra and the Vienna State Opera, serve as majestic bastions of artistic prowess. Prepare to be submersed in the opulent and multi-faceted cultural kaleidoscope that Vienna unfurls before you. A staggering collection of over a hundred museums and galleries awaits, showcasing a splendid and eclectic assortment of ancient relics and avant-garde contemporary artistry. For the discerning aficionados of coffee, Vienna‚Äôs renowned coffee culture beckons, enticing them to indulge in an alluring array of specialized brews and savor the delightful gastronomic offerings of its quaint and inviting cafes. Allow yourself to become enraptured by the harmonious symphony of music, the captivating allure of artistic expression, and the artistry of the brewing process. Vienna, with its diverse m√©lange of experiences, promises an unparalleled journey tailored to satiate your most refined and discerning palate.
Vienna places a strong emphasis on prioritizing favorable rental conditions for its esteemed residents, ensuring a wide range of accessible and affordable housing options are readily available. With its thriving rental market, the city goes above and beyond to safeguard against exorbitant prices and promotes the widespread availability of high-quality subsidized housing. The rental agreements in Vienna operate under a comprehensive system that meticulously regulates the duration of leases, termination policies, and rent adjustments, aiming to strike a fair and equitable balance. Moreover, the city boasts a significant number of social housing units that are either owned or supported by benevolent non-profit organizations and dedicated local governments. These invaluable resources serve as an indomitable force for the well-being of diverse groups, including hardworking students, cherished seniors, and intrepid immigrants, by providing them with secure, comfortable, and cost-effective housing solutions. It is worth highlighting that Vienna stands tall, with an impressive 62% of its remarkable housing stock being designated as social housing, surging past the European average of a mere 11%, as diligently reported by the reputable organization, Housing Europe. Indisputably, Vienna takes immense pride in offering an alluring tapestry of housing options, adeptly tailored to suit the unique preferences and discerning tastes of its cherished residents. Whether one is in pursuit of a cozy haven nestled in an enchanting apartment, a grandiose residence adorned with spaciousness and elegance, or a harmonious fusion of both, Vienna proudly presents an expansive array of choices. Spanning from the labyrinthine streets of the inner city, pulsating with vibrant energy and cultural splendor, to the idyllic, serene realms of the sprawling suburbs, where tranquility dances in harmony with nature‚Äôs embrace, Vienna weaves a captivating narrative of architectural brilliance and captivating neighborhoods that beckon to be explored.
Vienna emanates an enchanting allure, captivating all those who venture into its embrace. This mesmerizing metropolis proudly showcases an immaculate atmosphere and minimal pollution, owing to its vast expanses of verdant landscapes and steadfast dedication to environmental preservation. Nestled within the confines of Vienna are an abundance of luxuriant settings, ranging from sprawling parks and flourishing gardens to majestic forests and picturesque vineyards. These scenic havens not only provide idyllic habitats for a diverse array of wildlife but also beckon as serene retreats for both denizens and visitors, seamlessly blending urban sophistication with nature‚Äôs resplendent charms. Moreover, Vienna stands as a beacon of environmental consciousness, implementing a comprehensive array of policies to curtail greenhouse gas emissions, champion renewable energy sources, and spearhead waste reduction and recycling endeavors. As attested by the esteemed European Environment Agency, Vienna proudly boasts a remarkable 50% more expanse of green space than the average European city, underscoring its unwavering commitment to preserving the magnificence of the natural world. Should you yearn for a city where you can revel in invigorating zephyrs and immerse yourself in the awe-inspiring wonders of the natural realm, Vienna beckons as an extraordinary destination to carve out your path.
In conclusion, Vienna has achieved widespread global recognition for its unparalleled provision of residents and visitors with an extraordinary quality of life. The city‚Äôs consistent acquisition of the esteemed distinction as the world‚Äôs most livable city for two consecutive years, as supported by a multitude of international studies and rankings, further enhances its reputation. Vienna‚Äôs exceptional livability can be attributed to an array of multifaceted factors that set it apart from others. These encompass its outstanding healthcare system, efficiently interconnected public transportation network, flourishing arts and cultural scene, advantageous rental market, commendably low crime rates, and immaculate environmental conditions. Vienna truly embodies a distinctive fusion of health, convenience, vibrancy, affordability, safety, and sustainability. Should you be in pursuit of a city that encapsulates all these benefits and more, Vienna stands as the ultimate destination of choice. Whether you are contemplating a permanent relocation or planning a visit, this city guarantees an extraordinary and memorable experience like no other. There, you will uncover invaluable resources to aid in your trip planning, exploration of noteworthy attractions, selection of accommodations and dining options, as well as seamless navigation throughout the city. Embark on an enlightening journey to discover the myriad reasons behind Vienna‚Äôs prestigious recognition as the world‚Äôs most livable city for two consecutive years. Seize this invaluable opportunity to immerse yourself in the captivating wonders that Vienna has to offer.

Title: Vienna is an elegant city
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Tuesday and Wednesday, May 6 and 7
This may be a long post because it covers two days. We are greeted by the Empress Maria Theresa, one of the rare female monarchs we have encountered. The Viennese speak warmly of her and I believe she had a long and peaceful reign. She also had 16 (!) children, one being Marie Antoinette. They were all intermarried, it seems.
There is another monarch, Empress Elizabeth, whose life was much more complicated, but more about her later.
To be honest, I have taken so many pictures of so many buildings that I can‚Äôt remember three days later which is which. I just want to give you a sense of each place. All of the cities started with the Celts, then Vikings, then the Roman Empire. Only rare bits of Roman roads and buildings can be seen.
The streets are narrow and curved in the medieval style. The buildings are from later periods. Many have been rebuilt because of WW II.
In Germany the Renaissance style buildings were over the top, like Baroque and Rococo. But Vienna is a little more subdued. It is spacious and grand and elegant without overwhelm.
So here are a few pictures of various buildings and statues. The only thing I can discern is when I‚Äôm taking pictures of a church.
This is not a church. This is the old city gate and its alcove, home to the Sisi Museum and the Lippizaner Museum ( the famous dancing white horses).
Speaking of horses, they have horse drawn carriages you can ride? But we didn‚Äôt do this.
What was cool was that the horses all had these decorative head pieces that covered their ears. I guess it gets cold in Vienna in the winter.
This is the Imperial Palace in Vienna, which has a ridiculous number of rooms.
This is some statue monarch made to associate himself with God. I‚Äôm not sure if was to honor God or himself, but there was that ‚Äúdivine right of kings‚Äù thing going centuries ago. And then you remember all the Prince Bishops‚Ä¶ so much intertwining of religious and political power.
I was surprised that a truck drove through a pedestrian area! I didn‚Äôt expect that.
Street food.
Now this really surprised me. Here is this beautiful building covered with an advertisement. I looked closed and this is actually a fabric painting reproducing the building; it hides the scaffolding and the ad helps disguise the fabric covering. You don‚Äôt even notice it‚Äôs fake. A disguise of a disguise.
This is a church. I think it‚Äôs St. Stephen‚Äôs.
Note the beautiful tiled roof.
It‚Äôs always hard to get a picture of the whole church but I got this replica.
Pictures of inside the church follow.
And there is always a gift shop.
After the official tour we decided to go wander around Vienna. Chocolate, anyone? ( I‚Äôm talking to you, Abby.) They gave samples, like at an ice cream store.
This made us hungry so we stopped in a coffee shop and of course you need a pastry to go along with your coffee. Even Chappell drank coffee in honor of the tradition.
Interesting sights along the way. Bicycles often have a large front container to carry groceries or to ferry children. If they ferry children they have little car seats with seat belts.
Poor dog!
(Rachel I know. I don‚Äôt have many dogs here but not as many people have dogs and they don‚Äôt let you pet them.)
Chappell asked me what I wanted to do next. I wanted to go to the Sisi Museum. I‚Äôm sure Jeremy knows all about this because he knows about everything. I had never heard of her but she had a tragic life. I am told it is now a Netflix series called ‚ÄúPrincess Elizabeth.‚Äù
When you go into the museum the first thing you see a is a plaster death mask. She was quite poetic and expressed her melancholy in her journals. They were posted on the walls throughout.
‚ÄúBut mournfully I spread my wide, white wings, return home to the fairy kingdom and nothing shall bring me back again.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am Sunday‚Äôs child, a child of the sun. Her golden rays she wove into my throne; with her glow she wove her crown. It is her light that I live, but should she ever wane from me, I must die.‚Äù
Sisi grew up in Bavaria out in the countryside. It was an idyllic childhood. She is the little girl in each of these pictures.
This is a bust of her at age 10. She grew into a beautiful young woman who was known for her beautiful hair.
These were some of her Crown Jewels.
And some of her ball gowns.
Her fan
These were her staterooms.
And her personal exercise room.
And her bedroom
Sisi lived a very sad life. She hated the constraints of the court and its duties, but her real torture was her mother-in-law. Her mother-in-law was terribly overbearing and ruled with an iron fist.
Even so, the couple was reasonably happy. Sisi was away on a state visit with her husband when their child died at age 6. That caused a rift in their marriage that was never repaired. Sisi began traveling throughout Europe without her husband; she seemed to have given up on her son and left him behind to the ‚Äúcare‚Äù of his mother-in-law. (Sisi‚Äôs son Rudolph was a disaster, probably as a result of his horrible upbringing.) Sisi, herself, wore black during these sad, later years.
‚ÄúElizabeth‚Äôs incessant traveling is increasingly characterized by unease and restlessness. The ‚Äúlady in black‚Äù constantly sought to escape the burden of her own personality and was prey to profound melancholy.‚Äù
At age 61 she was assassinated by an anarchist who just wanted to create some chaos. She was never meant to be the target, but she was at the wrong place at the wrong time. What a tragic life.
The next day we woke up with a boat gas station and attendant right outside our balcony. I had never thought about the need to fuel up or how they would do that. I‚Äôd love to know more about all the behind the scenes workings of the ship.
Chappell had gone to the Schonnbrun Palace (the summer residence), so I had the morning to myself. I had been thinking about going to the Klint Museum but couldn‚Äôt get an appointment that didn‚Äôt conflict with a planned afternoon tour of the Vienna Boys Choir. So I just spent a sunny morning in the lounge. (This is also where I caught up on my posts.)
This was the view of modern Vienna on the opposite bank from the old city. It‚Äôs all very new and modern.
That afternoon I took a trip to the home of the Vienna Boys choir, but it‚Äôs more than one choir of boys.
It functions as a boarding school set in a beautiful old neighborhood in Vienna.
These are the formal gardens.
Everything is ‚Äúold Vienna.‚Äù
The choir has been in existence since before 1500 and was always supported by the royalty. During these centuries the boys were dressed as little soldiers in the king‚Äôs army. After the fall of the monarchy the uniforms were changed to sailor suits. This was not because they had a navy but because sailor suits were normal attire for children at that time.
We were escorted into an oval room with perfect acoustics and serenaded by 18 boys in the choir.
Of course the music was angelic. Their voices were were so pure and clear. I think I will never forget the sound of their voices.
I had hoped for that but I learned things I never expected.
They started the performance with ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no business like show business‚Äù which was quite a surprise. They sang a wide range of music as a group, with occasional solos and duets.
The children are from all over the world and tour all over the world. It was touching to see a Russian boy and a Ukrainian boys singing side by side. It was perhaps appropriate because their last song was ‚ÄúWe are the world, we are the children.‚Äù They consider themselves as ambassadors.
They are more than a boys choir. There is a non-residential elementary school for children ages 6‚Äì10, with quite an emphasis on music. If the children show an interest and aptitude, there are simple auditions for admission to the residential middle school and choir for ages 10‚Äì14.
There are actually four choirs of about 24 boys each. Each choir is named after a great composer, such as the Brahms choir, the Mozart choir, etc. One choir is always on tour while the other choirs have school. There is also a girls‚Äô choir for ages 10‚Äì14 with their own conductor. The girls attend the school but go home at night; a dormitory for them is being planned. Their is now a high school, so the children can continue their education and be part of the youth choir. Some stay, but others opt for a normal high school life (if such a thing exists).
It‚Äôs good to know, though, that they have a normal life. I got this photo of some of the boys were playing soccer. They still get to be kids.

With the greatest of delights I just realised something: all my life, I have been living in Red Cities ‚Äî cities with a Socialist history. All the cities I loved and lived in ‚Äî Ghent in Belgium, Jerusalem in Israel, Firenze in Italy, and now Vienna ‚Äî were, and sometimes still are, fiery red, and proud of it.
I have been in Vienna for nearly fifteen years now, and I have gradually discovered a place and a history that traditional travel guides won‚Äôt tell you much about. Yet this Rotes Wien is visible everywhere, in every district you visit and on nearly every street you walk through.

Title: Dear Summer
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
For the first time in a long time,
I feel like myself again.
Not the version I had to shrink to be loved,
not the one who stayed quiet to keep the peace,
not the girl who called the bare minimum ‚Äúenough.‚Äù
She walked through hell,
but I left her there ‚Äî
with the people who fed off her silence
and mistook her kindness for weakness.
Now, I‚Äôm done explaining,
done waiting to be chosen,
done carrying weight that was never mine.
I‚Äôve never felt so *light.*
There‚Äôs sunlight in my bones again,
a laugh I don‚Äôt have to fake,
and dreams I‚Äôm finally letting breathe.
Next week: Florida.
Me and my friends, chasing the sun,
singing too loud, dancing barefoot,
and soaking in every golden hour like it‚Äôs a promise.
Then‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäEurope.
A one-way ticket and no return date.
No plan but joy.
No map but instinct.
I want to get lost on purpose.
To fall in love with places, moments, and maybe even myself again.
To write my story across coastlines and caf√©s,
with no one‚Äôs voice in my head but mine.
This summer isn‚Äôt an escape ‚Äî
it‚Äôs a return.
To who I was before the noise.
To who I‚Äôve *always* been, underneath the wreckage.
And this time,
I‚Äôm not just moving on ‚Äî
I‚Äôm moving *up.*
Unapologetically.
Unstoppably.
Unforgettably.
With love (and finally, freedom),
**Me**
