Title: ‚ÄúRed Vienna‚Äù: the most liveable city on Earth, and why we need to be good ancestors
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
1.
‚ÄúAre we being good ancestors?‚Äù. This was the question posed by the American virologist Jonas Salk in 1955, after developing the first effective vaccine against polio. He refused to patent the vaccine, missing out on millions in earnings, believing that the best way to become a good ancestor was to give it away to anyone who needed it.
Long-term thinking, and becoming a good ancestor, does not come naturally to humanity. Corporate executives are flustered about quarterly reports, and seek the dopamine hit of immediate growth rather than implementing a long-term strategy. Political leaders focus on the next set of parliamentary elections, rather than worry about long-term issues, such as the climate crisis or sustainable development. Far too often, we are consumed by the ‚Äútyranny of now‚Äù, rather than the ‚Äúpower of yet‚Äù, to use Carol Dweck‚Äôs phrase.
We see this in Ireland, and its attitude to housing. Last year, there was a lot of chat in the media about the ‚Ç¨750 tax credit for renters, announced in the last budget. I appreciate this, but it does nothing to address the real problem ‚Äî lack of supply. Everybody in this country, except possibly legislators in the D√°il, knows that there is an acute shortage of housing here.
No tax credit ever built a house or an apartment. It also means nothing to the person that can‚Äôt find a property to rent in Dublin or Cork. This example of the ‚Äútyranny of now‚Äù, which the coalition government may be using to gain voters for next year‚Äôs general election, needs to be replaced with a longer-term strategy, the ‚Äúpower of yet‚Äù. One city provides an example of such a strategy.
In this essay, I discuss Vienna, a city that used the ‚Äúpower of yet‚Äù to fix a housing crisis 100 years ago. Immigration exacerbated the city‚Äôs housing shortage, leaving hundreds of thousands of Viennese living without running water or toilet facilities. I will tell you about ‚ÄúRed Vienna‚Äù, and how a left-wing municipal government built a ‚ÄúRing Road of the Proletariat‚Äù, without creating crime-ridden communities. I will also show you how this legacy endures today ‚Äî today, Vienna is the most liveable city in the world. Viennese policymakers from 100 years ago are rightly remembered as good ancestors; Irish policymakers could be as well.
2.
Following the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire after the First World War, Vienna, then home to 2 million people, found itself in a desperate situation. Wartime rationing and inflation had left middle-class professionals and businessowners on the brink of starvation and vulnerable to infectious diseases. Vienna, once the sparkling capital of a multi-ethnic empire, home to Croats, Slovenes, Czechs, Poles, and of course Austrians and Hungarians, was now an overcrowded city within a war-ravaged state. The treaty of Saint-Germain, signed in 1919, explicitly forbade the new German-speaking republic from unifying with Germany, enraging socialists and nationalists alike.
Vienna, now home to 28% of the population of the newly established Republic of Austria, lacked basic amenities, such as food and clothing, largely due to trade embargos imposed on it by the Triple Entente. Hyperinflation rendered War Bonds worthless, eliminating the savings of the middle and upper classes. Supply chains to Vienna from its empire were cut off by the existence of new borders, making the supply of food even more difficult. Communists and fascists in the city stirred up working-class grievances, leading to strikes and political violence.
Just as we see in the English-speaking world today, Vienna had a chronic shortage of affordable housing. Over 250,000 Viennese workers lived in small apartment blocks, known as ‚ÄúBassena‚Äù, with no access to running water. Many of Vienna‚Äôs ‚ÄúBettgeher‚Äù (‚Äúbed lodgers‚Äù) lived in rent-by-the-room accommodations, in which residents could only sleep in their beds for half of the day, effectively sleeping in shifts. These units lacked windows or toilet facilities, depriving renters of cleanliness and sunlight. The units weren‚Äôt even cheap; a 2022 study from MIT calculated that rent could cost up to 25% of a family‚Äôs income. These unsanitary yet expensive homes remind me of Awaab Ishak, a two-year-old child who died from exposure to mould in a flat in Rochdale in England last year.
Like Ireland today, Vienna‚Äôs housing shortage came in response to an influx of immigrants. Between 1880 and 1910, its total number of inhabitants jumped from 726,000 to over 2 million, placing it on a par with Paris and Berlin. For instance, Jewish immigrants, granted full citizenship by the Empire in 1867, flocked to the city from Hungary, Moravia and Galicia. The names of the new arrivals read like a who‚Äôs who of fin-de-si√®cle European intellectual life: Sigmund Freud was born in Moravia, before moving to the city with his family when he was four years old. Theodor Herzl, the founder of the modern Zionist movement, was born in Budapest, before arriving in Vienna to study law.
3.
In 1919, the city held its Gemeinderat (Municipal Elections), electing as its mayor the socialist Jakob Reumann. Reumann, a member of the Social Democratic Workers Party of Austria (SDAP), made the then-innovative decision to build 25,000 units subsided public housing for Austrian workers, financed by progressive taxes on land and luxury goods, such as champagne and cars. About 40 percent of the costs of building the houses came from taxes on upper-class properties. From 1919 to 1933, the city council was the only entity that built new homes.
In 1927, construction began on Karl-Marx-Hof (literally ‚ÄúKarl Marx Court‚Äù). Finished in 1930, it was designed by Karl Ehn, an architect and socialist who apprenticed under Otto Wagner, a native of Vienna, and founder of the Art Nouveau architectural movement. The Karl-Marx-Hof consisted of green spaces, play areas and amenities such as a pharmacy and a post office. Comprised of 1,382 apartments, and designed for a population of about 5,000, it spanned about 1.2 kilometres in length, making it the longest single residential buildings in the world. Other hofe, such as Engelshof, Bebelhof, and George-Washington-Hof, emerged during the same period. Public baths like the Amalienbad, opened in 1926, provided proper sanitation for lower-class Viennese, as well as a safe place to socialise.
Just as NIMBYists (not-in-my-back-yard) today warn that increasing the supply of social housing will create a new generation of ‚Äúschool dropouts, drug users, non-workers and criminals‚Äù, there was a moral panic around the provision of housing in Vienna too. The taxes needed to finance their construction were viciously opposed by ‚ÄúBlack Vienna‚Äù, which consisted of conservative landowners and leaders, monarchists, anti-Semites and Catholic radicals. They whined about ‚Äútax bolshevism‚Äù and ‚Äúcommunist tyranny‚Äù, potentially effective dog whistles in the aftermath of the Russian Revolution.
As noted previously, the planners of ‚ÄúRed Vienna‚Äù were followers of Otto Wagner and his Art Nouveau movement. The Art Nouveau style, used to design Viennese buildings such as the Majolica House and the Secession Building, used intricate patterns, curving lines, and the use of materials like glass, ceramics and iron. Using similarly elaborate patterns helped to make the new apartment blocks, spanning the ‚ÄúRing Road of the Proletariat‚Äù on Margaretengurtel in southern Vienna, look like upper-class dwellings. Harvard historian Eve Blau sums up the pragmatic case for beautiful social houses thus: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre planning something radical, it‚Äôs not a bad idea to come across as conservative as possible‚Äù.
4.
By 1934, the Viennese city council had built about 64,000 apartments, which housed 10% of the city‚Äôs population. Like the Karl-Marx-Hof, these too were equipped with everyday amenities. As well as the city‚Äôs progressive tax system, this impressive rate of construction was assisted by the city council‚Äôs intelligent use of rent controls. First implemented in 1922, rent controls initially disincentivised the private development of private buildings, reducing the price of urban land. The council could then purchase the land at the discounted price and create jobs by building on it.
‚ÄúRed Vienna‚Äù would be suspended in 1934, following the establishment of the Standestaat, a one-party fascist state rendered paranoid by the perceived evils of ‚Äútax bolshevism‚Äù and ‚Äúcommunist tyranny‚Äù. Between 1938 and 1945, the country would be occupied by the Nazis, led of course by a genocidal Austrian corporal with a silly moustache. After the war, which left over 20% of the city‚Äôs housing stock partially or completely destroyed, the Social Democrats regained power, and ‚ÄúRed Vienna‚Äù returned with a vengeance. Projects such as the Per-Albin-Hansson-Siedlung in Favoriten, home to 14,000 residents, came into being. In 1969, Vienna constructed its 100,000th new home since the end of Nazi rule.
Today, over 60% of Vienna‚Äôs 1.8 million people live in subsidized housing. Local authorities own and manage about 220,000 housing units, about one-quarter of the city‚Äôs total housing stock, and indirectly controls 200,000 units that are owned by private-developers but governed by a city-regulated process. In 1984, the city set up a ‚ÄúLand Procurement and Urban Renewal Fund‚Äù that reserves land in the city for affordable homes and amenities ‚Äî as of 2019, the fund owned over 3 million square metres of land. In 2018, the city passed legislation, requiring that for all housing projects with over 5,000 square metres of space, at least two thirds of the new builds must be subsided. Recent projects include the 850-apartment Wohnpark Neue Donau and the 1,004-unit Kabelwerk estate.
5.
The positive consequences of Vienna‚Äôs commitment to housing development are obvious. A 2023 report shows that average rents are just over a quarter those of European cities such as Paris and Oslo. Figures for monthly rents, which by law cannot be more than 25% of a tenant‚Äôs income, are often as low as ‚Ç¨500 or ‚Ç¨600, less than one-third those of Dublin, and can even fall as low as ‚Ç¨250 for long-term residents.
It should therefore come as little surprise that Vienna has been selected as the most liveable city in the world in eight of the past ten years by the Economist, including last year. For context, London ranks 34th and Dublin comes in at 37th. This survey takes each city‚Äôs accessibility, healthcare, infrastructure and culture into account, and is a testament to the enduring legacy of ‚ÄúRed Vienna‚Äù and the ‚Äúpower of yet‚Äù.
6.
In this essay, I have described ‚ÄúRed Vienna‚Äù, and how it demonstrates the significance of long-term thinking. I have shown you how a formerly impoverished place became the most liveable city on Earth. It is not as if the ‚Äúpower of yet‚Äù is entirely foreign to Ireland ‚Äî in the 1920s, the German company Siemens built the Ardnacrusha Generating Station in County Clare, a project that required almost one-fifth of the Free State‚Äôs entire annual budget. The new power station harnessed the waters of the river Shannon to generate about 96% of Ireland‚Äôs electricity requirements. The State was poor back then. Now it is estimated that the country will have a ‚Ç¨65.2 billion budget surplus by 2027; a pot of gold from foreign multinationals. Let us be good ancestors and spend it.

Title: Professor Martina Huemann Of The WU Vienna University of Economics and Business On How We Can Increase Women‚Äôs Engagement in Leadership
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

In-depth Interviews with Authorities in Business, Pop Culture, Wellness, Social Impact, and Tech. We use interviews to draw out stories that are both empowering and actionable.

--
Listen
Share
‚Ä¶Inclusive leadership training and culture change are necessary to break away from traditional, male-dominated leadership models. Women should be encouraged to lead without having to adopt a ‚Äúmale‚Äù style, and leadership training should highlight the strengths women bring to the table. I‚Äôve seen organisations that revamped their training programs to focus on emotional intelligence and collaborative leadership. This approach helped one female manager I know feel more confident and authentic in her promotion to a top management role‚Ä¶
We had the pleasure of interviewing Martina Huemann. Martina is Professor at the WU Vienna University of Economics and Business where she heads the Project Management Group in the Department Strategy and Innovation and is the Academic Director of the Professional MBA Program: Project Management. She has published widely in the fields of Project Management and Human Resource Management. For her Research on Human Resource management in Project-oriented Organisations, she received the IPMA Research Award 2015.
Thank you so much for doing this with us! Before we dig in, our readers would like to get to know you a bit more. Can you tell us a bit about your ‚Äúbackstory‚Äù? What led you to this particular career path?
Born in Vienna, Austria I am currently living between Vienna and London. While in Vienna I am Academic Director of the Vienna Executive MBA: Strategic Project Management and lead the Project Management Group in the Institute of Strategic Management at WU Vienna. For 1,5 years I am a Full Professor of Project Leadership and Society at University College London, Bartlett School of Sustainable Construction.
I am Editor-in Chief of International Journal of Project Management, the leading journal in Project Research and Founding Editor-in-Chief of Project Leadership and Society and hold several board positions in national and international Associations.
I have two children, two boys, one born 1997 and one born 2005.
Can you share the most interesting story that happened to you since you began your career?
My career was probably not expected from me. As I was the first one in my family who made it to university. My parents came from a simple background, my mother was educated as a tailor but run a small shop and my father was a warehouse worker for a newspaper. While both not having much formal education, they always gave me the feeling that I can achieve everything what I want.
I also did my studies at WU Vienna and when I entered the building I felt not belonging there, more an alien. I had no role models in my family. However, I decided that I wanted to get more knowledge and a formal education. I studied Business Administration. During the weekends Friday to Sunday night, I worked 20 hours plus in an ice cream shop to contribute to financing my life.
I always having a drive for learning, getting to know something new, but also for visiting other countries and traveling. I am a quite curious person interested in understanding different subjects and contexts, meeting new people and making a difference.
During my studies I spent one semester in Prague and later one semester in Lund Sweden. I was travelling and had the opportunity to engage in different projects, one of those was an EU funded project bringing Didactics to Middle and Eastern Europe countries like Poland, Tech Republic and Slovakia. I was engaged there as a student evaluator. Looking back this got me interested in universities, teachings and in projects and how change can be organised trough projects. Which set the ground also for my interest to research and educate how to manage projects.
When I finally finished my graduate studies, I got a position at a newly established small department at WU focused on Project Management. I supported the establishment of that university unit, its research and education programme. Finally, I received a position funded by the university and started my doctorate in Project Management. I early got involved internationally in the International Project Management Association as I was taken there through my professor. That helped me immensely to build my network.
My first son was born shortly after I received my first university financed position. This caused quite some turbulence. I was questioned by my work environment if family was now my priority and if leaving academia would be better for me. I took a quite short maternity leave and went back to keep my position and finished my doctorate.
My career was only possible with my partner and especially the of my mother and the father of my partner. who helped a lot with the childcare. To make a university career in my context I had to pursue a Habitation, and which set a further milestone in my career that opened the door for my professorship.
Can you share a pivotal moment in your career that significantly influenced your path to leadership?
As an early career researcher, I received a quite tempting invitation to apply for positions at another university abroad. But I decided not to go for it as I would have needed to take the whole family to a different country. It would have been very difficult for my partner to find a job and I felt it was not appropriate to ask my partner and my family to start somewhere new just because of my career aspirations.
This is also the reason why I did my career at WU Vienna. While it was international and I have been engaged in International Associations like International Project Management Association or Project Management Institute, I remained a stable main position at WU Vienna. However as my children are now grown up, I did apply for a professorship at University College London and reduced my position at WU.
Ok, thank you for that. Let‚Äôs now jump to the primary focus of our interview. According to this report, only about 31.7% of top executive positions across industries are held by women. This reflects great historical progress, but it also shows that more work still has to be done to empower women. In your opinion and experience what is currently holding back women from leadership and management?
Many different issues. Most of them are structural
Woman are socialized with a set of desired behaviours expected from them.
Can you share a few reasons why more women should become leaders and managers?
Women and men are different, and this is good. People are different in their personalities and talents and hey bring different perspective and contributions.
Studies show that women in board rooms make a positive effect on company performance. The offer is to see women (and other minorities) rather as an asset and help to build structures to support them to provide contributions.
Can you please share ‚Äú5 Things We Need To Increase Women‚Äôs Engagement in Leadership and Management?‚Äù If you can, please share an example or story for each.
First, targeted mentoring and coaching are essential. Women often face barriers to accessing high-quality mentorship, so structured programs help women identify their strengths, set clear goals, and navigate leadership challenges. I remember when my employer once said, ‚ÄúTry it for six months. If it doesn‚Äôt work, you can go back.‚Äù That kind of mentoring gave me a safe space to test my leadership skills without the fear of permanent failure, which really helped me move forward in my career.
Proactive networking is another important factor. Women need to actively create or join networks that connect them with senior leaders and like-minded peers. These networks provide access to important contacts and sponsorship opportunities.
Flexible working arrangements are also crucial. The challenge of balancing professional and family responsibilities often deters women from pursuing leadership roles. By adopting flexible hours, job-sharing, or part-time management positions, leadership roles can be made more accessible. In my own experience, I‚Äôve seen the positive effects of companies offering more flexibility. In one example, a company revamped its policies to allow flexible scheduling, which allowed a talented leader to balance her childcare responsibilities with her role on the board. The result was improved team performance.
Inclusive leadership training and culture change are necessary to break away from traditional, male-dominated leadership models. Women should be encouraged to lead without having to adopt a ‚Äúmale‚Äù style, and leadership training should highlight the strengths women bring to the table. I‚Äôve seen organisations that revamped their training programs to focus on emotional intelligence and collaborative leadership. This approach helped one female manager I know feel more confident and authentic in her promotion to a top management role.
Finally, objective recruitment and promotion processes are critical. Using methods like structured personality assessments and behaviour-based interviews helps combat unconscious bias and ensures candidates are chosen based on merit.
In your opinion, what systemic changes are needed to facilitate more equitable access for women to leadership roles?
Companies must embrace legislation that promotes gender diversity, like the EU‚Äôs push for more women on boards. However, quotas alone aren‚Äôt enough ‚Äî accountability is key to preventing tokenism.
Corporate cultures need to evolve to value leadership traits that women excel in, such as empathy and collaboration. Changing outdated success metrics to reflect these qualities is essential, and recruitment and promotion processes must also be free from bias, prioritising merit over personal connections.
Work-life integration policies should be standard, not exceptions. Companies must normalise flexible work options for everyone, not just working mothers. Investing in female leadership development early on through mentorship, training, and networks like the WU Executive Academy‚Äôs Female Leaders Network ensures women have the resources to succeed in senior roles.
These systemic changes won‚Äôt happen overnight, but when companies and policymakers commit to action rather than discussion, real progress follows.
What strategies have you found most effective in mentoring and supporting other women to pursue leadership positions?
My main strategy is to empower young women to find their own ways and learn to trust in themselves. I am mentoring several women to help them in their academic careers. Very operationally I help them to understand their strengths and especially help them to understand they are not required to deliver 110% all the time. A trap that I have tapped in during my career and which I could not continue especially after I had my children.
A funny story to share was at one of my first panels I was invited to. I prepared so much and worked on my performance in every detail. I just wanted to be able to provide the perfect answers to all possible questions. Which is of cause not possible. However, I did not stop preparing and did not sleep the night before the event. So, when I was sitting at the panel, I was very tired, very serious and concentrated to get it all right. Without any smile, quite fact oriented. I was knowledgeable, said the right things, but my message was not convincing. It was just one boring smart voice among many others. Additionally, when others were speaking, I was so tiered that I simply fell asleep in front of 300 people. My sleep only took some seconds, and I still hope nobody saw it. However, that situation taught me an important lesson which I use to encourage women not to over prepare, take life a little easier, consider the package, how to deliver the message and not only what.
And yes we women cannot have everything at the same time. Children and major career steps at the same time is (almost) not possible to pursue at the same time. But there is also the right time for everything. Not everything needs to happen till the age of 35.
A good personal example is my recent career step, the appointment as Professor at University College London. When I was invited to apply, my youngest child was to finish School thus it was a window of opportunity that had opened, but it is then also a decision if you want to get you out of your comfort zone.
How would you advise a woman leader about how to navigate the challenges of being a woman in a leadership role within a male-dominated industry?
When I did my first formal education in Project Management, it was in 1996 and it was the Certificate Programme ‚ÄúInternational Project Management‚Äù, back then offered by the WU Vienna and the Technical University Vienna. There were 20 participants in class, 19 men and me. All of them having technical background mainly Engineering, Construction and Information Technology, the typical industries in which Project Management was applied back then. My background was Business Administration (specialized in Marketing) and I was the only woman. I was again an obvious alien, especially as I was the only woman in the room, and I was young. In this situation I asked myself whether I fit in? But reframed my question in what I can bring to the table, what are my competencies my talents that I can contribute and makes me add value. In this situation it was my social competencies, my strength to observe, listen and ask questions, thus my talent to lead processes in groups that added value and allowed me to add value. This is also my advice to women, know what you are good at understand what added value you can bring to the table. Be authentic and play to your strengths.
How do you balance the demand for authoritative leadership with the stereotypical expectations of female behaviour in professional settings?
Well use stereotypes like the hard man and the soft woman because that makes live easier to us. But the world is not black and white. If we look in more detail I do not believe in authoritarian leadership. Hero leadership is not working, especially not with younger generations. Hierarchies have become flatter, people want to work flexible, self organised, autonomy has become important, that is reflected in a modern leadership that is flatter, shared, distributed and often puts purpose in the foreground.
A leader needs be reflective person who takes decisions timely and is accountable for them. Core competences are to navigate uncertainty, embrace change, give orientation to others, think strategically and engaging others to co-create the future of an organisation. Today leaders should be able to stand in the spotlight but also is able to share the spotlight with others.
How can our readers further follow your work online?
Easiest is to follow me on LinkedIn
Professor Martina Huemann https://www.linkedin.com/in/martinahuemann/?originalSubdomain=at
The Project Hub
https://www.linkedin.com/company/projecthubucl/?viewAsMember=true
I especially interested how we can co-create the future with projects.
Current I look into value creation by projects, careers of project professionals and investigates what motivates (young) project professionals to work on projects
Thank you for these fantastic insights. We greatly appreciate the time you spent on this.

I woke up this morning at dawn‚Ä¶I wasn‚Äôt quite sure where I was until I opened the window. The sun was rising in the horizon and it clicked: ‚ÄúVienna!‚Äù
I had always dreamed of Vienna as this elegant and majestuous city, home of Sisi the Empress and fairy tales my mum used to read me in bed. I remember the history books in high school with pictures of the Austro-Hungarian Empire portraying royal families and castles. The heart of Europe.
I left my hotel not knowing exactly where I was headed to; all I wanted was to travel back in time, wander through history, let the city surprise me and instinct be my guide.
As I approached the centre, the magic started to unfold: majestic buildings like the Parliament, the Museum‚Ä¶I walked through a manicured garden that led me straight into the statue of Mozart. It reminded me that Vienna is The City Of Music, home to Beethoven and Schubert and I can understand where they got the inspiration to‚Ä¶

I wish I never met you.
I don't think there was any good reason behind it I think it was an accident.
Like, Fate got distracted looking at its phone, and when it looked back up, we‚Äôd crashed into each other, and it was too late.
The damage was done, and we had met.
I don't think it was a good lesson or that it had made me tougher or a better person I think it just became part of the reason I'm not the same anymore.
The reason I'm so closed off, the reason I don't trust people at all anymore.
I don't think we were supposed to meet.
I think it was a complete misfortune.
And sometimes I think about the day it happened and how one minor decision could have stopped the whole thing.
One moment could have saved me.
Because if we had never met, I would still be all the good parts of me, and there would be a few less parts that need to be fixed.
And I would still go for drives, but you wouldn't enter my thoughts like you were robbing a bank.
And I would still have these friends, but we would not reflect on how warped I was during the time you were a part of my life.
And I would still have fallen in love again, and it wouldn't have taken as much reassurance.
I wouldn't have been shocked that love is so different than I had originally thought.
What doesn't kill you makes you stronger, sure, but I'd be strong anyway, and the time I spent around you is dead to me, wasted time.
I wish I never met you.
I wish fate had been paying attention.
It was an accident that wasn't waiting to happen, a calamity, a catastrophe, a mistake.

Title: A Weekend in Vienna
Content:

Vienna, the capital of Austria, is a city steeped in history and culture, with a breathtaking array of stunning architecture, art, and museums. From the grand Baroque palaces to the intricately designed cathedrals, Vienna is a city that exudes elegance and sophistication. As you stroll through the streets of Vienna, you can‚Äôt help but be enchanted by the city‚Äôs rich history, its artistic vibrancy, and its charming atmosphere.
One of the must-see architectural wonders of Vienna is the St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral, a Gothic masterpiece that dominates the city‚Äôs skyline. With its towering spires and intricate stained glass windows, this cathedral is a testament to the city‚Äôs religious heritage and artistic prowess.
Another iconic landmark in Vienna is the Hofburg Palace, a grand and sprawling complex that served as the home of the Habsburg emperors for over six centuries. This Baroque palace is a magnificent example of Vienna‚Äôs architectural legacy, with its ornate facades, grand ballrooms, and opulent gardens.
Vienna is also home to a wide range of world-class museums, showcasing everything from classical art to modern design. The Kunsthistorisches Museum, for instance, is a treasure trove of paintings, sculptures, and decorative arts from across the globe, while the Belvedere Palace is home to an impressive collection of Austrian art, including works by Gustav Klimt and Egon Schiele.
As you explore the streets of Vienna, you‚Äôll discover a city that is steeped in history and culture, with an atmosphere that is at once lively and relaxed. Whether you‚Äôre a history buff, an art lover, or simply looking to soak up the city‚Äôs unique charm, Vienna is sure to captivate your senses and leave you with memories that will last a lifetime.
Austria is renowned for its rich culinary traditions that draw inspiration from both its imperial past and its diverse cultural influences. From the classic Wiener Schnitzel to the sweet and indulgent Sachertorte, the city is a food lover‚Äôs paradise. The atmosphere and vibe of the Viennese food and drink scene is a delightful combination of tradition and innovation, showcasing the city‚Äôs culinary creativity and history.
Austrian cuisine is heavily influenced by its location in Central Europe, with hearty meat dishes and stews, such as Tafelspitz, a traditional beef dish, and Gulasch, a Hungarian-inspired beef and paprika stew, being popular staples. The Wiener Schnitzel is perhaps the most well-known Viennese dish, consisting of a thin, breaded and pan-fried veal cutlet served with a side of potato salad. The aroma of sizzling schnitzels and the sound of the crisp breading are unmistakable, and the dish is ubiquitous across the city‚Äôs traditional taverns and high-end restaurants alike.
But Austrian cuisine is not just about meat dishes. The country is also famous for its pastries and sweets, which are often enjoyed alongside a cup of coffee in one of the city‚Äôs many traditional coffeehouses. The Sachertorte, a rich chocolate cake with a layer of apricot jam, is an iconic Viennese dessert that has been served in the city since the 19th century. Another classic is the Apfelstrudel, a pastry filled with apples, cinnamon and raisins, which is a perfect accompaniment to a hot cup of coffee on a chilly afternoon.
Vienna is also renowned for its coffee culture, with a long history of traditional coffeehouses that date back to the 18th century. These coffeehouses are more than just places to grab a caffeine fix, they are social and cultural hubs where locals come to relax, read the newspaper, and engage in conversation. The atmosphere is one of relaxed elegance, with plush chairs, marble tables, and waiters dressed in traditional attire. A visit to one of these coffeehouses is a quintessential Viennese experience, and a must-do for any traveler.
For those looking for something stronger, Austria is also famous for its wines and beers. The country‚Äôs wine regions are concentrated in the east, and produce some of the world‚Äôs finest white wines, such as Gruner Veltliner and Riesling. Austrian beer, on the other hand, is renowned for its crisp, refreshing taste, with brands such as Ottakringer and Schwechater being popular choices among locals.
Vienna is a city of contrasts, where grand palaces and museums coexist with gritty street art and alternative subcultures. While the city‚Äôs famous landmarks and tourist attractions are undoubtedly worth a visit, there are also many creative and less touristic neighborhoods that offer a glimpse into a different side of Vienna. These neighborhoods are full of character and charm, with a vibrant atmosphere and a unique vibe that is sure to leave a lasting impression on any traveler.
One such neighborhood is Neubau, located just west of the city center. Neubau is known for its artsy and bohemian vibe, with streets lined with independent shops, galleries, and cafes. The area is a hub for creative types, with many artists, designers, and musicians calling it home. The streets are adorned with colorful murals and street art, and the atmosphere is one of creativity and innovation. In Neubau, you‚Äôll find a plethora of vintage and second-hand shops, as well as trendy boutiques selling the latest fashion and design.
Another neighborhood worth exploring is Ottakring, located in the northwestern part of the city. Ottakring is a diverse and multicultural neighborhood, with a strong Turkish and Balkan influence. The area is known for its lively street markets and ethnic cuisine, with many family-owned restaurants serving up traditional dishes from around the world. Ottakring is also home to many artists and creatives, with a thriving street art scene and numerous galleries showcasing the latest contemporary art.
If you‚Äôre looking for a neighborhood that‚Äôs off the beaten path, then head to Favoriten. Located in the south of the city, Favoriten is a working-class neighborhood that has a vibrant and authentic feel. The area is a melting pot of cultures, with a strong immigrant community that has shaped its unique character. Here, you‚Äôll find a diverse range of restaurants and cafes serving up traditional dishes from around the world, as well as colorful markets selling everything from fresh produce to exotic spices. The atmosphere in Favoriten is one of community and togetherness, with locals gathering in parks and public spaces to socialize and enjoy each other‚Äôs company.
Another neighborhood that‚Äôs worth exploring is Leopoldstadt, located on the eastern side of the Danube River. Leopoldstadt is a multicultural neighborhood that has a rich Jewish history, with many synagogues and Jewish institutions still present today. The area is known for its lively nightlife, with many bars, clubs, and music venues catering to a young and hip crowd. In Leopoldstadt, you‚Äôll find a mix of traditional and modern, with historic buildings and cobblestone streets sitting alongside modern apartments and trendy cafes.
Finally, for those looking to escape the hustle and bustle of the city, the Vienna Woods offer a peaceful retreat just outside of Vienna. The woods are located to the west of the city, and are a popular destination for hikers and nature lovers. The area is home to many scenic trails, as well as historic castles and ruins that offer a glimpse into Vienna‚Äôs past.
Vienna has a rich and complex history, with cultural influences from all over Europe and beyond. The city‚Äôs impressive architecture and museums are a testament to this legacy, showcasing the many different styles and periods that have shaped Vienna‚Äôs cultural heritage.
The atmosphere in Vienna is one of refinement and sophistication, with a strong sense of history and tradition. The city‚Äôs grand palaces and elegant streets are a testament to its imperial past, with ornate facades and elaborate details that harken back to a bygone era. The atmosphere is one of grandeur and elegance, with a strong emphasis on the arts and culture.
One of the most iconic symbols of Vienna‚Äôs cultural heritage is the Vienna State Opera, located in the heart of the city. The opera house is renowned for its stunning architecture and world-class performances, with many of the world‚Äôs greatest singers and musicians having performed there over the years. The atmosphere at the Vienna State Opera is one of sophistication and elegance, with a strong emphasis on the arts and culture.
Another must-see cultural attraction in Vienna is the Hofburg Palace, the former residence of the Habsburg dynasty. The palace is a magnificent example of imperial architecture, with grand halls and opulent furnishings that give visitors a glimpse into the grandeur of the Habsburg Empire. The atmosphere at the Hofburg Palace is one of refinement and elegance, with a strong sense of history and tradition.
For those interested in art, Vienna is home to many world-class museums and galleries. The Kunsthistorisches Museum is one of the most notable, with a vast collection of European art from the Renaissance to the Baroque period. The museum‚Äôs grand halls and elaborate ceilings are a testament to Vienna‚Äôs rich cultural heritage, with an atmosphere of sophistication and refinement.
Vienna is also known for its classical music scene, with many famous composers having lived and worked in the city over the centuries. The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra is one of the most prestigious orchestras in the world, with a long history of performing the works of the great composers such as Mozart, Beethoven, and Brahms. The atmosphere at a classical music performance in Vienna is one of sophistication and elegance, with a strong emphasis on the arts and culture.
While Vienna is a city with a rich cultural heritage and plenty of sights to see, sometimes it can be nice to escape the hustle and bustle of the city and explore some of the recreational spaces outside of Vienna. These areas offer a chance to relax, recharge, and take in the natural beauty of the surrounding landscape.
One popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts is the Vienna Woods, a range of hills and forests just outside of the city. The Vienna Woods offer a range of activities, including hiking, cycling, and horseback riding, as well as numerous picnic areas and lookout points that offer stunning views of the surrounding countryside. The atmosphere in the Vienna Woods is one of peace and tranquility, with a strong connection to nature.
For those interested in history and architecture, a visit to Sch√∂nbrunn Palace and its gardens is a must. The palace and its surrounding parklands are a UNESCO World Heritage site and offer a glimpse into the grandeur of imperial Vienna. The gardens are home to a variety of plant and animal species, as well as numerous fountains, statues, and other decorative elements. The atmosphere at Sch√∂nbrunn Palace is one of refinement and elegance, with a strong sense of history and tradition.
Another popular recreational area outside of Vienna is the Danube River, which flows through the heart of the city and beyond. The Danube offers a range of activities, from boat tours and river cruises to cycling and walking along its banks. The atmosphere along the Danube is one of relaxation and enjoyment, with a strong connection to the water and the natural beauty of the surrounding landscape.
Finally, for those looking to combine outdoor recreation with cultural heritage, a visit to the Wachau Valley is a must. This picturesque region is known for its vineyards, historic towns, and stunning scenery, with numerous hiking and cycling trails that offer a chance to explore the area at your own pace. The atmosphere in the Wachau Valley is one of peace and tranquility, with a strong connection to the natural beauty and cultural heritage of the area.
Vienna is a city that is easily navigable, with a well-developed public transportation system that makes it easy to get around. One of the most efficient ways to explore Vienna is by using the U-Bahn, the city‚Äôs underground metro system, which covers a large portion of the city and provides quick and convenient access to many of Vienna‚Äôs top sights and attractions. The U-Bahn has a modern and efficient vibe, with clean and well-maintained stations and trains that run frequently throughout the day.
Another popular option for getting around Vienna is by bicycle. Vienna has an extensive network of bike paths and bike lanes that make it easy and safe to cycle through the city. Renting a bike is a great way to explore Vienna‚Äôs neighborhoods and get a closer look at the city‚Äôs architecture and historic landmarks. The atmosphere while cycling through Vienna is one of freedom and independence, with a strong sense of connection to the city and its surroundings.
For those who prefer a more leisurely pace, walking is also a great way to explore Vienna. The city is compact and easy to navigate on foot, with many of the top sights and attractions within walking distance of each other. Walking through Vienna allows you to take in the atmosphere of the city at a slower pace, with plenty of opportunities to stop and explore the many shops, cafes, and restaurants that line the streets.
Vienna is a city that can be enjoyed throughout the year, with each season offering a unique atmosphere and vibe. However, the best time to visit Vienna in terms of climate is during the spring and fall months. In the spring, the city comes to life as the weather warms up, with colorful blooms and lush greenery lining the streets and parks. In the fall, the cooler temperatures bring a crispness to the air, and the changing leaves paint the city in hues of red and gold. The atmosphere during these seasons is one of vibrancy and renewal, making it an ideal time to explore Vienna‚Äôs rich culture and history while enjoying comfortable weather conditions.

Title: Steirereck
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
Collected Writings
Follow publication

Listen
Share
It is supposed to be the best restaurant in Vienna and the only Austrian entry (at No.15) on The List. Everyone we met in Vienna had only good things to say about the place, and we‚Äôd managed (I am still not sure how) to get a reservation at short notice. By the time Wednesday evening came, we‚Äôd had our fill of Weinerschnitzel and Tafelschpitz and 4 long days of conference food, and our anticipation over this meal had reached a fever pitch.
The Steirereck is located at the end of a long driveway leading into the heart of Stadtpark. It‚Äôs ensconsed in an elegant glass walled building that was glowing golden with incandescent light on a dismal wet Austrian evening of our dinner reservation. As I walked up the drive I was almost disappointed that we only managed a dinner reservation. I could imagine how incredibly impressive the high glass windows of the nouveau architectural building would have looked on a sunny Austrian afternoon.
When we sit down we are informed by the server that Austrian law requires that allergy information be printed on the menu alongside every dish. And so it is, in excruciating detail with a legend down by the bottom of the page listing every conceivable food item that you can be allergic to. A short while later, dish after dish of pre-starters pour out of the kitchen. As we start to go through them we realise a curious alignment with the legend at the bottom of the menu. Displaying a decidedly non-Austrian sense of humour, the restaurant has used the allergy information that they are required to include on the menu as the inspiration for each of the starters.
I‚Äôm not sure how it got to be like that but I get the distinct feeling that the chef draws a lot of his inspiration from bees and honey. And it starts with the char that is cooked (by the side of our table) in molten beeswax. I‚Äôve seen a number of table-side preparations and been to my share of molecular magic side-shows but this was a truly impressive (unexpectedly so) performance. The char fillets are placed carefully in a nondescript wooden tray. They then pour molten beeswax into the tray till it completely covers the fish. Before our eyes the fillets begin to change colour from their normal translucent state to the opaque white that we are accustomed to seeing.
They give it about 15 minutes and then gently ease the fish out of the beeswax that has now hardened solid. The fish pops out whole and perfectly cooked. They take it away to do some magic in the kitchen and it comes to the table beautifully plated with a long carrot and some sour cream.
They aren‚Äôt stingy with their vegetables at Stierereck and for someone who really likes his meat that can sometimes come in the way. Hidden somewhere under the many layers of coloured bell peppers and melon was some Venus clam and I was darned if I could find it. That apart the dish tasted exquisite with many layers of flavour and texture from the mild sweetness of the peppers and melon, to the mouthfeel of Jerusalem artichokes all tied in with the oily overtones of macadamia and black olives.
They followed this up with a mini garden of herbs, porcini mushrooms, green verbena leaves and nuts that I have to admit was not overwhelming, delicate presentation notwithstanding. It‚Äôs a dish I thought they would have done well to leave out of the tasting menu and serve only to the vegetarians (but maybe that is my prejudice showing).
The meal is accompanied by little cards that they stick in a sort of a stand by your plate. It contains a description of the dish you are currently eating ‚Äì with far more detail than one would get from a traditional restaurant menu. They are also convenient pocket-sized keepsakes of the meal and saved me from requesting a copy of the menu as I always do.
It‚Äôs from these little cards that I realised that the Job‚Äôs Tears that were referred to in the description of the next course on the menu was more than just a Biblical reference but an actual plant (Coix lacrimal-jobi) that is eaten as a vegetable in China and the Far East. In this dish the Job‚Äôs Tears had been crisped up and served in a tiny conical wrap that preserved its crunchy texture. I am a fan of carp so I had no complaints with the fish or in fact the entire dish, which had a distinctly Eastern sensibility ‚Äì thanks in large part, I am sure, to the flavours of Pandan Oil that tied the entire thing together.
I can‚Äôt say I was terribly enthused by the Lamb. It was a good hunk of meat, well cooked, if not particularly well seasoned. I can‚Äôt fault the technique except that at a restaurant with these credentials I‚Äôd have expected a more tasty serving. I thought the popcorn was a treat ‚Äì it carried the flavour of coffee (which was interesting) and the vegetables were tasty and crunchy ‚Äì I particularly liked the grilled baby corn. I learned that the sauce was made from the Scarlet Monarde grown in the Steirereck gardens and that imparted the familiar flavours of bergamot to the dish.
The meat course of the day had to be the Venison. I‚Äôm a huge fan of well cooked venison ‚Äì I like the tender, pliable and succulent texture of the meat as well as characteristic slightly games (in a good way) flavour of the meat. They serve the venison with perfectly cooked half moons of squash, baby artichoke hearts sliced flat and a sauce of orange blossom. All in all an excellent pairing of textures and tastes. Clearly the dish of the day for me.
I can‚Äôt say any of the desserts really knocked it out of the park. They were all fruity and seasonal ‚Äî summery even which was a bit of a contrast to the wet weather outside. But none of them rose to the level of brilliance that I have seen at the best restaurants in the world.
Of the desserts on the table, the prize for prettiness clearly went to the Crepe which was served in a roll of delicate strips of crisp and crunchy batter. Alongside the shredded crepe was a colourful row of violet flowers and a delicious puree of medlar.
I started out by remarking on the subliminal presence of bees and honey that hovers in the background of the meal. As I should have expected, the finale to the meal was a selection from the impressive selection of artisanal honeys available at Steirereck.
They rolled out a trolley that contained racks and racks of different varieties of honey, including a healthy selection of honeycombs. They made a show of opening a small porthole at the side ‚Äî whereupon we heard a furious buzzing. It took us a moment ‚Äî a very nervous moment ‚Äî to realise that this was just a recording and that we were not about to be swarmed by angry bees. The server was knowledgeable ‚Äî or at least he seemed to be given that I have next to no apiary knowledge to be able to question his claims ‚Äî and we all selected a few varieties to taste.
But taste was all we could manage. Much as I love raw honey, at the end of a sumptuous meal a few licks of the back of a spoon was all I could manage. What we did taste was, surprisingly, subtly different ‚Äî the local floral conditions clearly make a difference to the end product. I wish we could have carried a few bottles home.
There is no doubt that Chef Heinz Reitbauer is a master of his ingredients. He has two Michellin Stars, four Toques and a place in The List. The location of the restaurant, inside the large and verdant Stadtpark is unmatched and from pictures on the Internet, I would imagine it would have been even more spectacular on a sunny Austrian summer afternoon.
And it is a good restaurant. Some of the dishes (the molten beeswax char in particular) were imaginative and unique. The use of locally produced ingredients and the quaint connection with honeybees is charming. Not having eaten extensively in the region, I cannot really comment with authority but I will not be putting up any arguments if someone claims it is the best restaurant in Austria.
But is it deserving of its place on the list (which, I should remind you, is down from its highest rank at No. 9 in 2013)? I am not convinced. I have eaten at places far lower down the list that have turned out food that is equally exquisite but done so consistently, course upon course without a hitch.
No. 15? Maybe not.

These cute animals are European Ground Squirrels, which I saw whilst on holiday in Vienna.
I hadn‚Äôt even heard of them until quite recently. Over the last few years, the British media have been publishing more and more photos of ground squirrels and other wildlife in Vienna. Eventually, I couldn‚Äôt resist heading over to Austria to see what was going on for myself.
There are plenty of public parks in Vienna, but, as far as I know, only a couple of them have ground squirrels. All of my photos were taken at the Blumeng√§rten Hirschstetten, which you can get to quite easily by tram.
Visit in spring or summer, and you should have a great chance of seeing the squirrels. I spotted several within minutes of arriving, and one of them ran right up to my feet as if it was welcoming me to the park.
I assume the squirrels are used to people feeding them, although there are signs asking you not to.

Title: Two Cities, Two Lifestyles: Munich and Vienna in Perspective
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen

Since I am currently in Munich but usually live in Vienna, I would like to highlight the differences between Viennese and Munich residents. At first glance, one might not believe that Munich residents differ so much from Viennese, but a comparison reveals significant differences. Let‚Äôs first compare the cities to illustrate the differences.
The most noticeable difference is that Vienna is the capital of Austria, while Munich is ‚Äúonly‚Äù a large city in Germany. Munich is slightly smaller than Vienna and has fewer inhabitants. Although Munich has only three-quarters of Vienna‚Äôs population, it is three times as wealthy, which is evident in the people.
Usually, the population is divided into three classes: lower, middle, and upper class. In Munich, however, there seems to be no clear middle class, and the upper class appears very snobbish. This does not mean that there is no middle class, but rather that it is less noticeable. You see either people who look wealthy or those who appear poorer. The middle class behaves more subtly and hides in public: they either dress elegantly to appear upper class or wear normal clothes, making them seem poorer. I correct my previous statement and say that the middle class behaves discreetly. Now let‚Äôs look at the people in Vienna.
Vienna is divided into districts, but there are only a few districts that clearly represent a social class. Even in the wealthy districts, there are hardly any snobs or visibly rich people. In Vienna, the middle class predominates. Everyone looks as if they earn roughly the same. There are exceptions here as well, just like in Munich.
Although I have strongly criticized Munich here, it is a beautiful city. Of course, there are also unfriendly people in Munich, but I have not encountered any so far. In conclusion, both Munich and Vienna are worth visiting.

Title: Vienna‚Äôs stories and tales
Content:

The Viennese street names not only serve as orientation in the street network, but they also tell stories and describe the character of the city.
The narrow Hafnersteig leads to the center of the ‚ÄúFleischmarkt‚Äù. It was mentioned for the first time in 1220. Therefore, it‚Äôs the oldest meat market in Vienna.
In the basement of the house, that dates from the 17th century, is housed a well-known tavern, the ‚ÄúYellow Eagle‚Äù, later known as ‚ÄúThe Golden Eagle.
Learn a little patience. You never know what might be around the corner. Still, around it, there may wait, a new road or a secret gate.
The bakery in ‚ÄúSch√∂nlaternegasse‚Äù was well known for its good bread. According to the legend, the basilisk was found in the well of a bakery by a young maid.
The Basilisk a mythological lizard type beast that was supposedly a cross-breeding of a cock, a toad, and a snake.
Georg, one of the baker‚Äôs helpers, who was secretly in love with the maid, volunteered to undertake this task to gain the Master‚Äôs approval of their marriage plan.
Down in the well, the basilisk looked into the mirror and when he saw how ugly he really was, burst up.
The well was filled in with stones, and our hero Georg married the young maid.
The blocks of houses in the so-called ‚ÄúBlutgassen‚Äù quarter in the first district, between Singerstra√üe, Blutgasse, Gr√ºnangergasse, and Domgasse, are among the oldest in Vienna.
Their foundations date back to the 12th century. The buildings erected on them date from the 16th and 17th centuries.
To which circumstance the blood alley (Blutgasse) owes its name has not yet been established. According to the legend, in Medieval times (1312) the Templars (monks) were brutally slaughtered in their courtyard (F√§hnrichhof) and the blood ran down the little lane like a stream.
Nearby the St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral is the small street named Domgasse.
At the address ‚ÄúDomgasse 5‚Äù you can visit the only one existing Mozart‚Äôs apartments in Vienna. From 1784 to 1787, the composer lived in this Haus with his wife Constanza. During this period, Mozart wrote many works including his opera ‚ÄúThe Marriage of Figaro‚Äù.
The first documented mention of a house on this property dates back to the 14th century. Since 1458 the bakers have settled in this area. According to the reports, this place is the birthplace of the famous Viennese croissants (Kipferl).
It is very unlikely, however, that this shape did not appear first at 1683 (allegedly to mock the Turks by the chosen shape of a crescent), as we already know that from the 13th century the bakers gave ‚Äúchipfen‚Äù to dignitaries as a Christmas present.
Above the portal, there is a house sign with old pastry molds, which reminds us of the tradition.
From left to right and from top to bottom the following pastries are visible: Bosniakerl, Schusterlaberl, Kipfel, Brezel, Beugel and, a Girafferl.
The southern tower of St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral (136.7 m) is, without doubt, the main landmark of the city of Vienna.
Tradition speaks for Rudolf IV as the founder of the tower, the duke himself has laid the foundation stone in 1368. Its construction lasted 65 years, from 1368 to 1433.
At that time the south tower was the highest tower Europa‚Äôs, meanwhile, it‚Äôs between the top ten church buildings. The tallest church is in Ulm, Germany (161,5 m.)
During the Austria ‚Äî Hungary monarchy no building was allowed to be built higher than St. Stephen‚Äôs Cathedral.

You know that feeling when a song hits you right in the gut? Like, it wasn‚Äôt just made for you, but like it somehow knew what you needed to hear before you even did? That‚Äôs what ‚ÄúVienna‚Äù by Billy Joel did to me.
I came across that song again during my drive home, on a random night just a few weeks ago, when I was overanalyzing my life, my future, and whether I‚Äôm already too late to do something meaningful. The classic mid-to-late 20s spiral, you know? One minute I‚Äôm driving slowly through the city, the next I‚Äôm questioning my entire existence.
Then, boom; ‚ÄúVienna waits for you‚Äù.
I don‚Äôt know what it is about that line, but it unlocked something in me. I‚Äôve never thought about, let alone visited Vienna. Maybe it‚Äôs the gentle piano intro. Maybe it‚Äôs the way Billy sings it like a wise old friend sitting next to me at 3AM, telling me to breathe.
‚ÄúSlow down, you crazy child. You‚Äôre so ambitious for a juvenile.‚Äù
I felt exposed. How dare he come for my entire personality like that? But also, he‚Äôs right. I am ambitious. I‚Äôve always wanted to get things done fast, prove myself, complete all the milestones before I hit my imaginary deadline. And lately, that mindset has been eating at me. I kept thinking, ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt I have everything figured out yet?‚Äù
But Vienna reminds me that I don‚Äôt have to. I‚Äôm still young. A 26 year-old is basically a 6 year-old in the ‚Äúadult‚Äù life. And ‚Äúyouth‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean I have to hustle 24/7. It means I have time to figure things out. It means I can still dream big without burning out trying to make it happen as fast as possible.
There‚Äôs something deeply comforting about being told that it‚Äôs okay to not be in a rush. We don‚Äôt get that a lot. Being told that success doesn‚Äôt expire at 30. That if I haven‚Äôt landed my dream job, or released that album, or written that book yet, it doesn‚Äôt mean I have failed. It just means I‚Äôm still on my way.
And that‚Äôs more than okay.
‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the fire, what‚Äôs the hurry about? You better cool it off before you burn it out.‚Äù
That line gets me every time. Because that fire, yes. I have felt it. I still feel it. The desire to do something great, to not waste time. But sometimes, that fire turns into anxiety. Into comparison. Into restlessness. And this song basically told me, ‚ÄúHey, chill. You have time. You‚Äôre doing fine.‚Äù
Lately, every time I get overwhelmed about the future or about the feeling like I‚Äôm not doing enough, I put this song on. And for those three and a half minutes, I always feel like the noise quiets down. I remember that life isn‚Äôt a race. That I don‚Äôt have to catch up to anyone. That I‚Äôm allowed to take detours, to pause, to just‚Ä¶ be.
And beyond all that, the song just feels beautiful. The melody is gentle, a little wistful, but hopeful. It‚Äôs not sad. It‚Äôs patient. Like Vienna itself, whatever it symbolizes, it can wait. It‚Äôs not going anywhere. And neither is my worth.
I think the main thing that Vienna taught me is: I‚Äôm not late. I‚Äôm not behind. I‚Äôm exactly where I need to be. And sometimes, slowing things down is the most powerful thing I can do.
Because Vienna waits for me.
And that‚Äôs more than enough.

by Jefferson Batesimah
The Vienna Conference on Autonomous Weapons, dubbed ‚ÄúHumanity at the Crossroads,‚Äù addressed the urgent need to regulate deadly autonomous weapons systems. As a youth delegate, I gained valuable insights into this critical issue. Here‚Äôs a snapshot of what I learned:
Understanding the Big Picture
The conference shed light on the serious challenges posed by autonomous weapons. They could make conflicts worse, harm civilians, and disrupt efforts to keep peace worldwide.
Why Human Control Matters
A key lesson was the importance of humans staying in charge of decisions about using force. Letting machines make life-or-death choices raises big moral and legal questions. We need clear rules to make sure people are responsible and to stop these weapons from causing harm.
Talking Ethics
We spent time discussing what‚Äôs right and wrong when it comes to autonomous weapons. We talked about how to respect people‚Äôs dignity and protect them from these weapons‚Äô dangers. We also thought about how using these weapons might change society in the long run and change our relationship with technology.
Challenges We Face
Even though many people agree on the need for rules, there are still big challenges ahead. Some powerful governments and tech companies control a lot of the conversation. It‚Äôs tough for other voices, like from everyday people and community groups, to be heard.
Youth Power
Young people like us played a big part in the conference. Our fresh ideas and energy showed how important it is to get everyone involved in the discussion to address autonomous weapons. We left feeling inspired and ready to push for change in our communities.
What Comes Next
The conference wasn‚Äôt just talk, it was a call to action. We agreed to work even harder to establish strong global rules for autonomous weapons. But it won‚Äôt happen overnight. We need to keep up the pressure and work together to make real change.
In sum, the Vienna Conference on Autonomous Weapons was a chance to learn, share ideas, and get ready for action. We learned how crucial it is to keep humans in control of decisions about life and death in warfare. As we move forward, let‚Äôs stay focused on making the world safer and fairer for everyone.

Me: Shit, I don‚Äôt.
Caroline: You didn‚Äôt get one?
Me: I forgot.
Then, we heard a knock at the door.
Bartender: We don‚Äôt allow fucking in here. Come out now or I‚Äôm coming in.
We scrambled to put our clothes back on, then I opened the door. The bartender was still standing there, bill in hand.
Bartender: I added a cleaning fee. Pay now and go.
I handed him whatever money I had on me, then Caroline and I ran out laughing hysterically.
On the walk back to the hostel, we smoked a joint and Caroline threw up. I expected to be the one puking, on account of the Sambuca, but it was Caroline heaving on the side of the road. I held her hair back. Most women cry when they‚Äôre wasted and vomiting, but Caroline laughed. She had no shame. Mid-vomit she posed a very serious question.
Caroline: Don‚Äôt you think we should end on a high note?
Me: You mean, tonight? This doesn‚Äôt seem like a very high note.
Caroline: No, I mean ‚Äúus.‚Äù Like, tonight we go to bed, and we never see each other again. We just go on our separate ways when we wake up. I want to remember you like this.
Me: Holding your hair back while you vomit?
Caroline: No. I mean, before we complicate things. I want you to live in my mind as a perfect memory.
Me: It‚Äôs not because you don‚Äôt want to have sex with me, right?
Caroline: I very much want to have sex with you. It isn‚Äôt about that. It‚Äôs about preserving a special memory and locking it away in a little box that you can peek in whenever you want. I want you just like this.
Me: I could use a box with something nice in it‚Ä¶ Right now, I only have ones I want to keep shut.
Caroline: You see what I‚Äôm saying?
Me: So, this would be it, forever?
Caroline: Yeah.
Me: What if we end up seeing each other again in another country?
Caroline: Then it was meant to be.
Me: Fair enough, pretty lady.
Caroline: Goodbye, my sweet Johnny Mac.
Me: Goodbye, Caroline.
I walked her to her room, gave her a kiss on the cheek, and that was it. She flew away the next morning, leaving me to hop around on my own, with my little box.
--

Content:

In praise of 15 minute cities: Why a ‚Äòcity of short distances‚Äô feels better.
‚ÄúPeople realised the state of their neighbourhoods could change. They could enjoy life in front of their front doors without owning a garden, without having a balcony,‚Äù said Vienna‚Äôs former Deputy Mayor, Maria Vassilakou.
Rated no.1 in the Economist Intelligence Unit‚Äôs (EIU) Global Liveability Index, Vienna frequently places as one of the world‚Äôs top cities to live in. And while it‚Äôs never explicitly called a 15- or 20-minute city, it nevertheless responds to the social, technological and ecological challenges that we all face.
Described as ‚Äúthe city of short distances‚Äù, urban planning policy in the city has long put pedestrians first (since the 80s, in fact). And, a few decades down the line, the results are evident everywhere: pavement expansions, improvements to public transport connectivity, sports provision and ‚Äî notably ‚Äî the longest continuous pedestrianised space in Europe, in the form of shopping street Mariahilferstra√üe.
Vienna feels equitable and inclusive, too. It‚Äôs affordable, for starters. And a focus on gender mainstreaming, a strategy adopted to achieve gender equality in society, has translated to things like fully illuminated footpaths, more entrances and exits to parks, grants for neighbourhood open space, and additional premiums for research conducted by women ‚Äî a real-world commitment to urban planning that‚Äôs led by the needs and safety of citizens.
LIVEABILITY SCORE: 8/10. A compact and connected city geared towards pedestrians, safety and people-first infrastructure.

I‚Äôve now been living in Vienna about a year and a half (my how time flies!).
I‚Äôve seen so much so far but there are a couple of places I didn‚Äôt get to until today.
We‚Äôve had very cold weather the past week or so, down to close to freezing temps at night, and so walking around or exploring isn‚Äôt exactly what one wants to do.
Today is a glorious sunny (and finally warm) day so I headed to the center to take in two beautiful and interesting historical places.
Kaiserliche Schatzkammer
First I went to the Imperial Treasury (Kaiserliche Schatzkammer) which is part of the large Hofburg palace complex the emperors of Austria lived in.
I highly recommend purchasing tickets online before you go. While today‚Äôs line wasn‚Äôt too long, in spite of the plethora of tourists in town, you can just walk right in and get your online ticket scanned to enter without having to wait for than a few seconds.
You enter a few darkened rooms which contain all kinds of imperial and church artifacts, such as crowns, robes, orbs and the like. It‚Äôs not that big but you do learn a lot about Austrian history throughout the ages and also the growth and collapse of the Austrian-Hungarian empire over the centuries.

Congratulations! You managed to make the girl who didn‚Äôt believe in love fall for you.
You made her believe the two of you shared something special, something meant to be.
You made her feel like you‚Äôd never truly hurt her.
She had her doubts, but they were born out of fear ‚Äî fear because she loved you so much that she couldn‚Äôt imagine life without you.
She thought she was just being protective of her heart, until one day, all her fears became reality.
She watched the man she loved with her whole heart hurt her and let her down.
Seeing you talk to your ex, sounding so happy, broke something deep inside her.
Every ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù and ‚ÄúI promise‚Äù now feels like empty words.
She wonders how someone who says they love you could hurt you so deeply, break your trust, and make you feel like a fool for believing in them.
And yet, she stays.
She tries to work through it because she doesn‚Äôt want to give up on you.
But your words are starting to cut deeper than you realize.
She‚Äôs ‚Äútoo emotional,‚Äù a ‚Äúpick me,‚Äù or just the ‚Äúsad girl.‚Äù
The person she once felt so close and safe with now feels like a stranger.
She‚Äôs scared to be herself, scared to open up. Her heart no longer feels safe with the man she loves.
The worst part?
There‚Äôs still nothing she wouldn‚Äôt do for you. She‚Äôd destroy herself emotionally a million times over if it meant making you happy.

Title: Vienna waits for you.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The first time I heard Vienna by Billy Joel, I was on a train home after college, the world outside dipped in the amber light of a tired evening. I had just bombed an interview I had poured my soul into. My head was a whirlwind of spiralling doubts‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääabout my future, about whether I had what it takes, about everything. And then Vienna arrived‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot like a pop anthem or an uplifting chorus, but like a friend who sits with you in silence and tells you exactly what you need to hear.
‚ÄúSlow down, you crazy child
You‚Äôre so ambitious for a juvenile
But then if you‚Äôre so smart, tell me
Why are you still so afraid?‚Äù
In that moment, tears welled up ‚Äî not because of the failure, but because of how deeply the song understood the ache behind it. How it met me in the in-between, where so many of us live: driven but unsure, hopeful but exhausted.
That lyric wasn‚Äôt just about me. It was about a generation raised to hustle, to quantify their worth through grades, internships, side projects, and glowing LinkedIn posts. I had come to think of life as a ladder. But Vienna whispered of a different metaphor ‚Äî a garden, perhaps. Something that grows in time, with pauses, with pruning, with seasons of bloom and rest.
It reminded me of The Midnight Library by Matt Haig ‚Äî a book about a woman who, burdened by regret, stumbles upon a mystical library containing infinite versions of her life. Each book in the library reveals a different path she could have taken. The novel forces you to ask: what if the life you‚Äôre racing toward isn‚Äôt the one that would‚Äôve made you happy? What if the pauses, the missed exits, the so-called failures, are the very fabric of the life meant for you?
‚ÄúWhen will you realize, Vienna waits for you?‚Äù
In Joel‚Äôs metaphor, Vienna isn‚Äôt a destination you rush to. It‚Äôs the life that waits ‚Äî patiently, quietly ‚Äî for you to stop sprinting long enough to hear its music. It‚Äôs the version of you that grows not by doing more, but by understanding what enough feels like. That revelation mirrored the essence of The Midnight Library: the idea that you‚Äôre not a failure just because you‚Äôre not on someone else‚Äôs timeline.
The truth is, I didn‚Äôt need a new plan that day on the train. I needed perspective. I needed someone ‚Äî or something ‚Äî to tell me that I hadn‚Äôt missed my moment, that there are many doors yet to open. And Vienna, in its tender, piano-laced wisdom, did exactly that.
‚ÄúYou can get what you want or you can just get old
You‚Äôre gonna kick off before you even get halfway through‚Äù
Those words haunted me. Because I had never thought of burnout as a kind of death. But that‚Äôs what it is: the death of wonder, of joy, of being here. I was chasing a life so hard that I was forgetting to live the one already unfolding around me.
Billy Joel‚Äôs Vienna didn‚Äôt just soften my ambition ‚Äî it redefined it. It told me that ambition rooted in fear is a form of imprisonment. But ambition rooted in patience? In stillness? That‚Äôs purpose. That‚Äôs wisdom.
So now, when I feel that panic ‚Äî that rising tide of ‚Äúnot enough,‚Äù of ‚Äútoo late,‚Äù of ‚Äúwhat am I doing with my life?‚Äù ‚Äî I don‚Äôt drown. I return to the song. To Joel‚Äôs voice, gently guiding me back.
‚ÄúSlow down, you‚Äôre doing fine.‚Äù
And just like the woman in The Midnight Library learns: the life you‚Äôre meant to live isn‚Äôt the one with the loudest applause. It‚Äôs the one where you‚Äôre fully alive. The one that waits for you ‚Äî just like Vienna.
--
--

Things that I‚Äôm a sucker for while traveling: a unique building, a nice park, and a spooky cemetery. I will go out of my way to see these. Even if it means traveling across an entire city.
So years ago, when I was traveling in Vienna with my parents, that‚Äôs exactly what I did. I had heard about this cool building, called Hundertwasserhaus.
Although I was in my 30s, living on my own in a foreign country, and had traveled around the world, my mom didn‚Äôt want me to go alone. So she tagged along.
It‚Äôs curved, it‚Äôs straight, it‚Äôs a building, and it‚Äôs a garden.
Hundertwasserhaus is hard to describe, but it overloads your mind when you see it. There is so much to look at.
It is a colorful, eclectic apartment building. It was built in the 1980s with multiple styles and built on different planes. The windows are different sizes. The facade changes from stucco to trompe l‚Äôoeil to brick to mosaic. The street level boasts unusual, non-uniform colorful columns.
Trees pop out of the building in unexpected places. The artist called these trees on the building ‚Äútree tenants.‚Äù

Title: Escape to Shanghai
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚Üí Vienna
By 1938, America, England, Canada, Australia and most other countries had either tightened immigration intake or outright banned foreigners. Apparently a Mr. Rogers, an Australian businessman, was visiting Vienna in 1938 and somehow met our family. He offered to help and assisted my father applying for a visa to Australia, sponsoring us. The application was refused. Mr. Rogers subsequently wrote telling my father that stating to be a tradesman as a ‚Äúchauffeur‚Äù was the worst entry possible as his son, aged 17, ‚Äúcould drive a car better than you can!‚Äù That was the end of that.
The Depression had not lifted entirely in most of the Western world. In any case, the few who did receive visas to desired country destinations had to have sums of money my father did not possess. My grandfather‚Äôs business, in which my father and his brother Walter worked, barely supported the family. This was not entirely due to economic conditions ‚Äî it has been attributed largely to my grandfather‚Äôs second marriage to a beautiful woman some 30 years younger than himself. She apparently required a new house with the best trimmings.
Jews who didn‚Äôt make it to desired country destinations had the possibility of buying passports for entry to South American countries like Argentina and Uruguay. Switzerland was open only to the super rich, and then only as permanent ‚Äòtourists‚Äô. Refugees like my parents, who left matters too late with very little money, found safety in the few destinations that made no demands. There was Shanghai, Trinidad, Curacao, and small black African states. Israel, Palestine in those days, was quite sealed against Jewish immigration by British decree, although several hundred young people entered and were smuggled in right throughout the war.
You didn‚Äôt need an entry visa, you just had to get there.
My parents found a way to Shanghai, as did about 19,000 Jewish refugees from Hitler. A temporary ‚ÄúThru-visa‚Äù was available from Italy. This was issued on sight of a steamship ticket to Shanghai purchased from Italian line Lloyd Triestino, on one of the boats that steamed a regular route from Genoa to Shanghai, for an exorbitant sum. Only First Class tickets were available as a matter of course. I don‚Äôt know how but this sum was found for the Hahn family of 2 adults and a child. Train tickets were purchased to Genoa.
I remember a young girl, about my age, boarded the train with us. I never learned what was the family‚Äôs relationship to us, but my parents agreed to take her along. She was taken off the train at the border between Austria and Italy during the night, I presume because she was without papers. I have never been told what became of her and I have since often wondered whether she was returned to Vienna and her parents safely.
After a few days in Genoa we embarked on the mv. Victoria, the smallest but newest of the Lloyd Triestino fleet that sailed to the Orient regularly. We owned several ‚Äòcabin trunks‚Äô full of possessions and 114 British pounds. The voyage was a great delight for my parents, despite what must have been anxiety for the future. The mv. Victoria was the smallest ship in the line, but the latest and most modern.
First class service in all respects was still pre-war and luxurious. The voyage was very romantic, landing at exotic ports along the way. In Port Said, at the southern end of the Suez Canal, a great f√™te was held with native dancers and a feast was prepared on the dock. I believe it was an Egyptian version of an Aussie barbecue with whole beasts being cooked. Local citizens were present as well as the ship‚Äôs passengers. I was allowed down to the wharf for a little while and then taken to the cabin to sleep. I never learned why the celebration. I cannot remember the landing in Bombay or the three days passed in Singapore. Then came Hong Kong and lastly Shanghai.
